Other people I have known did not have the knowledge or assistance to enable them to contest these denials, and went without coverage.'b'Many appropriate steps are being taken to resolve this pressing issue. But until it is addressed with overriding legislation, these types of concerns will continue.'b'Because mental health coverage is needed to maintain a person\xe2\x80\x99s ability to achieve stability and everyday functioning and remain in the community, resolving this should be a legislative priority.'b'CARL HERR'b'\nKew Gardens, Queens, Dec. 24, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is board president of the Alexandre Foundation, which provides advocacy services.'b''b'THERE is an unspoken rule in medicine: we do not tell tales out of school.'b'As an emergency room physician, an Army veteran who was deployed to a combat support hospital in Baghdad in 2005, and a biomedical researcher in the field of cardiac-arrest resuscitation, I have been and am, on a daily basis, a witness to grave misfortune. Ordinarily, though, except for medical purposes, I will not discuss what I have seen.'b'Last week a colleague asked me to make an exception. The father of two young children, he was moved by the rampage at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., to ask his professional circle to reconsider our silence. I am an expectant father, and his words resonated with me. They reminded me that we doctors are at the front lines of the scourge of gun violence, and that to remain silent as this threat to public health continues unabated would be no different than for an oncologist or a cardiologist to stay mum on the dangers of smoking.'b'The doctor\xe2\x80\x99s balance between discretion and education is complex. But the news from Newtown, and my colleague\xe2\x80\x99s request, convinced me that we have reached the threshold. I can no longer stay silent.'b'Here is just some of what I have seen over the years. In Baghdad, I saw a 5-year-old girl who was shot in the head while in her car seat. Her father, who knew she was dying before I said it, wept in my arms, as bits of her body clung to his shirt.'b'Much of the gun violence I have seen, though, I have seen on home soil, here in the United States. There was a 9-year-old girl, shot in the chest by an assault rifle during a \xe2\x80\x9cdrive-by\xe2\x80\x9d gang shooting, in a botched retaliation for a shooting earlier that day. She was baffled, and in pain, with a gaping hole under her collarbone.'b'I have also seen an 8-year-old who found a shotgun in the closet while playing with a friend. The two boys pointed the weapon at each other a number of times before the gun accidentally discharged. The 8-year-old arrived in my emergency department with most of his face blown off. Miraculously, he survived.'b'Another child I will never forget was a 13-year-old who was shot twice in the abdomen by an older boy who mistook him for one of a group that had bullied and berated him a week earlier. Slick with sweat and barely conscious, he groaned and turned to look at me. Soon after, he died in the operating room. His mother arrived minutes later, wide-eyed and breathless.'b'I do not know exactly what measures should be taken to reduce gun violence like this. But I know that most homicides and suicides in America are carried out with guns. Research suggests that homes with a gun are 'b'two'b' to 'b'three'b' times more likely to experience a firearm death than homes without guns, and that members of the household are 'b'18 times more likely'b' to be the victim than intruders.'b'I know that in 2009, the most recent year for which data is available, nearly 400 American children (age 14 and under) were killed with a firearm and nearly 1,000 were injured. That means that this week we can expect 26 more children to be injured or killed with a firearm.'b'Emergency rooms are themselves volatile environments, not immune to violence. Over the last decade, a quarter of gun crimes in American E.R.\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'were committed with guns wrested from armed guards'b'.'b'I have sworn an oath to heal and to protect humans. Guns, invented to maim and destroy, are my natural enemy.'b'Sally Cox, a school nurse in Newtown, told Scott Pelley of \xe2\x80\x9c60 Minutes\xe2\x80\x9d that when state troopers led her out of the school after the mass shooting they instructed her to cover her eyes. This was humane, and right. But some of us see every day what no one should, ever. If the carnage remains undiscussed, we risk complacency about an American epidemic \xe2\x80\x94 one that is profoundly difficult, but necessary, to watch, and to confront. That is why I bear witness.'b'Washington'b'IN the days following the Newtown massacre the nation\xe2\x80\x99s newspapers were filled with heart-wrenching pictures of the innocent victims. The slaughter was unimaginably shocking. But the broader tragedy of gun violence is felt mostly not in leafy suburbs, but in America\xe2\x80\x99s inner cities.'b'The right to bear arms typically invokes the romantic image of a cowboy toting a rifle on the plains. In modern-day America, though, the more realistic picture is that of a young black man gunned down in his prime in a dark alley. When we celebrate gun rights, we all too often ignore their disproportionate racial burdens. Any effort to address gun violence must focus on the inner city.'b'Last year Chicago had some 500 homicides, 'b'87 percent of them gun-related'b'. In the city\xe2\x80\x99s public schools, 319 students were shot in the 2011-12 school year, 24 of them fatally. African-Americans are 33 percent of the Chicago population, but about 70 percent of the murder victims.'b'The same is true in other cities. In 2011, 80 percent of the 324 people killed in Philadelphia were killed by guns, and three-quarters of the victims were black.'b'Racial disparities in gun violence far outstrip those in almost any other area of life. Black unemployment is double that for whites, as is black infant mortality. But young black men die of gun homicide at a rate 'b'eight times'b' that of young white men. Could it be that the laxity of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s gun laws is tolerated because its deadly costs are borne by the segregated black and Latino populations of North Philadelphia and Chicago\xe2\x80\x99s South Side?'b'The history of gun regulation is inextricably interwoven with race. Some of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s most stringent gun laws emerged in the South after the Civil War, as Southern whites feared what newly freed slaves might do if armed. At the same time, Northerners saw the freed slaves\xe2\x80\x99 right to bear arms as critical to protecting them from the Ku Klux Klan.'b'In the 1960s, Huey P. Newton and the Black Panther Party made the gun a central 'b'symbol of black power,'b' claiming that \xe2\x80\x9cthe gun is the only thing that will free us.\xe2\x80\x9d On May 2, 1967, taking advantage of California\xe2\x80\x99s lax gun laws, several Panthers marched through the State Capitol in Sacramento 'b'carrying raised and loaded weapons'b', generating widespread news coverage.'b'The police could do nothing, as the Panthers broke no laws. But three months later, Gov. Ronald Reagan signed into law one of the strictest gun control laws in the country.'b'The urban riots of the late 1960s \xe2\x80\x94 combined with rising crime rates and a string of high-profile assassinations \xe2\x80\x94 spurred Congress to pass federal gun control laws, banning interstate commerce in guns except for federally licensed dealers and collectors; prohibiting sales to felons, the mentally ill, substance abusers and minors; and expanding licensing requirements.'b'These laws contain large loopholes, however, and are plainly inadequate to deal with the increased number and lethality of modern weapons. But as long as gun violence largely targets young black men in urban ghettos, the nation seems indifferent. At Newtown, the often all-too-invisible costs of the right to bear arms were made starkly visible \xe2\x80\x94 precisely because these weren\xe2\x80\x99t the usual victims. The nation took note, and President Obama has promised reform, though he has not yet made a specific proposal.'b'Gun rights defenders argue that gun laws don\xe2\x80\x99t reduce violence, noting that many cities with high gun violence already have strict gun laws. But this ignores the ease with which urban residents can evade local laws by obtaining guns from dealers outside their cities or states. Effective gun regulation requires a nationally coordinated response.'b'A cynic might propose resurrecting the Black Panthers to heighten white anxiety as the swiftest route to breaking the logjam on gun reform. I hope we are better than that. If the nation were to view the everyday tragedies that befall young black and Latino men in the inner cities with the same sympathy that it has shown for the Newtown victims, there would be a groundswell of support not just for gun law reform, but for much broader measures.'b'If we are to reduce the inequitable costs of gun rights, it\xe2\x80\x99s not enough to tighten licensing requirements, expand background checks to private gun sales or ban assault weapons. In addition to such national measures, meaningful reform must include initiatives directed to where gun violence is worst: the inner cities. Aggressive interventions by police and social workers focused on gang gun violence, coupled with economic investment, better schools and more after-school and job training programs, are all necessary if we are to reduce the violence that gun rights entail.'b'To tweak the National Rifle Association\xe2\x80\x99s refrain, \xe2\x80\x9cguns don\xe2\x80\x99t kill people; indifference to poverty kills people.\xe2\x80\x9d We can\xe2\x80\x99t in good conscience keep making young black men pay the cost of our right to bear arms.'b'I LIVED for 24 years in New Delhi, a city where sexual harassment is as regular as mealtime. Every day, somewhere in the city, it crosses the line into rape.'b'As a teenager, I learned to protect myself. I never stood alone if I could help it, and I walked quickly, crossing my arms over my chest, refusing to make eye contact or smile. I cleaved through crowds shoulder-first, and avoided leaving the house after dark except in a private car. At an age when young women elsewhere were experimenting with daring new looks, I wore clothes that were two sizes too large. I still cannot dress attractively without feeling that I am endangering myself.'b'Things didn\xe2\x80\x99t change when I became an adult. Pepper spray wasn\xe2\x80\x99t available, and my friends, all of them middle- or upper-middle-class like me, carried safety pins or other makeshift weapons to and from their universities and jobs. One carried a knife, and insisted I do the same. I refused; some days I was so full of anger I would have used it \xe2\x80\x94 or, worse, had it used on me.'b'The steady thrum of whistles, catcalls, hisses, sexual innuendos and open threats continued. Packs of men dawdled on the street, and singing Hindi film songs, rich with double entendres, was how they communicated. To make their demands clear, they would thrust their pelvises at female passers-by.'b'If only it was just public spaces that were unsafe. In my office at a prominent newsmagazine, at the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s office, even at a house party \xe2\x80\x94 I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t escape the intimidation.'b'On Dec. 16, as the world now knows, a 23-year-old woman and a male friend were returning home after watching the movie \xe2\x80\x9cLife of Pi\xe2\x80\x9d at a mall in southwest Delhi. After they boarded what seemed to be a passenger bus, the six men inside 'b'gang-raped and tortured'b' the woman so brutally that her intestines were destroyed. The bus service had been a ruse. The attackers also severely beat up the woman\xe2\x80\x99s friend and threw them from the vehicle, leaving her to die.'b'The young woman didn\xe2\x80\x99t oblige. She had started that evening watching a film about a survivor, and must have been determined to survive herself. Then she produced another miracle. In Delhi, a city habituated to the debasement of women, tens of thousands of people took to the streets and faced down police officers, tear gas and water cannons to express their outrage. It was the most vocal protest against sexual assault and rape in India to date, and it set off nationwide demonstrations.'b'To protect her privacy the victim\xe2\x80\x99s name was not released publicly. But while she remains nameless, she did not remain faceless. To see her face, women had only to look in the mirror. The full measure of their vulnerability was finally understood.'b'When I was 26, I moved to Mumbai. A commercial and financial megalopolis, it has its own special set of problems, but has, culturally, been more cosmopolitan and liberal than Delhi. Giddy with my new freedom, I started to report from the red-light district and traveled across rough suburbs late at night \xe2\x80\x94 on my own and using public transit. It seemed that something good had come out of living in Delhi: I was so grateful for the comparatively safe environment of Mumbai that I took full advantage of it.'b'The young woman, however, will never have such an opportunity. On Saturday morning, 13 days after she was brutalized, this student of physical therapy, who had, no doubt, dreamt of improving lives, lost her own. She died of multiple organ failure.'b'India has laws against rape; seats reserved for women in buses, female officers; special police help lines. But these measures have been ineffective in the face of a patriarchal and misogynistic culture. It is a culture that believes that the worst aspect of rape is the defilement of the victim, who will no longer be able to find a man to marry her \xe2\x80\x94 and that the solution is to marry the rapist.'b'These beliefs aren\xe2\x80\x99t restricted to living rooms, but are expressed openly. In the months before the gang rape, some prominent politicians had attributed 'b'rising rape statistics'b' to women\xe2\x80\x99s increasing use of cellphones and going out at night. \xe2\x80\x9cJust because India achieved freedom at midnight does not mean that women can venture out after dark,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'said'b' Botsa Satyanarayana, the Congress Party leader in the state of Andhra Pradesh.'b'Change is possible, but the police must document reports of rape and sexual assault, and investigations and court cases have to be fast-tracked and not left to linger for years. Of the more than 600 rape cases reported in Delhi in 2012, 'b'only one led to a conviction'b'. If victims believe they will receive justice, they will be more willing to speak up. If potential rapists fear the consequences of their actions, they will not pluck women off the streets with impunity.'b'The volume of protests in public and in the media has made clear that the attack was a turning point. The unspeakable truth is that the young woman attacked on Dec. 16 was more fortunate than many rape victims. She was among the 'b'very few to receive anything close to justice'b'. She was hospitalized, her statement was recorded and within days all six of the suspected rapists were caught and, now, 'b'charged with murder'b'. Such efficiency is unheard-of in India.'b'In retrospect it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the brutality of the attack on the young woman that made her tragedy unusual; it was that an attack had, at last, elicited a response.'b'Every night until dawn, after people in apartment buildings and houses put out their sorted and bagged garbage for pickup from the sidewalks, the waiting piles are quietly picked over by some 5,000 scavengers called \xe2\x80\x9ccanners.\xe2\x80\x9d In the dark, they loom as silhouettes carrying giant plastic sacks to cart away countless soda cans and bottles, redeemable for 5 cents each.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a beautiful thing,\xe2\x80\x9d explains Marcus Moore, a canner who roams his unofficial territory barely ahead of the sanitation trucks. He makes maybe $500 a month from canning \xe2\x80\x94 peanuts, he says, compared with the take of Gene Rice, a kind of canning jedi master who tutored him at 'b'Picture the Homeless'b', an organization that serves people living on the city\xe2\x80\x99s edgier corners.'b'Mr. Moore is refashioning himself as an \xe2\x80\x9cecological engineer,\xe2\x80\x9d he says with a laugh, while warily looking out for rats attracted to the same garbage piles.'b'Seven years ago, Ana Martinez de Luco, a Roman Catholic nun, became a canner herself in creating 'b'Sure We Can'b', a project for the destitute, with the help of Eugene Gadsden, a street legend as a scavenger. Sister Ana estimated that the garbage piles back then were worked by about 2,500 people, who were predominantly poor and black, often mentally ill loners. But now in the struggling economy, there are Hispanic families, Chinese couples and other newcomers who are laboring overtime in what Sister Ana says is a doubling of the volume of empties being retrieved and cashed in.'b'This means that Sister Ana now manages a booming depot on McKibbin Street in Brooklyn that lays claim to being the city\xe2\x80\x99s only nonprofit redemption center, collecting 3 1/2 cents from the industry for handling each redeemable. Cans and bottles go through by the hundreds of thousands and canners walk into the morning light with money in their pockets. This year, Sister Ana aims to turn the center into a cooperative, controlled by a board of canners empowered by pride and castoff empties that don\xe2\x80\x99t belong in the garbage. 'b'  FRANCIS X. CLINES 'b''b'On the eve of the third anniversary of 'b'the earthquake that devastated Haiti in January 2010'b', the country remains in a fragile state. Billions of dollars in aid and lofty promises to \xe2\x80\x9cbuild back better\xe2\x80\x9d have brought it only so far. A recent article by Deborah Sontag of The Times showed, 'b'in disheartening detail,'b' the distance between hope and reality.'b'Ambitious projects are stuck on drawing boards or have been held up, she wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cby land and ideological disputes, logistical and contracting problems, staffing shortages and even weather.\xe2\x80\x9d A recovery commission led by the Haitian prime minister and former President Bill Clinton was meant to oversee the great rebuilding, but was slow to get started and is now defunct, with not much to show for its 18-month mission.'b'The flood of aid has slowed to a trickle; much of what was promised was never delivered or remains undisbursed, or was disbursed but not actually spent, or was spent on things like emergency food, water and tents, which are important but don\xe2\x80\x99t leave a lasting imprint. Money for long-term recovery has proved hard to spend, or slow to show results.'b'More than $1 billion allocated for Haiti remains in the United States Treasury, almost all of it for recovery, though America is hardly the only donor sitting on unspent aid. And more than 350,000 people who lost their homes that terrible day are still living in tent camps. The rubble has finally been cleared, but building permanent homes has taken a back seat to other matters.'b'The Times article reads like a catalog of missteps, of old mistakes and new ones that together present \xe2\x80\x94 to put the most optimistic spin on it \xe2\x80\x94 fresh opportunities to learn. One was the tendency of humanitarian aid organizations to go back to what they had been doing before the earthquake, in areas like sanitation, health, education and transportation, without the guidance of a broad plan and clear priorities for how best to repair the nation. Another failure has been the persistent unwillingness to include Haitians in the planning and execution of projects, leaving them feeling like bystanders in their own country and squandering opportunities to build government ministries and institutions capable of sustaining themselves once the world\xe2\x80\x99s attention and donations are gone.'b'Most recovery aid has been channeled through foreign agencies, nonprofit organizations and private contractors, a practice that inflates administrative costs and perpetuates cycles of dependency. And then there was the simple and shameful failure of global donors to meet their promises to deliver money and aid.'b'The State Department and other defenders of the international response point to some progress, like a new industrial park north of Port-au-Prince, the capital, providing the first 1,300 of what are supposed to be many thousands of manufacturing jobs. They say homes are being built, even if permanent ones are rising slowly and expensively. They plead for patience in a country where institutions were weak or nonexistent before the quake, which all but destroyed the government, flattening nearly every ministry and killing 20 percent of Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s civil servants.'b'Throughout the halting recovery, Haitians have borne up under other severe but unrelated afflictions: destructive storms, food shortages and disease. A 'b'recently announced'b' 10-year and $2.2 billion effort to rid Haiti and the Dominican Republic of cholera by improving water and sanitation will require close coordination among the Haitian government, the United Nations, United States and other partners. Senator John Kerry, who has paid astute attention to Haitian issues in the Senate, will be well placed to do so if he becomes the next secretary of state. As long as the miseries continue, the need for the world to get this right remains.'b'When the Supreme Court 'b'reinstated'b' the death penalty in 1976, it said there were two social purposes for imposing capital punishment for the most egregious crimes: deterrence and retribution. In recent months, these justifications for a cruel and uncivilized punishment have been seriously undermined by a growing group of judges, prosecutors, scholars and others involved in criminal justice, conservatives and liberals alike.'b'A distinguished committee of scholars convened by the National Research Council 'b'found'b' that there is no useful evidence to determine if the death penalty deters serious crimes. Many first-rate scholars have tried to prove the theory of deterrence, but that research \xe2\x80\x9cis not informative about whether capital punishment increases, decreases, or has no effect on homicide rates,\xe2\x80\x9d the committee said.'b'A host of other respected experts have also concluded that life imprisonment is a far more practical form of retribution, because the death penalty process is too expensive, too time-consuming and unfairly applied.'b'The punishment is supposed to be reserved for the very worst criminals, but dozens of studies in state after state have shown that the process for deciding who should be sent to death row is arbitrary and discriminatory.'b'Thanks to the 'b'Innocence Project'b' and the overturning of 18 wrongful convictions of death-row inmates with DNA evidence and the exonerations of 16 others charged with capital crimes, the American public is increasingly aware that the system makes terrible mistakes. Since 1973, a total of 142 people have been freed from death row after being exonerated with DNA or other kinds of evidence.'b'All of these factors have led the states to retreat from the death penalty in recent years \xe2\x80\x94 in both law and in practice. In 2012, Connecticut became the fifth state in five years to abolish the penalty. Nine states executed inmates, the fewest in two decades. Three-fourths of the 43 executions in 2012 were carried out in only four states. The number of new death sentences remained low at 77 \xe2\x80\x94 about one-third the number in 2000 \xe2\x80\x94 with just four states accounting for almost two-thirds of those sentences. While 33 states retain the death penalty on their books, 13 of them have not executed anyone for at least 'b'five years'b'.'b'Those 13 states plus the 17 without the penalty means that 30 states are not carrying it out \xe2\x80\x94 and that includes California, which retained the death penalty in a November referendum vote. Almost one-quarter of the 3,146 death row inmates in the United States, as of October, are imprisoned in California, but that state has not executed anyone in seven years.'b'California\xe2\x80\x99s chief justice 'b'said'b' recently that the state\xe2\x80\x99s official moratorium, which has been in place for six years, is likely to continue for at least three more because of problems with the execution method.'b'In January, executions are 'b'scheduled'b' to take place in Pennsylvania, Virginia and Texas. As it happens, major reviews of the death penalty are under way in each of those states. The reviews are very likely to find that those states have failed to meet standards of fairness under the Constitution, just as reviews of the capital systems in other states have concluded in the last decade.'b'The large number of states no longer carrying out executions indicates a kind of national consensus. It points to \xe2\x80\x9cthe evolving standards of decency that mark the progress of a maturing society,\xe2\x80\x9d an idea that the Supreme Court has evoked in judging the constitutionality of punishments. The court used that analysis most recently when it 'b'ruled'b' that mandatory life sentences without possibility of parole are unconstitutional for juvenile offenders even if they are convicted of homicide.'b'It should similarly recognize that under evolving standards capital punishment is cruel and unusual and should be abolished.'b'WASHINGTON'b'Michael Bennet was supposed to be going off a cliff in Vail.'b'But instead of his usual New Year\xe2\x80\x99s trip to a ski lodge with his wife and three daughters, the junior senator from Colorado found himself in a strange, unfamiliar place in the middle of the night: breaking with the president and his party to become one of only three Democratic senators and eight senators total to vote against President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s fiscal deal.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI was a little surprised that the margin of the vote was so big,\xe2\x80\x9d said a weary Senator Bennet, who seemed a bit taken aback to be such an outlier. He was munching on a late-afternoon cheese steak sandwich at \xe2\x80\x9cGeorge\xe2\x80\x99s, King of Falafel and Cheese Steaks.\xe2\x80\x9d (The senator loves falafel, which his girls call \xe2\x80\x9cfeel awful.\xe2\x80\x9d)'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI almost ordered extra cheese,\xe2\x80\x9d he said sheepishly, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I would have been embarrassed.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Long before Bennet came to work in the \xe2\x80\x9cland of flickering lights,\xe2\x80\x9d as he mockingly calls the dysfunctional nation\xe2\x80\x99s capital where he grew up, Frank Capra dreamed him up. In a Congress that has become op\xc3\xa9ra bouffe, Bennet is the freckled blond choir boy singing a cappella. The 48-year-old senator looks like the Yale law student he once was, wearing a Jos. A. Bank plaid shirt, gray sweater and khakis. \xe2\x80\x9cThese are the only clothes I have in Washington that\xe2\x80\x99s not a suit,\xe2\x80\x9d he grins.'b'As Katherine Boo wrote in The New Yorker, back when Bennet was the crusading Denver schools superintendent, his open face and amiable manner \xe2\x80\x9conly partly masked the intensity and severity of his judgments.\xe2\x80\x9d He was, Boo wrote, \xe2\x80\x9can overachiever. He liked to announce improbable goals, then defy expectations of failure.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Voting to let the country fall off the cliff was an audacious, even precocious, move by the Democratic golden boy and presidential pet \xe2\x80\x94 one that, oddly, put him on the side of Marco Rubio and Rand Paul rather than Obama and Joe Biden. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is an interesting group,\xe2\x80\x9d he deadpanned about the naysayers.'b'He also had to go against Majority Leader Harry Reid, who anointed the freshman to be the new leader of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.'b'Bennet, the future of his party, comes from the fertile territory of the Mountain West. Asked if his vote was a way to stake out some centrist and independent territory for a future White House run, he demurred, \xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, no.\xe2\x80\x9d Appointed in 2009 and little known in his state, he managed to survive the conservative wave that swept out so many Democrats in 2010 and his coalition of Hispanics and women became the model for the Obama campaign in Colorado in 2012. Democrats are counting on Bennet to recruit a new generation of candidates who will broaden the appeal and geographic reach of the party.'b'In frantic New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Day deal-making, he voted \xe2\x80\x9cnay\xe2\x80\x9d at about 2 a.m., and the House passed the bill around 11 p.m. He said he did so because the deal did not have meaningful deficit reduction, explaining: \xe2\x80\x9cGoing over the cliff is a lousy choice and continuing to ignore the fiscal realities that we face is a lousy choice.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He said he thinks the president wants serious deficit cuts but is dealing with people \xe2\x80\x9cso intransigent I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure they could be brought to an agreement that\xe2\x80\x99s meaningful in the absence of going over the cliff. But it\xe2\x80\x99s a terrible thing to say. People at home are so bone-tired of these outcomes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He said his focus now is the same as when he was the Denver superintendent trying to get more poor kids to stay in school.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe burden of proof has to shift from the people who want to change the system to the people who want to keep it the same,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI think if we can get people focused to do what we need to do to keep our kids from being stuck with this debt that they didn\xe2\x80\x99t accrue, you might be surprised at how far we can move this conversation.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWashington politics no longer follows the example of our parents and our grandparents who saw as their first job creating more opportunity, not less, for the people who came after. My mother\xe2\x80\x99s parents were refugees from Warsaw who came here after World War II because they could rebuild their shattered lives. But the political debate now is a zero-sum game that creates more problems than solutions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He thinks the trouble is not so much a clash of Democratic and Republican orthodoxies as it is a clash of past and future. \xe2\x80\x9cI think the inhabitants of the past are fighting hard to keep the rents they acquired in the 20th century,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'I noted that his wife said that his special skill is knowing the difference between worthy challenges and impossible ones. He laughed, then mused: \xe2\x80\x9cThis may be one of the impossible ones. But we have to do it. I know this country is not going to allow itself to go bankrupt. It\xe2\x80\x99s challenging, though, because in this town there are all kinds of people whose job it is to obfuscate the facts.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Then the exhausted senator left to see \xe2\x80\x9cSkyfall.\xe2\x80\x9d The one with James Bond, not John Boehner.'b'Roslyn Heights, N.Y.'b'IT\xe2\x80\x99S my last full day as a member of the Congress, and I have it all under control \xe2\x80\x94 I think.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m fulfilled and grateful to have been able to pay back a small portion for the good things that happened to me in life. To retire after 35 years in elected office, with no formulated plan as yet but goofing off with my grandchildren, seems right for the moment. I\xe2\x80\x99m happy to play the rest of life by ear.'b'I had hoped to keep my emotions in check, to put off the question of who I am. Did I become the job? Without it, who will I be? The question tomorrow will be \xe2\x80\x94 as Jean Valjean sings in \xe2\x80\x9cLes Mis\xc3\xa9rables\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cWho am I?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But my emotions have a mind of their own. This week I cast my last vote \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cto extend certain tax relief provisions enacted in 2001 and 2003\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cfor other purposes\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 of what I estimate have been more than 16,000 votes cast in my career.'b'Coming from an immigrant family of Polish Jews with peasant origins, sheltered by decent, safe public housing (the Kingsborough Houses in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, and the Pomonok Houses in Flushing, Queens), receiving great medical care when I needed it thanks to a generous society (and charity hospitals such as St. Giles the Cripple and St. Luke\xe2\x80\x99s), educated by wonderful public schools, with a priceless, cost-free degree from Queens College, I have lived my entire life knowing that I owed somebody something.'b'And I fancied myself becoming somebody, and paying it forward. I taught in public schools. I helped start a business. (Yes, liberals can be job creators and believe in capitalism.) As a state senator and then a congressman, I\xe2\x80\x99ve had the privilege of trying to do good things for people to whom I owe so much and can never fully repay. I\xe2\x80\x99ve personally demanded that tyrants let their people go. I\xe2\x80\x99ve tried to feed the hungry, clothe the poor, protect the elderly and infirm, and defend the needy from the aggressively greedy. I\xe2\x80\x99ve led a blessed life. What a kick for a kid from the projects.'b'I entered government service at a time when America was becoming more and more diverse. Some neighborhoods in my hometown, New York City, were changing so rapidly, welcoming people with so much hope and talent and pride, one just had to know that so much promise could only make a great nation better.'b'I remember from my childhood a wooden jigsaw puzzle map of what were then the 48 states. The puzzle wasn\xe2\x80\x99t complete unless one could fit all the pieces together to make one country, our country. But the House of Representatives has 435 separate pieces, each piece represented by a person speaking for communities with different ideas and approaches. On many occasions, we made it all fit together. Compromise was not heresy. Your opponent was not your enemy. The debate was choosing between better or worse policies, not good or evil ideologies. Of course, between good and bad there is a void of gray.'b'Two months shy of 30 years in the House, I leave a chamber in which we challenge one another\xe2\x80\x99s legitimacy, not one another\xe2\x80\x99s ideas. When I arrived in Washington, in 1983, Ronald Reagan was president, the Republicans controlled the Senate, and the Democrats were the majority in the House. Today the situation is reversed: Barack Obama is about to be sworn in for a second term, the Democrats control the Senate and the Republicans are in the majority in the House.'b'What has changed is the disappearance of the spirit of cooperation and shared sacrifice that, only three decades ago, could bring political opponents together. I came at a time of great hope and leave at a time when finding a middle path has become a much greater challenge.'b'My last votes capped off a chapter of a storybook life I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have dreamed up: the fiscal compromise approved by the House, with the support of nearly all Democrats and a minority of Republicans, staved off what would have been devastating tax-rate increases for nearly all but the wealthiest American households. The background music of Claude-Michel Sch\xc3\xb6nberg sounded in my mind.'b'Sadly, there was a disappointing coda, as House leaders failed to bring to a vote legislation to provide emergency aid to those left desperate and dispirited by Hurricane Sandy. (House Republican leaders are now promising a vote on that legislation on Friday, when the new, 113th Congress will have been seated.) I found myself hoping for \xe2\x80\x9cone day more.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As I walked out of La Guardia Airport this morning, on my last flight as a congressman from Reagan National Airport, I suddenly felt lost. I got misty. Without a musket to raise, a barricade to storm, a flag to wave, the question hit me in the face like the cold air: \xe2\x80\x9cWho am I?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Back home on Long Island, I am slowly regrouping, stunned by my own question. This latest budget deal, like all the others, fails to confront the long-term budget problems, like trillions in unfunded liabilities.'b'Sooner or later we\xe2\x80\x99re going to look down and see that there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing under our feet except future generations, who are lying on the canyon floor far below with our mountainous debt descending on them.'b'Too bad it\xe2\x80\x99s not all a cartoon. Or is it?'b'MARK R. GODBURN'b'\nNorth Canaan, Conn., Jan. 2, 2013'b''b'ACCORDING to the United States government, nearly 7 out of 10 American adults weigh too much. (In 2010, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention categorized 74 percent of men and 65 percent of women as either overweight or obese.)'b'But a new meta-analysis of the relationship between weight and mortality risk, involving nearly three million subjects from more than a dozen countries, illustrates just how exaggerated and unscientific that claim is.'b'The meta-analysis, published this week in 'b'The Journal of the American Medical Association'b', reviewed data from nearly a hundred large epidemiological studies to determine the correlation between body mass and mortality risk. The results ought to stun anyone who assumes the definition of \xe2\x80\x9cnormal\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9chealthy\xe2\x80\x9d weight used by our public health authorities is actually supported by the medical literature.'b'The 'b'study'b', by Katherine M. Flegal and her associates at the C.D.C. and the National Institutes of Health, found that all adults categorized as overweight and most of those categorized as obese have a lower mortality risk than so-called normal-weight individuals. If the government were to redefine normal weight as one that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t increase the risk of death, then about 130 million of the 165 million American adults currently categorized as overweight and obese would be re-categorized as normal weight instead.'b'To put some flesh on these statistical bones, the study found a 6 percent 'b'decrease'b' in mortality risk among people classified as overweight and a 5 percent decrease in people classified as Grade 1 obese, the lowest level (most of the obese fall in this category). This means that average-height women \xe2\x80\x94 5 feet 4 inches \xe2\x80\x94 who weigh between 108 and 145 pounds have a higher mortality risk than average-height women who weigh between 146 and 203 pounds. For average-height men \xe2\x80\x94 5 feet 10 inches \xe2\x80\x94 those who weigh between 129 and 174 pounds have a higher mortality risk than those who weigh between 175 and 243 pounds.'b'Now, if we were to employ the logic of our public health authorities, who treat any correlation between weight and increased mortality risk as a good reason to encourage people to try to modify their weight, we ought to be telling the 75 million American adults currently occupying the government\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9chealthy weight\xe2\x80\x9d category to put on some pounds, so they can move into the lower risk, higher-weight categories.'b'In reality, of course, it would be nonsensical to tell so-called normal-weight people to try to become heavier to lower their mortality risk. Such advice would ignore the fact that tiny variations in relative risk in observational studies provide no scientific basis for concluding either that those variations are causally related to the variable in question or that this risk would change if the variable were altered.'b'This is because observational studies merely record statistical correlations: we don\xe2\x80\x99t know to what extent, if any, the slight decrease in mortality risk observed among people defined as overweight or moderately obese is caused by higher weight or by other factors. Similarly, we don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether the small increase in mortality risk observed among very obese people is caused by their weight or by any number of other factors, including lower socioeconomic status, dieting and the weight cycling that accompanies it, social discrimination and stigma, or stress.'b'In other words, there is no reason to believe that the trivial variations in mortality risk observed across an enormous weight range actually have anything to do with weight or that intentional weight gain or loss would affect that risk in a predictable way.'b'How did we get into this absurd situation? That is a long and complex story. Over the past century, Americans have become increasingly obsessed with the supposed desirability of thinness, as thinness has become both a marker for upper-class status and a reflection of beauty ideals that bring a kind of privilege.'b'In addition, baselessly categorizing at least 130 million Americans \xe2\x80\x94 and hundreds of millions in the rest of the world \xe2\x80\x94 as people in need of \xe2\x80\x9ctreatment\xe2\x80\x9d for their \xe2\x80\x9ccondition\xe2\x80\x9d serves the economic interests of, among others, the multibillion-dollar weight-loss industry and large pharmaceutical companies, which have invested a great deal of money in winning the good will of those who will determine the regulatory fate of the next generation of diet drugs.'b'Anyone familiar with history will not be surprised to learn that \xe2\x80\x9cfacts\xe2\x80\x9d have been enlisted before to confirm the legitimacy of a cultural obsession and to advance the economic interests of those who profit from that obsession.'b'Don\xe2\x80\x99t expect those who have made their careers on fomenting panic to understand that our current definition of \xe2\x80\x9cnormal weight\xe2\x80\x9d makes absolutely no sense.'b'Tampa, Fla.'b'LAST month, HSBC admitted in court pleadings that it had allowed big Mexican and Colombian drug cartels to launder at least $881 million. The bank also admitted to using various schemes to move hundreds of millions of dollars to nations subject to trade sanctions, including Iran, Cuba and Sudan, in violation of the Trading With the Enemy Act. \xe2\x80\x9cOn at least one occasion,\xe2\x80\x9d according to a statement by Assistant Attorney General Lanny A. Breuer, \xe2\x80\x9cHSBC instructed a bank in Iran on how to format payment messages so that the transactions would not be blocked or rejected by the United States.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Those were some of the transgressions uncovered during a two-year investigation led by the Justice and Treasury Departments and acknowledged by HSBC in a settlement, known as a 'b'deferred prosecution agreement'b', that was filed in a federal court in December. Not a single executive was charged with a crime. Instead, the bank paid 'b'$1.9 billion'b' in fines and forfeitures \xe2\x80\x94 or roughly 10 percent of the pretax profits it earned in just 2010, one of the more than five years during which it admitted to criminal conduct.'b'HSBC is hardly alone. Court filings show that, since 2006, more than a dozen banks have reached settlements with the Justice Department regarding violations related to money laundering. 'b'ING Bank paid'b' a $619 million fine for altering records and secretly transferring more than $2 billion for entities trading with Iran and other nations under sanctions. American Express Bank International acknowledged that more than $55 million in drug proceeds may have been laundered through offshore shell accounts it maintained. The Justice Department has signed similar agreements, withholding prosecution in exchange for bank promises to tighten oversight, with Wachovia, Union Bank of California, Lloyds, Credit Suisse, ABN Amro Holding (now owned by Royal Bank of Scotland), Barclays and Standard Chartered. All admitted to criminal offenses; all were handed the equivalent of traffic tickets \xe2\x80\x94 pay a fine on your way out the door.'b'This has been the government\xe2\x80\x99s playbook in fighting terrorism and the drug trade. For make no mistake, without the ability to \xe2\x80\x9cwash\xe2\x80\x9d billions of dollars of money from illicit sources each year and bank the untraceable profits, both of these criminal enterprises would falter.'b'In November, the House Subcommittee on Oversight, Investigations and Management issued a shocking 'b'report'b' documenting the collaboration between Mexican and Colombian drug cartels and Hezbollah in narcotics and human trafficking, smuggling and financial crimes in the United States and Latin America \xe2\x80\x94 a partnership that, in just the border region between Brazil, Paraguay and Argentina, produces an estimated $12 billion in cash each year.'b'Yet data from the Department of Justice Asset Forfeiture Fund and the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime Research Report show that United States law enforcement tracks down and seizes no more than 1 percent of the drug fortunes generated each year by global cartels.'b'The rest isn\xe2\x80\x99t hiding in mattresses. It\xe2\x80\x99s being washed \xe2\x80\x94 stripped clean of information that would identify its source, then transferred from one account to another, and often moved surreptitiously through various business enterprises, until it can settle safely in a criminal\xe2\x80\x99s private 'b'offshore bank'b' account. None of this happens without help from bankers, lawyers and businessmen.'b'I have seen this firsthand. I was a federal agent for 27 years and worked undercover as a money launderer within this murky realm for five of them. I worked on teams that put leaders of drug cartels behind bars. The largest and most sophisticated of these criminal enterprises don\xe2\x80\x99t trick banks into laundering their money \xe2\x80\x94 they partner with that small segment of the international banking and business community that recirculates drug profits and cash from other illicit trades, like black-market arms dealing.'b'The only way to stop the flow of this dirty money is to get tough on the bankers who help mask and transfer it around the world. Banks themselves don\xe2\x80\x99t launder money, after all; people do.'b'The standard of proof needed to charge and convict a bank officer of money laundering is simple. If the person knows that funds are proceeds of a crime and, thereafter, he attempts to disguise or conceal the true source of the funds, he has committed the criminal offense of money laundering. Any individual who intentionally provides financial services to criminal organizations should be dealt with as harshly as possible under the law.'b'Bank officers at HSBC branches in Mexico who facilitated the transfer of $881 million for the Sinaloa Cartel in Mexico, the Norte del Valle Cartel in Colombia and other narcotics traffickers \xe2\x80\x94 deposits that were often passed through teller windows in cash-filled boxes, some with hundreds of thousands of dollars in them \xe2\x80\x94 might contend that they were na\xc3\xafve about this money\xe2\x80\x99s source. But there\xe2\x80\x99s little incentive for them, or any bank officer, to be more vigilant when turning a blind eye comes with little or no penalty.'b'The stakes are simply too high for such a soft-glove approach on money laundering. As long as drug traffickers can wash the stain from 99 percent of their ill-gotten gains, as long as terrorists can move their cash freely around the world, we\xe2\x80\x99ll have no chance to halt their deadly trades. We can help put an end to both of these scourges by putting the bankers who facilitate them in jail.'b'Washington'b'CALLING the massacre in Newtown, Conn., \xe2\x80\x9cthe worst day of my presidency,\xe2\x80\x9d President Obama recently told NBC\xe2\x80\x99s David Gregory: \xe2\x80\x9cMy response is, something has to work. And it is not enough for us to say, \xe2\x80\x98This is too hard, so we\xe2\x80\x99re not going to try.\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Almost 20 years ago, Senator Dianne Feinstein and other lawmakers took the same approach to build a bipartisan majority in Congress, tortuously, vote by vote, for legislation banning the future manufacture and sale of assault weapons and high-capacity ammunition magazines.'b'As Senator Feinstein\xe2\x80\x99s counsel for the Senate Judiciary Committee in 1993, I worked with her to get the assault weapons bill to President Bill Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s desk. But the legislation expired in 2004 and hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been renewed. Understanding what worked then is the key to doing it again in the new Congress, as Senator Feinstein has vowed to do.'b'Then, as now, legislation was the product of spectacular violence. On July 1, 1993, a man carrying two semiautomatic pistols equipped with high-capacity ammunition magazines and \xe2\x80\x9chellfire\xe2\x80\x9d triggers, and another pistol, strolled off an elevator in a San Francisco building. He entered the offices of a law firm and killed eight people and injured six others before taking his own life. In the wake of that horror, Senator Feinstein asked me to review earlier bills by two other Democratic senators at the time, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio, and blend them with her own proposals to create meaningful new legislation that could pass Congress.'b'The law that resulted is best known for regulating certain semiautomatic weapons and large ammunition magazines, but it\xe2\x80\x99s worth remembering that its official name was the Public Safety and Recreational Firearms Use Protection Act.'b'That title wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a euphemism: the law needed support from lawmakers who had viewed prior legislative efforts as toothless, as well as those who feared that a ban on assault weapons could lead to the confiscation of guns used for hunting and target shooting.'b'The bill had three main components. The first was a list of well-known, deeply feared guns that were banned by name (like Uzis). The second banned the future manufacture and sale of any new semiautomatic weapon with a detachable magazine and more than two of several assault-style features (like a forward handgrip). The third and most critical section was Appendix A, which listed every single hunting rifle and shotgun in use at the time \xe2\x80\x94 there were hundreds \xe2\x80\x94 that didn\xe2\x80\x99t run afoul of the features test in the second component. Those firearms were unequivocally exempted from the bill.'b'At the time, gun-control advocates resisted the incorporation of Appendix A. But the idea behind it was and remains crucial to making any meaningful changes in America\xe2\x80\x99s gun laws. They must gain the support of gun owners, most of whom are heartsick over senseless carnage.'b'By explicitly protecting hundreds of popular sporting guns, the bill enabled senators and representatives to push back against the tide of protests \xe2\x80\x94 many of them generated by the National Rifle Association \xe2\x80\x94 at town hall-style meetings in their states and districts. They could show their constituents that their ordinary hunting rifles and shotguns were protected in Appendix A or that their guns could be added to it, if need be. Proponents of the legislation distributed blue booklets describing all three parts of the bill, including pictures of the assault weapons banned by name and the full list of guns protected by Appendix A.'b'The nation\xe2\x80\x99s principal law enforcement organizations, whose leaders testified and lobbied aggressively for the bill, also made great use of the booklets and Appendix A. In fact, it was a survey showing overwhelming support for an assault-weapons ban from police chiefs in and around his Congressional district that persuaded Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, the top Republican on the House Judiciary Committee at the time, to support the bill. His surprise yes vote offset the no vote of the committee\xe2\x80\x99s conservative chairman, Representative Jack Brooks, a Texas Democrat, so that the bill could move to the floor of the House.'b'The existence of Appendix A also made it possible for Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a Colorado Democrat and longtime N.R.A. member \xe2\x80\x94 coupled with his own reaction to a torrent of gun-lobby phone calls \xe2\x80\x94 to commit to supporting Senator Feinstein\xe2\x80\x99s bill if it was essential. That moment came when a motion to table, or effectively kill, the bill came before the Senate. Although the motion would have failed with a tie vote of 50 to 50, Senator Feinstein asked Senator Campbell for his vote to show that a majority of senators supported the bill. He honored his commitment, and the motion to table failed, 49 to 51, paving the way for the ultimate passage of the bill by a vote of 57 to 43.'b'Following the Newtown tragedy, inaction is not an option, morally or politically. President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. (who championed the original assault-weapons ban when he served in the Senate) are on the right track with their plan to present legislation before the new Congress.'b'Preventing another slaughter will require not just new gun regulations, but also education, mental health care, greater access by law enforcement agencies to mental health records and assistance for parents, while respecting the whole Bill of Rights.'b'But the lesson from nearly two decades ago remains clear. If any meaningful change is to come, legislators must again devise a bill that both regulates assault weapons and respects and protects gun owners.'b'If we want to reimpose a permanent assault-weapons ban and restrict high capacity ammunition magazines, let\xe2\x80\x99s include a new list of exempted rifles and shotguns used for recreational shooting in a new Appendix A (updated annually) and actively solicit input from the shooting community to make it work.'b'If we want to require background checks for all private sales at gun shows, let\xe2\x80\x99s cap the cost so that private sales aren\xe2\x80\x99t prohibitively expensive. But then let\xe2\x80\x99s also relieve gun owners of the burden of identifying and complying with a patchwork of different state laws covering the transport of firearms and permit, under federal law, the transport of any lawfully owned gun across state lines if it\xe2\x80\x99s unloaded and locked in the trunk of a car, in a childproof case.'b'Finally, if only because it\xe2\x80\x99s the fair thing to do, let\xe2\x80\x99s require states and localities to process gun registration and other applications by law-abiding gun owners within a reasonable period of time, and with firm deadlines.'b'We need comprehensive proposals that can gain wide support. As always, the resulting legislation won\xe2\x80\x99t be perfect. Bev Perdue of North Carolina, proclaiming the innocence of the Wilmington 10, a group of civil rights activists who were wrongly convicted and imprisoned when a white-owned grocery store was firebombed in 1971.'b'The injustice of their trial was fully documented by a federal appeals court in a 1980 ruling that overturned the conviction on the grounds of perjured testimony and prosecution misconduct. But the 10 activists remained under an official cloud for decades, their lives shadowed by public doubts and the theoretical possibility of a new trial on the old charges.'b'Governor Perdue put an end to those questions Monday with 'b'a forthright acknowledgment'b' that \xe2\x80\x9cthese convictions were tainted by naked racism and represent an ugly stain on North Carolina\xe2\x80\x99s criminal justice system.\xe2\x80\x9d The convictions fell apart when the crucial witness recanted his testimony amid mounting evidence that the prosecution abused the rights of the defendants as they maintained their innocence.'b'The governor said she was \xe2\x80\x9cappalled\xe2\x80\x9d by the prosecutor\xe2\x80\x99s recently uncovered notes showing that he had favored Ku Klux Klan members in putting a white majority on the jury.'b'Four of the Wilmington 10 have died, and others have had trouble recovering from the ordeal. Ben Chavis, who was a 24-year-old civil rights activist when he was sentenced to 34 years in prison at the trial, thanked the governor for showing \xe2\x80\x9ctremendous courage\xe2\x80\x9d in declaring that the 10 were never guilty of anything. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have justice today,\xe2\x80\x9d said Chavis, now 64. The pardon by Ms. Perdue, who leaves office this month, helps to close a dark chapter in the state\xe2\x80\x99s history.'b'Few relationships are as important to stability in Asia as the one between Japan and South Korea. Yet Japan\xe2\x80\x99s new prime minister, Shinzo Abe, seems inclined to start his tenure with a serious mistake that would inflame tensions with South Korea and make cooperation harder. 'b'He has signaled'b' that he might seek to revise Japan\xe2\x80\x99s apologies for its World War II aggression, including one for using Koreans and other women as sex slaves.'b''b'In 1993'b', Japan finally acknowledged that the Japanese military had raped and enslaved thousands of Asian and European women in army brothels, and offered its first full apology for those atrocities. A broader apology by Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama 'b'in 1995'b' conceded that \xe2\x80\x9cthrough its colonial rule and invasion,\xe2\x80\x9d Japan had caused \xe2\x80\x9ctremendous damage and suffering to the people of many countries, particularly to those of Asian nations.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In an interview with the Sankei Shimbun newspaper, Mr. Abe, a right-wing nationalist, was quoted by Reuters on Monday as saying he wants to replace the 1995 apology with an unspecified \xe2\x80\x9cforward looking statement.\xe2\x80\x9d He said that his previous administration, in 2006-7, had found no evidence that the women who served as sex slaves to Japan\xe2\x80\x99s wartime military had, in fact, been coerced. However, at a news conference last week, the chief cabinet secretary, Yoshihide Suga, said that Mr. Abe would uphold the 1995 apology but hinted he may revise the 1993 statement.'b'It is not clear how Mr. Abe, the leader of the Liberal Democratic Party of Japan, might modify the apologies, but he has previously made no secret of his desire to rewrite his country\xe2\x80\x99s wartime history. Any attempt to deny the crimes and dilute the apologies will outrage South Korea, as well as China and the Philippines, which suffered under Japan\xe2\x80\x99s brutal wartime rule.'b'Mr. Abe\xe2\x80\x99s shameful impulses could threaten critical cooperation in the region on issues like North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear weapons program. Such revisionism is an embarrassment to a country that should be focused on improving its long-stagnant economy, not whitewashing the past.'b'Republicans won more in the fiscal-cliff deal than they had any right to expect. Permanent tax cuts for the middle class and millions of wealthy families, a permanent break on the estate tax and dividends, a five-year limit on tax credits for low-income families, and only a single year of extended unemployment insurance. Yet 'b'64 percent of House Republicans'b' 'b'voted against it Tuesday night'b'.'b'Their explanations reeked of tired ideology about never raising anyone\xe2\x80\x99s taxes and the lack of spending cuts. If not for Speaker John Boehner\xe2\x80\x99s last-moment decision to allow the bill to pass without a Republican majority, everyone\xe2\x80\x99s income taxes would have gone up.'b'The unwillingness of Mr. Boehner\xe2\x80\x99s caucus to join such decisions for the common good suggests that the 113th Congress, which begins on Thursday, will be bitterly unproductive, and possibly even more dangerous than the last Congress. Republicans say they are more determined than ever to extract the maximum amount of budget-cutting pain in the next two months by threatening not to 'b'raise the debt ceiling'b'.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s a far more serious prospect than going over the fiscal cliff. Letting the Treasury run out of borrowing authority would mean a default on the nation\xe2\x80\x99s credit, a catastrophic prospect for holders of government bonds around the world. It could result in further credit downgrades and lead to sharply higher borrowing costs. It is an unimaginable prospect for a responsible country, yet 'b'it almost happened in 2011'b' because of the irresponsibility of Congressional Republicans.'b'Mr. Obama sounded resolute on Tuesday night in vowing he will not submit to this blackmail. \xe2\x80\x9cI will not have another debate with this Congress over whether or not they should pay the bills that they\xe2\x80\x99ve already racked up through the laws that they passed,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. But will he really keep this promise?'b'The White House won several victories in the fiscal-cliff package, but its eagerness for a deal disappointed many who believed the president\xe2\x80\x99s promise to raise far more revenue. It is hard to see how he avoids giving in to Republican demands, as he was forced to do in 2011.'b'Mr. Obama has also said he will demand equivalent revenue increases for every dollar of spending cuts won by Republicans over the next year. That could be done by further limits on deductions and loopholes for corporations and the rich, including eliminating the carried-interest loophole that lets hedge fund managers declare that their income is a form of capital gains. But it will be a struggle to uphold that pledge, given the maddening nature of his opponents.'b'In the weeks to come, Republicans will use not just the debt-ceiling threat, but also the $100 billion across-the-board cuts known as the sequester, delayed for two months in this week\xe2\x80\x99s deal, and the potential shutdown of the government when the current spending resolution expires in March. Standing up to brinkmanship will require a level of resolve that the president has yet to fully demonstrate.'b'We have a deal. But please hold your applause, indefinitely.'b'We momentarily went over the fiscal cliff but clawed our way back up the rock face. Unfortunately, we are most likely in store for a never-ending series of cliffs for our economy, our government and indeed our country. Soon we\xe2\x80\x99ll have to deal with the sequester, a debt-ceiling extension and possibly a budget, all of which hold the specter of revisiting the unresolvable conflicts and intransigence of the fiscal cliff. Imagine an M. C. Escher drawing of cliffs.'b'Be clear: there is no reason to celebrate. This is a mournful moment. We \xe2\x80\x94 and by we I mean Congress, and by Congress I mean the Republicans in Congress \xe2\x80\x94 have again demonstrated just how broken and paralyzed our government has become, how beholden to hostage-takers, how vulnerable to extremism.'b'A fiscal cliff deal was cut at the last possible minute, covering a minimal number of issues. It was far from perfect and barely palatable. It was a compromise, and compromises are inherently imperfect. No one likes the whole of it, but they balance the bad parts against the good and see beyond dissension.'b'As the fiscal cliff votes came down to the wire, many repeated the aphorism: don\xe2\x80\x99t let the perfect be the enemy of the good. But sadly, we are beyond even that. Now the perfunctory has become the victim of the grueling.'b'The American people suffered through another moment of manufactured suspense brought on by political malpractice. There was no grand bargain. There was only a begrudging acquiescence.'b'Not only is the 'b'era of grand bargains \xe2\x80\x9cover,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' as Jennifer Steinhauer wrote in The Times on Tuesday, I believe that the era of basic governance is screeching to a halt.'b'As Steinhauer 'b'pointed out in September'b':'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe 112th Congress is set to enter the Congressional record books as the least productive body in a generation, passing a mere 173 public laws as of last month. That was well below the 906 'b'enacted from January 1947 through December 1948'b' by the body President Harry S. Truman referred to as the \xe2\x80\x98do-nothing\xe2\x80\x99 Congress, and far fewer than even a single session of many prior Congresses.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s an abominable shame. The one function of a lawmaker is to make laws. They can no longer seem to do that in any meaningful way.'b'It is no wonder that Gallup finds Congress\xe2\x80\x99s approval rating 'b'stuck in the teens'b'.'b'We have moved from a type of governance where the art of the compromise was invaluable to one where adherence to ridiculous pledges is inviolable. (By approving this fiscal cliff deal, many Republicans voted to broadly raise taxes for the first time in decades and many are still grousing about it.)'b'The change has taken place primarily among Republicans, who have struggled to balance the responsibilities and prerogatives of minority-party status with the anxiety of losing their long-held power at the expense of the growing influence of minority and historically marginalized constituencies like women and gays.'b'Smaller federal government! Out-of-control federal spending! States\xe2\x80\x99 rights! Defense of Marriage! Defund Planned Parenthood! There is an individual argument (merit not withstanding) to be made about each of these issues in its own right. But only a person who is willfully blind or hopelessly ignorant would not acknowledge the common thread that runs through them: the fear of a future in which income, wealth and cultural inequalities dissipate and traditional power structures dissolve.'b'The country\xe2\x80\x99s debt and solvency are real and legitimate concerns, but the true crux of the friction lies in the implicit arguments about the cause of our troubles. It is the tired and worn takers vs. makers argument just slathered in lipstick \xe2\x80\x94 Resistance Red, I suppose.'b'And since some of these Republicans are from safely gerrymandered districts, they have little to lose and something to gain by holding the line even if it continually pushes the country to the brink.'b'House Republicans like to say that Americans voted for a divided government and this gridlock is what becomes it. But that\xe2\x80\x99s not entirely correct. As 'b'The Economist'b' pointed out in November:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Democrats won 50.6% of the votes for president, to 47.8% for the Republicans; 53.6% of the votes for the Senate, to 42.9% for the Republicans; and... 49% of the votes for the House, to 48.2% for the Republicans (some ballots are still being counted). That\xe2\x80\x99s not a vote for divided government. It\xe2\x80\x99s a clean sweep.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Republicans control the House in part because of the geography of ideology \xe2\x80\x94 cities tend to have high concentrations of Democrats and rural areas have high concentrations of Republicans \xe2\x80\x94 and because of the way district lines were redrawn, in many cases by Republican-led state legislatures.'b'So we will be soon be pushed back into a state of panic because Republican members of Congress demand a state of paralysis.'b'We are stuck with this reckless, whining and ultimately dangerous gaggle of wounded spirits. As many people can attest, an animal is often at its most dangerous when it\xe2\x80\x99s sick, wounded or afraid. Brace yourselves.'b'There is a lot of finger-pointing in Washington about who is responsible for the mess made of the so-called fiscal-cliff negotiations, but there is no doubt about who 'b'failed thousands of residents and businesses devastated by Hurricane Sandy'b' and still waiting for help: Speaker John Boehner.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s not just our view. Mr. Christie said there was \xe2\x80\x9conly one group to blame\xe2\x80\x9d for the money being delayed six times longer than relief for Hurricane Katrina: the Republican majority and Mr. Boehner personally.'b'In 'b'a joint statement'b', Mr. Christie and Gov. That tradition was abandoned in the House last night.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Christie called the delay in aid \xe2\x80\x9cdisappointing and disgusting.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Boehner had promised to allow the House to vote this week on a $60.4 billion aid package that easily passed the Senate. But he reneged while trying to get out of the way of a final agreement on the fiscal cliff. Now the relief effort will have to begin again with the incoming Congress, and that means more time wasted and possibly less help for those who need it.'b'Whether Mr. Boehner can revive the Senate package in a few weeks, as now promised, is uncertain, because it\xe2\x80\x99s not clear whether he actually leads the right-dominated Republican caucus anymore. House Republicans are now looking at a patchwork response, starting with a $9 billion down payment mostly for flood insurance. The rest, if it comes at all, would come in other measures.'b'It has been more than 66 days since Hurricane Sandy slammed into New York and New Jersey killing more than 130 people and causing an estimated $82 billion in damage. Within 10 days after Hurricane Katrina flooded the Gulf Coast in 2005, Washington agreed on more than $60 billion in aid with more to come.'b'Residents and political leaders in the areas hit hardest by Sandy are understandably outraged about the delay. Mr. King was right both in substance and tenor on Wednesday when he said: \xe2\x80\x9cThese Republicans have no problem finding New York when they\xe2\x80\x99re out raising millions of dollars.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. King said Northeasterners should stop donating money to Republican lawmakers, who he said had \xe2\x80\x9cput a knife in the back of New Yorkers and New Jerseyans.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The $60.4 billion falls short of the original request by Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Christie, but it would at least make a good start. The Senate bill included money to reimburse local governments for overtime. There was $17 billion to help finance the rebuilding of homes and businesses that the Federal Emergency Management Agency would not cover. There was $11 billion for rebuilding and hardening the transportation system in the region, and more than $5 billion for flood control and shore strengthening projects.'b'The aid was overdue before Mr. Boehner tossed the Senate package aside on Tuesday.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'So Many Snapshots, So Few Voices Saved'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Sunday Observer, Dec. 30): Let\xe2\x80\x99s hear it for Verlyn Klinkenborg. 'b''b''b'To the Editor: 'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Unspeakable Truth About Rape in India'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by Sonia Faleiro (Op-Ed, Jan. 2):'b'Finally, women are speaking out.
