'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Unspeakable Truth About Rape in India\xe2\x80\x9d and your Dec. 29 editorial \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Rape in the World\xe2\x80\x99s Largest Democracy'b'\xe2\x80\x9d miss a key point. While both are correct to note that India has terribly high rates of sexual assault and other forms of violence against women, they do not mention the fact that violence is a global epidemic, not solely a byproduct of Indian culture.'b'Our similarly high rates of sexual assault and other forms of gender-based violence in American culture seem to be accepted by a collective shrug and a \xe2\x80\x9cblame the victim\xe2\x80\x9d mentality. We could learn from the Indian response to the recent horrific death of a young medical student: collective action and demands for change.'b'American and Indian women deserve better.'b'HILLARY HALDANE'b'\nFairfield, Conn., Jan. 2, 2013'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is an assistant professor of anthropology at Quinnipiac University and co-editor of \xe2\x80\x9cAnthropology at the Front Lines of Gender-Based Violence.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Chicago'b'WITHIN moments of their release on Thursday afternoon, the minutes from the Federal Reserve\xe2\x80\x99s December policy meeting caused a bond-market sell-off. Yields on Treasury bonds jumped as traders quickly dumped 10- and 30-year government bonds.'b'What was the profound economic news that caused this mini-convulsion in the market? Did the minutes reveal a weak spot in the nation\xe2\x80\x99s economic-growth prospects? Was word of December\xe2\x80\x99s employment numbers, scheduled for announcement on Friday, somehow leaked?'b'No. What spooked traders was surprise. The Fed minutes revealed deeper divisions within the central bank\xe2\x80\x99s ranks about the Fed\xe2\x80\x99s aggressive bond-buying efforts than many observers had supposed.'b'The events in the bond market today are an instructive lesson in the power of communication: when the Fed speaks, the fewer surprises, the better.'b'In the 1990s, those who hoped to divine the Fed\xe2\x80\x99s next move would study the girth of 'b'Alan Greenspan\xe2\x80\x99s briefcase'b'. If the Fed chairman\xe2\x80\x99s worn black satchel appeared to be bulging, many believed that a new monetary policy action was imminent. If not, then no change was foretold.'b'Until that time, the Fed chairman, governors and regional Fed bank presidents, like most central bankers around the world, gave few, if any, hints about the group\xe2\x80\x99s long-term thinking on interest rates and strategies for regulating the nation\xe2\x80\x99s money supply \xe2\x80\x94 decisions that would ultimately affect the borrowing costs for tens of millions of Americans. And when the Fed did speak, it was mostly in impenetrable syntax-bending tidbits of Delphic inscrutability.'b'The grand tradition of the oracular tight-lipped central banker, however, ended with a bang last month, when the current Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said it would keep short-term interest rates near zero at least as long as the unemployment rate 'b'remained above 6.5 percent'b' and as long inflation and inflation expectations continued to be contained. As the meeting minutes released on Thursday showed, this was a controversial change within the Fed; most of the group wanted to give an explicit unemployment threshold rather than continue the traditional approach of elegant vagueness \xe2\x80\x94 but not all.'b'All of this may seem like mumbo-jumbo to those unfamiliar with the jargon of monetary policy. But to veteran Fed watchers, this was a \xe2\x80\x9cReal Housewives\xe2\x80\x9d-level of candor.'b'Strong arguments can be made for whether or not it\xe2\x80\x99s appropriate for the Fed to continue its extraordinary effort to stimulate the economy by flatlining interest rates, by buying up Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities and by flooding the economy with bank reserves \xe2\x80\x94 a policy known as quantitative easing. I believe the two previous rounds helped to prevent a 1930s-style deflation from taking hold but share the group\xe2\x80\x99s concern, as revealed in the December minutes, that \xe2\x80\x9cthe benefits of ongoing purchases were uncertain and that the potential costs could rise as the size of the balance sheet increased.\xe2\x80\x9d (It was that concern \xe2\x80\x94 that the program of asset purchases could be 'b'cut short'b' \xe2\x80\x94 that caused the ruckus in the markets on Thursday.)'b'But that said, the fewer surprises and mixed messages in communication there are, the more likely the Fed\xe2\x80\x99s efforts to shore up the American economy will be effective. In this regard, the central bank\xe2\x80\x99s newest strategy of talking about itself \xe2\x80\x94 and notably, of its decision to tie its interest-rate moves to an unemployment threshold \xe2\x80\x94 is a great step forward in economic stewardship. Now, everyone knows what criteria Fed officials are using to guide future policy.'b'As stark as this move to transparency may seem, it has actually been some two decades in the making. An unlikely proponent was Mr. Greenspan himself when, under his chairmanship, the Fed began to issue brief explanations after each monetary policy meeting, including the votes of each member of the Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank\xe2\x80\x99s policy body. This was in contrast to the first eight decades of the Fed\xe2\x80\x99s existence, when the Fed would simply buy or sell securities in the market to try to affect credit conditions \xe2\x80\x94 so-called open market operations \xe2\x80\x94 without acknowledging its actions or revealing its intentions.'b'Under Mr. Bernanke, lips have loosened rapidly with quarterly news conferences, forecasts by F.O.M.C. members of key economic indicators, countless testimonies before Congress and, now, the explicit adoption of a 2 percent inflation goal.'b'The advantage of such glasnost is that it can give the Fed greater bang for its buck. Buying more government bonds may bring down interest rates today, but getting people to believe that the Fed will continue such \xe2\x80\x9caccommodative\xe2\x80\x9d policies adds to the potency of its actions in two ways: expectations of future borrowing costs stay low, and uncertainty about future monetary policy (and hence, future borrowing costs) declines. Such knowledge lets firms be more confident about investing and hiring, and gives homeowners and potential home buyers more faith that mortgages will stay affordable, providing support for the housing market.'b'Still, for the 'b'open-mouth strategy'b' to work, the words must be consistent with the direction of the policy action, otherwise those words can sabotage the impact of the actions. That\xe2\x80\x99s the lesson we learned from the Bank of Japan.'b'After the Japanese economy declined in the early 1990s and fell into deflation, the Bank of Japan dropped interest rates to nearly zero and embarked on a huge asset-purchase program (the pioneering \xe2\x80\x9cquantitative easing\xe2\x80\x9d program). The actions were on a much larger scale relative to G.D.P. than what the Fed has done.'b'Japan\xe2\x80\x99s central bank, however, made the mistake of emphasizing that these purchases were only temporary and would be reversed at the first signs of the proverbial \xe2\x80\x9cgreen shoots\xe2\x80\x9d of recovery. Despite the bank\xe2\x80\x99s large-scale asset purchases, the uncertainty that these statements created undermined confidence and the willingness to borrow. The bank\xe2\x80\x99s words spoke louder than actions.'b'The highest priority in the economic revival plan of the newly elected prime minister, Shinzo Abe, is to strong-arm the 'b'Bank of Japan'b' into acknowledging that it will do simply \xe2\x80\x9cwhatever it takes\xe2\x80\x9d to reverse deflation there and allow a recovery to take root.'b''b'Mark J. Carney'b', the head of Canada\xe2\x80\x99s central bank and soon to be the governor of the Bank of England, also seems to be embracing the \xe2\x80\x9cwhatever it takes\xe2\x80\x9d theory of communications: tying monetary policy to a single measure of overall economic health (like nominal income) rather than multiple metrics (inflation, inflation expectations, unemployment numbers) that may be even easier to understand.'b'The Fed might well consider alternative economic indicators as it assesses whether its interventions are reducing uncertainty and promoting recovery. But the key, it seems, is to be forthcoming about its thinking with the American people. For now, the bank\xe2\x80\x99s smart, calibrated open-mouth policy has been a step in the right direction.'b'That old black satchel of Mr. Greenspan\xe2\x80\x99s, meanwhile, ought to get a prominent spot in the Smithsonian.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Let\xe2\x80\x99s Give Up on the Constitution'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Op-Ed, Dec. 31):'b'Louis Michael Seidman wants us to \xe2\x80\x9ckick our constitutional-law addiction.\xe2\x80\x9d Why? He proclaims our political system \xe2\x80\x9cdysfunctional\xe2\x80\x9d and our government \xe2\x80\x9cbroken\xe2\x80\x9d but makes no convincing case that the Constitution is to blame for our recurring political breakdowns or that giving up on it would reduce our dysfunction. But malformed though it is, the rickety old structure has served us well over the centuries.'b'Mr. Seidman offers nothing to suggest how we might go about governing ourselves once liberated from the Constitution, the skeletal structure that frames a living conversation about our relationship with government, not blind worship of \xe2\x80\x9ca poetic piece of parchment.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He confidently predicts that his proposal wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t yield total anarchy. But he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t explain how we could preserve even the \xe2\x80\x9cpolitical stability\xe2\x80\x9d he values while treating the Constitution\xe2\x80\x99s provisions as mere recommendations, to be accepted or rejected through processes whose constitution-free structure he never specifies.'b'He tells us that he would preserve free speech and religion, equal protection and limited government, but he never explains how he picks those values over others or how his maddeningly vague proposal would \xe2\x80\x9cgive real freedom a chance\xe2\x80\x9d rather than risk tyranny.'b'LAURENCE H. Too often, job training for people with disabilities is far too rudimentary and does not take into account what a person with disabilities can bring to an organization.'b'Rather than providing general job training in the hopes that a vacant position will appear, the equation should be flipped and employers should tell training agencies what skills they are seeking, so that specialized training can qualify the person with a disability for the job.'b'That is what our foundation has tried to do, in partnership with other Jewish service organizations in Boston, in a program called Transitions to Work. The early results are showing success.'b'JAY RUDERMAN'b'\nRehovot, Israel, Dec. 26, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is the president of the Ruderman Family Foundation.'b''b'IF there are any two words in Persian that President Obama should learn, they are \xe2\x80\x9cmaslahat\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9caberu.\xe2\x80\x9d Maslahat is often translated as expediency, or self-interest. Aberu means face \xe2\x80\x94 as in, saving face. In the nearly 34 years since the Islamic revolution in Iran, expediency has been a pillar of decision making, but within a framework that has allowed Iranian leaders to save face. If there is to be any resolution of the nuclear standoff, Western leaders must grasp these concepts. \xc2\xa0'b'Two examples illustrate this point. In 1988, after eight years of devastating war with Saddam Hussein\xe2\x80\x99s Iraq, Iran\xe2\x80\x99s first supreme leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, accepted a United Nations-brokered cease-fire agreement, deeming it to be in Iran\xe2\x80\x99s maslahat. It was crucial that Iraqi forces had been pushed off Iranian soil, so Tehran could claim a victory.'b'Thirteen years later, after the 9/11 attacks, the United States overthrew the Taliban regime in Afghanistan, which had sheltered Al Qaeda, in a matter of weeks. American troops would never have made it to Kabul and Mazar-i-Sharif with such speed had Iran\xe2\x80\x99s leaders not acquiesced to the toppling of their enemies to the east. But the George W. Bush administration squandered an opportunity for dialogue by spurning this potential diplomatic overture by Iran.'b'For thousands of years, Persian culture has been distinguished by customs that revolve around honor and esteem. Preserving one\xe2\x80\x99s aberu is tantamount to maintaining one\xe2\x80\x99s dignity. There are almost no instances in modern Iranian history when maslahat has trumped aberu. The West has poorly understood these concepts. This was particularly true under President Bush, who rewarded Iran\xe2\x80\x99s tacit acceptance of the American invasion of Afghanistan by labeling Iran a member of an \xe2\x80\x9caxis of evil.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Following the 2003 allied invasion of Iraq, the Swiss ambassador to Iran 'b'reached out'b' to Washington with an unofficial outline for a \xe2\x80\x9cgrand bargain\xe2\x80\x9d with Tehran that would cover everything from Iran\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear program to its support for militant groups in the region. Despite this bold step, Iran was left out in the cold. Vice President Dick Cheney 'b'is said to have dismissed the initiative'b', reportedly asserting that \xe2\x80\x9cwe don\xe2\x80\x99t talk to evil.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We now know, thanks to a recent memoir by the former Iranian nuclear negotiator Hassan Rowhani, that the Bush administration reached out to Tehran a year after dismissing the proposal. Not surprisingly, partly because of the blow to its pride, the Iranian government rejected the offer of direct, high-level talks as insincere. In the nine years since, Iran\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear program \xe2\x80\x94 a major symbol of prestige for Iranians \xe2\x80\x94 has grown immensely. Things have gotten a lot more complicated.'b'The pattern of missed opportunities has persisted for more than three decades now. The result is that Barack Obama is the sixth consecutive president who has been led to view Iran as a threat rather than an opportunity. It is time for America to exit this vicious cycle and disregard irrational voices intent on sabotaging efforts to reach an understanding.'b'When Mr. Obama took office in 2009, he promised a real dialogue with Iran. Many in Tehran are still waiting for him to deliver on that promise. But how?'b'The foundation of post-1979 decision making in Iran is the pursuit of sovereignty within a framework that balances maslahat and aberu. We believe Iran would be open to new measures regarding the transparency of its nuclear program, and would agree not to pursue any capability to enrich uranium beyond that needed to fuel atomic power plants, if its legitimate right to enrichment under the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty was recognized and if an agreement to remove sanctions was reached.'b'Equally important is how a deal would be implemented. Decades of mutual, institutionalized hostility have created a gulf of mistrust that neither side can unilaterally bridge. So getting the sequence right would be crucial to any accord.'b'While Tehran views a deal on its nuclear program as being in its self-interest, Western leaders need to grasp that it would be devastating for Iran\xe2\x80\x99s aberu to take the first step solely in exchange for promises. The dominant discourse in Tehran portrays the 2004 decision by the former Iranian president Mohammad Khatami to suspend uranium enrichment on a voluntary, temporary basis as a failure because it resulted only in humiliating calls by the West for an indefinite suspension. The moral of this narrative is that placing maslahat above aberu, even temporarily, leads to nothing good.'b'In the coming months, Iran is expected to again engage with the so-called P5+1 (the United States, Russia, China, Britain and France, along with Germany). Mr. Obama and his team, including his chief Iran negotiator, Under Secretary of State Wendy Sherman, should reflect on the meaning of maslahat and aberu. Understanding the Iranian mentality is key to grasping why the Iranians won\xe2\x80\x99t put expediency above dignity. The only way to stop the dispute over Iran\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear program from spinning out of control is to offer the Islamic Republic a face-saving way out.'b'The centrist fantasy of a Grand Bargain on the budget never had a chance. Even if some kind of bargain had supposedly been reached, key players would soon have reneged on the deal \xe2\x80\x94 probably the next time a Republican occupied the White House.'b'For the reality is that our two major political parties are engaged in a fierce struggle over the future shape of American society. Democrats want to preserve the legacy of the New Deal and the Great Society \xe2\x80\x94 Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid \xe2\x80\x94 and add to them what every other advanced country has: a more or less universal guarantee of essential health care. Republicans want to roll all of that back, making room for drastically lower taxes on the wealthy. Yes, it\xe2\x80\x99s essentially a class war.'b'The fight over the fiscal cliff was just one battle in that war. It ended, arguably, in a tactical victory for Democrats. The question is whether it was a Pyrrhic victory that set the stage for a larger defeat.'b'Why do I say that it was a tactical victory? Mainly because of what didn\xe2\x80\x99t happen: There were no benefit cuts.'b'This was by no means a foregone conclusion. In 2011, the Obama administration was reportedly willing to raise the age of Medicare eligibility, a terrible and cruel policy idea. This time around, it was willing to cut Social Security benefits by changing the formula for cost-of-living adjustments, a less terrible idea that would nonetheless have imposed a lot of hardship \xe2\x80\x94 and probably have been politically disastrous as well. In the end, however, it didn\xe2\x80\x99t happen. And progressives, always worried that President Obama seems much too willing to compromise about fundamentals, breathed a sigh of relief.'b'There were also some actual positives from a progressive point of view. Expanded unemployment benefits were given another year to run, a huge benefit to many families and a significant boost to our economic prospects (because this is money that will be spent, and hence help preserve jobs). Other benefits to lower-income families were given another five years \xe2\x80\x94 although, unfortunately, the payroll tax break was allowed to expire, which will hurt both working families and job creation.'b'The biggest progressive gripe about the legislation is that Mr. Obama extracted less revenue from the affluent than expected \xe2\x80\x94 about $600 billion versus $800 billion over the next decade. In perspective, however, this isn\xe2\x80\x99t that big a deal. Put it this way: A reasonable estimate is that gross domestic product over the next 10 years will be around $200 trillion. So if the revenue take had matched expectations, it would still have amounted to only 0.4 percent of G.D.P.; as it turned out, this was reduced to 0.3 percent. Either way, it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t make much difference in the fights over revenue versus spending still to come.'b'Oh, and not only did Republicans vote for a tax increase for the first time in decades, the overall result of the tax changes now taking effect \xe2\x80\x94 which include new taxes associated with Obamacare as well as the new legislation \xe2\x80\x94 will be a significant reduction in income inequality, with the top 1 percent and even more so the top 0.1 percent taking a much bigger hit than middle-income families.'b'So why are many progressives \xe2\x80\x94 myself included \xe2\x80\x94 feeling very apprehensive? Because we\xe2\x80\x99re worried about the confrontations to come.'b'According to the normal rules of politics, Republicans should have very little bargaining power at this point. With Democrats holding the White House and the Senate, the G.O.P. can\xe2\x80\x99t pass legislation; and since the biggest progressive policy priority of recent years, health reform, is already law, Republicans wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to have many bargaining chips.'b'But the G.O.P. retains the power to destroy, in particular by refusing to raise the debt limit \xe2\x80\x94 which could cause a financial crisis. And Republicans have made it clear that they plan to use their destructive power to extract major policy concessions.'b'Now, the president has said that he won\xe2\x80\x99t negotiate on that basis, and rightly so. Threatening to hurt tens of millions of innocent victims unless you get your way \xe2\x80\x94 which is what the G.O.P. strategy boils down to \xe2\x80\x94 shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be treated as a legitimate political tactic.'b'But will Mr. Obama stick to his anti-blackmail position as the moment of truth approaches? He blinked during the 2011 debt limit confrontation. And the last few days of the fiscal cliff negotiations were also marked by a clear unwillingness on his part to let the deadline expire. Since the consequences of a missed deadline on the debt limit would potentially be much worse, this bodes ill for administration resolve in the clinch.'b'So, as I said, in a tactical sense the fiscal cliff ended in a modest victory for the White House. But that victory could all too easily turn into defeat in just a few weeks.'b'Recently I was reading a magazine profile of a brilliant statistician. The article mentioned, in passing, that this guy doesn\xe2\x80\x99t suffer fools gladly.'b'I come across that phrase a lot. I\xe2\x80\x99ve read that Al Gore and former Representative Barney Frank don\xe2\x80\x99t suffer fools gladly. Neither, apparently, did Steve Jobs, George Harrison, Pauline Kael or even Henry David Thoreau.'b'The phrase originally came from William Tyndale\xe2\x80\x99s 1534 translation of the Bible. In it, Paul was ripping into the decadent citizens of Corinth for turning away from his own authoritative teaching and falling for a bunch of second-rate false apostles. \xe2\x80\x9cFor ye suffers fool gladly,\xe2\x80\x9d Paul says with withering sarcasm, \xe2\x80\x9cseeing ye yourselves are wise.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Today, the phrase is often used as an ambiguous compliment. It suggests that a person is so smart he has trouble tolerating people who are far below his own high standards. It is used to describe a person who is so passionately committed to a vital cause that he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have time for social niceties toward those idiots who stand in its way. It is used to suggest a level of social courage; a person who has the guts to tell idiots what he really thinks.'b'Sure, it would be better if such people were nicer to those around them, the phrase implies, but this is a forgivable sin in one so talented. The actor Ed Harris\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cpenetrating gaze signals that this is a serious, somber man on a singular quest,\xe2\x80\x9d a writer observed in The Toronto Sun. \xe2\x80\x9cHe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t suffer fools gladly, if at all.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This sounds fine in the abstract, but when you actually witness somebody in the act of not suffering fools gladly, it looks rotten. Once I watched a senior member of the House of Representatives rip into a young reporter after she nervously asked him an ill-informed question.'b'She was foolish about that particular piece of legislation, but, in the moment, he looked the bigger fool. He was making a snap judgment about a person with no real information about her actual qualities. He was exposing a yawning gap between his own high opinion of himself and his actual conduct in the world. He was making the mistake, which metaphysical fools tend to make, that there is no connection between your inner moral quality and the level of courtesy you present to others.'b'Smart people who\xe2\x80\x99ve thought about this usually understand that the habits we put in practice end up shaping the people we are within. \xe2\x80\x9cManners are of more importance than laws,\xe2\x80\x9d Edmund Burke wrote. \xe2\x80\x9cManners are what vex or soothe, corrupt or purify, exalt or debase, barbarize or refine us, by a constant, steady, uniform, insensible operation, like that of the air we breathe in.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In his extremely French book, \xe2\x80\x9cA Small Treatise on the Great Virtues,\xe2\x80\x9d the contemporary philosopher Andr\xc3\xa9 Comte-Sponville argues that \xe2\x80\x9cpoliteness is the first virtue, and the origin perhaps of all the others.\xe2\x80\x9d Politeness is a discipline that compels respectful behavior. Morality, he writes \xe2\x80\x9cis like a politeness of the soul, an etiquette of the inner life, a code of duties, a ceremonial of the essential.\xe2\x80\x9d (I told you it was very French.)'b'Jane Austen is the novelist most famous for advocating this point of view. In her novel \xe2\x80\x9cEmma,\xe2\x80\x9d the lead character is rude to a foolish and verbose old woman named Miss Bates. Emma\xe2\x80\x99s friend George Knightley rebukes her.'b'If Miss Bates were rich or smart or your equal, maybe this rudeness would have been tolerable, Mr. Knightley tells her, but \xe2\x80\x9cshe is poor; she has sunk from the comforts she was born to; and, if she live to old age, must probably sink more. Her situation should secure your compassion. It was badly done, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I don\xe2\x80\x99t give myself high marks on suffering fools. I\xe2\x80\x99m not rude to those I consider foolish, but I strenuously and lamentably evade them. But I do see people who handle fools well. Many members of the clergy do, as do many great teachers. In my experience, Midwesterners are more likely to treat fools well. Natural politicians do so, too. Joe Biden is effective because he loves humanity in all its shapes and sizes.'b'G. K. Chesterton had the best advice on suffering fools gladly. He put emphasis on the gladly. When you\xe2\x80\x99re with fools, laugh with them and at them simultaneously: \xe2\x80\x9cAn obvious instance is that of ordinary and happy marriage. A man and a woman cannot live together without having against each other a kind of everlasting joke. Each has discovered that the other is a fool, but a great fool. This largeness, this grossness and gorgeousness of folly is the thing which we all find about those with whom we are in intimate contact; and it is the one enduring basis of affection, and even of respect.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'For years, President Obama has been stretching executive power to claim that the authorization to use military force against Al Qaeda gives him the unilateral authority to order people killed away from any battlefield without judicial oversight or public accountability \xe2\x80\x94 even when the target is an American citizen.'b'On Wednesday, a federal judge in Manhattan 'b'came down on the side of preserving secrecy'b' regarding how this dangerous view of executive power gets exercised. We strongly disagree with Judge McMahon\xe2\x80\x99s conclusion that she was compelled by a \xe2\x80\x9cthicket of laws and precedents\xe2\x80\x9d to deny access to the legal memo \xe2\x80\x94 prepared by the Department of Justice\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'Office of Legal Counsel'b' \xe2\x80\x94 and other documents that provided the legal and factual basis for the killings.'b'For starters, various government officials have spoken publicly about the American role in killing Mr. Awlaki and the circumstances under which the government considers targeted killings, including of American citizens. But the idea that progress toward racial harmony would or should be steady and continuous is fraying. And the pillars of the institution \xe2\x80\x94 the fundamental devaluation of dark skin and strained justifications for the unconscionable \xe2\x80\x94 have proved surprisingly resilient.'b'For instance, in October, The Arkansas Times 'b'reported'b' that Jon Hubbard, a Republican state representative, wrote in a 2009 self-published book that \xe2\x80\x9cthe institution of slavery that the black race has long believed to be an abomination upon its people may actually have been a blessing in disguise.\xe2\x80\x9d His misguided point was that for all the horrors of slavery, blacks were better off in America than in Africa.'b'This was a prevailing, wrongheaded, ethically empty justification for American slavery when it was legal.'b'Robert E. Lee wrote in 1856: \xe2\x80\x9cThe blacks are immeasurably better off here than in Africa, morally, physically, and socially. The painful discipline they are undergoing is necessary for their further instruction as a race, and will prepare them, I hope, for better things.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And in a famous 1837 speech on the Senate floor, John C. Calhoun declared: \xe2\x80\x9cI hold that in the present state of civilization, where two races of different origin, and distinguished by color, and other physical differences, as well as intellectual, are brought together, the relation now existing in the slaveholding States between the two, is, instead of an evil, a good \xe2\x80\x94 a positive good.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Lee was later appointed commander in chief of the armies of the South, and Calhoun had been vice president and became secretary of state. But in November, Hubbard lost his seat; I guess that\xe2\x80\x99s progress.'b'Still, the persistence of such a ridiculous argument does not sit well with me. And we should all be unsettled by the tendency of some people to romanticize and empathize with the Confederacy.'b'A 'b'Pew Research Center poll'b' released in April 2011 found that most Southern whites think it\xe2\x80\x99s appropriate for modern-day politicians to praise Confederate leaders, the only demographic to believe that.'b'A 'b'CNN poll'b' also released that month found that nearly 4 in 10 white Southerners sympathize more with the Confederacy than with the Union.'b'What is perhaps more problematic is that negative attitudes about blacks are increasing. According to an October 'b'survey by The Associated Press'b': \xe2\x80\x9cIn all, 51 percent of Americans now express explicit anti-black attitudes, compared with 48 percent in a similar 2008 survey. When measured by an implicit racial attitudes test, the number of Americans with anti-black sentiments jumped to 56 percent, up from 49 percent during the last presidential election.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Not progress.'b'In fact, it feels as though slavery as an analogy has become subversively chic. Herman Cain, running as a Republican presidential candidate, built an entire campaign around this not-so-coded language, 'b'saying'b' that he had left \xe2\x80\x9cthe Democrat plantation,\xe2\x80\x9d calling blacks \xe2\x80\x9c'b'brainwashed'b'\xe2\x80\x9d and arguing, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe racism in this country today holds anybody back in a big way.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As the best-selling author Michelle Alexander pointed out in her sensational 2010 book \xe2\x80\x9cThe New Jim Crow,\xe2\x80\x9d various factors, including the methodical mass incarceration of black men, has led to the disintegration of the black family, the disenfranchisement of millions of people, and a new and very real era of American oppression.'b'As Alexander confirmed to me Friday: \xe2\x80\x9cToday there are more African-American adults under correctional control \xe2\x80\x94 in prison or jail, on probation or parole \xe2\x80\x94 than were enslaved in 1850, a decade before the Civil War began.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Definitely not progress.'b'2012: I call it the year in \xe2\x80\x9cmeh.\xe2\x80\x9d Not the worst we\xe2\x80\x99ve ever experienced, but nothing particularly great to say about it either. Like being a socialite, but in Tampa.'b'I am looking forward to 2013, however, because I love the odd-numbered years \xe2\x80\x94 they\xe2\x80\x99re the ones without congressional elections, Olympics, World Cups or weird extra days tacked onto the calendar by so-called scientists. Odd-numbered years are chill. They\xe2\x80\x99re the 3 p.m. of years \xe2\x80\x94 that small sliver of time when lunch is digested and it\xe2\x80\x99s too early to think about dinner and you stand at least a fighting chance of getting something done.'b'In that spirit, here are the New Rules for the new year:'b''b'NEW RULE'b' Now that their end-of-the-world prophecy has proved to be complete baloney, the Mayans must be given a job predicting election results for Fox News.'b''b'NEW RULE'b' Sometime during the 2013 awards show season, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Gangnam Style'b'\xe2\x80\x9d must be given an award for the shortest amount of time between my finding out what something is to my being completely sick of it. Besting the time of 7 hours, 12 minutes, set by \xe2\x80\x9cThe Macarena\xe2\x80\x9d in 1996.'b''b'NEW RULE'b' Congress must make it a tradition to drive off the fiscal cliff every year. And I mean really off the cliff, like Toonces the cat drove that car. This way Republicans can learn that lower military spending won\xe2\x80\x99t lead to China invading. And Democrats can learn that no one cares what the Commerce Department does anyway.'b''b'NEW RULE'b' No more mixing politics with pizza. The filthy rich founder of Papa John\xe2\x80\x99s, John Schnatter, said he\xe2\x80\x99d cut his employees\xe2\x80\x99 hours to avoid the costs of Obamacare. This is where I\xe2\x80\x99d normally suggest boycotting Papa John\xe2\x80\x99s, but that\xe2\x80\x99s like telling people to boycott sadness. Nobody eats Papa John\xe2\x80\x99s because they like it. They eat it because Domino\xe2\x80\x99s won\xe2\x80\x99t deliver to crack houses.'b''b'NEW RULE'b' The winners of next month\xe2\x80\x99s Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show must later compete against the winners of \xe2\x80\x9cToddlers &amp; Tiaras\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 so we can get their handlers in one place, lock the doors and let the kids and dogs run for their lives.'b''b'NEW RULE'b' The New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Eve ball drop must be moved to one of the two states that recently legalized pot, so we can hear the crowd sing in unison, \xe2\x80\x9cShould old acquaintance be... what are the words again?\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'NEW RULE'b' Second-term Obama must have a few laughs by acting out the Tea Party\xe2\x80\x99s worst fears. He must order Air Force One to fly everywhere upside-down like Denzel and replace Bo the White House dog with two pit bulls named \xe2\x80\x9cMalcolm\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cX.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'NEW RULE'b' Drugstores, supermarkets, department stores and all other retail establishments must stop asking me to join their \xe2\x80\x9cclub.\xe2\x80\x9d A club is a place to have a few drinks. What you\xe2\x80\x99re offering me is two dollars off a bottle of NyQuil. And that\xe2\x80\x99s nothing like being in a club. Unless I drink the whole bottle at once.'b''b'NEW RULE'b' You can\xe2\x80\x99t run for president if you don\xe2\x80\x99t know how old the world is. Please \xe2\x80\x94 I\xe2\x80\x99m trying to watch a video of a nipple slip from last night\xe2\x80\x99s episode of \xe2\x80\x9cReal Housewives of Atlanta.\xe2\x80\x9d Let\xe2\x80\x99s not cheapen it.'b'W'b'HAT'b''b' do you get when you cross a fragrance with an actor?'b''b''b'Answer: a smell Gibson.'b''b'Groan away, but you should know that this joke was written by a computer. \xe2\x80\x9cSmell Gibson\xe2\x80\x9d is the C.P.U. child of something called 'b'Standup'b' (for System to Augment Non-Speakers\xe2\x80\x99 Dialogue Using Puns), a program that generates punning riddles to help kids with language disabilities increase their verbal skills.'b'Though it\xe2\x80\x99s not quite Louis C. K., the Standup program, engineered by a team of computer scientists in Scotland, is one of the more successful efforts to emerge from a branch of artificial intelligence known as computational humor, which seeks to model comedy using machines.'b'As verbal interaction between humans and computers becomes more prominent in daily life \xe2\x80\x94 from Siri, Apple\xe2\x80\x99s voice-activated assistant technology, to speech-based search engines to fully automated call centers \xe2\x80\x94 demand has grown for \xe2\x80\x9csocial computers\xe2\x80\x9d that can communicate with humans in a natural way. Teaching computers to grapple with humor is a key part of this equation.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHumor is everywhere in human life,\xe2\x80\x9d says the Purdue computer scientist 'b'Julia M. Taylor'b', who helped organize the first-ever United States symposium on the artificial intelligence of humor, in November. If we want a computational system to communicate with human life, it needs to know how to be funny, she says.'b'As it turns out, this is one of the most challenging tasks in computer science. Like much of language, humor is loaded with abstraction and ambiguity. To understand it, computers need to contend with linguistic sleights like irony, sarcasm, metaphor, idiom and allegory \xe2\x80\x94 things that don\xe2\x80\x99t readily translate into ones and zeros.'b'On top of that, says 'b'Lawrence J. Mazlack'b' of the University of Cincinnati, a seminal figure in the field of computational linguistics, humor is context-dependent: what\xe2\x80\x99s funny in one situation may not be funny in another. As an example, he cites Henny Youngman\xe2\x80\x99s signature line, \xe2\x80\x9cTake my wife \xe2\x80\x94 please,\xe2\x80\x9d which came about by 'b'accident'b' when an usher seating Youngman\xe2\x80\x99s wife mistook the comedian\xe2\x80\x99s request for a gag.'b'The cognitive processes that cause people to snicker at this sort of one-liner are only partly understood, which makes it all the more difficult for computers to mimic them. Unlike, say, chess, which is grounded in a fixed set of rules, there are no hard-and-fast formulas for comedy.'b'To get around that cognitive complexity, computational humor researchers have by and large taken a more concrete approach: focusing on simple linguistic relationships, like double meanings, rather than on trying to model the high-level mental mechanics that underlie humor.'b'Standup, for instance, 'b'writes jokes'b' by searching through a \xe2\x80\x9clexical database\xe2\x80\x9d (basically, a huge dictionary) for words that fit linguistic patterns found in puns \xe2\x80\x94 phonetic and semantic similarities, mostly \xe2\x80\x94 and comes up with doozies like: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you call a fish tank that has a horn? A goldfish bull.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Another tack has been to apply machine-learning algorithms, which crunch mountains of data to identify statistical features that can be used to classify text as funny or unfunny. This is more or less how spam filters work: they decide which messages to tag by analyzing billions of e-mails and compiling a database of red flags (like any urgent message from a deposed Nigerian prince).'b'Figuring out when a joke is a joke is where artificial intelligence researchers have made, perhaps, the most progress. For her Ph.D. dissertation, Dr. Taylor 'b'built a system'b' that could identify children\xe2\x80\x99s jokes out of various selections of prose with remarkable accuracy. Not only that, but it could also explain why it found something funny, which suggests that on some level it \xe2\x80\x9cgot\xe2\x80\x9d the jokes.'b'In a related 'b'experiment'b', the computer scientists Rada Mihalcea at the University of North Texas, Denton, and Carlo Strapparava, now at Fondazione Bruno Kessler in Italy, trained computers to separate humorous one-liners from nonhumorous sentences borrowed from Reuters headlines, proverbs and other texts. By 'b'analyzing'b' the content and style of these sentences, the program was able to spot the jokes with an average accuracy of 87 percent.'b'Putting such research to good use, a pair of wags at the University of Washington last year taught a computer when to use the refrain \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what she said\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 theirs being one of the few academic papers to cite \xe2\x80\x9cThe Office\xe2\x80\x9d among its references.'b'Some will surely wonder if the point of such research goes beyond devising software that can make the C++ set crack up at hackathons. Thankfully, it does. The goal of computational humor, and of computational linguistics as a whole, is to design machines akin to the shipboard computer on \xe2\x80\x9cStar Trek\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 ones that can answer open-ended questions and carry on casual conversations with human beings, even William Shatner.'b'In the process, scientists hope to gain insights into the nature of humor: Why do we laugh at certain things and not at others? Why does anyone watch \xe2\x80\x9cTwo and a Half Men\xe2\x80\x9d?'b'If computer humorists can answer any of these questions, we won\xe2\x80\x99t just get a deeper understanding of how language works but also, ultimately, what it means to be human.'b'Google scored a big victory 'b'last week'b' when the Federal Trade Commission concluded that the company was not manipulating search results in ways that harmed consumers. But the 'b'agency\xe2\x80\x99s finding'b' does not completely settle the question of whether the company, which is used for more than 70 percent of all Internet searches in the United States, has abused its dominance. The European Commission and attorneys general in Texas, New York and other states who are also investigating Google could come to very different conclusions about that question.'b'While reaching a settlement with Google on a handful of relatively modest issues, the F.T.C. has left unresolved the legitimate fears that Internet companies like Expedia and Yelp have about how Google uses its power to push into online businesses like travel bookings and restaurant reviews while pushing aside rivals.'b'Even if that does not immediately leave users worse off, Google\xe2\x80\x99s critics rightly argue that it could eventually result in fewer choices for consumers if worthy Internet services fail because Google actively makes it difficult for people to find them. Competitors of Google, including Microsoft, have argued that Google often displays search results to highlight its own products, like Google Maps, Google Flights and Google Shopping. They say that by doing so it is acting as Microsoft did in the 1990s when it forced PC makers to pre-install its Internet Explorer software with the Windows operating system at the expense of rivals like Netscape.'b'But the F.T.C. did not buy that argument and concluded that Google had not harmed competition in the marketplace, even if it may have hurt individual rivals.'b'Although Google dominates Internet search today, Web users have many options. And the company\xe2\x80\x99s continued dominance is far from assured when it comes to the fast-growing world of smartphones and tablets, where many users download apps without relying on Google. But the company clearly stepped over the line with the practices it has agreed to change.'b'Google will now be required to make it easier for competitors to license certain patents that it had previously agreed to provide. It will also change policies that make it hard for businesses to manage their advertising campaigns on Google and other search engines, and it will give Web sites the ability to opt out of having their content used to bolster its specialized services like Google Local.'b'Fifteen years ago, few people predicted that Microsoft\xe2\x80\x99s commanding position would be undercut so drastically by the rise of Google, Apple and others. History, however, is not necessarily prologue to the future. Antitrust regulators must remain watchful that Google does not abuse its dominant position in ways that unfairly limit consumer choices and competition.'b'Capt. Mark Kelly is a former Navy pilot and NASA astronaut and is the husband of the former congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords, who survived an assassination attempt in 2011. The couple has formed a political action committee, 'b'Gabby PAC'b', to promote civil political discourse and the election of moderates to Congress. Captain Kelly is also the author of 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMousetronaut,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' a recently published children\xe2\x80\x99s book loosely based on a mouse that accompanied him on one of his space shuttle missions.'b''b'READING'b' I used to read a lot of science fiction \xe2\x80\x94 Robert Heinlein and Isaac Asimov \xe2\x80\x94 but then I started doing science reality. Now I read more nonfiction, particularly if it has a military aspect to it. I\xe2\x80\x99m about halfway through 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cUnbroken,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' by Laura Hillenbrand. The strength, toughness and tenacity of the main character reminds me of my wife, Gabby. Also I flew ground attack in Operation Desert Storm, which is what the character in \xe2\x80\x9cUnbroken\xe2\x80\x9d was doing in World War II, so I could relate to the story a little bit. I got shot at a lot, but I never got shot down like he did.'b''b'LISTENING'b' That doesn\xe2\x80\x99t change much for me: 'b'U2'b' and 'b'Aerosmith'b'. Also Coldplay. We picked their song 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSpeed of Sound\xe2\x80\x9d'b' to go along with a slide show we put together for my second space shuttle flight. It went really well with the pictures. Also, Chris Martin, the lead singer of Coldplay, is married to Gabby\xe2\x80\x99s second cousin, Gwyneth Paltrow. 'b'Calexico'b' is one of Gabby\xe2\x80\x99s favorite bands. They\xe2\x80\x99re from Tucson and are a rock band but their music has a heavy Mexican influence, with mariachis. It\xe2\x80\x99s pretty neat with the horns.'b''b'WATCHING'b' Gabby and I saw the latest James Bond movie, 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSkyfall.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b' It was good, but my personal favorite 007 movie is \xe2\x80\x9cCasino Royale,\xe2\x80\x9d because of the poker scene. I used to have a poker game at home a couple of times a month. I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t good, but more important than that, the people I was playing with \xe2\x80\x94 other astronauts and a few neighbors \xe2\x80\x94 were really bad.'b''b'PURCHASING'b' I bought my wife a new engagement ring for our fifth anniversary \xe2\x80\x94 a diamond with a couple of sapphires. I never was happy with the first one. She was happy with it, but I thought she deserved better.'b''b'RACING'b' I recently went with a friend and drove a couple of racecars \xe2\x80\x94 a Porsche 911 and 944 \xe2\x80\x94 at 'b'Inde Motorsports Ranch'b', a private track in Willcox, Ariz. It was a lot of fun. Without spaceflight being available to me anymore, I have to find a replacement. It reminded me of flying high-speed, low-altitude routes in the military.'b''b'EATING'b' I\xe2\x80\x99ve started to eat more 'b'kale'b'. But delicious and kale are not synonymous. If you put it in scrambled eggs, it isn\xe2\x80\x99t so bad.'b'IN a recent conversation with a fellow journalist, I voiced my exasperation at the endless talk about faith in God as the only consolation for those devastated by the unfathomable murders in Newtown, Conn. Some of those grieving parents surely believe, as I do, that this is our one and only life. Atheists cannot find solace in the idea that dead children are now angels in heaven. \xe2\x80\x9cThat only shows the limits of atheism,\xe2\x80\x9d my colleague replied. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all about nonbelief and has nothing to offer when people are suffering.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This widespread misapprehension that atheists believe in nothing positive is one of the main reasons secularly inclined Americans \xe2\x80\x94 roughly 'b'20 percent of the population'b' \xe2\x80\x94 do not wield public influence commensurate with their numbers. One major problem is the dearth of secular community institutions. But the most powerful force holding us back is our own reluctance to speak, particularly at moments of high national drama and emotion, with the combination of reason and passion needed to erase the image of the atheist as a bloodless intellectual robot.'b'The secular community is fearful of seeming to proselytize. When giving talks on college campuses, I used to avoid personal discussions of my atheism. But over the years, I have changed my mind because such diffidence contributes to the false image of the atheist as someone whose convictions are removed from ordinary experience. It is vital to show that there are indeed atheists in foxholes, and wherever else human beings suffer and die.'b'Now when students ask how I came to believe what I believe, I tell them that I trace my atheism to my first encounter, at age 7, with the scourge of polio. In 1952, a 9-year-old friend was stricken by the disease and clinging to life in an iron lung. After visiting him in the hospital, I asked my mother, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy would God do that to a little boy?\xe2\x80\x9d She sighed in a way that telegraphed her lack of conviction and said: \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. The priest would say God must have his reasons, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what they could be.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Just two years later, in 1954, Jonas Salk\xe2\x80\x99s vaccine began the process of eradicating polio, and my mother took the opportunity to suggest that God may have guided his research. I remember replying, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, God should have guided the doctors a long time ago so that Al wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be in an iron lung.\xe2\x80\x9d (He was to die only eight years later, by which time I was a committed atheist.)'b'The first time I told this story to a class, I was deeply gratified when one student confided that his religious doubts arose from the struggles of a severely disabled sibling, and that he had never been able to discuss the subject candidly with his fundamentalist parents. One of the most positive things any atheist can do is provide a willing ear for a doubter \xe2\x80\x94 even if the doubter remains a religious believer.'b'IT is primarily in the face of suffering, whether the tragedy is individual or collective, that I am forcefully reminded of what atheism has to offer. When I try to help a loved one losing his mind to Alzheimer\xe2\x80\x99s, when I see homeless people shivering in the wake of a deadly storm, when the news media bring me almost obscenely close to the raw grief of bereft parents, I do not have to ask, as all people of faith must, why an all-powerful, all-good God allows such things to happen.'b'It is a positive blessing, not a negation of belief, to be free of what is known as the theodicy problem. Human \xe2\x80\x9cfree will\xe2\x80\x9d is Western monotheism\xe2\x80\x99s answer to the question of why God does not use his power to prevent the slaughter of innocents, and many people throughout history (some murdered as heretics) have not been able to let God off the hook in that fashion.'b'The atheist is free to concentrate on the fate of this world \xe2\x80\x94 whether that means visiting a friend in a hospital or advocating for tougher gun control laws \xe2\x80\x94 without trying to square things with an unseen overlord in the next. Atheists do not want to deny religious believers the comfort of their faith. We do want our fellow citizens to respect our deeply held conviction that the absence of an afterlife lends a greater, not a lesser, moral importance to our actions on earth.'b'Today\xe2\x80\x99s atheists would do well to emulate some of the great 19th-century American freethinkers, who insisted that reason and emotion were not opposed but complementary.'b'Robert Green Ingersoll, who died in 1899 and was one of the most famous orators of his generation, personified this combination of passion and rationality. Called \xe2\x80\x9cThe Great Agnostic,\xe2\x80\x9d Ingersoll insisted that there was no difference between atheism and agnosticism because it was impossible for anyone to \xe2\x80\x9cknow\xe2\x80\x9d whether God existed or not. He used his secular pulpit to advocate for social causes like justice for African-Americans, women\xe2\x80\x99s rights, prison reform and the elimination of cruelty to animals.'b'He also frequently delivered secular eulogies at funerals and offered consolation that he clearly considered an important part of his mission. In 1882, at the graveside of a friend\xe2\x80\x99s child, he declared: \xe2\x80\x9cThey who stand with breaking hearts around this little grave, need have no fear. The larger and the nobler faith in all that is, and is to be, tells us that death, even at its worst, is only perfect rest ... The dead do not suffer.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Today\xe2\x80\x99s secularists must do more than mount defensive campaigns proclaiming that we can be \xe2\x80\x9cgood without God.\xe2\x80\x9d Atheists must stand up instead of calling themselves freethinkers, agnostics, secular humanists or \xe2\x80\x9cspiritual, but not religious.\xe2\x80\x9d The last phrase, translated from the psychobabble, can mean just about anything \xe2\x80\x94 that the speaker is an atheist who fears social disapproval or a fence-sitter who wants the theoretical benefits of faith, including hope of eternal life, without the obligations of actually practicing a religion. Atheists may also be secular humanists and freethinkers \xe2\x80\x94 I answer to all three \xe2\x80\x94 but avoidance of identification with atheism confines us to a closet that encourages us to fade or be pushed into the background when tragedy strikes.'b'We must speak up as atheists in order to take responsibility for whatever it is humans are responsible for \xe2\x80\x94 including violence in our streets and schools. We need to demonstrate that atheism is rooted in empathy as well as intellect. And although atheism is not a religion, we need community-based outreach programs so that our activists will be as recognizable to their neighbors as the clergy.'b'Finally, we need to show up at gravesides, as Ingersoll did, to offer whatever consolation we can.'b'In his speech at an interfaith prayer vigil in Newtown on Dec. 16, President Obama observed that \xe2\x80\x9cthe world\xe2\x80\x99s religions \xe2\x80\x94 so many of them represented here today \xe2\x80\x94 start with a simple question: Why are we here? What gives our life meaning?\xe2\x80\x9d He could easily have amended that to \xe2\x80\x9cthe world\xe2\x80\x99s religions and secular philosophies.\xe2\x80\x9d He could have said something like, \xe2\x80\x9cWhether you are religious or nonreligious, may you find solace in the knowledge that the suffering is ours, but that those we love suffer no more.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0'b'Somewhere in that audience, and in the larger national audience, there were mourners who would have been comforted by the acknowledgment that their lives have meaning even if they do not regard death as the door to another life, but \xe2\x80\x9conly perfect rest.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'BEIJING'b'HERE is my prediction about China: The new paramount leader, 'b'Xi Jinping'b', will spearhead a resurgence of economic reform, and probably some political easing as well. Mao\xe2\x80\x99s body will be hauled out of Tiananmen Square on his watch, and Liu Xiaobo, the Nobel Peace Prize-winning writer, will be released from prison.'b'These won\xe2\x80\x99t happen immediately \xe2\x80\x94 Xi won\xe2\x80\x99t even be named president until March \xe2\x80\x94 and I may be wrong entirely. But my hunch on this return to China, my old home, is that change is coming.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s my case for Xi as a reformer.'b'First, it\xe2\x80\x99s in his genes. His father, Xi Zhongxun, was a pioneer of economic restructuring and publicly denounced the massacre of pro-democracy protesters in 1989. Xi\xe2\x80\x99s mother chooses to live in Shenzhen, the most capitalist enclave in the country.'b'Xi is also one of the first Chinese leaders to send a child to the United States as an undergraduate. His daughter is a junior at Harvard, reflecting her parents\xe2\x80\x99 emphasis on learning English and their admiration for American education.'b'It helps that the bar is low for Xi: he follows President Hu Jintao, who is widely regarded in China as a failure. Even government ministers complain that he squandered his 10 years as leader. Today there is pent-up demand for change.'b'President Hu, who always reads speeches from texts, is a robot who surrounds himself with robots. One such robot aide is Ling Jihua, whose 23-year-old son was driving a Ferrari one night last March with two half-naked women as passengers. The car crashed on a Beijing road, killing the young man and badly injuring the women, one of whom later died.'b'Ling feared a scandal and reportedly 'b'began a cover-up'b'. He went to the morgue, according to the account I got from one Chinese official, and looked at the body \xe2\x80\x94 and then coldly denied that it was his son. He continued to work in the following weeks as if nothing had happened. The cover-up failed, and the episode underscored all that was wrong with the old leadership: the flaunting of dubious wealth, the abuse of power and the lack of any heart.'b'Xi is trying to send a message that he is different. His first act upon becoming Communist Party general secretary in November was to replicate a famous \xe2\x80\x9csouthern tour\xe2\x80\x9d by 'b'Deng Xiaoping'b' in 1992 that revived economic reforms. Xi and his team have also startled officials by telling them to stop reading empty speeches at meetings.'b'Another good sign: I hear that Wang Yang, a reformist who has been the party chief in Guangdong Province and is perhaps the single most capable leader in China today, will be named a vice premier in March.'b'The new leaders would probably prefer to accelerate economic change while minimizing political relaxation, but that is increasingly difficult as China develops an educated, worldly and self-confident middle class. Over the years, most of China\xe2\x80\x99s neighbors \xe2\x80\x94 from Taiwan to Mongolia, South Korea to Thailand \xe2\x80\x94 have become more democratic, and now even Myanmar is joining the parade. How can mighty China be more backward than Myanmar?'b'For 25 years, I\xe2\x80\x99ve regularly been visiting my wife\xe2\x80\x99s ancestral village in the 'b'Taishan'b' area of southern China. At first, the villagers were semiliterate and isolated, but now their world has been transformed. On this visit, we dropped by a farmhouse where a former peasant was using the Internet to trade stocks on his laptop. An artist might work for a decade on the prototype for a work that must then be painstakingly cast, fabricated and assembled. The theory states that in any given culture, at any given time, only 2 percent of the art, music and literature being produced is truly great.'b'The theory has two important corollaries. The first is that every generation complains about the amount of junk being produced by comparing the present scene to some purported Golden Age. English professors lament the trashy novels cluttering up the best-seller lists by calling up Dickens, Thackeray, Eliot and Hardy, handily ignoring the hundreds upon hundreds of novels that have rightly been forgotten. I vote for the latter.'b'CONGRESS and President Obama have pushed through a relatively modest stopgap measure to avoid the \xe2\x80\x9cfiscal cliff,\xe2\x80\x9d but over the coming years, the United States will confront another huge cliff: Social Security.'b'In the 'b'first presidential debate'b', Mr. Obama described Social Security as \xe2\x80\x9cstructurally sound,\xe2\x80\x9d and Mitt Romney said that \xe2\x80\x9cneither the president nor I are proposing any changes\xe2\x80\x9d to the program. It was a rare issue on which both men agreed \xe2\x80\x94 and both were utterly wrong.'b'For the first time in more than a quarter-century, Social Security ran a deficit in 2010: It spent $49 billion dollars more in benefits than it received in revenues, and drew from its trust funds to cover the shortfall. Those funds \xe2\x80\x94 a $2.7 trillion buffer built in anticipation of retiring baby boomers \xe2\x80\x94 will be exhausted by 2033, the government currently projects.'b'Those facts are widely known. What\xe2\x80\x99s not is that the Social Security Administration underestimates how long Americans will live and how much the trust funds will need to pay out \xe2\x80\x94 to the tune of $800 billion by 2031, more than the current annual defense budget \xe2\x80\x94 and that the trust funds will run out, if nothing is done, two years earlier than the government has predicted.'b'We reached these conclusions, and presented them in an 'b'article'b' in the journal Demography, after finding that the government\xe2\x80\x99s methods for forecasting Americans\xe2\x80\x99 longevity were outdated and omitted crucial health and demographic factors. Historic declines in smoking and improvements in the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease are adding years of life that the government hasn\xe2\x80\x99t accounted for. (While obesity has rapidly increased, it is not likely, at this point, to offset these public health and medical successes.) More retirees will receive benefits for longer than predicted, supported by the payroll taxes of relatively fewer working adults than projected.'b'Remarkably, since Social Security was created in 1935, the government\xe2\x80\x99s forecasting methods have barely changed, even as a revolution in big data and statistics has transformed everything from baseball to retailing.'b'This omission can be explained by the fact that the 'b'Office of the Chief Actuary'b', the branch of the Social Security Administration that is responsible for the forecasts, is almost exclusively composed of, well, actuaries \xe2\x80\x94 without any serious representation of statisticians or social science methodologists. While these actuaries are highly responsible and careful and do excellent work curating and describing the data that go into the forecasts, their job is not to make statistical predictions. Yet the agency badly needs such expertise.'b'With considerable help from the actuaries and other officials at the Social Security Administration, we unearthed how the agency makes mortality forecasts and uses them to predict the program\xe2\x80\x99s solvency. We learned that the methods are antiquated, subjective and needlessly complicated \xe2\x80\x94 and, as a result, are prone to error and to potential interference from political appointees. This may explain why the agency\xe2\x80\x99s forecasts have, at times, changed significantly from year to year, even when there was little change in the underlying data.'b'We have made our methods, calculations and software available online at 'b'j.mp/SSecurity'b' so that others can replicate or improve our forecasts. The implications of our findings go beyond social science. As the wave of retirement by the baby boomers continues, doing nothing to shore up Social Security\xe2\x80\x99s solvency is irresponsible. If the amount of money coming in through payroll taxes does not increase and if the amount of money going out as benefits remains the same, the trust funds will become insolvent less than 20 years from now.'b'To save Social Security, which has lifted generations of elderly people out of poverty, tough choices have to be made. One option is to continue raising the retirement age, perhaps to as high as 69 or 70. While the full retirement age is gradually increasing to 67 (for people born in 1960 or later) from 65, this increase is not enough to counterbalance the gains in longevity.'b'A second option is to increase payroll taxes, for example by taxing wages over $113,700, the current earnings limit. A third is to limit the annual cost-of-living adjustments, possibly by changing how those adjustments are calculated. A fourth is to reduce benefits \xe2\x80\x94 for example, by lowering the initial benefits for workers whose lifetime wages are above the national average (currently $43,000 a year). But in the quarter-century since, there have been only modest changes in the program.'b'We know much more now about mortality and demography, and so an open debate today about Social Security\xe2\x80\x99s future could be even more productive than it was then. But few issues are more important to more Americans, of both parties, and the longer we ignore the problem, the more disruptive any change will need to be to keep Social Security alive.'b'HERE are a few things that happened to John Boehner, ostensibly one of the most powerful men in Washington, during the past two weeks.'b'First his own backbenchers blew up his attempt at a fiscal cliff negotiating maneuver. (It\xe2\x80\x99s far, far easier to be a successful legislator when you\xe2\x80\x99re negotiating over an expanding pie.) Second, there\xe2\x80\x99s the combination of gridlocked government and ideological polarization, which simultaneously requires compromise while reducing the common ground available to would-be deal makers.'b'Such obstacles might be enough to frustrate even the legislative giants of the past. Pundits talk blithely about the good old days of bipartisanship, but there\xe2\x80\x99s no real precedent in modern American history for a bipartisan bargain in which two bitterly divided sides both accept so many painful sacrifices.'b'The Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 current position makes things harder still, because Boehner\xe2\x80\x99s party has much more power in Washington than it has support in the nation as a whole. This mismatch leaves the base spoiling for fights that can\xe2\x80\x99t actually be won: House Republicans have just enough real power to raise conservative expectations but not nearly enough to bend a liberal president and a Democratic Senate to their will.'b'Boehner\xe2\x80\x99s job, then, requires constantly pushing hard enough to persuade his caucus that he\xe2\x80\x99s maximizing Republican leverage, while simultaneously looking for ways to make small, can-kicking deals at the last possible moment. (For a glimpse of the alternative, just imagine rerunning the last two years with Newt Gingrich in the speaker\xe2\x80\x99s chair.)'b'You might say that this is no way to run a government. I\xe2\x80\x99d agree. But the nation\xe2\x80\x99s polarization and his party\xe2\x80\x99s dysfunction are beyond a speaker\xe2\x80\x99s ability to undo.
