If Mr. Cuomo is looking for a place to start, it should be real gun control, a minimum-wage increase and campaign finance reform.'b'LOS ANGELES'b'THE fiscal cliff may have been avoided, but an even higher-stakes political standoff \xe2\x80\x94 this time, over the 'b'federal debt ceiling'b' \xe2\x80\x94 is just around the bend.'b'Congressional Republicans have said they will demand immense cuts to popular government programs in exchange for agreeing to raise the nation\xe2\x80\x99s authorized borrowing limit of 'b'$16.4 trillion'b'. The Treasury Department briefly nudged against that ceiling on Dec. 31, but used \xe2\x80\x9cextraordinary\xe2\x80\x9d financial measures to buy more time. If nothing is done, the government will soon be unable to pay all of its bills in a timely manner. This unprecedented event would profoundly damage the government\xe2\x80\x99s credit rating and send the financial system into a tailspin.'b'So far, President Obama isn\xe2\x80\x99t giving in. As he rightly said last week, he \xe2\x80\x9cwill not have another debate with this Congress over whether or not they should pay the bills that they\xe2\x80\x99ve already racked up through the laws that they passed.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But for the president\xe2\x80\x99s tough talk to be credible, Congress and the country need to know before we reach the breach point \xe2\x80\x94 an event that could come as early as February \xe2\x80\x94 that he has a plausible plan to work around the debt ceiling.'b'There are no great options. Most of the ideas floated so far would either severely disrupt the public markets for Treasury debt or rely on a constitutional claim of executive authority so far-reaching that we would very likely spend the next two years locked in an impeachment fight.'b'Some have suggested, for instance, that the president could ignore the debt ceiling and direct the Treasury to issue more bonds to cover its obligations. But the Constitution is clear, and Mr. Obama agrees, that Congress alone has 'b'the power to authorize new borrowing'b'.'b'Other supposed solutions \xe2\x80\x94 like the notion that the Treasury Department could create a 'b'$1 trillion dollar platinum coin'b' and deposit it in its own account at the Federal Reserve \xe2\x80\x94 are even more fantastical.'b'However, there is a plausible course of action, one that the president should publicly adopt in the coming weeks as his contingency plan should debt-ceiling negotiations falter. He should threaten to issue scrip \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cregistered warrants\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 to existing claims holders (other than those who own actual government debt) in lieu of money. Recipients of these I.O.U.\xe2\x80\x99s could include federal employees, defense contractors, Medicare service providers, Social Security recipients and others.'b'The 'b'scrip would not violate'b' the debt ceiling because it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t constitute a new borrowing of money backed by the credit of the United States. It would merely be a formal acknowledgment of a pre-existing monetary claim against the United States that the Treasury was not currently able to pay. The president could therefore establish a scrip program by executive order without piling a constitutional crisis on top of a fiscal one.'b'To avoid any confusion with actual Treasury debt, and to be consistent with the law governing claims against the United States more generally, the scrip would not pay interest in most cases. And unlike debt, it would have no fixed maturity date but rather would become redeemable in cash only when the secretary of the Treasury was able to certify that there\xe2\x80\x99s enough money available in the Treasury\xe2\x80\x99s general fund to cover it.'b'Finally, the scrip would be transferable, allowing financial institutions to buy it at a high percentage of its face value, knowing that the political crisis would almost certainly be resolved before long.'b'The federal 'b'Anti-Assignment Act'b' generally prohibits the transfer of claims against the United States from one private actor to another, but the government could waive the act\xe2\x80\x99s application, which is what the president would do here.'b'The strategy may sound far-fetched, but it has been used before: in fact, California relied on it as recently as 2009.'b'Beginning in July of that year, California addressed its budget crisis by 'b'issuing 450,000 registered warrants'b', totaling $2.6 billion, to individual and business claimants, including recipients of aid programs, recipients of tax refunds and government contractors. Those holders who needed immediate cash were usually able to sell their registered warrants to banks at face value, though some institutions limited such purchases.'b'Whether as a result of public shaming, pressure from banks or a newfound sense of responsibility, the Legislature quickly worked out a budget deal and the scrip was then redeemed for cash.'b'Throughout the ordeal, California continued to pay its public debt service in cash and on schedule and never lost an investment-grade credit rating.'b'A federal scrip program, importantly, would not explicitly challenge any constitutional allocation of powers. Nor would there be confusion in the marketplace between valid Treasury bonds and this new paper, which would have a different name, financial terms and legal status. And because the scrip would be transferable, claimants forced to accept it would be able to turn it into immediate cash in private markets, for as long as the Treasury was unable to issue new debt.'b'Would a federal scrip program be a painless way of resolving a debt ceiling crisis? Hardly. But it would be the least awful way to defang the most extortionate demands of Congressional hard-liners \xe2\x80\x94 and one that would not permanently damage America\xe2\x80\x99s fiscal standing in the world.'b'RETURNING home from a visit to Russia in 1774, the 'b'philosophe'b' Denis Diderot wrote that in France, he could not \xe2\x80\x9chelp but think that I\xe2\x80\x99ve the soul of a slave in a country where men\xc2\xa0are called free,\xe2\x80\x9d whereas in Russia he \xe2\x80\x9chad the soul of a free man in a country where men are called slaves.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Has G\xc3\xa9rard Depardieu had similar thoughts of late?'b'On Sunday, President Vladimir V. Putin 'b'welcomed'b' the French actor to Russia with a newly issued Russian passport. Mr. Depardieu, outraged by the French Socialist government\xe2\x80\x99s proposed 75 percent wealth tax, had walked out on his country. A fan of Russia\xe2\x80\x99s low taxes, he also praised its \xe2\x80\x9cgreat democracy\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cI love your country, Russia \xe2\x80\x94 its people, its history, its writers. I love your culture, your intelligence.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Putin\xe2\x80\x99s increasing authoritarianism went unmentioned.'b'In the centuries since French celebrities began washing up on its shores, Russia has used them to affirm itself as a center of European culture, as well as to poke its finger in the eye of Western nations. Russia has always needed its Depardieus, just as much as they needed Russia.'b'Diderot\xe2\x80\x99s reasons for visiting were not terribly different from Mr. Depardieu\xe2\x80\x99s. Catherine the Great had repeatedly expressed her desire to meet the celebrated 'b'philosophe'b'. In an age of enlightened despotism, when kings made a show of seeking the guidance of philosophers on how best to rule, such an invitation was hard to ignore. This was certainly the case for Diderot, editor of the Encyclop\xc3\xa9die, whose entry on government affirmed that the laws of nature and reason must guide rulers in bettering the lot of the people, for whom the greatest good is liberty. (That famous line attributed to Diderot \xe2\x80\x94 about the last king being strangled by the entrails of the last priest \xe2\x80\x94 did not make the great work.)'b'The more pressing motivation, however, was financial: Diderot was broke. Catherine thus took the extraordinary step of buying Diderot\xe2\x80\x99s personal library, leaving it in his possession until his death and paying him a salary as librarian. In return, in 1773, Diderot went to St. Petersburg, where he enjoyed long t\xc3\xaate-\xc3\xa0-t\xc3\xaates with Catherine, whom he described as embodying the charms of Cleopatra and the soul of Caesar.'b'Catherine was thrilled to boast of Diderot\xe2\x80\x99s friendship, and their conversations left some lasting marks \xe2\x80\x94 the bruises on Catherine\xe2\x80\x99s legs, for example, when the excited 'b'philosophe'b' grasped them tightly to make a point \xe2\x80\x94 but the empress had little patience with his idealism. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I had followed his advice,\xe2\x80\x9d she said of her visiting Frenchman, \xe2\x80\x9ceverything would have been turned upside down in my kingdom.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'La mission civilisatrice \xe2\x80\x94 France\xe2\x80\x99s civilizing mission \xe2\x80\x94 was nevertheless started in Russia, and furthered by a wave of French celebrity \xc3\xa9migr\xc3\xa9s fleeing the very event for which thinkers like Diderot were held responsible: the revolution. Few countries seemed safer for French aristocrats than reactionary Russia.'b'Small wonder, then, that Joseph de Maistre, the dark genius of counterrevolutionary thought from Savoy, ended up taking a diplomatic posting in St. Petersburg. The city became the setting for his \xe2\x80\x9cSt. Petersburg Dialogues,\xe2\x80\x9d which, in voluptuous French, offered a profoundly grim view of human nature. Man was violent and domineering; society needed a strong hand. Near the beginning, Maistre, gazing on a statue of Peter the Great, rhapsodized: \xe2\x80\x9cHis terrible arm is still extended\xe2\x80\x9d over Russia. \xe2\x80\x9cLooking at him, one does not know whether this bronze hand protects or threatens.\xe2\x80\x9d The answer for Maistre, of course, was both, and he helped provide an intellectual justification for the dim brutality of the czarist state.'b'A new generation of French intellectuals and artists arrived after 1917, the revolution that grew out of 1789. The Surrealist Louis Aragon, who toured Russia in the 1930s, was just one who was dazzled by what he wanted to see. He praised the science of the re-education of man unfolding in Stalin\xe2\x80\x99s gulag, while in his notorious poem \xe2\x80\x9cRed Front\xe2\x80\x9d he urged, in Lenin\xe2\x80\x99s name, the massacre of France\xe2\x80\x99s bourgeois political leaders.'b'Set alongside these remarks, Mr. Depardieu\xe2\x80\x99s sallies on Russian democracy are mostly silly. But they also have a history. From enlightened despotism through absolute autocracy to Soviet communism, Russia has been a screen against which France has projected its ideological or merely idiosyncratic dreams. That these dreams have proved nightmares for those who really lived them is, of course, beside the point for Russia\xe2\x80\x99s leaders.'b'One of Mr. Depardieu\xe2\x80\x99s best-known roles is as Georges Danton, the revolutionary leader consumed by the events he helped incite. HARRINGTON'b'\nWallingford, Conn., Jan. 5, 2013'b''b'Matthew Descamps was 'b'convicted'b' in 2008 of being a felon in possession of a handgun and ammunition under federal law, which usually leads to a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison. But a federal trial judge in Washington State more than doubled that sentence to 21 years and 10 months under the Armed Career Criminal Act.'b'That federal statute imposes a minimum sentence of 15 years and a maximum of life for a felon who commits a crime with a gun after three prior convictions for violent felonies. The judge concluded that Mr. Descamps\xe2\x80\x99s previous conviction for burglary under California law should count as one of the three felonies.'b'Mr. Descamps appealed the sentence, arguing that the burglary should not be counted against him because the state law does not involve illegal entry into a building (a person could be convicted of burglary even if he legally entered the premises) and the Supreme Court has 'b'said'b' that a burglary conviction under the Armed Career Criminal Act has to involve \xe2\x80\x9cbasic elements,\xe2\x80\x9d including an illegal entry. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed his sentence.'b'In 'b'Descamps v. United States'b', which the Supreme Court heard this week, Mr. Descamps makes a persuasive argument that the trial judge should not have disregarded the California\xe2\x80\x99s definition of burglary to fit the Armed Career Criminal Act. Trial judges can 'b'look'b' at certain documents, like a defendant\xe2\x80\x99s plea agreement, to figure out whether a state crime involved the basic elements required under the federal statute. But they cannot fish for facts to match such elements if they aren\xe2\x80\x99t included in the state\xe2\x80\x99s definition of the crime, as the judge did in this case.'b'During the 'b'oral argument'b', the justices sometimes sounded frustrated by this approach. Justice Elena Kagan pointed out that it means that any conviction under California\xe2\x80\x99s burglary law would not qualify as a prior crime. But given what is at stake, it\xe2\x80\x99s only right that state convictions be carefully considered if they are used under the federal statute to lengthen criminal sentences.'b'A committee of central bankers and regulators from more than two dozen countries, including the United States, has disappointingly given in to lobbying by big banks and 'b'watered down important rules'b' meant to strengthen the global financial system. 'b'The change'b' will let banks include risky financial instruments like corporate bonds and mortgage-backed securities as part of their liquid asset reserves, which are meant to cover up to 30 days of cash outflows during crises. And the banks have until 2019, not 2015, to comply fully with the easier standards. Each nation will decide when and how to implement the rules.'b'The committee unanimously rolled back the so-called Basel III rules that were adopted in 2010 to make them \xe2\x80\x9cmore realistic,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mervyn King, the governor of the Bank of England. The banks argued that requiring them to hold most of their liquid reserves as cash and government securities would restrict their ability to lend to small businesses and consumers because they would have less money to lend.'b'The problem is that the new assets defined as liquid are precisely those that banks found difficult to value and trade in 2008. Relying on them to provide liquidity during a crisis is a recipe for disaster, said Anat Admati, a professor of finance and economics at Stanford University.'b'But the banks want to be allowed to hold more such assets because they are more profitable than cash or government bonds, like 10-year Treasury notes, which were yielding just 1.86 percent a year on Wednesday. Big banks also know that in a crisis they would likely receive emergency loans and capital from central banks and their governments, so why tie up their reserves with assets that provide only modest returns?'b'Coming four years after the failure of Lehman Brothers, the dilution of liquidity standards suggests that banks are again dictating policy in ways that will put the world at greater risk of another crisis. Policy makers in Washington and other capitals need to ask banking regulators to hold the line on the very limited progress made so far.'b'The only reason that income taxes on 99 percent of Americans did not go up 'b'this month'b' was that Speaker John Boehner briefly broke with an iron rule of Republican control over the House. He allowed the fiscal-cliff deal to be put to a full vote of the House even though a strong majority of Republicans opposed it.'b'That informal rule, which bars a vote on legislation unless it has the support of a majority of Republicans, has been one of the biggest stumbling blocks to progress and consensus in Congress, and, in its own way, is even more pernicious than the filibuster abuse that often ties up the Senate. Under the 60-vote requirement to break a filibuster, at least, coalitions can occasionally be formed between the Democratic majority and enough Republicans to reach the three-fifths threshold.'b'But under the majority-of-the-majority rule in the House, Democrats are completely cut out of the governing process, not even given a chance to vote unless Republicans have decided to pass something. Since 2010, there have been enough extremist Republicans in the caucus to block consideration of most of the bills requested by the White House or sent over from the Senate. If President Obama is for something, it\xe2\x80\x99s a safe bet that most House Republicans are against it, and thus won\xe2\x80\x99t bring it up.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why the House never took a vote on the Senate\xe2\x80\x99s latest five-year farm bill. Or the Violence Against Women Act. Or a full six-year transportation bill. Republican opposition prevented consideration in the last term 'b'of the Senate\xe2\x80\x99s $60 billion'b' in providing relief from Hurricane Sandy; so far, 'b'the House has been willing to approve'b' only a measly $9.7 billion after members claimed the Senate\xe2\x80\x99s bill was full of (nonexistent) pork.'b'The House has always been a sprawling, unruly chamber, and its leaders have long used some form of control to choose which bills reach the floor and to push their party\xe2\x80\x99s policies. The majority-of-the-majority requirement, however, is relatively new and entirely a Republican creation. Newt Gingrich occasionally used it when he was speaker, but it was 'b'institutionalized in 2004'b' by Speaker Dennis Hastert (and Tom DeLay, the power behind the throne).'b'This anti-democratic tactic, now known as the \xe2\x80\x9cHastert rule,\xe2\x80\x9d helped turn the chamber into a one-party institution that utterly silenced the minority. A post-9/11 intelligence reform bill, urgently sought by President George W. Bush, was bottled up by Mr. Hastert and his allies, who knew it would pass if Democrats were allowed to vote.'b'This was not a rule used by Democrats. In a world in which anti-Semitism actually does persist, this is devaluing the term so that it becomes simply a glib right-wing insult. Maybe that\xe2\x80\x99s why Jewish Voice for Peace, a liberal American Jewish organization, has announced that its supporters have sent 10,000 e-mails to President Obama in support of Hagel\xe2\x80\x99s nomination.'b'As for Iran, Hagel will need to sound more hawkish in public to mesh with the administration, and it is useful for Iran to worry about a military strike. But I hope that Hagel, in private, continues to be cautious. Obama has been painting himself in a corner so that if a nuclear deal with Tehran isn\xe2\x80\x99t reached, he would have to order bombings sometime in 2013 or 2014. A skeptic at the Pentagon would be a useful addition to that debate.'b'As a journalist who spends a good deal of time in the field, I am often alarmed that Washington policy-making can become an echo chamber reinforcing the prejudices of whoever is in charge without giving weight to inconvenient complexities on the ground. With his combat experience, Chuck Hagel would offer not an echo but a thoughtful and independent voice.'b'Venzuela\xe2\x80\x99s presidential inauguration is missing a president.'b'Regarding \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Greece\xe2\x80\x99s rotten oligarchy'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Views, Jan. 7): In citing the mendacity, corruption and avarice overrunning Athens, Kostas Vaxevanis describes a country whose political establishment has betrayed its citizenry. Iaconis, Mineola, New York'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'David Brooks (\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Why Hagel Was Picked'b',\xe2\x80\x9d column, Jan. 8) is off the mark when he suggests that Chuck Hagel, President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s nominee for defense secretary, will end up presiding over a period of \xe2\x80\x9cmilitary decline.\xe2\x80\x9d We need to reshape our military to address new threats, and we can save substantial sums in the process. This should happen regardless of how the debate over Medicare is resolved.'b'With the end of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and the shift toward challenges like nuclear proliferation and climate change that can\xe2\x80\x99t be solved through traditional military approaches, the time is ripe to truly put the Pentagon on a budget. HARTUNG'b'\nNew York, Jan. 8, 2013'b''b''b'The writer is director of the Arms and Security Project at the Center for International Policy.'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'I disagree with David Brooks\xe2\x80\x99s view of previous and current reductions in military spending.'b'Defense planners did not really underestimate the size of the cuts that materialized after the Vietnam War, the cold war and the 1991 Persian Gulf war. The cuts made under Presidents Richard M. Nixon (and later Gerald R. Ford) reflected the reductions associated with the arms control negotiations with the Soviet Union, the opening to China and the Nixon doctrine of no more land wars in Asia, and never went below the level of the last prewar budget.'b'Similarly, the cuts that occurred from 1993 to 1998 were less than the 25 percent cuts proposed by Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs.'b'Additionally, even if the whole $500 billion in defense reductions called for by the Simpson-Bowles plan and numerous other bipartisan debt-reduction plans were carried out, military spending in real terms would return only to its fiscal year 2007 level and will still be 40 percent higher than it was on 9/11.'b'LAWRENCE KORB'b'\nAlexandria, Va., Jan. 9, 2013'b''b''b'The writer, a senior fellow at the Center for American Progress, was an assistant secretary of defense in the Reagan administration.'b''b'EVERY four years the cabinet briefly becomes the focus of national attention in December and January \xe2\x80\x94 only to fade from view again after Inauguration Day. True, individual cabinet secretaries will be in the news from time to time, but the cabinet as an institution will be all but forgotten. Yet the United States could benefit greatly by strengthening its scope and role.'b'Although the cabinet is not established in the Constitution, presidents since George Washington have convened a collective body of the heads of the executive departments. Washington used these meetings to tap into the wisdom of Secretary of State Thomas Jefferson and Treasury Secretary Alexander Hamilton. Abraham Lincoln assembled a strong \xe2\x80\x9cteam of rivals\xe2\x80\x9d in his cabinet to gird the nation at its time of greatest peril. Franklin D. Roosevelt convened his cabinet the day after the Pearl Harbor attacks, while John F. Kennedy relied on a subset of his cabinet during the Cuban missile crisis.'b'Over the past half-century, however, the expansion of the White House staff has centralized deliberation and decision making increasingly within the confines of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue NW. This reliance on professional staffers, political advisers and media spinmeisters within a constrictive White House \xe2\x80\x9csecurity bubble\xe2\x80\x9d deprives presidents not only of the deep substantive policy expertise of top civil servants but also of the political judgment of cabinet members who are often successful politicians.'b'A strengthened cabinet could promote frank and creative deliberation, help coordinate policy across government and make sure all members are delivering the same political message. All of this could go far in staving off the inertia and drift so common in presidential second terms.'b'Cabinet secretaries given a more prominent role would also enjoy a higher profile, enhancing their effectiveness in Washington and beyond, and enabling them to serve as more effective proxies for the president. Here are four ideas to maximize the reach and impact of the next cabinet:'b'\xc2\x95 Employ the cabinet as a deliberative body: Cabinet meetings have become little more than occasional photo ops. Under Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, for example, cabinet meetings were held monthly; the Obama team has met less than one-third as often. By contrast, the British, German and many other parliamentary cabinets meet weekly to assure that the entire team shares a common and coordinated vision. More regular and meaningful cabinet meetings could strengthen links across departments and with the White House staff, bolstering cooperation and reducing overlap and miscommunication.'b'\xc2\x95 Strengthen links between cabinet members and Congress: The Congressional committee structure is already designed to roughly parallel the cabinet departments, with each linked to one or more committees in each house. Without violating separation of powers, cabinet secretaries could be given nonvoting ex officio status as members of committees. This would empower them and their designees to work more closely with lawmakers in devising legislation and participating in hearings and other legislative work. They also would be eligible to address committees or even Congress as a whole.'b'\xc2\x95 Deploy cabinet members as presidential proxies: Countless ceremonial duties and foreign trips tax the time and energy of presidents. While cabinet members do fill in for the president at times, they could do much more by meeting with foreign dignitaries, presiding at ceremonial events and presenting honors and awards. This would elevate their stature and make them more effective policy messengers.'b'\xc2\x95 Cultivate the next generation of leadership: Almost uniquely among established democracies, a cabinet post in the United States can be more of a political grave than a cradle for leaders. No cabinet official has gone on to become president in nearly 85 years, and few have run. Yet the experience gained running an executive department and learning the ways of Washington offers great expertise for future presidential candidates. It may be Hillary Rodham Clinton who breaks this trend in 2016, drawing in no small part on her experience as secretary of state.'b'There is a risk, of course, that a stronger cabinet could undermine the president. But cabinet secretaries would continue to serve \xe2\x80\x9cat the pleasure of the president.\xe2\x80\x9d And while presidents could benefit from the collective wisdom of their cabinet, they would not be bound by it. When members of Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s cabinet once unanimously outvoted him, Lincoln closed the meeting by saying, \xe2\x80\x9cSeven nays and one aye, the ayes have it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'An enhanced cabinet would not have its own independent mandate, but it could share more fully in the president\xe2\x80\x99s, and thus advance that mandate more effectively.'b'WASHINGTON'b'IN 2010, I was branded a member of the \xe2\x80\x9cAl Qaeda 7\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a notorious label attached to Department of Justice lawyers who were 'b'mocked by critics'b' claiming they had \xe2\x80\x9cflocked to 'b'Guant\xc3\xa1namo'b' to take up the cause of the terrorists.\xe2\x80\x9d My crime: I advocated for the closure of the detention facility \xe2\x80\x94 a position that has also been taken up by the likes of former President George W. Bush, former Secretary of Defense Robert M. Gates and former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell \xe2\x80\x94 and for more humane living conditions for those imprisoned there.'b'At the time, I reacted defensively. I was indignant. I insisted on the legitimacy of my convictions. But even then the writing was on the wall. For a core group of detainees, closing Guant\xc3\xa1namo would not mean release or prosecution, as most human rights and civil liberties groups have long advocated. Rather, it would mean relocation to the United States, or elsewhere, for continued detention.'b'Now, almost four years later, I have changed my mind. Despite recognizing the many policy imperatives in favor of closure, despite the bipartisan support for this position, and despite the fact that 'b'166 men'b' still languish there, I now believe that Guant\xc3\xa1namo should stay open \xe2\x80\x94 at least for the short term.'b'While I have been slow to come to this realization, the signs have been evident for some time. Three years ago, Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s administration conducted a comprehensive review of the Guant\xc3\xa1namo detainees and concluded that about four dozen prisoners couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be prosecuted, but were too dangerous to be transferred or released. They are still being held under rules of war that allow detention without charge for the duration of hostilities.'b'Others happened to hail from Yemen. Although many of them were cleared for transfer, the transfers were put on indefinite hold because of instability in Yemen, the fear that some might join Al Qaeda forces, and Yemen\xe2\x80\x99s inability to put adequate security measures in place.'b'While the specific numbers have most likely shifted over time, the basic categories persist. These are men whom the current administration will not transfer, release or prosecute, so long as the legal authority to detain, pursuant to the law of war, endures.'b'President Obama raised the hopes of the human rights community when during his re-election campaign he once again said the detention center should be closed. But it was not clear whether he had a viable plan, and any such plan would almost certainly involve moving many of the detainees into continued detention in the United States, where their living conditions would almost certainly deteriorate.'b'Guant\xc3\xa1namo in 2013 is a far cry from Guant\xc3\xa1namo in 2002. Thanks to the spotlight placed on the facility by human rights groups, international observers and detainees\xe2\x80\x99 lawyers, there has been a significant, if not uniform, improvement in conditions.'b'The majority of Guant\xc3\xa1namo detainees now live in communal facilities where they can eat, pray and exercise together. If moved to the United States, these same men would most likely be held in military detention in conditions akin to supermax prisons \xe2\x80\x94 confined to their cells 22 hours a day and prohibited from engaging in group activities, including communal prayer. The hard-won improvements in conditions would be ratcheted back half a decade to their previous level of harshness.'b'And Guant\xc3\xa1namo would no longer be that failed experiment on an island many miles away. The Obama administration would be affirmatively creating a new system of detention without charge for terrorism suspects on American soil, setting a precedent and creating a facility readily available to future presidents wanting to rid themselves of a range of potentially dangerous actors.'b'The political reality is that closure of Guant\xc3\xa1namo is unlikely to happen anytime soon, and if it did, it would do more harm than good. We should instead focus on finding places to transfer those cleared to leave the facility and, more important, on defining the end to the war.'b'In a recent speech, Jeh Johnson, then the Department of Defense general counsel, 'b'discussed'b' a future \xe2\x80\x9ctipping point\xe2\x80\x9d at which Al Qaeda would be so decimated that the armed conflict would be deemed over. Statements from high level officials suggest that this point may be near. And as the United States pulls out of Afghanistan, there is an increasingly strong argument that the war against Al Qaeda is coming to a close. With the end of the conflict, the legal justification for the detentions will finally disappear.'b'At that point, the remaining men in Guant\xc3\xa1namo can no longer be held without charge, at least not without running afoul of basic constitutional and international law prohibitions. Only then is there a realistic hope for meaningful closure, not by recreating a prison in the United States but through the arduous process of transferring, releasing or prosecuting the detainees left there.'b'In the meantime, we should keep Guant\xc3\xa1namo open.'b'If you want to deter crime, it seems that you\xe2\x80\x99d want to lengthen prison sentences so that criminals would face steeper costs for breaking the law. In fact, a mountain of research shows that increases in prison terms have done nothing to deter crime. Criminals, like the rest of us, aren\xe2\x80\x99t much influenced by things they might have to experience far in the future.'b'If a police officer witnesses the death of his partner, it seems that you\xe2\x80\x99d want to quickly send in a grief counselor. In fact, this sort of immediate counseling freezes and fortifies memories of the trauma, making the aftershocks more damaging.'b'If you want to get people to vote more, it seems you\xe2\x80\x99d want to tell them what a problem low turnout is. In fact, if you want people to vote, tell them everybody else is already voting and they should join the club. Voting is mostly about social membership and personal expression.'b'These are three examples of policies and practices that are based on bad psychology. The list of examples could go on and fill this page. That\xe2\x80\x99s because we spend trillions of dollars putting policies and practices into place, but most of these efforts are based on the crudest possible psychological guesswork.'b'Fortunately, people in the behavioral sciences are putting policies to the test. I know of groups at Duke and Penn that are applying behavioral research findings to policy issues. Eldar Shafir of Princeton has edited a weighty new book, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Behavioral Foundations of Public Policy,\xe2\x80\x9d which is a master compendium of what we know.'b'One of the things we know is that seemingly trivial changes can have big effects. People who are presented with a wide variety of choices of, say, yogurt, will eat more than people who are presented with a small array of choices or no choice. People who were randomly given a short, wide 22-ounce glass, poured 88 percent more juice or soda into it than people who were offered a tall, narrow 22-ounce glass, but they believed they only poured in half as much as they actually did.'b'Sometimes the behavioral research leads us to completely change how we think about an issue. For example, many of our anti-discrimination policies focus on finding the bad apples who are explicitly prejudiced. In fact, the serious discrimination is implicit, subtle and nearly universal. Both blacks and whites subtly try to get a white partner when asked to team up to do an intellectually difficult task. In computer shooting simulations, both black and white participants were more likely to think black figures were armed. In emergency rooms, whites are pervasively given stronger painkillers than blacks or Hispanics. Clearly, we should spend more effort rigging situations to reduce universal, unconscious racism.'b'The research is also leading to new policy approaches. The most famous involve default settings. Roughly 98 percent of people take part in organ donor programs in European countries where you have to check a box to opt out. Only 10 percent or 20 percent take part in neighboring countries where you have to check a box to opt in.'b'In one clever program, dieters were told to phone in their weight to a nurse daily. Every day they called, they got an encouraging text and a lottery ticket, with a chance of winning a small amount. These dieters lost three times more weight than people who didn\xe2\x80\x99t get tickets. Another ingenious program automatically diverts some money into your savings account every time you buy a state lottery ticket.'b'Prime Minister David Cameron\xe2\x80\x99s government in Britain has gone furthest in implementing these sorts of programs. Personalized text messages were found to be six times more effective in getting people to pay fines than warning letters. If you tell people what percentage of their neighbors has already paid their taxes, you are more likely to get late filers to actually pay than if you nag them another way.'b'My problem with these efforts is that they are still so modest. What about the big problems? How do we get people to restrain government commitments now so that debt down the road won\xe2\x80\x99t be so ruinous? How do we calculate the multiplier effects of tax cuts or spending increases among different subgroups of the population, or under different emotional conditions? How do we rig the context of budget negotiations so participants can actually come to a deal? How are people in different cultures likely to react to drone strikes? How do we structure sanctions against Iran to cause the greatest psychic humiliation?'b'These are the big questions, and most of our policies rely on crude folk psychology from a few politicians. But there\xe2\x80\x99s hope. As Brian Wansink notes in Eldar Shafir\xe2\x80\x99s volume, the 20th century saw great gains in sanitation and public health. The 21st century could be a great period for behavior change.'b'So, have you heard the one about the trillion-dollar coin? It may sound like a joke. But if we aren\xe2\x80\x99t ready to mint that coin or take some equivalent action, the joke will be on us \xe2\x80\x94 and a very sick joke it will be, too.'b'Let\xe2\x80\x99s talk for a minute about the vile absurdity of the debt-ceiling confrontation.'b'Under the Constitution, fiscal decisions rest with Congress, which passes laws specifying tax rates and establishing spending programs. If the revenue brought in by those legally established tax rates falls short of the costs of those legally established programs, the Treasury Department normally borrows the difference.'b'Lately, revenue has fallen far short of spending, mainly because of the depressed state of the economy. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t like this, there\xe2\x80\x99s a simple remedy: demand that Congress raise taxes or cut back on spending. And if you\xe2\x80\x99re frustrated by Congress\xe2\x80\x99s failure to act, well, democracy means that you can\xe2\x80\x99t always get what you want.'b'Where does the debt ceiling fit into all this? Actually, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t. Since Congress already determines revenue and spending, and hence the amount the Treasury needs to borrow, we shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t need another vote empowering that borrowing. But for historical reasons any increase in federal debt must be approved by yet another vote. And now Republicans in the House are threatening to deny that approval unless President Obama makes major policy concessions.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s crucial to understand three things about this situation. First, raising the debt ceiling wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t grant the president any new powers; every dollar he spent would still have to be approved by Congress. Second, if the debt ceiling isn\xe2\x80\x99t raised, the president will be forced to break the law, one way or another; either he borrows funds in defiance of Congress, or he fails to spend money Congress has told him to spend.'b'Finally, just consider the vileness of that G.O.P. threat. If we were to hit the debt ceiling, the U.S. government would end up defaulting on many of its obligations. This would have disastrous effects on financial markets, the economy, and our standing in the world. Yet Republicans are threatening to trigger this disaster unless they get spending cuts that they weren\xe2\x80\x99t able to enact through normal, Constitutional means.'b'Republicans go wild at this analogy, but it\xe2\x80\x99s unavoidable. This is exactly like someone walking into a crowded room, announcing that he has a bomb strapped to his chest, and threatening to set that bomb off unless his demands are met.'b'Which brings us to the coin.'b'As it happens, 'b'an obscure legal clause grants'b' the secretary of the Treasury the right to mint and issue platinum coins in any quantity or denomination he chooses. Such coins were, of course, intended to be collectors\xe2\x80\x99 items, struck to commemorate special occasions. But the law is the law \xe2\x80\x94 and it offers a simple if strange way out of the crisis.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s how it would work: The Treasury would mint a platinum coin with a face value of $1 trillion (or many coins with smaller values; it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t really matter). This coin would immediately be deposited at the Federal Reserve, which would credit the sum to the government\xe2\x80\x99s account. And the government could then write checks against that account, continuing normal operations without issuing new debt.'b'In case you\xe2\x80\x99re wondering, no, this wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be an inflationary exercise in printing money. Aside from the fact that 'b'printing money isn\xe2\x80\x99t inflationary'b' under current conditions, the Fed could and would offset the Treasury\xe2\x80\x99s cash withdrawals by selling other assets or borrowing more from banks, so that in reality the U.S. government as a whole (which includes the Fed) would continue to engage in normal borrowing. Basically, this would just be an accounting trick, but that\xe2\x80\x99s a good thing. The debt ceiling is a case of accounting nonsense gone malignant; using an accounting trick to negate it is entirely appropriate.'b'But wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t the coin trick be undignified? Yes, it would \xe2\x80\x94 but better to look slightly silly than to let a financial and Constitutional crisis explode.'b'Now, the platinum coin may not be the only option. Maybe the president can simply declare that as he understands the Constitution, his duty to carry out Congressional mandates on taxes and spending takes priority over the debt ceiling. Or he might be able to finance government operations 'b'by issuing coupons'b' that look like debt and act like debt but that, he insists, aren\xe2\x80\x99t debt and, therefore, don\xe2\x80\x99t count against the ceiling.'b'Or, best of all, there might be enough sane Republicans that the party will blink and stop making destructive threats.'b'Unless this last possibility materializes, however, it\xe2\x80\x99s the president\xe2\x80\x99s duty to do whatever it takes, no matter how offbeat or silly it may sound, to defuse this hostage situation. Mint that coin!'b'It is no secret that the United States spends a lot more on health care than any other country yet ranks far behind other advanced nations in keeping its citizens healthy. This has been well documented in studies of older people and of newborn infants. It is now shockingly clear that poor health is a much broader and deeper problem than past studies have suggested.'b'An authoritative 'b'report issued by the Institute of Medicine this week'b' found that, on average, Americans experience higher rates of disease and injury and die sooner than people in other high-income countries. That is true at all ages between birth and 75 and for even well-off Americans who mistakenly think that top-tier medical care ensures that they will remain in good health. The study found that even upper-income Americans with health insurance and college educations appear to be sicker than their peers in other rich nations.'b'The study was commissioned by the National Institutes of Health, the federal government\xe2\x80\x99s top medical research agency, and was carried out by experts appointed by the National Research Council and the Institute of Medicine, two units of the prestigious National Academy of Sciences. It is the first analysis to compare the burden of multiple diseases and injuries in the United States and 16 other affluent democracies, including Western European countries, Australia, Canada and Japan.'b'American men ranked last in life expectancy among the 17 countries and American women ranked next to last. The United States also ranked at or near the bottom in nine areas, including heart disease, chronic lung disease, obesity and diabetes, injuries and homicides, and sexually transmitted diseases. \xe2\x80\x9cWe were struck by the gravity of these findings,\xe2\x80\x9d said the panel chairman, 'b'Dr. Steven Woolf'b', a professor of family medicine at Virginia Commonwealth University. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat concerns our panel is why, for decades, we have been slipping behind.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Likely explanations include a large uninsured population and more limited access to primary care, two problems that should be mitigated by the health care reforms that will kick in next year; higher levels of poverty and income inequality in this country; weaker safety net programs; sedentary lifestyles and obesity; higher rates of drug abuse and traffic accidents that involve alcohol; and greater use of firearms in acts of violence.'b'The panel suggested a campaign to raise public awareness of the American health disadvantage and a study of what other countries are doing that might be useful here.'b'The Palestinian Authority, which governs parts of the West Bank not under Israeli control, 'b'is in financial crisis'b'. Its leaders are finding it increasingly difficult to pay 180,000 government employees, including security forces as well as other civil servants.'b'This is not a problem that can be swept under the rug. Whatever the criticisms of the Palestinian Authority, and there are many, Israel has increasingly depended on it to manage and keep the peace in a strategically critical swath of territory. If there is ever to be a peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians, there has to be a competent government to run a Palestinian state and leaders with whom to make a deal.'b'The authority, established under the 1993 Oslo Accords that were to lead to a permanent peace agreement, was supposed to be that vehicle. But it is in danger of being so weakened that it would be unable to carry out those responsibilities. 'b'Its financial woes'b' are not new. 'b'A World Bank report in September'b' said a \xe2\x80\x9cpersistent shortfall in donor funding has exacerbated the P.A.\xe2\x80\x99s increasingly difficult fiscal situation, leaving a financing gap of almost $400 million.\xe2\x80\x9d And, in an interview with The Associated Press 'b'on Sunday'b', the Palestinian prime minister, Salam Fayyad, the official in charge of the government bureaucracy, said the problems are worsening and the authority is on the \xe2\x80\x9cverge of being completely incapacitated.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There are many causes. After Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, won an upgrade for the status of Palestine as a nonmember observer state at the United Nations General Assembly 'b'last fall'b', Israel retaliated by withholding the $100 million in monthly tax revenues it collects on behalf of the Palestinians. Congress, meanwhile, has been withholding more than $450 million in American aid. Last year, Mr. Fayyad said he hoped to improve the authority\xe2\x80\x99s financial condition by cutting spending and raising taxes on wealthier Palestinians. The tax plan ran into strong protest and the West Bank\xe2\x80\x99s modest economic growth has slowed.'b'In the recent interview Mr. Fayyad put most of the blame for the authority\xe2\x80\x99s financial distress on Arab donors who are \xe2\x80\x9cnot fulfilling their pledge of support\xe2\x80\x9d made in Arab League resolutions to make up the money Israel is withholding. This should come as little surprise. Arab leaders have often promised political and economic support for the Palestinians and failed to deliver. Arab foreign ministers are expected to meet Sunday in Cairo to discuss Palestinian issues, including the promised aid. They should affirm their commitment to assist the Palestinian Authority and get the funds flowing.'b'There are many threats to a two-state solution, including an Israeli government that could become even more hard-line after the Jan. 22 election. But, as the World Bank has said, Mr. Fayyad has made progress in building a functioning government. MYERS'b'\nPresident'b'\nCampaign for Tobacco-Free Kids'b'\nWashington, Jan. 8, 2013'b''b''b''b'MORE than one million people in the Chinese city of Handan awoke last week to the alarming news that an essential source of their drinking water, the Zhouzhang River, had been dangerously contaminated by a 39-ton chemical spill in the nearby city of Changzhi. What made the news even more shocking was that the leak, from a factory pipe, had started at least 'b'five days earlier'b' but had been kept secret by government officials, who allowed millions of their neighbors to keep drinking.'b'The people of Handan reacted to these disclosures the same way almost anyone else would. First, they panicked, mobbing stores for bottled water. Then, they were furious, demanding to know why no one had told them they were drinking water laced with a probable carcinogen. If history is any guide, they will never get a satisfactory answer.'b'For me, reading about Handan prompted a sick feeling of d\xc3\xa9j\xc3\xa0 vu. For the last five years I have been writing a history of the chemical industry\xe2\x80\x99s egregious 60-year involvement in the New Jersey shore town of Toms River, which gained unwanted notoriety in the late 1990s thanks to a remarkably well-documented cluster of childhood cancer cases and a long history of often hidden industrial pollution.'b'When news of the cancer cluster leaked in 1996, there was the predictable townwide panic, including a run on bottled water supplies. After a wrenching 'b'five-year investigation'b', state and federal health officials concluded that the sick children were more likely to have lived in parts of town where exposure to industrial chemicals \xe2\x80\x94 via drinking water and polluted air \xe2\x80\x94 were highest.'b'It was, by definition, an association, not a causal relationship, and it was statistically significant only for girls with leukemia. But in the murky world of neighborhood cancer cluster studies, that\xe2\x80\x99s as close to a definitive finding as you\xe2\x80\x99re ever likely to see. That same year, 2001, the families of 69 children with cancer won a multimillion-dollar legal settlement against two chemical companies and the water utility.'b'As in Toms River, so many things about last week\xe2\x80\x99s debacle in Handan were infuriating, starting with the chemical involved: aniline. That was the compound that launched the synthetic chemical industry in 1856, when a precocious 18-year-old named William Henry Perkin, experimenting in his parents\xe2\x80\x99 London attic, inadvertently discovered that aniline, dissolved in sulfuric acid and mixed with potassium dichromate, made a superb purple dye.'b'Soon London, Basel, Switzerland, and the Ruhr Valley in Germany were littered with aniline factories, many of which would morph into familiar corporate giants like CIBA, Geigy, Agfa and the German behemoth BASF, the industry leader. In Basel and London, it was said, you could tell which dyes were being made by the color of the nearby canals and rivers, where the factories dumped their waste. Factory bosses would send workers on clandestine midnight runs to the Middle Bridge in Basel to dump barrels of waste into the fast-moving Rhine.'b'Basel is a border city and the Rhine flows north, so the waste was Germany\xe2\x80\x99s problem \xe2\x80\x94 just as last week\xe2\x80\x99s spill was Handan\xe2\x80\x99s problem, not Changzhi\xe2\x80\x99s.'b'In 1895, a Frankfurt surgeon named Ludwig Wilhelm Carl Rehn began noticing unusual numbers of bladder cancers \xe2\x80\x94 he called them \xe2\x80\x9caniline tumors\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 among workers in dye plants. Whether aniline was the specific cause was hard to determine, since by then, chemical manufacturers had expanded well beyond aniline and were using dozens of compounds derived from coal and oil to make dyes and many other products. What was obvious was that these synthetic hydrocarbons were leaving a trail of tumors wherever they were manufactured.'b'The legacy of cancer followed the industry as it spread to America. In the 1950s, at Cincinnati Chemical Works, almost half of the long-term workers who handled a dye compound called 'b'benzidine'b' got bladder cancer. Soon after, the Cincinnati factories closed and their Swiss owners transferred manufacturing to a huge new facility in a small town where there would be less scrutiny: Toms River.'b'Today, there is little left of the vast complex the Swiss operated in Toms River for more than 40 years. Manufacturing ended there in 1996, just as the cluster controversy was heating up. Now, after so many years of painful publicity about cancer and pollution, many residents of Toms River are happy to have moved on, and who can blame them. They are much more likely to be worried about the damage Hurricane Sandy recently inflicted on hundreds of local homes than about any lingering effects from decades-old water and air pollution.'b'The reality of 21st-century globalism, however, is that none of us can pretend that by pushing the chemical industry out of our communities we have stopped enabling its dangerous practices. The industry jobs that started in Basel, and then migrated to Cincinnati and Toms River, are now in Shanxi Province and other coal-rich areas of China. BASF alone now owns or invests in 45 Chinese ventures. Meanwhile, hundreds of smaller companies like the Tianji Coal Chemical Industry Group, whose Changzhi factory was the source of last week\xe2\x80\x99s leak, are busy turning coal into aniline and a host of other chemical products.'b'Business is booming. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t believe me, head over to the Ocean County Mall in Toms River, where you can get a pair of 'b'jeans'b' dyed just the right shade of faded blue, thanks to aniline-based indigo dye. They\xe2\x80\x99re made in China, and they\xe2\x80\x99re cheap \xe2\x80\x94 if you don\xe2\x80\x99t count the long-term cost.'b'LEXINGTON, Ky.'b'It was the middle of the workday \xe2\x80\x94 a bright, chilly Wednesday afternoon in Lexington, Ky. \xe2\x80\x94 but Bud\xe2\x80\x99s Gun Shop was crowded. In Sweden, where I teach, it\xe2\x80\x99s estimated that more than half of psychiatric care staff members are exposed to physical violence each year, an experience mirrored in many other countries.'b'Efforts to reduce violence in psychiatric hospitals have focused on identifying potentially aggressive patients through clinical histories and improving staff training and care procedures. But these approaches, while worthy, are clearly not enough. While definitive numbers are hard to come by, the incidence of violence in care facilities appears to be going up.'b'Research suggests, however, that there\xe2\x80\x99s an effective solution that has largely been overlooked: designing hospital spaces that can reduce human aggression \xe2\x80\x94 to calm emotionally troubled patients through architecture.'b'Currently, questions about design at psychiatric care facilities are viewed through the prism of security. How many guard and isolation rooms are needed? Where should we put locked doors and alarms? But architecture can \xe2\x80\x94 and should \xe2\x80\x94 play a much larger role in patient safety and care.'b'One prominent goal of facility design, for example, should be to reduce stress, which often leads to aggression.'b'For patients, the stress of mental illness itself can be intensified by the trauma of being confined for weeks in a locked ward. A care facility that\xe2\x80\x99s also noisy, lacks privacy and hinders communication between staff and patients is sure to increase that trauma. Likewise, architectural designs that minimize noise and crowding, enhance patients\xe2\x80\x99 coping and sense of control, and offer calming distractions can reduce trauma.'b'Thanks to decades of study on the design of apartments, prisons, cardiac intensive care units and offices, environmental psychologists now have a clear understanding of the architectural features that can achieve the latter \xe2\x80\x94 and few of these elements, if incorporated into a hospital design from the outset, significantly raise the cost of construction.'b'Providing day rooms and other shared spaces with 'b'movable seating'b', for example, gives patients the ability to control their personal space and interactions with others. Sound-absorbing surfaces reduce noise (and stress), as do designs that offer more natural light.'b'Some features, like single-patient bedrooms with private toilets, do increase the building cost \xe2\x80\x94 but that is arguably offset by the reduced trauma for patients and hospital workers. Violence, after all, isn\xe2\x80\x99t just a danger to well-being, its effects \xe2\x80\x94 from medical care to lawsuits \xe2\x80\x94 are frequently expensive, too.'b'Colleagues from Chalmers University of Technology and Sahlgrenska University Hospital and I recently performed a study using a psychiatric hospital, Ostra Hospital in Gothenburg, that opened in 2006. Of the 10 architectural features researchers have identified that are likely to diminish stress and aggression, Ostra has nine.'b'Data on aggressive incidents were compiled for the hospital and compared with those from two other psychiatric facilities. One was an older facility replaced by Ostra, which had only one of the stress-reducing features. A third institution located in the same region also had just one of these architectural elements. Despite the wide differences in design, though, the three hospitals were similar with respect to the number of beds, types of patients, treatment protocols and staffing levels.'b'The drop in the use of patient restraints \xe2\x80\x94 a proxy for incidents of aggression \xe2\x80\x94 was striking. At the third facility \xe2\x80\x94 which operated during the years of both the old and new hospitals in Gothenburg and therefore served as an experimental control \xe2\x80\x94 the use of both forms of restraint continued to rise, suggesting that the difference was probably not because of a general improvement in care procedures over the period examined.'b'Comparison studies like this one have limitations, certainly. But evidence from myriad studies and design research strongly supports the notion that architectural design can reduce violence.'b'The principles, moreover, have implications for the wider health care system. If you have the misfortune of needing to visit the E.R., expect to feel even more stress if you find yourself in a crowded waiting room with fixed rows of seats and a blaring television whose channel cannot be changed.'b'Environments like these increase the chance that one patient or family member may accost another person in the waiting room, or speak or gesture angrily to a nurse or doctor.'b'To reduce the odds of such aggression, it\xe2\x80\x99s time we put our growing understanding about stress-reducing design into architectural practice. But there was little usable DNA evidence from Ellen\xe2\x80\x99s murder, and besides, the last thing California wanted was for its cases to be muddied by investigators from another state having access to its prisoner. So while the California cases went forward, Ellen and Cornelia Crilley would have to wait. We understood that. What we didn\xe2\x80\x99t understand was how long.'b'Over the years Rodney Alcala\xe2\x80\x99s lawyers managed to twice overturn, on technicalities, his conviction for the murder of Robin Samsoe. He aggressively fought the use of DNA evidence against him, but ultimately lost. Finally, in February 2010, a jury re-re-convicted him of the murder of Robin Samsoe, along with the other four California women. He has not stopped fighting his execution sentence and suing the state for things like failing to provide him with a low-fat diet.'b'Since Ellen was killed, both of her parents have died; her brother has died; her aunt, my mother, has died. I certainly didn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'Shortly after that, though, a detective let me see some of the New York Police Department\xe2\x80\x99s files on Rodney Alcala. Cyrus Vance Jr., who had recently been sworn in as Manhattan district attorney, ending the 35-year term of Robert Morgenthau, had made the opening of cold cases a priority. Suddenly it seemed Ellen had not been forgotten.'b'But it is not easy to open a case from the \xe2\x80\x9970s. Evidence lockers had been cleaned out; documents were moldering; investigators and prosecutors spent weeks and months tracking down witnesses, only to find out they were dead, whereupon they\xe2\x80\x99d politely ask spouses and grown-up children if they could dig up old files. \xe2\x80\x9cLooking for something from 1971,\xe2\x80\x9d Melissa Mourges, the chief of the Cold Case Unit, told me about Cornelia Crilley\xe2\x80\x99s case, \xe2\x80\x9cwe might as well have been looking at something from 1871.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'For two years investigators worked to turn Ellen\xe2\x80\x99s cold case warm. Eventually, their painstakingly obtained evidence built a timeline of Rodney Alcala\xe2\x80\x99s whereabouts, his route before and after murdering Ellen. It seemed to me like a devotional act.'b'Every victim deserves her own day in court, no matter what else the culprit has been arrested for, no matter how long ago the crime: this is the pure integrity of opening a cold case. There are hundreds of thousands of cold cases in the United States. Approximately 14 percent of all unsolved homicide cases and 18 percent of unsolved sexual assault cases contain forensic evidence that has not been sent to a crime lab for analysis.'b'One way to close more cold cases would be to enable more states to enter into national databases the DNA information of everyone they arrest, at least for violent crimes. The best way to honor them was to think that \xe2\x80\x9cone person died,\xe2\x80\x9d three thousand times. Evolutionary psychologists who study mating behavior often begin with a hypothesis about how modern humans mate: say, that men think about sex more than women do. Then they gather evidence \xe2\x80\x94 from studies, statistics and surveys \xe2\x80\x94 to support that assumption. Finally, and here\xe2\x80\x99s where the leap occurs, they construct an evolutionary theory to explain why men think about sex more than women, where that gender difference came from, what adaptive purpose it served in antiquity, and why we\xe2\x80\x99re stuck with the consequences today.'b'Lately, however, a new cohort of scientists have been challenging the very existence of the gender differences in sexual behavior that Darwinians have spent the past 40 years trying to explain and justify on evolutionary grounds.'b'Of course, no fossilized record can really tell us how people behaved or thought back then, much less 'b'why'b' they behaved or thought as they did. Assumptions about that behavior take on the immutability of a physical trait \xe2\x80\x94 they come to seem as biologically rooted as opposable thumbs or ejaculation.'b'Using evolutionary psychology to back up these assumptions about men and women is nothing new. In \xe2\x80\x9cThe Descent of Man, and Selection in Relation to Sex,\xe2\x80\x9d Charles Darwin gathered evidence for the notion that, through competition for mates and sustenance, natural selection had encouraged man\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cmore inventive genius\xe2\x80\x9d while nurturing woman\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cgreater tenderness.\xe2\x80\x9d In this way, he suggested that the gender differences he saw around him \xe2\x80\x94 men sought power and made money; women stayed at home \xe2\x80\x94 weren\xe2\x80\x99t simply the way things were in Victorian England. They were the way things had always been.'b'A century later, a new batch of scientists began applying Darwinian doctrine to the conduct of mating, and specifically to three assumptions that endure to this day: men are less selective about whom they\xe2\x80\x99ll sleep with; men like casual sex more than women; and men have more sexual partners over a lifetime.'b'In 1972, Robert L. Trivers, a graduate student at Harvard, addressed that first assumption in one of evolutionary psychology\xe2\x80\x99s landmark studies, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Parental Investment and Sexual Selection'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d He argued that women are more selective about whom they mate with because they\xe2\x80\x99re biologically obliged to invest more in offspring. Given the relative paucity of ova and plenitude of sperm, as well as the unequal feeding duties that fall to women, men invest less in children. Therefore, men should be expected to be less discriminating and more aggressive in competing for females.'b'It was an elegant, powerful application of evolutionary theory to the mating game. The evolutionary psychologists of the 1980s and \xe2\x80\x9990s built on Mr. Trivers\xe2\x80\x99s theory to explain a wide array of stereotypical gender differences in mating.'b'In 1993, David M. Buss and David P. Schmitt used parental investment theory to explain why men should be expected to \xe2\x80\x9cdevote a larger proportion of their total mating effort to short-term mating.\xe2\x80\x9d Because men invested less time and effort in their offspring, they evolved toward promiscuity, while women evolved away from it. Promiscuity, the researchers hypothesized, would have been more damaging to the female reputation than to the male reputation. If a man mated with a promiscuous woman, he would never be able to ensure his paternity. Men, on the other hand, could potentially enhance their status by pursuing a short-term mating strategy. (Think Kennedy, Clinton, Spitzer, Letterman and so forth. My space is limited.)'b'One of the earliest critics of this kind of thinking was Stephen Jay Gould. He wrote in 1997 that parental investment theory \xe2\x80\x9cwill not explain the full panoply of supposed sexual differences so dear to pop psychology.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Gould felt that the field had become overrun with \xe2\x80\x9cultra-Darwinians,\xe2\x80\x9d and that evolutionary psychology would be a more fruitful science if it didn\xe2\x80\x99t limit itself \xe2\x80\x9cto the blinkered view\xe2\x80\x9d that evolutionary explanations accounted for every difference.'b'BUT if evolution didn\xe2\x80\x99t determine human behavior, what did? The most common explanation is the effect of cultural norms. That, for instance, society tends to view promiscuous men as normal and promiscuous women as troubled outliers, or that our \xe2\x80\x9csocial script\xe2\x80\x9d requires men to approach women while the pickier women do the selecting. Over the past decade, sociocultural explanations have gained steam.'b'Take the question of promiscuity. Everyone has always assumed \xe2\x80\x94 and early research had shown \xe2\x80\x94 that women desired fewer sexual partners over a lifetime than men. But in 2003, two behavioral psychologists, Michele G. Alexander and Terri D. Fisher, published the results of a study that used a \xe2\x80\x9cbogus pipeline\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a fake lie detector. When asked about actual sexual partners, rather than just theoretical desires, the participants who were not attached to the fake lie detector displayed typical gender differences. Men reported having had more sexual partners than women. But when participants believed that lies about their sexual history would be revealed by the fake lie detector, gender differences in reported sexual partners vanished. In fact, women reported slightly more sexual partners (a mean of 4.4) than did men (a mean of 4.0).'b'In 2009, another long-assumed gender difference in mating \xe2\x80\x94 that women are choosier than men \xe2\x80\x94 also came under siege. In speed dating, as in life, the social norm instructs women to sit in one place, waiting to be approached, while the men rotate tables. But in one study of speed-dating behavior, the evolutionary psychologists Eli J. Finkel and Paul W. Eastwick switched the \xe2\x80\x9crotator\xe2\x80\x9d role. The men remained seated and the women rotated. By manipulating this component of the gender script, the researchers discovered that women became less selective \xe2\x80\x94 they behaved more like stereotypical men \xe2\x80\x94 while men were more selective and behaved more like stereotypical women. The mere act of physically approaching a potential romantic partner, they argued, engendered more favorable assessments of that person.'b'Recently, a third pillar appeared to fall. To back up the assumption that an enormous gap exists between men\xe2\x80\x99s and women\xe2\x80\x99s attitudes toward casual sex, evolutionary psychologists typically cite a classic study published in 1989. Men and women on a college campus were approached in public and propositioned with offers of casual sex by \xe2\x80\x9cconfederates\xe2\x80\x9d who worked for the study. The confederate would say: \xe2\x80\x9cI have been noticing you around campus and I find you to be very attractive.\xe2\x80\x9d The confederate would then ask one of three questions: (1) \xe2\x80\x9cWould you go out with me tonight?\xe2\x80\x9d (2) \xe2\x80\x9cWould you come over to my apartment tonight?\xe2\x80\x9d or (3) \xe2\x80\x9cWould you go to bed with me tonight?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Roughly equal numbers of men and women agreed to the date. But women were much less likely to agree to go to the confederate\xe2\x80\x99s apartment. As for going to bed with the confederate, zero women said yes, while about 70 percent of males agreed.'b'Those results seemed definitive \xe2\x80\x94 until a few years ago, when Terri D. Conley, a psychologist at the University of Michigan, set out to re-examine what she calls \xe2\x80\x9cone of the largest documented sexuality gender differences,\xe2\x80\x9d that men have a greater interest in casual sex than women.'b'Ms. Conley found the methodology of the 1989 paper to be less than ideal. \xe2\x80\x9cNo one really comes up to you in the middle of the quad and asks, \xe2\x80\x98Will you have sex with me?\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d she told me recently. \xe2\x80\x9cSo there needs to be a context for it. If you ask people what they would do in a specific situation, that\xe2\x80\x99s a far more accurate way of getting responses.\xe2\x80\x9d In her study, when men and women considered offers of casual sex from famous people, or offers from close friends whom they were told were good in bed, the gender differences in acceptance of casual-sex proposals evaporated nearly to zero.'b'IN light of this new research, will Darwinians consider revising their theories to reflect the possibility that our mating behavior is less hard-wired than they had believed?'b'Probably not. In an article responding to the new studies last year, Mr. Schmitt, a leading voice among hard-line Darwinians, ceded no ground. Addressing Ms. Conley\xe2\x80\x99s finding that women were more likely to agree to casual sex with a celebrity, Mr. Schmitt argued that this resulted from \xe2\x80\x9cwomen\xe2\x80\x99s (but not men\xe2\x80\x99s) short-term mating psychology being specially designed to obtain good genes from physically attractive short-term partners.\xe2\x80\x9d He continued: \xe2\x80\x9cWhen women\xe2\x80\x99s short-term-mating aim is activated (perhaps, temporarily, because of, e.g., high-fertility ovulatory status or desire for an extramarital affair, or more chronically, because of , e.g., a female-biased local sex ratio or a history of insecure parent-child attachment), they appear to express relatively focused desires for genetic traits in \xe2\x80\x98sexy men\xe2\x80\x99 that would biologically benefit women when short-term mating.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In other words: Nothing new here, it\xe2\x80\x99s all evolution.'b'Steven Pinker, the Harvard psychologist and popular author, also backs the Darwinians, whom he says still have the weight of evidence on their side. \xe2\x80\x9cA study which shows you can push some phenomenon around a bit at the margins,\xe2\x80\x9d he wrote to me in an e-mail, \xe2\x80\x9cis of dubious relevance to whether the phenomenon exists.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But the fact that some gender differences can be manipulated, if not eliminated, by controlling for cultural norms suggests that the explanatory power of evolution can\xe2\x80\x99t sustain itself when applied to mating behavior. This wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be the first time we\xe2\x80\x99ve pushed these theories too far. How many stereotypical racial and ethnic differences, once declared evolutionarily determined under the banner of science, have been revealed instead as vestiges of power dynamics from earlier societies?'b'Citing the speed-dating study, Mr. Pinker added, \xe2\x80\x9cThe only reason this flawed paper was published was that it challenged an evolutionary hypothesis ... in particular a sex difference \xe2\x80\x94 as the Larry Summers incident shows, claims about sex differences are still politically inflammatory in the academy.\xe2\x80\x9d Here, he was referring to the much criticized 2005 comments Mr. Summers made when he was Harvard\xe2\x80\x99s president suggesting that women\xe2\x80\x99s underrepresentation in science and engineering was attributable not to socialization but to \xe2\x80\x9cdifferent availability of aptitude at the high end.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Perhaps these phenomena exist. Perhaps men do, over all, pursue more short-term mating. But given new research, continued rigid reliance on evolution as an explanation seems to risk elevating a limited guide to teleological status \xe2\x80\x94 a way of thinking that scientists should abhor.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSome sexual features are deeply rooted in evolutionary heritage, such as the sex response and how quickly it takes men and women to become aroused,\xe2\x80\x9d said Paul Eastwick, a co-author of the speed-dating study. \xe2\x80\x9cHowever, if you\xe2\x80\x99re looking at features such as how men and women regulate themselves in society to achieve specific goals, I believe those features are unlikely to have evolved sex differences. I consider myself an evolutionary psychologist. But many evolutionary psychologists don\xe2\x80\x99t think this way. They think these features are getting shaped and honed by natural selection all the time.\xe2\x80\x9d How far does Darwin go in explaining human behavior?'b'WASHINGTON'b'PRESIDENT OBAMA ran promoting women\xe2\x80\x99s issues.'b'But how about promoting some women?'b'With the old white boys\xe2\x80\x99 club rearing its hoary head in the White House of the first black president, the historian Michael Beschloss recalled the days when the distaff was deemed biologically unsuited for the manly discourse of politics.
