'b'to work, one with another; cooperate, as on a literary work:'b' 'b'\n'b'They collaborated on a novel.'b''b''b'2. 'b'to cooperate, usually willingly, with an enemy nation, especially with an enemy occupying one\xe2\x80\x99s country:'b' 'b'\n'b'He collaborated with the Nazis during World War II.'b''b''b'IT is often said that Britain and America are two countries divided by a common language. That is also true of Washington and Silicon Valley. The other day, I was interviewing Alan S. Cohen, an expert on networks who has been involved in several successful start-ups. At one point, Cohen began talking about the importance of \xe2\x80\x9ccollaboration\xe2\x80\x9d both within and between firms in Silicon Valley. Then he stopped and said it\xe2\x80\x99s interesting that in Silicon Valley \xe2\x80\x9ccollaboration\xe2\x80\x9d is defined as something you do with another colleague or company to achieve greatness \xe2\x80\x94 something to be praised \xe2\x80\x94 as in: \xe2\x80\x9cThey collaborated on that beautiful piece of software.\xe2\x80\x9d But in Congress \xe2\x80\x9ccollaboration\xe2\x80\x9d means something very different today. It\xe2\x80\x99s the second definition \xe2\x80\x94 collaboration is an act of treason \xe2\x80\x94 'b'something you do when you cross over and vote with the other party'b'. In Silicon Valley, great \xe2\x80\x9ccollaborators\xe2\x80\x9d are prized; in Washington, they are hanged. Said Cohen, who was vice president at Nicira, a networking start-up that recently sold for $1.26 billion: \xe2\x80\x9cIn Washington, when they say \xe2\x80\x98collaborator\xe2\x80\x99 they mean \xe2\x80\x98traitor\xe2\x80\x99; here they mean \xe2\x80\x98colleague.\xe2\x80\x99'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not the only reason, but it\xe2\x80\x99s a big reason that Silicon Valley is thriving more than ever, finding more ways to solve bigger and bigger problems faster, and that Washington is only capable of producing 11th-hour, patched-together, Rube Goldberg compromises, with no due diligence, that produce only suboptimal outcomes to our biggest problems. In Washington today collaboration happens only to avert crises or to give out pork, not to build anything great. That is why if Congress were a start-up, the early-stage investors would have long ago been wiped out and the firm shuttered. Cause of death: an inability of the partners to collaborate. \xe2\x80\x9cPeople in Washington,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cohen, \xe2\x80\x9cforgot that they are developers: \xe2\x80\x98I am on this committee. I have to fix this problem and write some software to do it,\xe2\x80\x99 and that requires collaboration. They have forgotten their job and the customer.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Don\xe2\x80\x99t get me wrong, Silicon Valley is not some knitting circle where everyone happily shares their best ideas. It is the most competitive, dog-eat-dog, I-will-sue-you-if-you-even-think-about-infringing-my-patents innovation hub in the world. In that sense, it is, as politics is and should always be, a clash of ideas. What Silicon Valley is not, though, is 'b'only'b' a clash of ideas.'b'Despite the heated competition, lots of collaboration still happens here for one main reason: to serve the customer the best product or service. One way is through new open-source innovation platforms like GitHub \xe2\x80\x94 a kind of \xe2\x80\x9cWikipedia for programmers\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 where hobbyists, start-ups and big firms share ideas in order to enlist more people (either within a firm in restricted ways or from the outside in a wide open manner) to help improve their software or Web sites.'b'Another way is through \xe2\x80\x9cco-opetition.\xe2\x80\x9d There are many examples here of companies trying to kill each other in one market but working together in another \xe2\x80\x94 to better serve customers. Microsoft Windows runs on Apple Macs because customers wanted it. When Apple Maps failed, Apple asked its users to download Google Maps. Finally, within firms, it is understood that to thrive in today\xe2\x80\x99s market, solve the biggest problems and serve customers, you need to assemble the best minds from anywhere in the world.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you obsess about the customer, you end up defeating your competition as a byproduct,\xe2\x80\x9d said K.R. Sridhar, the founder of Bloom Energy, a fuel-cell company. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you are just obsessed about the competition, you end up killing yourself\xe2\x80\x9d as a byproduct \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cbecause you are not focused on the customer.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The far-right lurch of the G.O.P.\xe2\x80\x99s base has made this problem worse. When President Obama built his health care plan on Mitt Romney\xe2\x80\x99s operating system in Massachusetts, Romney was so focused on coddling his base to beat Obama \xe2\x80\x94 rather than trying to improve Obama\xe2\x80\x99s iteration of Romney\xe2\x80\x99s own design to best serve all the customers \xe2\x80\x94 that Romney disowned his own software. What company would do that?'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSure competition here is sharp-elbowed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Reid Hoffman, a co-founder of LinkedIn. \xe2\x80\x9cBut no one can succeed by themselves. Apple today is totally focused on how it can better work with its [applications] developer community.\xe2\x80\x9d It cannot thrive without them. \xe2\x80\x9cThe only way you can achieve something magnificent is by working with other people,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hoffman. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is lots of co-opetition.\xe2\x80\x9d LinkedIn competes with headhunters and is used by headhunters.'b'With collaboration, one plus one can often turn out to be four, says Jeff Weiner, the C.E.O. of LinkedIn, adding: \xe2\x80\x9cI will always work with you \xe2\x80\x94 if I know we\xe2\x80\x99ll get to four. You can\xe2\x80\x99t build great products alone. And if everyone understood that you can\xe2\x80\x99t build great government alone our country would be in a different place.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Supreme Court this week will consider whether to reverse a troubling 2002 decision that allowed judges greater sentencing power in certain circumstances. For the sake of fairness and consistency, it should overturn that 10-year-old ruling.'b'The question raised in the case to be argued Monday, 'b'Alleyne v. United States'b', is whether a trial judge can increase a defendant\xe2\x80\x99s prison term beyond a mandatory minimum sentence if the facts allowing for the longer sentence were not proved beyond a reasonable doubt.'b'This has been a murky area of sentencing law, made confusing by the Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s contradictory rulings. The justices 'b'ruled'b' in 2000 that any factual determination that allows a sentence to be increased beyond the statutory 'b'maximum'b' must be proved to a jury beyond a reasonable doubt. But in the 2002 case, 'b'Harris v. United States'b', the court said that this principle did not apply if the increase was added to a mandatory 'b'minimum'b'. In that situation, the justices said, a judge could do what a statute directed, \xe2\x80\x9cgive specific weight to certain facts when choosing the sentence,\xe2\x80\x9d without a finding by a jury.'b'In the new case, Allen Alleyne was convicted of robbery and of using or carrying a firearm during the robbery. But the jury acquitted him of brandishing the gun during the robbery. Nevertheless, a judge found \xe2\x80\x94 by a preponderance of the evidence, a lower standard of proof \xe2\x80\x94 that Mr. Alleyne reasonably foresaw that his accomplice would brandish a gun. In addition to a 46-month sentence on the robbery count, the judge increased his sentence by seven years instead of by the minimum sentence of five years for carrying a gun.'b'Because the increased term means a greater deprivation of the defendant\xe2\x80\x99s liberty, the constitutional rights to due process and trial by jury require that a jury determine the facts on which the increase depends.'b'Those rights have been eroded by two major reforms by Congress beginning in the 1980s: the federal sentencing guidelines, which called for specific sentences for specific crimes; and mandatory minimum sentences, which give enormous power to prosecutors to determine sentences through the charges they bring.'b'But since 2005, the Supreme Court has 'b'ruled'b' that the guidelines can only be advisory, because requiring judges to follow them violates a defendant\xe2\x80\x99s Sixth Amendment right to have a jury find the facts as a basis for sentences.'b'By reversing Harris, the court would be bolstering Sixth Amendment rights and restoring a role that the Constitution gives the jury.'b'At the end of last year, just shy of the 11th hour in the fiscal cliff negotiations, President Obama made an offer that included a Republican-backed idea to cut spending by lowering the cost-of-living adjustment for Social Security benefits. The move shocked Congressional Democrats and dismayed Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s liberal base.'b'The offer, however, was rejected by House Republicans who could not stomach the tax increases and other concessions that Mr. Obama demanded as part of the deal. The talks moved on, and when all was said and done, Republicans did not get the lower cost-of-living adjustments (known as COLAs) and Mr. Obama did not get the concessions he had sought.'b'But that is not the end of the story. As the next round of deficit reduction talks gets under way, the administration seems determined to include the COLA cut in any new package of spending reductions. Rather than using the issue as a bargaining ploy, the administration appears to have embraced it as a worthy end in itself.'b'Is it? In a word, no.'b'That is not to say that Social Security should be off the table. There are reforms that are eminently sensible, if only the political will could be found to enact them. But reducing the COLA is not a sound idea now and may never be.'b'At issue is the way inflation is calculated. The administration\xe2\x80\x99s offer in the fiscal cliff talks \xe2\x80\x94 and the approach long advocated by Republicans \xe2\x80\x94 calls for using a new measure of inflation, called the \xe2\x80\x9cchained\xe2\x80\x9d Consumer Price Index, to calculate the COLA.'b'Unlike the gauge of inflation currently in use, the chained index captures the ability of consumers to adjust their spending across categories as relative prices change \xe2\x80\x94 for instance, spending less on fuel as gas prices go up and more on groceries as food prices go down. Such substitution causes the chained C.P.I. to rise more slowly than the current measure, which would result in a lower annual COLA and huge budget savings. The move to a chained C.P.I. would reduce benefits by some $135 billion over 10 years, and far more in later decades because of compounding.'b'The administration and other proponents of switching to a chained C.P.I. contend that it is a technical fix in the interest of greater accuracy, not a benefit cut per se.'b'But that claim does not stand up to scrutiny. The chained index is in many ways a better method of tracking price changes for the broad working population, but there is no compelling evidence that it is better for computing the Social Security COLA.'b'What is known is that elderly households tend to have lower incomes and lower expenditures than younger households, and that more of their purchases are for needs that cannot be met by switching to products and services in unrelated categories. That indicates that they do not have the same flexibility as younger households to respond to price changes while still maintaining their standards of living. And because of the way it is calculated, the chained C.P.I. would also result in delayed upward adjustments in the COLA in times of accelerating inflation. Such delays would translate into real benefit cuts, leaving retirees worse off.'b'If, as the administration says, the aim is to set the COLA in the most accurate way possible, then the obvious approach is to have the Bureau of Labor Statistics develop a statistically rigorous index to track inflation as experienced by retirees. A more informal index from the bureau that looks at the effects of inflation on the elderly shows that the COLA is too low, not too high, in part because of medical costs. But the number of households sampled is too small to be sure.'b'A rigorous index would settle the issue of whether the current COLA adjustments are high, low or about right. The fact that some policy makers are willing, even eager, to move ahead with changing the COLA without having developed a more reliable gauge only feeds the impression that they are trying to get away with an unjustified benefit cut.'b'In the meantime, there are other, well-researched reforms to Social Security that the administration and other policy makers could pursue. For instance, it is well understood that upper-income people live longer than the less affluent. The formula for determining Social Security benefits could be gradually and modestly adjusted to reflect those longer lives, while making the system more progressive and cutting spending. Another sensible reform would be to raise the level of wages currently subject to the Social Security payroll tax, so that it better reflects the income gains of top earners over the past several decades.'b'But prematurely forcing through a COLA cut would be unnecessary and unwise.'b'FOR the textbook definition of not knowing enough to quit while you\xe2\x80\x99re ahead, please turn your attention to Harry Reid, he of the scabrous tongue and rotten temper, a boxer in his youth and a pugilist to this day, throwing mud along with punches and invariably soiling himself.'b'Reid, the Democratic majority leader in the Senate, couldn\xe2\x80\x99t just stand back and relish the recent spectacle of House Republicans making callous fools of themselves by stalling aid to communities walloped by Hurricane Sandy. He wasn\xe2\x80\x99t satisfied that these Republicans were vilified not only in the news media but also by some members of their own tribe, like Peter King and Chris Christie. No, he had to get into the ring himself, and his genius strategy once there was to pit one storm\xe2\x80\x99s victims against another\xe2\x80\x99s, to stage a bout between Atlantic City\xe2\x80\x99s splintered boardwalks and Louisiana\xe2\x80\x99s failed levees. What a titan of meteorological tact.'b'Noting that Congress had provided help after Hurricane Katrina more quickly and generously than after Sandy, Reid said: \xe2\x80\x9cThe people of New Orleans and that area, they were hurt, but nothing in comparison to what happened to the people in New York and New Jersey. Almost one million people have lost their homes. One million people lost their homes. That is homes, that is not people in those homes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Let\xe2\x80\x99s put aside, for the moment, his fleeting difficulty distinguishing a biped with a weak spot for reality TV from a wood, brick or maybe stucco structure in which several bipeds watch TV. Let\xe2\x80\x99s focus instead on his math. The one million figure is easily more than twice the combined tally of domiciles not only destroyed but also damaged in New York, New Jersey 'b'and'b' Connecticut. It\xe2\x80\x99s an invention. And if comparisons are to be made, consider this one: as a result of Katrina, 'b'1,833 people died'b' \xe2\x80\x94 more than nine times as many as died in connection with Sandy. Using the word \xe2\x80\x9cnothing\xe2\x80\x9d anywhere in the vicinity of Katrina defies both belief and decency, and Reid was indeed forced last week to apologize, his effort to shame his Republican foes having brought a full measure of shame to his own doorstep, yet again.'b'Why did he make the effort in the first place? Democrats came out of the 2012 elections looking good, and the country\xe2\x80\x99s changing demographics suggest that they could come out of 2016 and beyond looking even better, especially if Republicans don\xe2\x80\x99t accomplish a pretty thorough image overhaul. And that overhaul isn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly proceeding at a breakneck pace. The perseverance of far-right obstructionists in the House stands in the way, leaving the party in grave trouble. If its foes were smart and humble, they\xe2\x80\x99d do what a sports team with a big lead does. They\xe2\x80\x99d play error-free ball.'b'Not Reid. And not President Obama, whose recent actions have been careless at best and cavalier at worst. There was the gratuitously provocative nomination of Chuck Hagel for defense secretary, followed by the gratuitously insulting invitation of 'b'Louie Giglio'b', a Georgia pastor, to give the inaugural benediction. That plan was abandoned after the revelation of Giglio\xe2\x80\x99s past remarks that homosexuality offends God, that homosexuals yearn to take over society and that a conversion to heterosexuality is the only answer for them. Giglio would have been the second florid homophobe in a row to stand with Obama and a Bible in front of the Capitol \xe2\x80\x94 Rick Warren, in January 2009, was the first \xe2\x80\x94 and while it appears that this double bigotry whammy wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the administration\xe2\x80\x99s intent, it\xe2\x80\x99s an example of vetting so epically sloppy that it gives an observer serious pause about the delicacy with which Obama and his allies, no longer worried about his re-election, are operating.'b'The pick of Hagel underscores that indelicacy. There\xe2\x80\x99s a potent case to be made for his installation as secretary of defense, but there are potent cases for others, and it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to believe that Obama couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have found someone who shared his values and would further his agenda but 'b'wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t'b' be such a guaranteed lightning rod for his Jewish, LGBT and female supporters, all of whom played crucial roles in his November victory.'b'Regarding women, Hagel\xe2\x80\x99s record on reproductive freedom is as conservative as his record on gay rights, and it included his support for a ban on abortions in military hospitals, even for servicewomen prepared to pay for the procedures themselves. What\xe2\x80\x99s more, Obama rolled Hagel out in a cluster of other high-profile nominees (John Brennan, Jack Lew, John Kerry) sure to be noted for their gender uniformity and to rekindle questions about the predominantly 'b'male club of advisers'b' and golf and basketball partners who have the president\xe2\x80\x99s ear. The upset was predictable and avoidable.'b'It has been noted, rightly, that the president put two additional women on the Supreme Court and that his percentage of female appointees is as good as President Bill Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s was. But given the march of time since then, and given the questions raised during his first term about how valued women in the administration felt, and given his drumbeat that he was a champion for women in a way Mitt Romney could never be, shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t he be surpassing Clinton? Going out of his way? There\xe2\x80\x99s a perverse streak of defiance in him, and as donors and even Democratic lawmakers have long complained, gratitude isn\xe2\x80\x99t his strong suit.'b'While Hagel lurched toward his confirmation hearings and Giglio skittered away, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee announced that it was sending each of the 35 Republican freshmen in the House a \xe2\x80\x9ctea party membership card,\xe2\x80\x9d which spelled out their rights to put \xe2\x80\x9cideology over solutions,\xe2\x80\x9d to be horrid to women, to coddle Big Oil and \xe2\x80\x9cto create and/or ignore any national crisis.\xe2\x80\x9d Thus did the Dems turn legitimate gripes into schoolyard taunts that were more likely to inflame G.O.P. freshmen than to bully them into bipartisanship. What, beyond the theater of the gesture, was the point of it?'b'Granted, Republicans had done their own adolescent taunting, calling Democrats lap dogs in the Nancy Pelosi obedience school. But Democrats pride and market themselves as the reasonable adults in the equation, and that\xe2\x80\x99s part of their currency with many voters. Why fritter it away?'b'And why abide the overwrought antics of Reid? He once compared opponents of Obama\xe2\x80\x99s health care reform to enemies of emancipation. He took valid questions about Romney\xe2\x80\x99s low tax bill and spun them into the 'b'unsubstantiated claim'b' that Romney hadn\xe2\x80\x99t paid any taxes for an entire 10-year period. Then he said the burden was on Romney to prove the charge untrue. Good thing our criminal courts don\xe2\x80\x99t work that way.'b'Just before and after the 2012 election, it looked as if Republicans might be successfully burying themselves. All Democrats had to do was hammer the nail in the coffin. But the way they\xe2\x80\x99re behaving, they\xe2\x80\x99ll raise the dead.'b'JUST after Christmas, Poly Prep Country Day School, the venerable Brooklyn institution, settled a lawsuit alleging a more than 40-year cover-up of the predatory pedophilia of its legendary football coach, Philip Foglietta. The terms of the settlement have not been disclosed, but the lawsuit charged that school administrators were repeatedly informed from the 1960s until his forced retirement in 1991 that Mr. Foglietta was sexually abusing boys \xe2\x80\x94 on campus, in his apartment and during trips. Mr. Foglietta, who died in 1998, fondled and raped dozens, if not hundreds, of children.'b'I played, without distinction, on some of the great Poly teams of the 1970s; at least one of my teammates was a plaintiff in the case (there might well be others \xe2\x80\x94 not all plaintiffs were identified by name). The case raises difficult questions for a generation of Poly boys: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat did we know about Coach Phil?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cWho else must have known?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cWhat should we have done?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cWhat can we learn to protect our own kids?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What did we know about Coach Phil? It is difficult to separate what we felt as teenagers from what we have discovered since. We feared and loved him. He was a squat, grizzled bear of a man. Despite having only 300 boys, mainly of marginal talent, Poly beat New York City public high schools many times its size. We used to joke that there were guys on our team who would, if told to do so by Coach, try to tackle the B70 bus, which ran alongside our field. We were small and slow, but relentless.'b'Coach was often a bully. He would hit a player with his own helmet or instruct an offensive lineman who missed a block to hold the ball like a quarterback while the entire defensive line slammed into him. Water breaks in the August miasma of two-a-day practices had to be earned through performance. Kids who had quit the team, he would suggest, deserved to be beaten up. He would talk about the \xe2\x80\x9cfruits\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9chomos\xe2\x80\x9d on the male faculty. He would bark curse words in a strange argot of Italianized English.'b'But when he stopped yelling and his eyes twinkled and he said, \xe2\x80\x9cNice hit,\xe2\x80\x9d you would smile ear to ear. He brought alumni to practice, as well as big-time college and pro players, who appeared to revere him. He coached every summer at Joe Namath (Joe Namath!) football camp. I was desperate to go; my mother wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t let me. I recall returning to Poly years later and Coach\xe2\x80\x99s asking me to come to practice so he could tell the team how I stuck with football despite a lack of skill (I was no longer merely soft), and how my discipline and persistence should be an example to all. It was a peak moment for me, up there with my improbable interception against Horace Mann. Most of us would have said that Phil Foglietta taught us what it meant to be a man, circa 1975 in south Brooklyn.'b'But many of us also knew that Coach Phil showered with the fifth graders. We knew that he hung around the locker room and checked that each of us had thoroughly rinsed off. Most of us knew he invited kids for car rides to Coney Island in his green Chevy Impala and for overnight stays at the apartment he shared with his mother. Most of those kids were young and small, often boys who had lost their fathers. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t bother kids whose fathers were in local politics (my dad was in the State Senate) or allegedly high up in the mob (a couple of Gambino grandsons went to our school). Those boys were never offered a ride in the green Impala.'b'One of the plaintiffs in the lawsuit was the younger brother of a classmate. The brothers\xe2\x80\x99 dad died suddenly in 1970, when my classmate and I were in seventh grade. Both brothers were slight; only the younger one played football. My classmate, Scott Smith, went to Cornell, made a fortune in finance, and is now Poly\xe2\x80\x99s chairman of the board. His younger brother, Philip, never went to college and slid into multiple addictions. According to the lawsuit, he was sexually assaulted hundreds of times.'b'We knew something was going on. We joked with one another about the showers and the car rides. One of my teammates wrote on a Web site created for Coach\xe2\x80\x99s victims, \xe2\x80\x9cHow is it that as a 14-year-old Poly freshman, I just knew that something was very wrong?\xe2\x80\x9d Another former student wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cI am heartbroken that I lacked the wits and guts to comprehend what was happening to classmates, friends, and the guys that followed me.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I am not sure whether we would have known what raping boys entailed. We avoided knowing too much; the urge to repress and avert was overwhelming, not only for the victims but also for the bystanders, who understood that for whatever reason they had been left alone. As far as I know, none of the boys who were abused talked about it to other members of the team. The Poly board chairman has said he learned about the abuse of his brother only last year. Back then, we were uncomfortable and embarrassed, unwilling or unable to make sense of what was highly threatening to teenage boys in the homophobic hothouse of a Brooklyn boys\xe2\x80\x99 school. (Poly Prep went coed in 1977, two years after I graduated.)'b'But there is little doubt that senior administrators were told about the abuse on multiple occasions. The lawsuit recounts specific meetings between boys, their parents, the headmaster and the athletic director. That athletic director, who went on to become dean of students and assistant headmaster, reportedly witnessed abuse in the showers and walked away. In 1991, the headmaster allegedly told one of the victims that Coach was a bitter, sick old man who should be left alone. Coach Phil was powerful, intimidating, successful, not to be trifled with. And so for a quarter-century, he freely abused vulnerable boys, virtually in plain sight.'b'WHAT should we have done? We should have told our parents and teachers and other school officials that Coach was hanging out by the showers and it made us feel weird. Maybe we should have reached out to the boys who were riding off in the Impala and warned them away. We were just kids, of course, but in retrospect our lack of curiosity, our lack of action and our lack of courage were inexcusable.'b'Pedophilia remains endemic, a powerful, difficult-to-treat compulsion. Prosecutions are rare, and victims who come forward years later are often barred from court by inflexible rules. Statutes limiting lawsuits should be altered to recognize that these crimes emerge slowly. Every school should have an investigative protocol available to parents online. There should also be at least one experienced person in every institution to whom incidents can easily be reported on a confidential basis.'b'Sexual abuse of children presents itself in confusing, ambiguous ways, so pedophilia education should be a mandatory part of the curriculum, repeated in elementary, middle and high school, at age-appropriate levels of detail. Abused children need to understand that they have done nothing wrong, that it is safe to come forward.'b'Shame ruined lives at Poly Prep; our great successes of youth have turned to ashes. I am angry at the school for failing to protect so many boys. But I am also ashamed of myself, that I was so intimidated, so desperate for Coach\xe2\x80\x99s approval, so eager to be a boy winning football games, that I failed to be the man I know I should have been.'b'AS both his critics and admirers argue, the nomination of Chuck Hagel as secretary of defense last week tells us something important about Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s approach to foreign policy. But so does the man who was nominated alongside Hagel, to far less controversy and attention: John Brennan, now head of the White House\xe2\x80\x99s counterterrorism efforts, and soon to be the director of the C.I.A.'b'Both men were intimately involved in foreign policy debates during George W. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s administration, but had very different public profiles. As a C.I.A. official, Brennan publicly defended some of Bush\xe2\x80\x99s most controversial counterterrorism policies, including the 'b'\xe2\x80\x9crendition\xe2\x80\x9d of terror suspects'b' for interrogation in foreign countries. As a senator, Hagel was one of the few prominent Republicans to (eventually) turn against the war in Iraq. Now it\xe2\x80\x99s fitting that Obama has nominated them together, because his foreign policy has basically synthesized their respective Bush-era perspectives.'b'Like the once-hawkish Hagel, Obama has largely rejected Bush\xe2\x80\x99s strategic vision of America as the agent of a sweeping transformation of the Middle East, and retreated from the military commitments that this revolutionary vision required. And with this retreat has come a willingness to make substantial cuts in the Pentagon\xe2\x80\x99s budget \xe2\x80\x94 cuts that Hagel will be expected to oversee.'b'But the Brennan nomination crystallizes the ways in which Obama has also cemented and expanded the Bush approach to counterterrorism. Yes, waterboarding is no longer with us, but in its place we have a far-flung 'b'drone campaign'b' \xe2\x80\x94 overseen and defended by Brennan \xe2\x80\x94 that deals death, even to American citizens, on the say-so of the president and a secret administration \xe2\x80\x9cnominations\xe2\x80\x9d process.'b'Meanwhile, the imprimatur of a liberal president means that other controversial Bush-era counterterror policies are more secure than ever. Just last month, for instance, while Congress was embroiled in furious partisan arguments over the fiscal cliff, the practice of warrantless wiretapping was reaffirmed with broad bipartisan support.'b'To the extent that it\xe2\x80\x99s possible to define an \xe2\x80\x9cObama Doctrine,\xe2\x80\x9d then, it\xe2\x80\x99s basically the Hagel-Brennan two-step. Fewer boots on the ground, but lots of drones in the air. Assassination, yes; nation-building, no. An imperial presidency with a less-imperial global footprint.'b'This is a popular combination in a country that\xe2\x80\x99s tired of war but still remembers 9/11 vividly. Indeed, Obama\xe2\x80\x99s foreign policy has been an immense political success: he\xe2\x80\x99s co-opted foreign policy realists, neutralized antiwar Democrats and isolated Republican hawks.'b'This success, in turn, has given him a freer hand to choose appointees who embody his worldview. The left objected, successfully, when Brennan was floated as a possibility for C.I.A. director after Obama\xe2\x80\x99s 2008 victory, but the opposition is likely to be weaker this time around. Hagel\xe2\x80\x99s hawkish opponents have a slightly better chance, mostly because his views on Iran and Israel are more dovish than the White House\xe2\x80\x99s own stated positions. But the campaign against his nomination has often been more desperate than effective, offering tissue-thin charges of anti-Semitism and embarrassingly opportunistic criticisms of Hagel\xe2\x80\x99s record on gay rights.'b'If Hagel does get through, it will be the clearest sign yet that Obama enjoys more trust \xe2\x80\x94 and with it, more latitude \xe2\x80\x94 on foreign policy than any Democrat since Harry Truman. And in many ways he\xe2\x80\x99s earned it: his mix of caution and aggression has thus far avoided major military disasters (an underrated virtue in presidents), prevented major terror attacks and put an end to America\xe2\x80\x99s most infamous foe.'b'But that\xe2\x80\x99s a provisional judgment, contingent on events to come. The Obama way of statecraft has offered a plausible course correction after the debacles of the Bush era, but the ripples from many of his biggest choices \xe2\x80\x94 to leave Iraq outright, to surge and then withdraw in Afghanistan, to intervene more forcefully in Libya than in Syria \xe2\x80\x94 'b'are still spreading'b', and the ultimate success of those policies is still very much in doubt. Likewise with his looming defense cuts, whose wisdom depends entirely on what actually is trimmed.'b'Foreign policy is always a balancing act, in which no ideological system can guarantee success, and no effective action is without cost. The recent careers of the two nominees illustrate this point. Hagel was absolutely right to decide that the Iraq war was a blunder, but he was dead wrong (as was Obama) to then assume that the 2007 surge \xe2\x80\x94 a salvage job, but a brave and necessary one \xe2\x80\x94 would only make the situation worse. The drone campaign that Brennan has overseen has undoubtedly weakened Al Qaeda. But it\xe2\x80\x99s also killed innocents, fed anti-American sentiment and eroded the constraints on executive power in troubling ways.'b'These are not reasons to deny them the chance to serve this president in his second term. But they are reasons to ask them hard questions, and to look carefully for places where Obama\xe2\x80\x99s post-Bush course correction may need to be corrected in its turn.'b'Readers debate how to make Congress less dysfunctional.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'The founding fathers intended that voters should have personal knowledge of the people they sent to govern in Washington. Few of today\xe2\x80\x99s voters really know the candidates; this makes misrepresentation easy and effective, and creates the need for large sums of money for political campaigns, leaving the candidates beholden to those moneyed interests. So, what happened?'b'House districts were supposed to be small. The final act of the Constitutional Convention was to reduce the minimum size of a House district from 40,000 to 30,000. Today the average Congressional district includes 710,000 people, so only a small percentage of the voters have any idea what the candidates are like as people.'b'The founders believed that for a republican form of government to succeed, it should be populated with men of virtue. They also recognized that government quite naturally attracts the power-hungry. So they sought to build safeguards against scoundrels into the system. Over the years we\xe2\x80\x99ve allowed these safety mechanisms to be overridden.'b'The safeguard most easily restored is a return to small House districts. It can be achieved without a constitutional amendment by the simple passage of a bill to reduce the size of Congressional districts to, say, 100,000 people. House membership would increase from 435 \xe2\x80\x94 set by a 1911 law \xe2\x80\x94 to about 3,100.'b'This move has the added benefit of introducing a flow of new faces into Washington. These men and women would owe their seats more to the reputation they enjoyed within their community and less to the half-truths and misinformation put out by slick mass media campaigns paid for by the big-money interests. Surely among them would be the men and women of virtue so necessary to the proper functioning of our republican form of government. And so lacking today.'b'GAIL L. JOHNSON'b' Ewing, N.J., Jan. 7, 2013'b''b''b'The writer is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cTwo Years to Democracy: The 2Y2D Plan.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b''b'Readers React'b''b'While Ms. Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s idea of reducing the size of Congressional districts is intriguing, and would allow us to somewhat shed the yoke of gerrymandering, it is also hopelessly undoable. THOMAS'b' Sawyer, Mich., Jan. 9, 2013'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Like many commentators, Ms. Johnson oversimplifies how the founders of the American republic thought about representation. The anti-Federalist opponents of the Constitution wanted representatives who would show \xe2\x80\x9csympathy\xe2\x80\x9d for the interests of their constituents. Increasing the size of the House of Representatives, up to a point, would be compatible with their views.'b'But the Federalist supporters of the Constitution had a different view. Read James Madison\xe2\x80\x99s or Alexander Hamilton\xe2\x80\x99s writings on representation, for example, and you will find that they emphasize knowledge and deliberation. Madison thought that the House could hold a couple of hundred members. Beyond that, he worried that a continuing increase in size would destroy the possibility of deliberation.'b'Granted, Congress no longer operates in the grand debate manner of the late 18th and 19th centuries. But it still does a great deal of deliberation. How would a House composed of 3,100 members deliberate?'b'Ms. Johnson wants to solve a problem that may not really exist. Most members of the House, even from the safest seats, spend large amounts of time soliciting the views of voters in their districts. Nor has anyone faulted Congress for failing to provide constituent services.'b'The real problem, as virtually every observer notes, has been the measurable increase in the polarization of the parties and, arguably, the obstructionist ethos prevailing among Republicans.'b'Increasing the size of the House would only compound this problem. A much better answer would involve using the redistricting process to make Congressional races more competitive.'b'JACK RAKOVE'b' Stanford, Calif., Jan. 9, 2013'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of history and political science at Stanford University and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cOriginal Meanings,\xe2\x80\x9d which won the 1997 Pulitzer Prize for history.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Doing something about the currently dysfunctional House of Representatives is an excellent idea. Another downside would be that state legislatures would be able to gerrymander districts even more precisely than they do now.'b'Why not go in the opposite direction by doubling the size of districts to an even 1.5 million? It would harder to gerrymander such districts, and it could reverse the trend toward \xe2\x80\x9csafe seats\xe2\x80\x9d since the enlarged districts would include far more diverse populations. Second, that the United States was better governed earlier in our history when House districts were smaller.'b'The first assumption is questionable because of recent gerrymandering, which has made many districts more homogeneous. Indeed, many representatives, particularly Republicans, are so afraid of primary challenges that they dare not go against the orthodoxy their districts demand. If anything there is often too much affinity between constituents and the actions of representatives, restraining members of Congress from taking the risks that legislative leadership demands.'b'The second assumption is faulty because it enshrines the early Republic as the ideal that we should be striving to achieve in the present. It will make it easier for voters, not lobbyists, to know and to communicate with their representatives.'b'JOEL BLACKWELL'b' Corte Madera, Calif., Jan. 9, 2013'b''b''b'The writer is an author and consultant on exercising political power.'b''b''b'The Writer Responds'b''b'All the letter writers agree that the House has become dysfunctional.'b'Reducing the size of Congressional districts to 100,000 is not a prescription for an ideal government; it is a specific plan to make the House more viable within our existing Constitution. Congress and the president can make it happen. The states already have mechanisms to deal with the resulting reapportionment.'b'The alternatives offered by Mr. Thomas and Mr. Wilson \xe2\x80\x94 disbanding the House and term limits \xe2\x80\x94 require a constitutional amendment. JOHNSON'b' Ewing, N.J., Jan. 10, 2013'b''b'Jeffrey Sprecher is the founder and chief executive of 'b'IntercontinentalExchange'b', or ICE, an Atlanta-based operator of futures exchanges, credit markets and clearinghouses. It\xe2\x80\x99s a compendium of a lot of his graffiti work \xe2\x80\x94 outdoor anarchist work \xe2\x80\x94 with some commentary about what the pieces mean and how they ended up where they ended up and whether people painted them out or someone put a velvet rope around them to protect them.'b'I have an affinity toward street artists who are provocateurs and can capture the essence of a controversial topic in a single image. I similarly like the art of 'b'Jean-Michel Basquiat'b', who could also distill a strong statement into a single, graffiti-like image.'b''b'LISTENING'b' I keep the 'b'Shazam app'b' on my iPhone and use it to capture music I hear in the background, like when I\xe2\x80\x99m at a restaurant or a shop or in the car. It\xe2\x80\x99s funny to go back and see this chronological list. I have old cocktail songs from the \xe2\x80\x9950s, new stuff, avant-garde stuff and stuff that is totally uncool. One thing about being the C.E.O. of a public company, you find yourself in a lot of places with a lot of different people all around the world and it\xe2\x80\x99s kind of interesting to be able to take snapshots not only with pictures but also with snippets of music.'b''b'WATCHING'b' I watched 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWedding Crashers\xe2\x80\x9d'b' with my 14-year-old nephew over the holidays. It must have been the 10th time I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen it, but the two of us laughed as if it were the first. But I prefer documentaries and in the last month watched \xe2\x80\x9c'b'King of Kong'b': A Fistful of Quarters,\xe2\x80\x9d about the Guinness record-holder for Donkey Kong, 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBuck,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' about the real-life horse whisperer, and 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Cruise,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' about a Gray Line tour guide. All of them were great.'b''b'FOLLOWING'b' I read about watches on 'b'watchprosite.com'b'; Porsches on 'b'rennlist.org'b'; wines on 'b'cellartracker.com'b'. All three sites delve into the complicated nuances of seemingly simple objects and appeal to the side of me that is an engineer.'b''b'PURCHASING'b' I just bought at Sotheby\xe2\x80\x99s a 1910 'b'barograph'b' (barometer) owned by the recently deceased British watchmaker 'b'George Daniels'b'. He is among the most revered watchmakers in recent history, and I can imagine he relied upon it when quietly and painstakingly building watches in his atelier. Acquiring this old barometer was much less expensive than acquiring one of his watches, which can easily sell for more than $1 million.'b'I own about a dozen unique wristwatches \xe2\x80\x94 unique to somebody who likes watches. I like mechanical watches, the ones you have to wind. I like the process in the morning of standing at my dresser and winding my watch. There\xe2\x80\x99s something romantic and calming about it.'b'SOME of television\xe2\x80\x99s most compelling shows start up again this month \xe2\x80\x94 and thank heaven for that. \xe2\x80\x9cDownton Abbey,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThe Good Wife\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cGirls\xe2\x80\x9d will happily draw viewers \xe2\x80\x94 like me \xe2\x80\x94 back into their characters and their plot-heavy story lines.'b'There is a reason for our attraction to these shows other than that they simply entertain us. \xe2\x80\x9cDownton\xe2\x80\x9d and today\xe2\x80\x99s other quality television series also promise a welcome escape from a muddled, technology-addled existence.'b'By pulling us away from Twitter, texts, e-mails, pointless videos and all the other technological distractions demanding attention, \xe2\x80\x9cHomeland,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cMad Men\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cBreaking Bad\xe2\x80\x9d provide a coherent (albeit sometimes disturbing) refuge from our fragmented lives. I, for one, find a sense of narrative order, however fleeting, from these shows.'b'They provide relief from nonnarrative mobile messages, from different voices nattering away, all at once, on different subjects and the multiple, inconstant jobs that now fill so much of our lives.'b'Today\xe2\x80\x99s shows are qualitatively different from older, sophisticated shows like \xe2\x80\x9cSt. Elsewhere\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cHill Street Blues\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cthirtysomething,\xe2\x80\x9d all of which, though deftly written, were relatively formulaic. A \xe2\x80\x9cHill Street Blues\xe2\x80\x9d episode inevitably ended with a slow cop car chase around the same alley that eventually brought the criminal element to justice.'b'The conflicts presented in \xe2\x80\x9cthirtysomething,\xe2\x80\x9d one of the best shows of the late 1980s and early \xe2\x80\x9990s, were even less remarkable: in one episode, for example, the pretty boomer mom Hope Steadman struggled to find a good-enough nanny for her infant daughter. Story lines sometimes stretched beyond a single episode but, for the most part, dramas were neatly resolved in the allotted time slot. Madcap antics sometimes arose (an \xe2\x80\x9cL.A. Law\xe2\x80\x9d episode involved a member of the ensemble cast in a gorilla suit) but these were incidental to the central action.'b'The high-octane, multilayered story lines that drive today\xe2\x80\x99s best television represent one side of an opposition posed by Lev Manovich, a scholar at the City University of New York Graduate Center: narrative versus database. Database logic (that of the computer archive) tends to lack beginnings or endings, and thematic developments are not necessarily sequential. Professor Manovich has written that the database is simply a collection of individual items in which \xe2\x80\x9cevery item has the same significance as any other.\xe2\x80\x9d One bit of information stands on equal footing with every other bit of information. Information is gathered, without a fixed order.'b'IN the first years of the new century, television seemed to be looking to find a competitive niche for itself in a media world increasingly dominated by the database logic of the Web. \xe2\x80\x9cLost,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cHeroes\xe2\x80\x9d and other shows of this era (and films like \xe2\x80\x9cBabel\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cTraffic\xe2\x80\x9d) offered what I call \xe2\x80\x9chyperlink television\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9chyperlink cinema.\xe2\x80\x9d Their \xe2\x80\x9csideways\xe2\x80\x9d and flashback-laden narratives involved constant cutting back and forth among disparate characters, reflective of an emerging culture of sensory as well as existential multitasking. TV shows, like the rest of the world, started to operate at a frenetic pace.'b'Those shows made sense to Web-savvy audiences alive to the fun of skipping back and forth from one thread to the next, and to random-seeming series of nonlinear sequences directed mostly by whim, taste and mood.'b'Smartphones have helped make our lives so multilayered and cacophonous that only super-narrative television shows like \xe2\x80\x9cBoardwalk Empire\xe2\x80\x9d can offer respite from our everyday \xe2\x80\x9chyperlinked\xe2\x80\x9d reality. My preference for these shows over \xe2\x80\x9chyperlink\xe2\x80\x9d shows suggests that I, along with a large segment of the American viewing public, again want to be captivated by melodrama.'b'DVR, Netflix streaming videos, television series on iTunes and television box sets with commentaries mean we can now watch these high-charged, emotive narratives as we once read novels, in long sittings, without regard for a television network\xe2\x80\x99s schedule. We may well take in whole seasons or at least several episodes at once.'b'These marathons, hilariously mocked in the show \xe2\x80\x9cPortlandia,\xe2\x80\x9d when a couple give up their jobs and friends in order to spend a week watching every episode of the latest TV iteration of \xe2\x80\x9cBattlestar Galactica\xe2\x80\x9d back to back, may actually bespeak a shared hunger for continuing, connected conversation and community. Television shows watched in this fashion provide a kind of through-line that\xe2\x80\x99s missing from most of our lives.'b'Premium cable, with its loosened content restrictions and quality programming, has made possible a period of what the Brandeis University scholar Thomas Doherty called \xe2\x80\x9cArc TV,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cadult-minded serials\xe2\x80\x9d whose story lines unfold \xe2\x80\x9cover the life span of the series\xe2\x80\x9d and whose strongest kinship is to the serialized novel of the 19th century.'b'For many among today\xe2\x80\x99s intelligentsia, television serials like \xe2\x80\x9cHomeland,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBreaking Bad\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cMad Men\xe2\x80\x9d with their continuing fables of Alicia Florrick and Walter White, Don Draper and Carrie Mathison, occupy the cultural position of the Dickens tales that were famously doled out in monthly installments. (Except that spoilers are possible now in a way they were not in the age of Pip or Little Nell.) Narrative shows have become the entertainment of choice. And that\xe2\x80\x99s because stories, not algorithms, give order to our hectic world.'b'WHEN The New York Times called, inquiring if I might pen a few words \xe2\x80\x9cfrom the horse\xe2\x80\x99s mouth\xe2\x80\x9d about hypochondria, I confess I was taken aback. What light could I possibly shed on this type of crackpot behavior since, contrary to popular belief, I am not a hypochondriac but a totally different genus of crackpot?'b'What I am is an alarmist, which is in the same ballpark as the hypochondriac or, should I say, the same emergency room. Still there is a fundamental difference. I don\xe2\x80\x99t experience imaginary maladies \xe2\x80\x94 my maladies are real.'b'What distinguishes my hysteria is that at the appearance of the mildest symptom, let\xe2\x80\x99s say chapped lips, I instantly leap to the conclusion that the chapped lips indicate a brain tumor. Or maybe lung cancer. In one instance I thought it was Mad Cow.'b'The point is, I am always certain I\xe2\x80\x99ve come down with something life threatening. It matters little that few people are ever found dead of chapped lips. Every minor ache or pain sends me to a doctor\xe2\x80\x99s office in need of reassurance that my latest allergy will not require a heart transplant, or that I have misdiagnosed my hives and it\xe2\x80\x99s not possible for a human being to contract elm blight.'b'Unfortunately, my wife bears the brunt of these pathological dramas. Like the time I awoke at 3 a.m. with a spot on my neck that to me clearly had the earmarks of a melanoma. That it turned out to be a hickey was confirmed only later at the hospital after much wailing and gnashing of teeth. Sitting at an ungodly hour in the emergency room where my wife tried to talk me down, I was making my way through the five stages of grief and was up to either \xe2\x80\x9cdenial\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cbargaining\xe2\x80\x9d when a young resident fixed me with a rather supercilious eye and said sarcastically, \xe2\x80\x9cYour hickey is benign.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But why should I live in such constant terror? I take great care of myself. I have a personal trainer who has me up to 50 push-ups a month, and combined with my knee bends and situps, I can now press the 100-pound barbell over my head with only minimal tearing of my stomach wall. I never smoke and I watch what I eat, carefully avoiding any foods that give pleasure. (Basically, I adhere to the Mediterranean diet of olive oil, nuts, figs and goat cheese, and except for the occasional impulse to become a rug salesman, it works.) In addition to yearly physicals I get all available vaccines and inoculations, making me immune to everything from Whipple\xe2\x80\x99s disease to the Andromeda strain.'b'As far as vitamins go, if I take a few with each meal, over time I can usually get in quite a lot before the latest study confirms they\xe2\x80\x99re worthless. Regarding medications, I\xe2\x80\x99m flexible but prudent because while it\xe2\x80\x99s true antibiotics kill bad bacteria, I\xe2\x80\x99m always afraid they\xe2\x80\x99ll kill my good bacteria, not to mention my pheromones, and then I won\xe2\x80\x99t give off any sexual vibes in a crowded elevator.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s also true that when I leave the house to go for a stroll in Central Park or to Starbucks for a latte I might just pick up a quick cardiogram or CT scan prophylactically. My wife calls this nonsense and says that in the end it\xe2\x80\x99s all genetic. My parents both lived to ripe old ages but absolutely refused to pass their genes to me as they believed an inheritance often spoils the child.'b'Even when the results of my yearly checkup show perfect health, how can I relax knowing that the minute I leave the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s office something may start growing in me and, by the time a full year rolls around, my chest X-ray will look like a Jackson Pollock? Incidentally, this relentless preoccupation with health has made me quite the amateur medical expert. Not that I don\xe2\x80\x99t make an occasional mistake \xe2\x80\x94 but what doctor doesn\xe2\x80\x99t? For example, I once convinced a woman who experienced a mild ringing in her ears that she had the flesh-eating bacteria, and another time I pronounced a man dead who had simply dozed off in a chair.'b'But what\xe2\x80\x99s this obsession with personal vulnerability? When I panic over symptoms that require no more than an aspirin or a little calamine lotion, what is it I\xe2\x80\x99m really frightened of? My best guess is dying. I have always had an animal fear of death, a fate I rank second only to having to sit through a rock concert. My wife tries to be consoling about mortality and assures me that death is a natural part of life, and that we all die sooner or later. Oddly this news, whispered into my ear at 3 a.m., causes me to leap screaming from the bed, snap on every light in the house and play my recording of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Stars and Stripes Forever\xe2\x80\x9d at top volume till the sun comes up.'b'I sometimes imagine that death might be more tolerable if I passed away in my sleep, although the reality is, no form of dying is acceptable to me with the possible exception of being kicked to death by a pair of scantily clad cocktail waitresses.'b'Perhaps if I were a religious person, which I am not, although I sometimes do have the intimation that we all may be part of something larger \xe2\x80\x94 like a Ponzi scheme. A great Spanish philosopher wrote that all humans long for \xe2\x80\x9cthe eternal persistence of consciousness.\xe2\x80\x9d Not an easy state to maintain, especially when you\xe2\x80\x99re dining with people who keep talking about their children.'b'And yet, there are worse things than death. Many of them playing at a theater near you. For instance, I would not like to survive a stroke and for the rest of my life talk out of the side of my mouth like a racetrack tout. I would also not like to go into a coma, to lie in a hospital bed where I\xe2\x80\x99m not dead but can\xe2\x80\x99t even blink my eyes and signal the nurse to switch the channel from Fox News. And incidentally, who\xe2\x80\x99s to say the nurse isn\xe2\x80\x99t one of those angel of death crazies who hates to see people suffer and fills my intravenous glucose bag with Exxon regular.'b'Worse than death, too, is to be on life support listening to my loved ones in a heated debate over whether to terminate me and hear my wife say, \xe2\x80\x9cI think we can pull the plug, it\xe2\x80\x99s been 15 minutes and we\xe2\x80\x99ll be late for our dinner reservation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What worries me most is winding up a vegetable \xe2\x80\x94 any vegetable, and that includes corn, which under happier circumstances I rather like. And yet is it really so great to live forever? Sometimes in the news I see features about certain tall people who reside in snow-capped regions where a whole village population lives to 140 or so. Of course all they ever eat is yogurt, and when they finally do die they are not embalmed but pasteurized. And don\xe2\x80\x99t forget these healthy people walk everyplace because try getting a cab in the Himalayas. I mean do I really want to pass my days in some remote place where the main entertainment is seeing which guy in town can lift the ox highest with his bare hands?'b'Summing up, there are two distinct groups, hypochondriacs and alarmists. Both suffer in their own ways, and traits of one group may overlap the other, but whether you\xe2\x80\x99re a hypochondriac or an alarmist, at this point in time, either is probably better than being a Republican.'b'THE odds are good that you haven\xe2\x80\x99t yet given up on your New Year\xe2\x80\x99s resolutions and that one of them is to swear off those expensive cappuccinos and save money for your old age. That\xe2\x80\x99s a typical suggestion from finance gurus, who say we can add thousands of dollars annually to our nest eggs by eliminating such wasteful spending.'b'But deciding to take your lunch to work or to cancel your cable television won\xe2\x80\x99t help nearly as much as you\xe2\x80\x99d think. For all the attention we pay to overspending, we struggle with our personal finances not because we spend too much money on small luxuries but because salaries have stagnated at the same time as the costs of nonluxuries have gone up.'b'Even as the average household net worth plunged 'b'by almost 40 percent'b' between 2007 and 2010, the cost of everything from health care to housing has risen for decades at rates well beyond that of inflation. 'b'Almost half of us'b' are living paycheck to paycheck, barely able to save a penny.'b'In fact, it\xe2\x80\x99s long been known that the majority of bankruptcies result from health issues, job losses and fractured families, something no amount of cutting back can protect against.'b'One of the main reasons we need to borrow money is college loans. Our collective student loan debt is more than $1 trillion, a sum greater than both our credit card debt and our auto loans.'b'The student loan debt problem is basic: college tuitions have increased at more than quadruple the rate of inflation since the 1980s. If you\xe2\x80\x99re a parent, good luck saving for that expense. It\xe2\x80\x99s a primary reason students who borrow money (some two-thirds of all undergraduates) now graduate with 'b'an average of $26,600 of debt'b'. That, in turn, will make it harder for the next generation to save.'b'Those who do manage to save still cannot save as much as they need. According to the Center for Retirement Research at Boston College, the average baby boomer had 'b'$42,000 in his retirement account'b' in 2010. That won\xe2\x80\x99t go far toward meeting an average couple\xe2\x80\x99s future health care costs: $240,000.'b'And while financial planners often advise older people to work longer, how can they when many leave their jobs because of health problems, or are laid off and, as a consequence of their advanced age, are unable to find new employment?'b'We seem to want to believe we can budget-cut our way to financial success, maybe because we view monetary setbacks as shameful, nobody\xe2\x80\x99s fault but our own. The personal finance establishment endorses our self-blaming tendencies. David Bach became famous promulgating the idea that by cutting out the daily Starbucks run, people could retire as millionaires. Dave Ramsey has lauded men and women who \xe2\x80\x9crefused to participate in the recession,\xe2\x80\x9d as if a bad economy is a problem of attitude. Suze Orman told investors who lost money in Bernie Madoff\xe2\x80\x99s infamous scheme that they had \xe2\x80\x9cwalked right into that financial concentration camp,\xe2\x80\x9d suggesting they should have heeded complaints the Securities and Exchange Commission all but ignored.'b'So let me suggest another financial resolution, one that will do more for our future financial outlook than simply forgoing a few consumer goods: talk about money. It\xe2\x80\x99s not shameful. Pick a cause, and resolve to fight for change.'b'TRENTON'b'FIVE years ago, four titans of American foreign policy \xe2\x80\x94 the former secretaries of state George P. Shultz and Henry A. Kissinger, the former defense secretary William J. Perry and the former senator Sam Nunn \xe2\x80\x94 'b'called for'b' \xe2\x80\x9ca world free of 'b'nuclear weapons'b',\xe2\x80\x9d giving new momentum to an idea that had moved from the sidelines of pacifist idealism to the center of foreign policy debate.'b'America\xe2\x80\x99s 76 million baby boomers grew up during the cold war, when a deep fear of nuclear weapons permeated American life, from duck-and-cover school drills to backyard fallout shelters. Then, in the 1980s, President Ronald Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s leadership, combined with immense anti-nuclear demonstrations, led to negotiations with the Soviet Union that drastically reduced the size of the two superpowers\xe2\x80\x99 nuclear arsenals.'b'Sadly, the abolition movement seems stalled. Part of the reason is fear of nuclear weapons in the hands of others: President George W. Bush exploited anxieties over nuclear weapons to justify the 2003 invasion of Iraq; most Republican presidential candidates last year said they would fight a war with Iran rather than allow it to get the bomb.'b'There is also a small group of people who still believe fervently in nuclear weapons. President Obama had to buy passage of the New START treaty with Russia, in 2010, with a promise to spend $185 billion to modernize warheads and delivery systems over 10 years \xe2\x80\x94 revealing that while support for nuclear weapons may not be broad, it runs deep. That support endures because of five widely held myths.'b'The first is the myth that nuclear weapons altered the course of 'b'World War II'b'. Leaving aside the morality of America\xe2\x80\x99s decision to drop atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, new research by the historian Tsuyoshi Hasegawa and other scholars shows that Japan surrendered not because of the atom bomb but because the Soviets renounced neutrality and joined the war. Sixty-six Japanese cities had already been destroyed by conventional weapons \xe2\x80\x94 two more did not make the difference. Attributing surrender to the bomb was also convenient for Japan\xe2\x80\x99s leaders, allowing them to blame defeat on a \xe2\x80\x9cmiracle\xe2\x80\x9d weapon.'b'Second is the myth of \xe2\x80\x9cdecisive destruction.\xe2\x80\x9d Mass destruction doesn\xe2\x80\x99t win wars; killing soldiers does. No war has ever been won simply by killing civilians. The 1941-44 siege of Leningrad didn\xe2\x80\x99t deter Soviet leaders from pressing the fight against Hitler. Nor did the 1945 firebombing of Dresden force Germany to submit. As long as an army has a fighting chance at victory, wars continue. Building ever more destructive weapons simply increases the horror of war, not the certainty of ending it.'b'Third is the myth of reliable nuclear deterrence. Numerous leaders have taken risks and acted aggressively during nuclear crises. In 1962, President John F. Kennedy and his advisers knew that blockading Cuba risked nuclear war; they mentioned the possibility 60 times while debating their options. Yet they went ahead. Nuclear proponents might argue that no cold war crisis ever erupted into nuclear war, so deterrence must work. But they\xe2\x80\x99re moving the goal posts.'b'Originally it was claimed that nuclear weapons would assure success in negotiations, prevent any sort of attack \xe2\x80\x94 conventional or nuclear \xe2\x80\x94 and allow countries to protect their friends with a nuclear umbrella. When the Russians weren\xe2\x80\x99t intimidated during talks after World War II, the claim about negotiations was dropped. When the Yom Kippur War and the Falkland Islands War showed that fighting against nuclear-armed countries was possible, the prevention of conventional war claim was dropped. The nuclear umbrella claim ought to have been dropped at the same time, but there was too much American foreign policy riding on it for anyone to make this argument. After all, if Britain couldn\xe2\x80\x99t deter an attack on its own far-flung islands, how could deterrence prevent attacks on other countries?'b'Fourth is the myth of the long peace: the argument that the absence of nuclear war since 1945 means nuclear weapons have \xe2\x80\x9ckept the peace.\xe2\x80\x9d But we don\xe2\x80\x99t accept proof by absence in any circumstance where there is real risk. We wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t fly an airline that claimed to have invented a device that prevented metal fatigue, proved it by equipping 100 planes with the devices for one year without a single crash, and then suddenly ceased all metal-fatigue inspections and repairs, and decided instead to rely solely on these new devices.'b'The last and most stubborn myth is that of irreversibility. Whenever idealists say that they want to abolish nuclear weapons, so-called realists shake their heads and say, in tones of patient condescension, \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t stuff the nuclear genie back in the bottle.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This is a specious argument. It\xe2\x80\x99s true that no technology is ever disinvented, but technology does fall out of use all the time. (If you don\xe2\x80\x99t believe me, try to get tech support on any electronic device more than three years old.) Devices disappear either because they are displaced by better technology or because they simply weren\xe2\x80\x99t good. The question isn\xe2\x80\x99t whether nuclear weapons can be disinvented, but whether they are useful. And their usefulness is questionable, given that no one has found an occasion to use them in over 67 years.'b'NOT everyone wants nuclear weapons. What most people don\xe2\x80\x99t realize is that 12 countries have either abandoned nuclear programs, dismantled existing weapons, as South Africa did in the early 1990s, or handed them over, as Kazakhstan did after the 1991 breakup of the Soviet Union. By contrast, only nine have nukes today (the United States, Russia, Britain, France, China, India, Israel, Pakistan and North Korea).'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s often assumed that Israel would be the last nation to give up nuclear weapons, given its history and a deep sense of responsibility to protect the Jewish people after the horrors of the Holocaust. But Israel has a powerful conventional military, is allied with the strongest country in the world and its leaders have a keen appreciation of military realities. They understand that nukes pose a greater danger to small countries than large ones. Twenty nuclear weapons used on Israel would do far more overlapping damage than 20 used on Iran.'b'Small nations have always been vulnerable. In a world without nuclear weapons they would preserve themselves as they always have: by forming alliances with the powerful and avoiding antagonizing neighbors.'b'France, not Israel, would most likely be the last country to give up nuclear weapons, which help preserve its image as a world power. In a nuclear-free world, France would just be another middle-size power with great cuisine. The real value of nuclear bombs is as status symbols, not as practical weapons.'b'America and other nuclear powers must pursue the gradual abolition of nuclear weapons, but it will not be easy. Many leaders have little interest in giving up power, real or perceived. Any agreement would have to include stringent inspections and extensive safeguards. It would have to include all current nuclear-armed states in a complicated diplomatic process. But bans on other dangerous but clumsy armaments, like chemical and biological weapons, have been negotiated in the past. These bans \xe2\x80\x94 like laws \xe2\x80\x94 are sometimes broken. But the world is far safer with the bans than it would be without them.'b'As Reagan knew, nuclear weapons make the world more dangerous, not less. Imagine arming a bank guard with dynamite and a lighter and you get a good idea of nuclear weapons\xe2\x80\x99 utility: powerful, but too clumsy to use.'b'Nuclear weapons were born out of fear, nurtured in fear and sustained by fear. They are dinosaurs \xe2\x80\x94 an evolutionary dead end. The trend in warfare today is toward smaller, smarter, more effective precision-guided weapons. Nuclear weapons \xe2\x80\x94 extremely dangerous and not very useful \xe2\x80\x94 are the wave of the past.'b'YOU are the editor of a local newspaper. A reporter on your staff comes to you having obtained (by legal means) one of the following:'b'\xc2\x95 Police records of arrests for drunken driving;'b'\xc2\x95 The personal details of all the employees of local clinics that perform abortions;'b'\xc2\x95 The subscriber list of a survivalist magazine with pronounced racist overtones;'b'\xc2\x95 The names and addresses of food stamp recipients in your community;'b'\xc2\x95 The donors to a group that promotes L.G.B.T. rights;'b'\xc2\x95 The names of husbands accused of infidelity in divorce suits, along with the identities of the alleged lovers;'b'\xc2\x95 Addresses of homes where pit bulls are kept.'b'The reporter proposes to publish the names and home addresses and map them on a large graphic, all part of an article on \xe2\x80\x9cThe [drunks/abortionists/racists/poor/gays/cheats/scary dogs] next door.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Some of these lists might strike you as fair game. (Many community newspapers publish D.U.I. arrests, presumably to shame the accused into driving sober.) Others probably make you uncomfortable or indignant. You might find that the tricky part is articulating why: what is the boundary between a public service and an invasion of privacy?'b'My hypothetical editor\xe2\x80\x99s choice is inspired, of course, by an unhypothetical event: the decision by The Journal News in White Plains to map the names and addresses of 33,614 handgun permit holders in two surrounding counties, for a project called \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The gun owner next door'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d I\xe2\x80\x99ll return to that decision, but the striking thing was the volume and venom of the reader backlash: thousands of comments \xe2\x80\x94 and not only from gun owners \xe2\x80\x94 overwhelmingly outraged, some of them suggesting that Journal News journalists deserved to have their identities stolen, their homes burgled, their children taunted or, predictably, to be shot.'b'When it comes to privacy, we are all hypocrites. We howl when a newspaper publishes public records about personal behavior. At the same time, we are acquiescing in a much more sweeping erosion of our privacy \xe2\x80\x94 government surveillance, corporate data-mining, political microtargeting, hacker invasions \xe2\x80\x94 with no comparable outpouring of protest. As a society we have no coherent view of what information is worth defending and how to defend it.'b'When our privacy is invaded in the name of national security, we \xe2\x80\x94 and our elected representatives, afraid to be thought soft \xe2\x80\x94 generally go along quietly. Our complacency is reinforced by a popular culture that has forsaken Orwell\xe2\x80\x99s nightmares for a benign view of authority. In many of my own guilty-pleasure television favorites \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cThe Wire,\xe2\x80\x9d the British thriller series \xe2\x80\x9cMI-5,\xe2\x80\x9d the Danish original of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Killing,\xe2\x80\x9d the addictive \xe2\x80\x9cHomeland\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 surveillance is what the good guys do, and it saves the day.'b'Meanwhile, as Al Qaeda wanes, our surveillance state continues to grow more intrusive, with woefully little oversight or accountability.'b'Last month Julia Angwin of The Wall Street Journal disclosed that Attorney General Eric Holder had authorized the National Counterterrorism Center to copy and examine pretty much any information the government has collected about you. In the past, the agency couldn\xe2\x80\x99t store information about ordinary Americans unless they were suspects in or party to a specific investigation. Under the new orders, flight records, lists of Americans hosting foreign-exchange students, financial records of people seeking federally backed mortgages, health records of patients at veterans\xe2\x80\x99 hospitals \xe2\x80\x94 pick a database, and this obscure agency has permission to study it for patterns that ostensibly predict terrorist behavior, and to share it with foreign governments, whether or not you are suspected of any wrongdoing. The new rules were subjected to robust official debate \xe2\x80\x94 all behind closed doors.'b'Likewise, while we were all distracted by the dance on the fiscal cliff, the 112th Congress in its final days whisked through a renewal of the law that governs eavesdropping by American intelligence agencies on Americans\xe2\x80\x99 phone calls and e-mail traffic. A couple of senators made modest attempts to hold the eavesdroppers more accountable by, for example, disclosing the number of law-abiding citizens whose communications have been intercepted. Their efforts were voted down.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Obama administration\xe2\x80\x99s position on privacy is basically \xe2\x80\x98Trust us, we\xe2\x80\x99re good guys,\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d said Daniel Solove of George Washington University, whose book \xe2\x80\x9cNothing to Hide\xe2\x80\x9d challenges the myth that law-abiding citizens have nothing to fear from government snooping. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s exactly what Bush said. And it\xe2\x80\x99s also the same thing that any despot says. We shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have to trust.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Rigorous, independent oversight, he added, not only protects against abuses but also helps assure that what we do in the name of security actually works. But it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t happen if we don\xe2\x80\x99t demand it.'b'The government, of course, is not the only \xe2\x80\x94 not even the most aggressive \xe2\x80\x94 invader. You can take your pick of the ways Facebook and Google are monetizing you by serving up your personal profile and browsing habits to advertisers for profit. Some of this feels harmless, or even useful \xe2\x80\x94 why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t my mobile device serve me ads tailored to my interests? But some of it is flat-out creepy. One of the more obnoxious trends is the custom-targeting of that irresistibly vulnerable market, our children.'b'When our personal information is exploited this way, we may grumble, or we may seek the largely false comfort of tweaking our privacy settings, but we feel helpless before the mystifying rush of technology.'b'You would think the one sort of invasion just about everyone deplores was hacking. But even there we are ambivalent. When Rupert Murdoch\xe2\x80\x99s tabloids were caught pillaging the voice mail of celebrities, the public response was muted; when it turned out that they had hacked the phone of a 13-year-old murder victim, the pitchforks and torches came out.'b'Or take the 'b'Steubenville case'b'. In Steubenville, Ohio, authorities charged two members of the high school football team with the repeated rape of a passed-out-drunk 16-year-old, but did not charge the many others who allegedly cheered them on and made videos. So the online activists of Anonymous took it upon themselves to hack into private accounts, recover deleted and incriminating videos, and make them public.'b' Amanda Marcotte 'b'wrestled with the moral dilemma on Slate: \xe2\x80\x9cBy stepping in and holding people accountable, Anonymous stands a very good chance of taking action that actually does something to stop rape. But: This type of online vigilante justice is potentially invading the privacy of or defaming innocent Steubenville residents, and even if everything published is true, there are very serious legal limits to the Anonymous strategy.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As a journalist, I\xe2\x80\x99m more often on the side of the invaders than the invaded. I cherish the freedom to publish. But the freedom to publish includes the freedom 'b'not'b' to publish when the cost outweighs the benefit.'b'Which brings me back to The Journal News and its gun project. I sympathize with the paper\xe2\x80\x99s effort to dramatize the commonplace reality of gun ownership at a time when the subject is so sadly on our minds. I don\xe2\x80\x99t buy the gun owners\xe2\x80\x99 assertion that the disclosure is an invitation to burglars in search of firearms; on the contrary, the publicity sends criminals the same message as those front-door notices of your home alarm system: Try next door. It\xe2\x80\x99s also conceivable that the attention will prompt some owners to lock up unsecured weapons.'b'But when you are going to make a sizable population of law-abiding citizens feel violated, you have to ask yourself, what is the offsetting gain? In this case, I think, not much. The information The Journal News provided its readers is so far from complete as to be misleading. The public records identify only legal handguns. They tell you nothing about the neighbor who has an equally legal and equally lethal rifle or shotgun, let alone an illegal weapon. The publication has not spurred a healthy debate; it has merely escalated a shouting match, and given the N.R.A. a new rallying cry. The outcry may even provoke state legislatures to withdraw gun databases from public records, so they will not be available when they might really be useful. It\xe2\x80\x99s a close call, but I\xe2\x80\x99d have found a different way to make the point.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'The truly incredible two-decade legacy of flawed autopsies and pro-prosecution testimony by Dr. Steven T.
