The boardwalk is always in my thoughts, intermingled with other collective memories of summers in the 1940s and \xe2\x80\x9950s.'b'Although I did not receive my first kiss under the boards, I was pretty close when a boy planted one on my 12-year-old lips while standing in front of the bike rental store just a few steps from the West End ramp.'b'Closer to the East End, there was skeeball to enjoy, \xe2\x80\x9chorse racing games,\xe2\x80\x9d the Capri Theater and those phone-booth-like photo booths, where my girlfriends and I took endless shots, leaning together, with silly grins on our faces.'b'Young military men were often stationed next to each bench, looking out to sea in World War II, to prevent the enemy from coming ashore on Long Island.'b'Most of all, I attribute my love of reading to a boardwalk bench and a view of the beach. Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan who left lasting legacies. He has carefully studied what made those great presidents great. But he can also learn from presidents known primarily for their failures.'b'Consider, for example, James Monroe \xe2\x80\x94 the only person, besides Mr. Obama, to be the third president in a row to be re-elected. His first term, which began in 1817, was known as the Era of Good Feelings because it coincided with the demise of any viable opposition party. When he was re-elected in 1820, he won every electoral vote but one. Yet most Americans know nothing about his presidency except perhaps the Monroe Doctrine, which pledged American intervention to protect the Americas from European interference.'b'Once wildly popular, Monroe is now barely remembered. First, his legislative achievements eroded over time. He signed two of the most important laws of the 19th century: the Missouri Compromise, which admitted Missouri as a slave state and Maine as a free state, and the Tenure of Office Act of 1820, which restricted the terms of certain officials in the executive branch. But subsequent presidents tried to repeal or amend the laws, and the Supreme Court eventually declared both unconstitutional.'b'Second, Monroe had no distinctive constitutional vision. The last member of a \xe2\x80\x9cVirginia dynasty,\xe2\x80\x9d starting with Washington, Jefferson and Madison, he lacked their vision or stature. Even without opposition, Monroe was unsure where to lead the country. His last two years in office were so fractious that they became known as \xe2\x80\x9cthe era of bad feelings.\xe2\x80\x9d His collapse was extraordinary in its speed.'b'Third, Monroe, unlike his predecessor, Madison, had no natural heir. Subsequent presidents, including his successor, John Quincy Adams, who had been his secretary of state, felt little fidelity to his legacy.'b'If Mr. Obama wants to avoid Monroe\xe2\x80\x99s mistakes, he must extend the narrative of his presidency with a view to posterity. He should consider whom he wants to follow him and which of his legislative initiatives Republicans might support. If Mr. Obama doesn\xe2\x80\x99t get involved in the next election or cannot produce significant bipartisan achievements, he risks having his successors belittle or bury his legacy.'b'Grover Cleveland, who also served two terms (though they were not consecutive), is even more forgotten than Monroe. He was the only Democrat elected in the late 19th century and the only president other than Roosevelt to have won a plurality of the popular vote in three consecutive presidential elections. (Benjamin Harrison won the Electoral College in 1888, despite having received fewer votes.)'b'Cleveland is forgotten because he blocked rather than built. He devoted his first term, 1885 to 1889, to vetoing laws that he thought favored special interests. He eventually cast more vetoes than any president except Franklin Roosevelt. In his second term, from 1893 to 1897, the Senate retaliated against his efforts to replace executive officials by stalling hundreds of his nominations. Cleveland successfully appealed to the public to break the impasse with the Senate, but his contempt for Congress took its toll.'b'In his second term, his disdain for Congress, bullying and stubbornness prevented him from any meaningful action to relieve the depression that followed the Panic of 1893. Mr. Obama, whose relations with Congress, even members of his own party, have often been distant, should take heed.'b'Unlike Cleveland, Calvin Coolidge had the vision and rhetoric required for an enduring legacy, but he, too, failed the test of time. Virtually unknown when he became vice president to Warren G. Harding, Coolidge inherited a scandal-ridden administration when Harding died in 1923. He worked with Congress to root out corruption, established regular press briefings and handily won the 1924 election. Over the next four years, he signed the most significant federal disaster relief bill until Hurricane Katrina and the first federal regulation of broadcasting and aviation. He helped enact the Kellogg-Briand Pact, which famously (and unsuccessfully) tried to outlaw war.'b'Coolidge\xe2\x80\x99s vision had wide appeal. His conviction that the business of America is business still resonates among many Republicans, but he squandered his good will with the Republican-led Senate when, shortly after his inauguration in 1925, he insisted on renominating Charles Warren as attorney general after the Senate had rejected his nomination. Coolidge could have easily been elected to a second full term, but he lost interest in politics after his son died in 1924. He did not help his secretary of commerce, Herbert Hoover, win the presidency in 1928 and said nothing as the economy lapsed into the Great Depression. He was widely ridiculed for his penchant for silence. The eventual recognition of the failures of his international initiatives and laissez-faire economic policies destroyed his legacy.'b'A final president whose failures are instructive to Mr. Obama is Jimmy Carter. He is best praised for what he has done since leaving office, but Americans have forgotten that he actually accomplished almost everything he wanted legislatively, including landmark laws on the environment and government ethics. Carter\xe2\x80\x99s failure to communicate a positive vision of his presidency was arguably even more significant in his defeat in the 1980 election than the Iran hostage crisis and the high inflation of the late 1970s.'b'Being re-elected does not ensure Mr. Obama a permanent legacy. His challenge is to frame an inspiring vision that ties together the formidable achievements of his first term \xe2\x80\x94 the health care overhaul, the auto industry rescue, reform of financial regulations, withdrawal from Iraq and Afghanistan and the killing of Osama bin Laden \xe2\x80\x94 \xc2\xa0with goals, still not strongly articulated, for his second. He has to tell a story of his presidency that he wants Americans to remember and not allow others, particularly his detractors, to frame the narrative.'b'In this deeply partisan era, Mr. Obama won\xe2\x80\x99t be able to stand above the fray like Monroe and Coolidge, but he shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t become mired in it, like Cleveland and Carter. He must work with Congress rather than becoming embroiled in battles with it.'b'On several issues, including gay rights and the debt ceiling, Mr. Obama has appeared detached from the political process \xe2\x80\x94 \xc2\xa0 following rather than leading. He has only a few years\xc2\xa0to build on the real achievements of his first term and be remembered as something more than having been the first black president. By examining the failures of predecessors like Monroe, Cleveland, Coolidge and Carter, he can avoid suffering a similar disheartening fate.'b'A FEW years ago, I awoke at 2:30 a.m. to more than a \xe2\x80\x9crapping, rapping at my chamber door.\xe2\x80\x9d It was a full-force pounding of a body trying to break into my little house in Washington, D.C. It was the sound and scenario that, as a single woman living alone, I feared more than spiders in the house.'b'Because I was writing political speeches at the time, my BlackBerry slept on the pillow beside me. I grabbed it and looked out my bedroom window at the stoop below. There he was: tall, dark clothes, big. He backed up and then raced to the door, pounding his body against it. Then he kicked at it the way actors take boots to the heads of bad guys in the movies.'b'I dialed 911 and ran downstairs, my 100-pound Newfoundland with me.'b'I gave the dispatcher my address, let her know that I lived around the corner from a police station and said, \xe2\x80\x9cPlease hurry.\xe2\x80\x9d She heard the loud noise and remained on the line with me.'b'I put the BlackBerry on speaker and pushed a heavy armchair toward the door. I watched as the wood expanded with each pound. The white paint splintered some. The deadbolt held at the top, but the bottom half of the door popped open, letting in the steam heat from the summer night. I took that chair and slammed it so the side pushed the door back in line with the frame. I held that chair with everything my 5 foot 3 inches had. My dog sat right by me on the rug, ready.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe police are outside,\xe2\x80\x9d the dispatcher said.'b'I let go of the chair\xe2\x80\x99s arms and thanked the woman for staying on the phone with me. I answered the questions from the police and looked at the drunk man in the back of the patrol car, kicking at the seats. When they left, I pushed the couch, chair, coffee table and even a lamp in front of the locked door. I did that every night for a week until a steel-gated security door was installed.'b'And then, I did more.'b'I considered buying a gun. The threat of violence rattles you like that. What rolled round my head after that dark morning was: what if I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t heard the noise, what if it\xe2\x80\x99s different next time? While I held that chair with all of my strength, I wished that I had had a gun because if he had gotten in, then I could have pointed it at him, maybe deterred him and if necessary pulled the trigger.'b'So I looked at guns. Some had mother-of-pearl handles and looked like something Mae West would use in a movie. Others were Glocks, shotguns and rifles. The answer is yes \xe2\x80\x94 voluntarily. But because my hospitalization was years earlier and I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in treatment at the time, I could have gotten a gun.'b'My depression appeared for the first time in the late \xe2\x80\x9990s, right before I began writing for politicians. It comes and goes like fog. Medicine can help. I have my tricks to manage and get through it. Sometimes it sticks around for a day or a week, and sometimes it stays away for a couple of years. But it never leads me to sleep all day, cry and wear sweat pants like the people in the commercials. You\xe2\x80\x99d look at me and never know that sometimes my fight against the urge to die is so tough the only way I get through it is second by second; I live by the second hand.'b'According to the 'b'Centers for Disease Control and Prevention'b', 38,364 Americans lost that fight in 2010 and committed suicide; 'b'19,392'b' used a gun. If I had purchased that gun and it had been in my possession, I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure I would have been able to resist and would be here typing these words.'b'The other day, the president and the vice president announced their plans to curb gun violence in the wake of the shooting in Newtown, Conn. I\xe2\x80\x99d been eating like a rabbit, all carrots and greens that I\xe2\x80\x99d gathered, barehanded, from the baskets of the farmer\xe2\x80\x99s market, no gloves or plastic bags allowed. I was effectively a vegan because I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t find meat or cheese that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t wrapped in plastic, and I didn\xe2\x80\x99t have access to accommodating livestock.'b'My 7-year-old daughter and I were participating in a pilot study conducted in 2011 by the Silent Spring Institute and the 'b'Breast Cancer'b' Fund (a 'b'follow-up study'b' was published later that year in the journal Environmental Health Perspectives). We had urinated into some glass containers a few weeks earlier, back when we were \xe2\x80\x9cnormal\xe2\x80\x9d Americans, and now we were spending three days trying to reduce our exposure to plastics before supplying our urine again.'b'We wanted to see what it would take to nudge down our bodies\xe2\x80\x99 levels of a handful of common chemicals with the potential to mimic or disrupt hormones, including phthalates (found in some plastics and added to products like lotions to bind fragrances), triclosan (an antibacterial ingredient in many soaps, toothpastes and cutting boards) and 'b'bisphenol A'b' (or BPA, a plastic-hardener and epoxy additive that may affect children\xe2\x80\x99s brain development and that some believe may be linked to breast and 'b'prostate'b' cancers).'b'Manufacturers have phased BPA out of some products, and last year, the Food and Drug Administration 'b'outlawed its use in baby bottles'b' and sippy cups. This month Suffolk County, N.Y., 'b'banned certain cash register receipts'b' that carry it.'b'Risks aside, the normal phase was a lot more fun. My daughter and I painted our toenails, took floral-scented bubble baths, ate refried beans out of a can and drank a couple of sodas. Go America! For detox, I became an isolated Anxiety Mom. We scrubbed off the nail polish. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t venture far from home because I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t ride in a car (phthalates waft out of plastic interiors) or shop (because of those store receipts). That turned out to be something of a relief, since I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t wear makeup or deodorant. I lost three pounds. It was practically like living in the 19th century, except for my trusty bicycle helmet, which I wore despite the fact that it is a terrific example of the technology BPA makes possible.'b'A 'b'study published in 2010'b' found a very effective way to reduce urinary phthalate levels was to live meatless in a Buddhist temple for five days. A 'b'study'b' recently published in the journal NeuroToxicology found that pregnant women in Old Order Mennonite communities, which eschew many modern conveniences, had urinary BPA levels one-fourth the national median. Those Mennonites eat more fresh food than the rest of us and make their own dairy products, but they also buy fewer consumer goods, which can be additional sources of BPA. The chemical is found in dental fillings, eyeglass lenses and CDs, among other products.'b'In lab-animal studies, BPA has been linked to mammary gland tumors, prostate and urethra problems and cardiac irregularities. The Food and Drug Administration maintains that BPA is safe in low levels, although in 2010 it expressed \xe2\x80\x9c'b'some concern'b' about the potential effects of BPA on the brain, behavior and prostate gland in fetuses, infants and young children.\xe2\x80\x9d And yet, last year\xe2\x80\x99s bottle announcement seemed to be less about protecting infants than about putting confused parents at ease.'b'If anything, it has had the opposite effect. Parents who were worried about exposing their babies to a hormone-mimicking substance are just as worried about exposing their unborn children to it in the womb, or passing it along to newborns through 'b'breast milk'b'. New sippy cups won\xe2\x80\x99t change that.'b'One thing that could is adopting my extreme detox regime. My original BPA level was 5.1 nanograms per\xc2\xa0milliliter of urine, putting me in the upper quartile of Americans. The substance passes in and out of the body quickly, but we are fed it in a daily drip.'b'So is it time to crank up my crank meter and demand that my children step away from the rubber duckie and join a religious sect? It\xe2\x80\x99s why we need the government to require testing of commercial chemicals for hormonal effects, and to regulate them in a meaningful way. And it\xe2\x80\x99s why we need manufacturers to design products with safer substances in the first place.'b'As far as my family is concerned, we can eat only so much quinoa out of a paper bag.'b'This is a month when anyone with a telescope or good binoculars can gaze up at one of the brightest objects in the night sky and revisit a staggering achievement in astronomy: 'b'Galileo\xe2\x80\x99s discovery'b', over several January days in 1610, of Jupiter\xe2\x80\x99s four largest moons.'b'At first, Galileo thought he was seeing stars. But watching them move in relation to Jupiter, he figured out what they really were \xe2\x80\x94 an epiphany that began to upend the given view of the universe. Here was a celestial body with other celestial bodies circling it. For a biblical cosmology that placed Earth at the center of all that moved, the implications would prove devastating.'b'The Morgan Library and Museum in Manhattan has a beautifully preserved relic of that scientific triumph: the scrap of an 'b'envelope'b' on which Galileo, in 1611, tracked the shifting positions of the Jovian moons. He had published his findings about the moons the year before in \xe2\x80\x9cThe Starry Messenger,\xe2\x80\x9d and he was working, night after night, to better define the periods of the moons\xe2\x80\x99 orbits. In his (literally!) back-of-the-envelope jottings and little pictures, one can sense a great mind puzzling out a perplexing story.'b'Galileo\xe2\x80\x99s achievement was the end of geocentrism, but it was hardly the end of ignorance and magical thinking. When obstinacy places reason under siege, as it does to this day \xe2\x80\x94 when fundamentalism defames biological science in the classroom, or the politics of denial prevent action to deal with a changing climate, it helps to recall our debt to a man who set a different example more than 400 years ago. It took just a wooden tube and some polished lenses, a critical and inquisitive mind, and four points of light that didn\xe2\x80\x99t behave the way they were supposed to.'b'When Patricia Durkin was 19, she began having hallucinations. The 'b'University of Texas endowment'b' made a $75 million commitment; the 'b'Regents of the University of California'b' kicked in $40 million; the 'b'University of Missouri endowment'b' was an investor. So were 'b'the Los Angeles Fire and Police Pension'b' system, the 'b'Indiana Public Retirement System'b', and the 'b'Pennsylvania Public School Employees\xe2\x80\x99 Retirement System'b' (which kicked in $400 million). And plenty of others.'b'When I called these investors to ask their rationale for investing in a fund that financed a gun \xe2\x80\x9croll-up,\xe2\x80\x9d as the Cerberus strategy is called, I got three main responses. The first was that the percentage of their investment that went to Freedom Group was minuscule. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have a very small investment in Bushmaster, which translates to about $1 million,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dianne Klein, a spokeswoman for the University of California system. The fact that Feinberg decided to buy companies whose guns have repeatedly been used for mass slaughter was, in effect, his decision to make.'b'The third was that the core duty of a pension fund or university endowment is to maximize returns. Nobody made this point more vehemently than Bruce Zimmerman, a spokesman for the University of Texas Investment Management Company. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have no plans to divest,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe invest strictly on economic considerations, and we do not take into account social and political consideration.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Cerberus never tried to hide what it was doing. And why would it? It was proud of its gun strategy. It held annual meetings with its investors and talked freely about Freedom Group. Investors were also aware that in 2010, 'b'Cerberus had tried'b' (and failed) to take Freedom Group public.'b'But until Newtown, none of the investors gave the business a second\xe2\x80\x99s thought. Aurora, Fort Hood, Wisconsin \xe2\x80\x94 and dozens of other mass slaughters \xe2\x80\x94 came and went, and the investors stuck with Cerberus.'b'Newtown, it is often said, has changed that dynamic, sensitizing the country to the insanity of its gun laws, and giving gun control advocates hope that reform might finally be possible. But with the tragedy barely a month old, you can already feel the pushback. Supporters of the National Rifle Association in Congress are vowing to resist any effort to tighten the nation\xe2\x80\x99s gun laws. Gun-friendly state legislators are pushing absurd laws aimed at pre-empting federal gun legislation. And then there are the investors, who have a unique ability to push companies to change, if they so choose. (Just recall the South African boycott.)'b'What I learned this week is that, Newtown notwithstanding, too many of them have other priorities. Making money is still more important than saving lives.'b'There is nothing the world loves more than an athlete who\xe2\x80\x99s playing the game on behalf of a dying loved one.'b'In the land of sports, people who have terminal illnesses are always more interested in the team\xe2\x80\x99s fortunes than in having their son/brother/lover/best friend at their bedside. The story\xe2\x80\x99s been a staple ever since the expiring Ronald Reagan told Notre Dame to \xe2\x80\x9cwin just one for the Gipper\xe2\x80\x9d in \xe2\x80\x9cKnute Rockne \xe2\x80\x94 All American.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And now we have Manti Te\xe2\x80\x99o, the star linebacker for Notre Dame, whose dying girlfriend turned out to be imaginary. But imaginary with a lot of team spirit. \xe2\x80\x9cBabe, if anything happens to me, you promise that you\xe2\x80\x99ll stay there and you\xe2\x80\x99ll play and you\xe2\x80\x99ll honor me through the way you play,\xe2\x80\x9d she told him when she was critically injured in a car crash, fell into a coma and then emerged to learn she had leukemia. Somebody made her up, and the sports world is currently debating whether Te\xe2\x80\x99o was the victim of a hoax, or part of the conspiracy.'b'All I can say is, the story tells you a lot.'b'Fans cheered when Te\xe2\x80\x99o played through what he said was the day of the funeral of his girlfriend, Lennay Kekua, who died on the same day as his actual grandmother. (\xe2\x80\x9cI knew...that my girlfriend and my family would want me to be out there. They wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t want me to be sulking over things,\xe2\x80\x9d he told Sports Illustrated.)'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s the American way. But as the story unfolded, it turned out that she didn\xe2\x80\x99t 'b'ever'b' require his presence. In an interview with Sports Illustrated, Te\xe2\x80\x99o said that at one point, he was on his way home to Hawaii for summer break when the comatose Lennay almost died in a hospital in California. \xe2\x80\x9cThey were scheduled to pull the plug while I was in the air,\xe2\x80\x9d he told Sports Illustrated.'b'It didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to occur to him that he might have dropped by. Do you think this is a young-man fantasy \xe2\x80\x94 a girlfriend so lacking in neediness that you don\xe2\x80\x99t even have to visit her in the hospital while she\xe2\x80\x99s in a coma followed by leukemia?'b'In fact, there was apparently never any physical connection. They talked on the phone. Texted all the time. But the star linebacker \xe2\x80\x94 who reportedly saw other flesh-and-blood girls on campus \xe2\x80\x94 didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to feel this special romance was lacking anything simply because it had no three-dimensional aspects.'b'Maybe in an era when \xe2\x80\x9cdating\xe2\x80\x9d seems to mean \xe2\x80\x9csend texts about whether to get together later,\xe2\x80\x9d this counts as a fulfilling relationship.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s possible Te\xe2\x80\x99o was the credulous victim of an elaborate trick. But he was surrounded by a veritable army of coaches, chaplains and mentors, who were presumably privy to the Lennay saga from the start. Certainly they knew all about it when the Notre Dame publicity machine made it a core part of the football team\xe2\x80\x99s undefeated-until-the-championship-game season. But nobody seemed to raise an eyebrow.'b'If you listened to the story while sitting next to Te\xe2\x80\x99o on a 'b'bus'b', you would have warned him not to tell a national TV audience about this girlfriend until he got some proof she actually existed. (\xe2\x80\x9cWe met just, ummmm, just she knew my cousin. And kind of saw me there so. Just kind of regular,\xe2\x80\x9d he told Sports Illustrated.)'b'But nobody at Notre Dame seems to have paid enough attention to figure out that the girl at the center of their winning-season story existed in the same universe as the Little Mermaid.'b'Right after Christmas, Te\xe2\x80\x99o told his coach that a woman who sounded like the dead girlfriend had called him to say she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t deceased after all. The coach told the higher ups, and Notre Dame hired an outside firm to investigate the case. When an expos\xc3\xa9 broke on the Web site Deadspin, the school\xe2\x80\x99s athletic director, Jack Swarbrick, held a press conference to tearfully announce that the investigation showed that Te\xe2\x80\x99o was the victim of a \xe2\x80\x9cvery elaborate, sophisticated hoax perpetrated for reasons we can\xe2\x80\x99t fully understand. But it had a cruelty at its core.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This all occurred a couple of years after the Notre Dame team was involved in a genuine tragedy when a freshman from a neighboring girls\xe2\x80\x99 college reported she had been sexually assaulted by a football player. The school did not order up an outside investigation. In fact, there appeared to be no investigation at all. After a period of dead silence in which she received a threatening text from a friend of the player, the girl died from an overdose of medication. Nothing else happened. Writing this week in The Washington Post, Melinda Henneberger, a Notre Dame graduate, noted that \xe2\x80\x9cmy alma mater held the kind of emotional news conference for the fake dead girl they never held for the real one, Lizzy Seeberg.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Game\xe2\x80\x99s over. Notre Dame loses.'b'IN the first three weeks or so of trading this year, the Standard &amp; Poor\xe2\x80\x99s 500-stock index, a measure of the broad market, has climbed more than 4 percent \xe2\x80\x94 and on Jan. 18, in fact, closed at its 'b'highest level'b' since December 2007. Last January, the S.&amp;P. 500 rose 4.4 percent \xe2\x80\x94 a blistering pace that, if kept up for the rest of 2012, would have translated into a compound annual return of nearly 67 percent. (Alas, it did not.) January 2011 was also a hot one for stocks, its monthly return translating into an annualized gain of 31 percent.'b'Mention such returns to the average Wall Street type and you\xe2\x80\x99re likely to get a yawn. Going back to the 1920s, after all, the first month of the year has, with striking regularity, been a great time to invest \xe2\x80\x94 a phenomenon known, fittingly, as \xe2\x80\x9cthe 'b'January Effect'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'First discussed in a 'b'1942'b' article by the investment banker Sidney B. Wachtel, this celebrated winter anomaly has two components: the stock market tends to do well over all in January, and small-company shares typically outperform large stocks. For the rest of the year, the latter trend often reverses, and big stocks beat the small fry.'b'Why exactly the January Effect persists is a mystery \xe2\x80\x94 in an efficient market, such calendar-driven bonanzas aren\xe2\x80\x99t supposed to happen.'b'Some believe the phenomenon is a result of tax-loss selling: investors dump their loser stocks in December to recognize a capital loss and then buy them back in January, pushing up share prices. Others say it\xe2\x80\x99s because of institutional money managers, who shed their weakest-performing or riskiest-looking small stocks before Dec. 31 so that their reported year-end holdings look better to clients. Like the tax-loss sellers, these \xe2\x80\x9cwindow dressers\xe2\x80\x9d return to buying when the calendar turns anew.'b'But what if the January Effect has a more fundamental cause \xe2\x80\x94 one that ties directly to human nature?'b'In a 'b'paper'b' published in The Journal of Behavioral Finance in 2011, I proposed that this most famous of regular irregularities in the stock market was attributable to our strong inclination to be optimistic at the turn of the year. Investors, exhibiting the same flash of wishful thinking exuded by any New Year\xe2\x80\x99s resolution maker, take a flier on those little stocks that \xe2\x80\x9chave great potential.\xe2\x80\x9d Then, as the hopefulness fades over the year, the January could-bes fall back into might-have-beens, typically doing a little worse than the market as a whole.'b'For an experiment that might test this hypothesis, I gathered a portfolio of stocks particularly susceptible to optimism \xe2\x80\x94 those for which Wall Street analysts had sharply varying opinions regarding their prospects, with some analysts wildly upbeat in their assessments and others quite pessimistic. I argued that in January, share prices would reflect the optimistic view rather than the gloomy one and that in the rest of the year the opposite would occur \xe2\x80\x94 a pattern that monthly stock returns later bore out.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s more, recent research on the brain suggests that some human beings are hard-wired for such optimism. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, the neuroscientist 'b'Tali Sharot'b', at University College London, and her team have been 'b'studying'b' communication between the brain\xe2\x80\x99s frontal cortex and subcortical regions deep in the brain; inveterate optimists, it seems, tend to have stronger communication links between these areas.'b'Whether or not this brain cross-talk spikes in January is an open question \xe2\x80\x94 as is another major piece of the puzzle: Why doesn\xe2\x80\x99t the January Effect disappear in anticipation of the January Effect, as investors try to take advantage of what\xe2\x80\x99s coming? I believe that the \xe2\x80\x9cfalse hope syndrome,\xe2\x80\x9d a notion that has been explored by the psychologists 'b'Janet Polivy'b' and 'b'C. Peter Herman'b', may account for some of the reason.'b'The theory is that people are optimistic at the turn of the year and often make idealistic resolutions: lose 50 pounds, write that novel, cut down the binge spending or make a windfall in the stock market. As the year progresses, they fall short of their goals and eventually forget or give up. But come next January, the goals are back, starting the cycle of failure and renewed effort all over again.'b'Looking further into brain activity, Dr. Sharot and her team may have found why false hopes exist neurologically. They contend that unrealistic optimism is a pervasive human trait. Evaluating how this 'b'optimism is maintained'b' in the face of information that challenges it, they found that desirable information was encoded in a different part of the brain than undesirable information.'b'Optimists and pessimists both process desirable information effectively, but the brain neurons of extreme optimists do not effectively encode undesirable information. This reduced ability to remember disappointments is probably an advantage for many people \xe2\x80\x94 like professional athletes, who need confidence after tough losses. But for investors looking for long-term winners at the start of the year, it\xe2\x80\x99s best to give yourself a gut check before you buy.'b'HEGEL once wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat experience and history teaches us is that people and governments have never learned anything from history.\xe2\x80\x9d Actually, I think people do learn. The problem is that they forget \xe2\x80\x94 sometimes amazingly quickly. That seems to be happening today, even though recovery from the economic debacle of 2008-9 is far from complete.'b'Evidence of this forgetting is everywhere. The public has lost interest in the causes of the crisis; many, of course, are just struggling to get by. Unrepentant financiers whine about \xe2\x80\x9cexcessive\xe2\x80\x9d regulation and pay lobbyists to battle every step toward reform. Conservatives bemoan \xe2\x80\x9cbig government\xe2\x80\x9d and yearn to return to laissez-faire deregulation. Higher international standards for bank capital and liquidity have been delayed. I could go on.'b'Instead, let me try to encapsulate what we must remember about the financial crisis into 10 financial commandments, all of which were brazenly violated in the years leading up to the crisis.'b''b'1. Remember That People Forget'b''b'Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner lamented last year that before the crisis, \xe2\x80\x9cThere was no memory of extreme crisis, no memory of what can happen when a nation allows huge amounts of risk to build up.\xe2\x80\x9d He was right. As the renegade economist Hyman Minsky knew, it is normal for speculative markets to go to extremes. A key reason, Minsky believed, is that, unlike elephants, people forget. When the good times roll, investors expect them to roll indefinitely. When bubbles burst, they are always surprised.'b''b'2. Do Not Rely on Self-Regulation'b''b'Self-regulation of financial markets is a cruel oxymoron. We need zookeepers to watch over the animals. The government must not outsource this function to \xe2\x80\x9cmarket discipline\xe2\x80\x9d (another oxymoron) or to for-profit companies like credit-rating agencies. The Dodd-Frank Act of 2010 isn\xe2\x80\x99t perfect, but it has the potential to change regulation for the better. But most of its reforms are still being phased in, and as the rules are being drafted, the industry (here and abroad) is fighting them tooth and nail and often prevailing.'b''b'3. Honor Thy Shareholders'b''b'Boards of public corporations are supposed to protect the interests of shareholders, partly by monitoring the behavior of top executives, who are employees, not emperors. In the years before the crisis, too many directors forgot those responsibilities, and both their companies and the broader public suffered from the malign neglect. Will they now remember? Some will \xe2\x80\x94 for a while. But sanctions on directors for poor performance are minimal.'b''b'4. Elevate Risk Management'b''b'One bitter lesson of the crisis is that, when it comes to risk taking, what you don\xe2\x80\x99t know can hurt you. Too many C.E.O.\xe2\x80\x99s let their subordinates ride roughshod over risk managers, tipping the balance toward greed and away from fear. The primary responsibility for keeping risk-management systems up to snuff rests with top executives and boards of directors. But the Federal Reserve and other regulators are now watching and mustn\xe2\x80\x99t let up.'b''b'5. Use Less Leverage'b''b'Excessive leverage \xe2\x80\x94 otherwise known as over-borrowing \xe2\x80\x94 was one of the chief foundations of the house of cards that collapsed so violently in 2008. Overpaid investment \xe2\x80\x9cgeniuses\xe2\x80\x9d used leverage to manufacture extraordinary returns out of ordinary investments. Bankers and investors (not to mention home buyers) deluded themselves into thinking they could earn high returns without assuming big risks. But leverage is like alcohol: a little bit has health benefits, but too much can kill you. The banks\xe2\x80\x99 near-death experiences, plus preparation for higher capital requirements to come, are temporarily keeping them sober. But watch for the binge drinking to return.'b''b'6. Keep It Simple, Stupid'b''b'Modern finance profits from complexity, because befuddled customers are more profitable ones. But do all those fancy financial instruments actually do the economy any good? Paul A. Volcker, the former Fed chairman, once said the A.T.M. was the only beneficial financial innovation in the recent past. He may have exaggerated, but he had a point. Who needs credit default swaps on collateralized debt obligations, and other such concoctions?'b''b'7. Standardize Derivatives and Trade Them on Exchanges'b''b'Derivatives acquired a bad name in the crisis. But if they are straightforward, transparent, well collateralized, traded in liquid markets by well-capitalized counterparties and sensibly regulated, derivatives can help investors hedge risks. It is the customized, opaque, \xe2\x80\x9cover the counter\xe2\x80\x9d derivatives that are the most dangerous \xe2\x80\x94 and the ones more likely to serve the interests of the dealers than their customers. Dodd-Frank pushed some derivatives toward greater standardization and transparent trading on exchanges, but not enough. The industry is pushing to keep more derivatives trading out of the sunshine.'b''b'8. Keep Things on the Balance Sheet'b''b'Before the crisis, some banks took important financial activities off their balance sheets to hide how much leverage they had. But the joke was on them. The crisis revealed that some chief executives were only dimly aware of the off-balance-sheet entities their banks held. These \xe2\x80\x9cmasters of the universe\xe2\x80\x9d hadn\xe2\x80\x99t mastered their own books. Dodd-Frank specifies that \xe2\x80\x9ccapital requirements shall take into account any off-balance-sheet activities of the company.\xe2\x80\x9d That\xe2\x80\x99s a welcome step toward making off-balance-sheet entities safe and rare. Now regulators must make the rule work.'b''b'9. Fix Perverse Compensation 'b''b'Offering traders monumental rewards for success, but a mere slap on the wrist for failure, encourages them to take excessive risks. Chief executives and corporate directors should \xe2\x80\x9cclaw back\xe2\x80\x9d pay when putative gains turn into losses. If they don\xe2\x80\x99t, we may need the heavy hand of government to do it.'b''b'10. Watch Out for Consumers'b''b'The meek won\xe2\x80\x99t inherit their fair share of the earth if they are constantly being fleeced. What we learned in the crisis is that failure to protect unsophisticated consumers from financial predators can undermine the whole economy. That surprising lesson mustn\xe2\x80\x99t be forgotten. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau should institutionalize it.'b'Mark Twain is said to have quipped that while history doesn\xe2\x80\x99t repeat itself, it does rhyme. There will be financial crises in the future, and the next one won\xe2\x80\x99t be a carbon copy of the last. Neither, however, will it be so different that these commandments won\xe2\x80\x99t apply. Financial history does rhyme, but we\xe2\x80\x99re already forgetting the meter.'b'AS President Obama prepares to deliver his second Inaugural Address, beware: second inaugurals have not fared well in American history. First inaugurals have provided many memorable lines. Franklin D. Roosevelt, taking office in the riptide of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s greatest depression, asserted, \xe2\x80\x9cThe only thing we have to fear is fear itself.\xe2\x80\x9d John F. Kennedy told Americans, \xe2\x80\x9cAsk not what your country can do for you \xe2\x80\x94 ask what you can do for your country.\xe2\x80\x9d By contrast, the words of second inaugurals have largely slipped from memory.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s one important exception \xe2\x80\x94 the second inaugural of Abraham Lincoln, delivered on March 4, 1865.'b'Why have second inaugurals fared poorly, and why did Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s succeed?'b'To begin with, second inaugural addresses are almost always too long. Jefferson, Madison, Monroe, Jackson, Grant, Reagan, Clinton and Bush II all gave second addresses longer than their first. Lincoln understood that less is more. He spoke only 701 words.'b'Second, one word typically dominates second inaugural addresses \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cI,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x9d! Re-elected presidents like to personalize second inaugurals \xe2\x80\x94 believing they have more of a mandate than they did the first time around.'b'By contrast, Lincoln disappeared in his second inaugural. The speech contains the word \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x9d only once. Lincoln was pointing beyond himself to the future of the American democratic experiment, \xe2\x80\x9cto do all which may achieve and cherish a just, and a lasting peace, among ourselves; and with all nations.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Third, second inaugural addresses are often too predictable. Audiences come expecting to hear about second-term agendas. Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s audience expected him to answer key questions. Would the Confederate States of America be treated as a conquered nation? How should one distinguish the guilty from the innocent?'b'But maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s a bad idea to give an audience too much satisfaction. Lincoln decided not to address any of these questions. If his listeners expected a triumphalist address heralding a victorious North, they were instead asked to help initiate a new era of reconciliation \xe2\x80\x94 one marked \xe2\x80\x9cwith malice toward none, with charity toward all.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'LINCOLN also surprised his audience by steeping his address in religious language. In those 701 words he mentioned God 14 times, referenced the Bible 4 times and emphasized the importance of prayer 3 times. The point is not to count but to listen to the way he invoked religion as a balm for a nation deeply divided.'b'Lincoln, so knowledgeable of the Constitution, understood that even though the founders separated church and state, America has never separated religion and politics. Lincoln is instructive in how religion can become inclusive. \xe2\x80\x9cBoth read the same Bible, and pray to the same God,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, telling an audience angry at the deaths of so many sons that the South read the Bible as much as the North.'b'Lincoln made a final move that also set himself apart. Inaugural addresses can be exercises in self-congratulation, both of the candidate and the nation. In his second Inaugural Address Lincoln, quoting Matthew 18:7, lovingly scolded America. \xe2\x80\x9cWoe unto the world because of offenses,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. Lincoln dared to declare there was something evil at the core of this great nation: \xe2\x80\x9cIf we shall suppose that American Slavery is one of those offenses.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This year\xe2\x80\x99s audience will expect Mr. Obama to detail his priorities for the next four years, from fixing the economy to reforming immigration to curbing gun violence.'b'Maybe, like Lincoln, he should surprise his audience.'b'At the service in Newtown, Conn., we heard a president sure-footed in invoking faith as an antidote and using Scripture not as a mere illustration but as the core of his argument. Many have wondered why this side of the president remained veiled during his first four years. This summer, one of the president\xe2\x80\x99s spiritual advisers told me that the president did not want to politicize religion. I respect that answer. But his fellow citizens would welcome the spirit of the man we heard in Connecticut, who called for deep healing, not only for the grieving parents, but also for a hurting nation.'b'Daniel Day-Lewis\xe2\x80\x99s riveting portrayal of our 16th president in the movie \xe2\x80\x9cLincoln\xe2\x80\x9d has meant that our most eloquent president has emerged once again in our national dialogue. No president has come into office with a surer grasp of Lincoln than Barack Obama. He knows Lincoln continually surprised those closest to him. What the nation needs on Jan. 21 is not a lawyerly, rational address on the issues facing our nation but a president ready to share his heart. And daring to tell us how we must change.'b'IF you are in psychotherapy, there\xe2\x80\x99s a good chance your therapist knows more about your inner thoughts and secret desires than anyone else.'b'So, if you\xe2\x80\x99re looking for a mate, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t your therapist be a more reliable matchmaker than 'b'eHarmony'b' and 'b'Match.com'b' and other sites that rely on impersonal algorithms?'b'The idea that therapists might play Cupid with patients tantalizes patients and therapists. An anecdotal survey of my psychiatrist colleagues suggests that the matchmaking impulse is very common.'b'A senior colleague, for example, tells me he was treating a young man who was struggling to find a partner. My colleague said he knew someone who was perfect for his patient and wanted to set them up on a date, but didn\xe2\x80\x99t because he was afraid \xe2\x80\x94 there were too many ways even the most well-intentioned therapist fix-up could go wrong.'b'Why? Psychotherapy, especially insight-oriented therapy, is designed to conjure intense feelings \xe2\x80\x94 on the part of the patient and therapist. Much of what patients feel toward their therapists, the so-called transference, are unconscious feelings that are redirected from important early figures in their lives \xe2\x80\x94 parents, family members and teachers. Your therapist mirrors this phenomenon with his own countertransference.'b'One of psychotherapy\xe2\x80\x99s aims is to use the patient-therapist relationship to better understand the patient\xe2\x80\x99s relationships with others and to remedy problems in the little lab that is the therapeutic connection.'b'Both parties are under constant temptation to act on their unconscious feelings, rather than analyze and understand them. No matter how smart or experienced the therapist, it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to follow those feelings and get your patient \xe2\x80\x94 and possibly yourself \xe2\x80\x94 in trouble. Strict boundaries between personal and professional behavior are meant to insure against such hazards.'b'But temptation lurks. I\xe2\x80\x99ve had matchmaker fantasies myself. A patient of mine, who was divorced, told me she was reluctant to enter the online dating scene. It felt overwhelming, she said, and it seemed improbable that she would meet a plausible mate.'b'An old friend and colleague of mine lost his wife to cancer some years ago and I knew \xe2\x80\x94 or thought I knew \xe2\x80\x94 that he would hit it off with my patient. I began to wonder how I could discreetly bring them together. Could I invite him for dinner and tell him to meet me in the waiting area outside my office around the time of her appointment? Too chancy. Too obvious.'b'I thought maybe I should just ask my patient if she would like to meet my friend. That would involve crossing useful boundaries. And would bring my personal life in conflict with my job as therapist, which, among other things, is to help patients understand themselves and discover how to make their own lives as full and rich as possible. I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t find partners for my patient any more than I should cook her dinner: both are skills she has to develop for herself.'b'Additionally (and why was I thinking this through so fully?) she might feel coerced into something she really didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to do. A therapeutic relationship is by definition unequal; therapists have considerable power, and patients want to please their therapists. My patient might be reluctant to decline.'b'Worse yet, what if the date went badly? My patient might wonder whether I really understood her at all or whether I was setting her up as a kind of test.'b'A colleague told me that when she was in training, her boss, a senior psychiatrist, suggested that she go on a date with one of his patients. She thought it odd, but being curious and open-minded, she agreed.'b'They went out for drinks, she said, and her date spent the evening pumping her for information about her boss. My colleague\xe2\x80\x99s date seemed less interested in her than in learning more about his therapist.'b'My colleague later realized that her boss, who was married, had a crush on her. \xc2\xa0She thinks he set up the match so that he might vicariously enjoy the experience of dating her. True or not, it seems the therapist may not have been acting in his patient\xe2\x80\x99s best interest.'b'Freud himself dabbled in therapeutic matchmaking and in fact went so far as to encourage one of his patients to leave his wife and pursue another woman. At Freud\xe2\x80\x99s urging, Horace Frink, a psychiatrist Freud analyzed and later nominated to head the New York Psychoanalytic Society, divorced his wife and married Angelika Bijur, one of Dr. Frink\xe2\x80\x99s own patients.'b'Whatever else Freud had in mind, it seems he may have had personal and financial motives for the union between Dr. Frink and Ms. Bijur, who happened to be a wealthy heiress. In a letter to Dr. Frink, Freud said of the proposed marriage, \xe2\x80\x9cIf matters turn out all right, let us change this imaginary gift into a real contribution to the Psychoanalytic Funds.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A marriage arranged \xe2\x80\x94 and sanctified \xe2\x80\x94 by Freud himself! That\xe2\x80\x99s a proposition hard to defy. Alas, Dr. Frink experienced depression and psychosis soon after the marriage and divorced Ms. Bijur a few years later. Today such psychiatric meddling would be likely to create a public scandal and a malpractice suit.'b'PRAGMATIC psychotherapists continue to wrestle with questions involved in patient fix-ups. The psychologist Clifford N. Lazarus, for example, argues that therapists are in a good position to evaluate personality traits that could make or break a match, and with high-functioning patients, it is ethical to give it a try. He suggests that therapists use informed consent, the same way a psychiatrist discusses the pros and cons of an antidepressant medication before starting treatment. The idea is to inform the patient of the potential benefits (could be a good match) and hazards (rejection; hard feelings toward your therapist, with the potential to wreck the therapeutic relationship) and receive consent. Case closed.'b'Not quite. This approach skirts the untidy fact of transference and countertransference \xe2\x80\x94 the matching sets of powerful and unconscious feelings that patients and therapists have toward each other. You might get your patient to \xe2\x80\x9cagree\xe2\x80\x9d to any number of contingencies, but there is no bargaining with his unconscious.'b'The fact is that consent, no matter how well-informed \xe2\x80\x94 or well-intentioned \xe2\x80\x94 is insufficient to protect against the possible mischief inherent in therapist-driven matchmaking.'b'Looking to your therapist to set up a date is as ill-advised as it is to look to Match.com for help with depression or an eating disorder. Therapists would be wise to leave matchmaking to Cupid, or his online minions.'b'Readers discuss how to make workplaces more family-friendly.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'The United States lags behind most of the world\xe2\x80\x99s developed nations in rankings of the best places for mothers, especially working mothers. One reason is that the careers of many Americans demand schedules incompatible with the requirements of parenthood. Having no available middle ground, some primary caregivers (mostly mothers) leave their careers. If they do later return, they nearly always do so at salaries and positions well behind peers who did not interrupt their careers.'b'This problem can\xe2\x80\x99t be remedied simply by extending maternity and paternity leaves. Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and France have shown us a solution. By law, employers there cannot unreasonably refuse an employee\xe2\x80\x99s request for a part-time or nonstandard schedule. Employers in Britain must \xe2\x80\x9cseriously consider\xe2\x80\x9d such requests, and not discriminate against those who ask. As their needs change, employees can also seek to return to full time.'b'Legislation modeled after the modest British law and introduced six years ago by Representative Carolyn Maloney, with co-sponsorship by Senators Barack Obama, Edward M. Kennedy and Hillary Rodham Clinton, is stalled in Congress. By increasing access to part-time schedules, the 'b'Working Families Flexibility Act'b' would end or diminish the practice of assigning less important work to part-time workers and lessen their career stigma. Full-time workers taking reduced schedules might create jobs for those unemployed.'b'Workplace flexibility is not just for the benefit of parents. Significant numbers of men and women would gladly reduce their hours and pay to have more time for other pursuits. (Improving the circumstances of unskilled workers involuntarily on unpredictable part-time schedules is an important but different concern.)'b'More than a century ago, the labor movement introduced the then radical 40-hour workweek and the vacation to improve Americans\xe2\x80\x99 lives. Passage of the Working Families Flexibility Act by Congress would be another important step.'b'ROBERT WARING'b' Redwood City, Calif., Jan. 14, 2013'b''b''b'The writer is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cUpside Down: The Paradoxes of Gender in the Twenty-First Century.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b''b'Readers React'b''b'As a scholar who has studied the economics of work and family for more than 40 years, I applaud Mr. Waring\xe2\x80\x99s suggestion that Congress once again take up (and this time pass) the Working Families Flexibility Act.'b'But we need to recognize that as things stand now, taking advantage of flexible work arrangements is often a double-edged sword. Because of the stigma associated with part-time employment (allegations that those who work part time are not seriously committed to their jobs and therefore don\xe2\x80\x99t deserve serious consideration for promotion), employees who take a part-time option often suffer later when they wish to resume full-time work and move up in their organization.'b'We see this stigma operating in exactly those countries that Mr. Waring cites as being leaders in offering work-family flexibility, because those countries generally have less economic opportunity for women and fewer women in leadership positions.'b'Legislation by itself cannot remove the stigma of part-time work. Only organizations and the people who make promotion decisions can do that. Organizations could benefit by studying and emulating the flexibility model at Deloitte, which allows employees to move off and on career ladders without prejudice as their family and personal needs change. This model not only increases employee satisfaction, but also positively affects a company\xe2\x80\x99s bottom line.'b'MYRA H. STROBER'b' Stanford, Calif., Jan. 17, 2013'b''b''b'The writer is professor emerita at Stanford University.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Mr. Waring brings up a critical concern for a 21st-century work force \xe2\x80\x94 the dual demands on individuals and families to care for young children and/or older relatives while also managing job requirements. Study after study has shown that flexible work arrangements are key to meeting America\xe2\x80\x99s diverse work force needs.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why I will reintroduce the Working Families Flexibility Act in the new Congress. The bill gives employees the right to request flexible work options in terms of hours, schedules, work location and notice of scheduled assignments. For employees, these options help boost satisfaction and morale for themselves and their families.'b'For businesses, flexible work arrangements help increase employee retention and productivity while reducing absenteeism.'b'Given demographic and work force changes in the last 50 years, it makes sense to promote policies that are a win-win for the work force and the bottom line of businesses.'b'CAROLYN B. MALONEY'b' Washington, Jan. 17, 2013'b''b''b'The writer, a Democrat, represents the 12th Congressional District in New York.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'As the co-founder of a Web site whose mission is to connect flexible job seekers with local businesses, I think that the time for the passage of this bill has come and gone. Six years ago when the Working Families Flexibility Act was first proposed, the employment landscape was very different from what it is today. With unemployment at 4.6 percent and a competitive labor market, individuals had the ability to request flexibility in their schedule and have these demands met to keep morale high and retain talent.'b'Compare that with today, when not only are layoffs the norm, but also workers increasingly are seeing their hours trimmed by employers, not to offer them flexibility, but to manage the bottom line. This trend is likely to continue, with 'b'58 percent of businesses reporting'b' that they will hire more part-time and hourly workers in the years ahead, regardless of improvements in the market.'b'It is this group that needs increased consideration, not only for jobs, but also for having access to insurance and payment protections. Flexibility is not the problem. But it is not required to grant a request, at least as long as it can reasonably claim it would cost more to do so.'b'Two things that should happen to encourage part-time or flexible work arrangements:'b'First, exemptions from paying overtime pay should be tightened. Merely using one\xe2\x80\x99s brain on the job, or occasionally telling another employee what to do, should not prevent extra pay for more than 40 hours worked in a week. The average caregiver is 49 years old, and works. Some were caused by unexpected developments overseas. Some are the result of a dysfunctional Congress better known for logjams, corruption and ideological intransigence than action. (So much so that 'b'a recent poll'b' showed that Americans like Congress less than cockroaches, colonoscopies and root canals.)'b'But Mr. Obama and his team would benefit, as they begin the second term, by acknowledging that many of the biggest problems facing the administration flow directly from the man at the top. Mr. Obama is a lousy manager. As chief executive he gets a C \xe2\x80\x94 and then only if graded on a curve that takes into account his predecessor\xe2\x80\x99s managerial weaknesses.'b'For all of the notable achievements of Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s first term \xe2\x80\x94 getting troops out of Iraq, passing health care and financial services reform, signing legislation that guarantees that women get equal pay for equal work, removing Osama bin Laden \xe2\x80\x94 many of the administration\xe2\x80\x99s shortcomings are traceable, at least in part, to troubles connected to the way Mr. Obama has chosen to run the government.'b'The administration has not done a good job of delegating to and empowering cabinet officials. Nor does it seem to have built necessary teams and coalitions or anticipated and planned for likely challenges. The Obama team\xe2\x80\x99s failure to make the most of stimulus funding, to make progress on climate change, to react swiftly to international crises in Egypt, Libya and Syria, and to maintain good relations with allies on Capitol Hill and beyond stem from lack of managerial skill.'b'A predicate problem is that the president\xe2\x80\x99s team has focused so intently on presenting Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s strengths that they, like many senior managers, seem to have begun to believe their own news releases.'b'Consider what is, perhaps, the iconic image of the Obama presidency: the photo of Mr. Obama, in the Situation Room, with Hillary Rodham Clinton and other members of his national security team, awaiting news of the raid on Osama bin Laden. The May 2011 photo depicts an engaged leader, in the center of a closely knit team, willing to take calculated risks but viscerally aware of the human stakes involved.'b'Like many official photos, this one said much about the president without revealing the full truth. Seemingly united in that moment, the president\xe2\x80\x99s team is, in fact, a fractious group whose members are often at odds with one another, and Mr. Obama may be the most aloof president since Richard M. Nixon. Shot in the Situation Room, the nerve center of our government, the photo gives no indication that many of the president\xe2\x80\x99s appointees see it and the rest of the West Wing as kinds of fortresses far removed from other government agencies.'b'There is no single template for the effective exercise of presidential power. In the modern era, Dwight D. Eisenhower applied the skills he mastered as a general, Lyndon B. Johnson horse-traded his way to legislative triumphs, Ronald Reagan managed with a light touch as if he were a congenial \xe2\x80\x9cchairman of the board,\xe2\x80\x9d the elder George Bush oversaw what was arguably the most disciplined and inclusive national security process in recent history and Bill Clinton was able to strike a balance between master politician and wonk in chief.'b'Each of these presidents understood the danger of personalizing the presidency, of making it too much about one man; each took care to harness resources within his cabinet and among his deputies.'b'Successful modern presidents share an experience that Barack Obama does not have: before becoming president, each played an executive or leadership role that provided insight as to how to run an effective government.'b'The management troubles that have dogged the Obama administration are not unique to Mr. Obama or his team. One of the biggest problems facing America today is that in Washington, the ability to effectively run complex organizations is among the skill sets that is least valued in our leaders.'b'Often people with no management experience \xe2\x80\x94 academics, writers or politicians who have never run an office with more than a handful of people \xe2\x80\x94 are put in charge of giant, complicated government agencies or processes. In part this is because so many people in government mistakenly believe that being able to articulate ideas is the same as being able to put ideas into action.'b'This administration provides an object lesson in how, when too many staffers have excessive influence, political calculations often trump good policy choices. When an inner circle maintains too tight a stranglehold over the president\xe2\x80\x99s time and attention, too few views come into play. If isolated by an inner circle, the president will have a harder time fostering cooperation in his administration. During his first term, Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s inner circle included Michelle Obama, Valerie Jarrett, David Axelrod, David Plouffe and Pete Rouse. Battles with Ms. Jarrett reportedly played a role in at least one top official\xe2\x80\x99s decision to leave the administration.'b'Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s top advisers say they often feel alienated from the president. There is a sense in the White House that \xe2\x80\x9cBarack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s theory of government is he is the government.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s perceived aloofness didn\xe2\x80\x99t help his relations with Congress. Many Hill Democrats resent the fact that the president essentially did not consult with them during the last campaign, regularly keeping them away from him during his campaign appearances.'b'CHIEF executives who have visited the White House for much publicized consultations with the president and senior staff report that Mr. Obama appears to be more interested in delivering his message than in listening to others. This, too, speaks to Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s management weakness. Selecting a diverse team, creating a system in which ideas surface, listening to those ideas and then empowering others to put them into action are the cornerstones of good management \xe2\x80\x94 and of effective leadership.'b'The fact that Mr. Obama is not a good manager does not mean Americans were unwise to have elected him rather than Mitt Romney, who presented himself as an experienced business leader. There is no shortage of successful businessmen who flopped in government; Paul H. O\xe2\x80\x99Neill, John W. Snow or John E. Bryson are examples. Public sector management poses its own unique challenges. Great business leaders and great governmental leaders require different personalities, skill sets, tactics and backgrounds.'b'The challenge here extends beyond Mr. Obama. The American electorate doesn\xe2\x80\x99t ask questions about management skills. Congress rarely raises the issue of management when considering nominees for large, complicated cabinet agencies, many of which are larger than big corporations. Establishing a culture in which the metrics of successful governance are valued, discussed and evaluated is a vital step toward addressing a problem of which the current president\xe2\x80\x99s management troubles is but a symptom. It would be helpful to have a permanent professional bureaucracy with continuing management responsibilities, as do many other nations. It would also be useful to consider salaries for top officials that provide incentives to the most qualified (much could be learned here from Singapore, which has blazed an important trail in this regard).'b'In the end, the success of our constitutional system depends primarily on how the occupant of the Oval Office governs. No president can succeed unless he views his job as collaborative, as requiring the motivation and empowerment of a vast United States executive branch bureaucracy, as being in partnership with Congress, as benefiting from a broad and diverse group of advisers, as being the kind of undertaking that promotes creativity even if it means embracing unpopular or even unsuccessful ideas. It\xe2\x80\x99s the job.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b"Editors' note: We're resurfacing this story from the archives to help you get 2017 off to a successful start."b''b'WHAT does self-awareness have to do with a restaurant empire? A tennis championship? Or a rock star\xe2\x80\x99s dream?'b'David Chang\xe2\x80\x99s experience is instructive.'b'Mr. Chang is an internationally renowned, award-winning Korean-American chef, restaurateur and owner of the Momofuku restaurant group with eight restaurants from Toronto to Sydney, and other thriving enterprises, including bakeries and bars, a PBS TV show, guest spots on HBO\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cTreme\xe2\x80\x9d and a foodie magazine, Lucky Peach. He says he worked himself to the bone to realize his dream \xe2\x80\x94 to own a humble noodle bar.'b'He spent years cooking in some of New York City\xe2\x80\x99s best restaurants, apprenticed in different noodle shops in Japan and then, finally, worked 18-hour days in his tiny restaurant, Momofuku Noodle Bar.'b'Mr. Chang could barely pay himself a salary. He had trouble keeping staff. And he was miserably stressed.'b'He recalls a low moment when he went with his staff on a night off to eat burgers at a restaurant that was everything his wasn\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x94 packed, critically acclaimed and financially successful. He could cook better than they did, he thought, so why was his restaurant failing? \xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t figure out what the hell we were doing wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d he told us.'b'Mr. Chang could have blamed someone else for his troubles, or worked harder (though available evidence suggests that might not have been possible) or he could have made minor tweaks to the menu. Instead he looked inward and subjected himself to brutal self-assessment.'b'Was the humble noodle bar of his dreams economically viable? Sure, a traditional noodle dish had its charm but wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t work as the mainstay of a restaurant if he hoped to pay his bills.'b'Mr. Chang changed course. Rather than worry about what a noodle bar should serve, he and his cooks stalked the produce at the greenmarket for inspiration. Then they went back to the kitchen and cooked as if it was their last meal, crowding the menu with wild combinations of dishes they\xe2\x80\x99d want to eat \xe2\x80\x94 tripe and sweetbreads, headcheese and flavor-packed culinary mashups like a Korean-style burrito. What happened next Mr. Chang still considers \xe2\x80\x9ckind of ridiculous\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 the crowds came, rave reviews piled up, awards followed and unimaginable opportunities presented themselves.'b'During the 1970s, Chris Argyris, a business theorist at Harvard Business School (and now, at 89, a professor emeritus) began to research what happens to organizations and people, like Mr. Chang, when they find obstacles in their paths.'b'Professor Argyris called the most common response single loop learning \xe2\x80\x94 an insular mental process in which we consider possible external or technical reasons for obstacles.'b'LESS common but vastly more effective is the cognitive approach that Professor Argyris called double-loop learning. In this mode we \xe2\x80\x94 like Mr. Chang \xe2\x80\x94 question every aspect of our approach, including our methodology, biases and deeply held assumptions. This more psychologically nuanced self-examination requires that we honestly challenge our beliefs and summon the courage to act on that information, which may lead to fresh ways of thinking about our lives and our goals.'b'In interviews we did with high achievers for a book, we expected to hear that talent, persistence, dedication and luck played crucial roles in their success. Surprisingly, however, self-awareness played an equally strong role.'b'The successful people we spoke with \xe2\x80\x94 in business, entertainment, sports and the arts \xe2\x80\x94 all had similar responses when faced with obstacles: they subjected themselves to fairly merciless self-examination that prompted reinvention of their goals and the methods by which they endeavored to achieve them.'b'The tennis champion Martina Navratilova, for example, told us that after a galling loss to Chris Evert in 1981, she questioned her assumption that she could get by on talent and instinct alone. She began a long exploration of every aspect of her game. She adopted a rigorous cross-training practice (common today but essentially unheard of at the time), revamped her diet and her mental and tactical game and ultimately transformed herself into the most successful women\xe2\x80\x99s tennis player of her era.'b'The indie rock band OK Go described how it once operated under the business model of the 20th-century rock band. But when industry record sales collapsed and the band members found themselves creatively hamstrung by their recording company, they questioned their tactics. Rather than depend on their label, they made wildly unconventional music videos, which went viral, and collaborative art projects with companies like Google, State Farm and Range Rover, which financed future creative endeavors. The band now releases albums on its own label.'b'No one\xe2\x80\x99s idea of a good time is to take a brutal assessment of their animating assumptions and to acknowledge that those may have contributed to their failure. It\xe2\x80\x99s easy to find pat ways to explain why the world has not adequately rewarded our efforts. But what we learned from conversation with high achievers is that challenging our assumptions, objectives, at times even our goals, may sometimes push us further than we thought possible. Ask David Chang, who never imagined that sweetbreads and duck sausage rice cakes with kohlrabi and mint would find their way beside his humble noodle dishes \xe2\x80\x94 and make him a star.'b'When a city condemns private property to make way for a public highway, that is a classic \xe2\x80\x9ctaking\xe2\x80\x9d for which government must provide \xe2\x80\x9cjust compensation\xe2\x80\x9d under the Constitution\xe2\x80\x99s Fifth Amendment.'b'Over the last few decades, a divided Supreme Court has 'b'extended'b' property rights at the expense of community interests by 'b'expanding'b' the \xe2\x80\x9ctakings\xe2\x80\x9d concept to include regulatory actions that are \xe2\x80\x9cfunctionally equivalent\xe2\x80\x9d to direct appropriation. These might include actions that render the property essentially worthless, undermine an owner\xe2\x80\x99s right to keep it private, or greatly limit its use.'b'In 'b'Koontz v. St. Johns River Water Management District'b', however, the plaintiffs have asked for a radical redefinition of takings so elastic that even Justice Antonin Scalia, a strong advocate of property rights and of a broad interpretation of the takings law, rose up in protest.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA taking of what?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked the petitioner\xe2\x80\x99s lawyer during 'b'oral argument'b' before the Supreme Court last week. His question was echoed by Justice Elena Kagan, who asked, \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the taking?\xe2\x80\x9d and by Justice Sonia Sotomayor, who was even blunter: \xe2\x80\x9cWhy are we even in this case?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The justices were plainly skeptical, and a brief look at the case explains why. It involves a decision by the water management district in Central Florida \xe2\x80\x94 an agency charged with protecting wetlands \xe2\x80\x94 to deny a permit to the Koontz family to develop three-plus acres of wetlands near Orlando because the family refused to contribute money to wetlands protection elsewhere in the state.'b'This kind of mitigation under environmental law is common in cases involving statutes protecting clean water and endangered species. The family offered to preserve 11 acres that it owned, but the water management district rightly said that preserving what already existed was not mitigation.'b'The Koontz family sought monetary compensation, but as the justices noted, the district has not condemned an iota of the land and has not required the family to do anything to its property. It simply denied the family a permit for development.'b'That was the gist of the Florida Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'ruling'b' in favor of the district. The United States Supreme Court should uphold that decision, blocking efforts by the family and its ideological allies to stretch the notion of a regulatory taking far beyond any defensible limits.'b'A detailed report put out by JPMorgan Chase last week on how it lost $6 billion from ill-fated trading in 2012 should be required reading for policy makers and financial executives. The 129-page 'b'document'b' serves as a case study of how excessive complexity and poor oversight still threaten many parts of the financial system more than four years after the failure of Lehman Brothers.'b'The subject of the report is the bank\xe2\x80\x99s trading of complex derivatives known as credit default swaps that are similar to the instruments that forced the government to bail out the American International Group in 2008. At JPMorgan, the nation\xe2\x80\x99s largest bank and one of many that received government aid during the crisis, these investments did not threaten the institution\xe2\x80\x99s survival as they did with A.I.G. But they caused losses large enough to dent the bank\xe2\x80\x99s reputation for managing risk well, and cost its top executive, Jamie Dimon, a 50 percent reduction in his 2012 pay.'b'The report, which was prepared by JPMorgan executives, is not exhaustive: it does not explain, for instance, how an early loss estimate of $2 billion eventually grew to $6 billion. But it provides important insights into why the losses took the bank and regulators by surprise. The main reason is that they were not paying attention to a small group of traders working for the bank\xe2\x80\x99s chief investment unit, which was supposed to be hedging, or protecting against future losses.'b'In fact, far from mitigating the bank\xe2\x80\x99s risk, the London-based traders amassed a large, complex financial portfolio in the misguided hope that doing so would help the bank avoid a relatively modest loss of about $100 million, according to the report. As they dug themselves into a deeper and deeper hole, the risks they were taking were either kept from or ignored by senior managers and bank supervisors.'b'But not everybody was oblivious. Investors at other banks and hedge funds who were trading with JPMorgan noticed and took advantage of the situation. They even dubbed the group\xe2\x80\x99s principal trader the \xe2\x80\x9cLondon Whale\xe2\x80\x9d because he took a very large position in the market.'b'The report\xe2\x80\x99s findings suggest that some of the riskiest trading would have been either prohibited or at least better monitored had regulators finished drafting regulations about derivatives and short-term trading by banks that are required under the Dodd-Frank financial reform law.'b'But the far bigger lesson from this report is that senior bank officials and regulators need to be more vigilant than they have been in overseeing potentially risky activity wherever it may be taking place. The report found that even as the London group, which makes trades for JPMorgan itself, engaged in more complex transactions and took on more risk, its activities were more lightly monitored than the trading by other divisions, like JPMorgan\xe2\x80\x99s investment bank, which provides financial services and advice to corporations and others.'b'The board of JPMorgan did the right thing in making this report public so that investors, depositors and the general public can better understand what happened. 'b'Last week'b', federal banking regulators ordered JPMorgan to improve its risk management systems and told its board to report on its progress.
