KNICKMAN'b'\nPresident and Chief Executive'b'\nNew York State Health Foundation'b'\nNew York, Jan. 18, 2013'b''b''b''b'MIDDLETOWN, Conn.'b'THE Enlightenment polymath Denis Diderot turns 300 this year, and his October birthday is shaping up to be special. President Fran\xc3\xa7ois Hollande has indicated that he plans to honor the philosopher and novelist with what may be France\xe2\x80\x99s highest tribute: a symbolic reburial in the Panth\xc3\xa9on. In the roughly two centuries since this massive neo-Classical church was converted into a secular mausoleum, fewer than 80 people have been admitted into its gravestone club. If inducted, Diderot will arguably be the first member to be celebrated as much for his attacks on reigning orthodoxies as for his literary stature.'b'Like many Enlightenment writers, Diderot preached the right of the individual to determine the course of his or her life. But the type of liberty that underpins Diderot\xe2\x80\x99s body of work differs markedly from today\xe2\x80\x99s hackneyed understanding of freedom. His message was of intellectual emancipation from received authorities \xe2\x80\x94 be they religious, political or societal \xe2\x80\x94 and always in the interest of the common good. More so than the deists Voltaire and Rousseau, Diderot embodied the most progressive wing of Enlightenment thought, a position that stemmed from his belief that skepticism in all matters was \xe2\x80\x9cthe first step toward truth.\xe2\x80\x9d He was, in fact, the precise type of secular Enlightenment thinker that some members of the 'b'Texas State Board of Education'b' have attempted to write out of their high school curriculum.'b'Rare are the writers whose legacy has shifted as dramatically as Diderot\xe2\x80\x99s. When he died in 1784, at age 70, the vast majority of his short stories, novels and philosophical works lay hidden away in trunks. He was remembered primarily for two things: coediting the world\xe2\x80\x99s first comprehensive 'b'encyclopedia'b', a project to which he contributed an astonishing 10,000 articles, and being a scandalous freethinker and atheist.'b'Articles in the \xe2\x80\x9cEncyclop\xc3\xa9die\xe2\x80\x9d tweaked Christian dogma. A famous example was the cross-references provided for the word \xe2\x80\x9canthropophagy,\xe2\x80\x9d or cannibalism: they directed readers to the entries for \xe2\x80\x9cEucharist,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ccommunion\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9caltar.\xe2\x80\x9d Small wonder that the publication of the \xe2\x80\x9cEncyclop\xc3\xa9die\xe2\x80\x9d was twice banned and that the work was eventually driven underground.'b'The few works Diderot had published before becoming fully engaged in this project did not help his popularity. In 1748, he penned \xe2\x80\x9cThe Indiscreet Jewels,\xe2\x80\x9d a forerunner to \xe2\x80\x9cThe Vagina Monologues,\xe2\x80\x9d in which women\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cjewels\xe2\x80\x9d engaged in a frank discussion of their erotic adventures. The following year, he waded into deeper water when he challenged arguments supporting the existence of God in \xe2\x80\x9cLetter on the Blind\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a book that earned him three months in prison.'b'Armed with both hindsight and access to his 'b'unpublished writings'b', we now know a different Diderot. By the 19th century, the writer\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cdiscovered\xe2\x80\x9d texts began inspiring the likes of Goethe, Hegel and Nietzsche. Marx cited him as his favorite writer \xe2\x80\x94 twice. Freud, too, was a great fan. It was Diderot who had said that if you allowed a child to grow up totally without education, \xe2\x80\x9che would in time combine the reasoning of the infant with the passions of the grown man, and would strangle his father and sleep with his mother.\xe2\x80\x9d Ring a bell?'b'Readers today never fail to be amazed by Diderot\xe2\x80\x99s willingness to confront both the unconscionable and the uncomfortable, often embracing subject matter that his contemporaries fled. He vehemently condemned the enslavement of Africans (and gave a philosophical voice to the slave); he challenged his era\xe2\x80\x99s views on religious celibacy and forced vocations (in a tear-jerking pseudo-memoir of a sexually abused nun); and he entertained the possibility that his cherished materialism denied us free will (in his novel \xe2\x80\x9cJacques the Fatalist\xe2\x80\x9d).'b'An ardent empiricist, Diderot also took pride in questioning his own beliefs. In \xe2\x80\x9cRameau\xe2\x80\x99s Nephew,\xe2\x80\x9d Diderot gave life to a character who assailed the author\xe2\x80\x99s deep-rooted humanism. One of the most memorable eccentrics in all of literature, the hedonistic protagonist preached the beauty of evil, the joys of social parasitism and the right to be a self-seeking individual. This same ability to think beyond his own perspective also generated Diderot\xe2\x80\x99s most prophetic work of fiction, \xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Alembert\xe2\x80\x99s Dream,\xe2\x80\x9d a text that conjures up a godless world of speculative \xe2\x80\x9cgenetic\xe2\x80\x9d manipulation and proto-evolutionary theory, 90 years before Darwin.'b'After rejecting Diderot for panth\xc3\xa9onisation 100 years ago because of his atheism, the French now seem ready to bestow upon their countryman the high honor he has long deserved. No doubt Diderot himself would have been pleased. \xe2\x80\x9cPosterity is for the philosopher what the next world is for the man of religion,\xe2\x80\x9d he once wrote. But we all might take pride as well \xe2\x80\x94 because if Diderot is, at long last, welcomed into the Panth\xc3\xa9on, it will be a collective acknowledgment that part of what makes an artist great is having the courage to provoke and challenge.'b'The message ought to resonate on this side of the Atlantic, too. While it\xe2\x80\x99s sometimes easy for Americans to forget, thumbing one\xe2\x80\x99s nose at the establishment has been central to our own cultural and political traditions since, well, Diderot\xe2\x80\x99s time. After all, that\xe2\x80\x99s how we became Americans in the first place.'b'President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s second Inaugural Address offered a lot for progressives to like. There was the spirited defense of gay rights; there was the equally spirited defense of the role of government, and, in particular, of the safety net provided by Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security. But arguably the most encouraging thing of all was what he didn\xe2\x80\x99t say: He barely mentioned the budget deficit.'b'Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s clearly deliberate neglect of Washington\xe2\x80\x99s favorite obsession was just the latest sign that the self-styled deficit hawks \xe2\x80\x94 better described as deficit scolds \xe2\x80\x94 are losing their hold over political discourse. And that\xe2\x80\x99s a very good thing.'b'Why have the deficit scolds lost their grip? I\xe2\x80\x99d suggest four interrelated reasons.'b'First, they have cried wolf too many times. They\xe2\x80\x99ve spent three years warning of imminent crisis \xe2\x80\x94 if we don\xe2\x80\x99t slash the deficit now now now, we\xe2\x80\x99ll turn into Greece, Greece, I tell you. It is, for example, almost two years since Alan Simpson and Erskine Bowles declared that we should expect a fiscal crisis within, um, two years.'b'But that crisis keeps not happening. The still-depressed economy has kept interest rates at near-record lows despite large government borrowing, just as Keynesian economists predicted all along. So the credibility of the scolds has taken an understandable, and well-deserved, hit.'b'Second, both deficits and public spending as a share of G.D.P. have started to decline \xe2\x80\x94 again, just as those who never bought into the deficit hysteria predicted all along.'b'The truth is that the budget deficits of the past four years were mainly a temporary consequence of the financial crisis, which sent the economy into a tailspin \xe2\x80\x94 and which, therefore, led both to low tax receipts and to a rise in unemployment benefits and other government expenses. It should have been obvious that the deficit would come down as the economy recovered. But this point was hard to get across until deficit reduction started appearing in the data.'b'Now it has \xe2\x80\x94 and reasonable forecasts, like those of Jan Hatzius of Goldman Sachs, suggest that the federal deficit will be below 3 percent of G.D.P., a not very scary number, by 2015.'b'And it was, in fact, a good thing that the deficit was allowed to rise as the economy slumped. With private spending plunging as the housing bubble popped and cash-strapped families cut back, the willingness of the government to keep spending was one of the main reasons we didn\xe2\x80\x99t experience a full replay of the Great Depression. Which brings me to the third reason the deficit scolds have lost influence: the contrary doctrine, the claim that we need to practice fiscal austerity even in a depressed economy, has failed decisively in practice.'b'Consider, in particular, the case of Britain. In 2010, when the new government of Prime Minister David Cameron turned to austerity policies, it received fulsome praise from many people on this side of the Atlantic. For example, the late David Broder urged President Obama to \xe2\x80\x9cdo a Cameron\xe2\x80\x9d; he particularly commended Mr. Cameron for \xe2\x80\x9cbrushing aside the warnings of economists that the sudden, severe medicine could cut short Britain\xe2\x80\x99s economic recovery and throw the nation back into recession.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Sure enough, the sudden, severe medicine cut short Britain\xe2\x80\x99s economic recovery, and threw the nation back into recession.'b'At this point, then, it\xe2\x80\x99s clear that the deficit-scold movement was based on bad economic analysis. But that\xe2\x80\x99s not all: there was also clearly a lot of bad faith involved, as the scolds tried to exploit an economic (not fiscal) crisis on behalf of a political agenda that had nothing to do with deficits. And the growing transparency of that agenda is the fourth reason the deficit scolds have lost their clout.'b'What was it that finally pulled back the curtain here? Was it the way the election campaign revealed Representative Paul Ryan, who received a \xe2\x80\x9cfiscal responsibility\xe2\x80\x9d award from three leading deficit-scold organizations, as the con man he always was? Was it the decision of David Walker, alleged crusader for sound budgets, to endorse Mitt Romney and his budget-busting tax cuts for the rich? Or was it the brazenness of groups like Fix the Debt \xe2\x80\x94 basically corporate C.E.O.\xe2\x80\x99s declaring that you should be forced to delay your retirement while they get to pay lower taxes?'b'The answer probably is, all of the above. In any case, an era has ended. Prominent deficit scolds can no longer count on being treated as if their wisdom, probity and public-spiritedness were beyond question. But what difference will that make?'b'Sad to say, G.O.P. control of the House means that we won\xe2\x80\x99t do what we should be doing: spend more, not less, until the recovery is complete. But the fading of deficit hysteria means that the president can turn his focus to real problems. And that\xe2\x80\x99s a move in the right direction.'b'One of the features of the Obama years is that we get to witness an enormous race, which you might call the race between meritocracy and government. On the one side, there is the meritocracy, which widens inequality. On the other side, there is President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s team of progressives, who are trying to mitigate inequality. The big question is: Which side is winning?'b'First, there is our system of higher education, which is like a giant vacuum cleaner that sucks up some of the smartest people from across the country and concentrates them in a few privileged places.'b'Smart high school students from rural Nebraska, small-town Ohio and urban Newark get to go to good universities. When they get there they often find a culture shock.'b'They\xe2\x80\x99ve been raised in an atmosphere of social equality and now find themselves in a culture that emphasizes the relentless quest for distinction \xe2\x80\x94 to be more accomplished, more enlightened and more cutting edge. They may have been raised in a culture that emphasizes roots, but they go into a culture that emphasizes mobility \xe2\x80\x94 a multicultural cosmopolitanism that encourages you to go anywhere on your quest for self-fulfillment. They may have been raised among people who enter the rooms of the mighty with the nerves of a stranger, but they are now around people who enter the highest places with the confident sense they belong.'b'But the system works. In the dorms, classrooms, summer internships and early jobs they learn how to behave the way successful people do in the highly educated hubs. There\xe2\x80\x99s no economic reason to return home, and maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s not even socially possible anymore.'b'The highly educated cluster around a few small nodes. Decade after decade, smart and educated people flock away from Merced, Calif., Yuma, Ariz., Flint, Mich., and Vineland, N.J. In those places, less than 15 percent of the residents have college degrees. They flock to Washington, Boston, San Jose, Raleigh-Durham and San Francisco. In those places, nearly 50 percent of the residents have college degrees.'b'As Enrico Moretti writes in \xe2\x80\x9cThe New Geography of Jobs,\xe2\x80\x9d the magnet places have positive ecologies that multiply innovation, creativity and wealth. The abandoned places have negative ecologies and fall further behind.'b'This sorting is self-reinforcing, and it seems to grow more unforgiving every year. One small study caught my eye. Robert Oprisko of Butler University found that half of the jobs in university political science programs went to graduates of the top 11 schools. That is to say, if you have a Ph.D. from Harvard, Stanford, Princeton and so on, your odds of getting a job are very good. If you earned your degree from one of the other 100 degree-granting universities, your odds are not. These other 100 schools don\xe2\x80\x99t even want to hire the sort of graduates they themselves produce. They want the elite credential.'b'Barack Obama (Occidental, Columbia, Harvard) benefited from this sorting system. So did his wife (Princeton, Harvard). So did most people in his administration. So did many people who read this newspaper and many of us who write for it.'b'Members of the administration have worked reasonably hard to mitigate the inequality that their own rise has produced. They\xe2\x80\x99ve worked reasonably hard to redistribute money from the rich people in the magnet areas to the poorer people in the flight areas. For example, the health care law increases taxes on the top 1 percent by about $20,000 per household. It increases benefits for the working class by between $400 and $800 per household. The recent tax increases will do more of the same.'b'The first problem with the effort is that it\xe2\x80\x99s like shooting a water gun into a waterfall. The Obama measures, earned after a great deal of political pain, simply aren\xe2\x80\x99t significant enough to counteract the underlying trends.'b'The second problem is the focus on income redistribution. Recently, there\xe2\x80\x99s been far more talk about tax increases than any other subject. But the income disparities are a downstream effect of the human capital and geographic disparities. Pumping a few dollars into San Joaquin, Calif., where 2.9 percent of the residents have bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s degrees and 20.6 percent have high school degrees, may ease suffering, but it won\xe2\x80\x99t alter the dynamic.'b'The final problem is that, in an effort to reduce the economic concentration of power, the administration is concentrating political power in Washington. If the problem is that talent is fleeing blighted localities, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to see how you make that better if decision-making and resources are concentrated faraway in the nation\xe2\x80\x99s capital.'b'This is not to make a partisan point. The Republicans do not have a better approach. It\xe2\x80\x99s simply to say that the liberal agenda is not very good at addressing the inequality problem it seeks to solve. The meritocracy is overwhelming the liberal project.'b'The cinema complex in Aurora, Colo., 'b'reopened last week'b', six months after a gunman killed 12 patrons, wounded 58 and left deep scars on a community still struggling to recover. \xe2\x80\x9cEveryone heals, some slower, some in different ways,\xe2\x80\x9d contended Gov. John Hickenlooper of Colorado in the face of angry complaints from some of the victims\xe2\x80\x99 families that the reopening, with prayers, a \xe2\x80\x9cnight of remembrance\xe2\x80\x9d and a screening of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey,\xe2\x80\x9d was insensitive and crass.'b'His point about the certainty of healing, while undoubtedly heartfelt, is too often and too easily offered by political leaders when, in fact, Aurora, like Newtown, Conn., and countless other places savaged by multiple shootings across decades, must struggle for years with the legacy and its wounds, largely alone as the spotlight fades. The trials of gun-damaged victims who survive mass assaults is one of the intangibles that must not be overlooked if the nation, and the political system, is to have any hope in the renewed fight for stronger gun controls.'b'For all the talk at the movie house of healing, one surviving victim, 23-year-old Caleb Medley, remained in grievous suffering on his back with severe brain and motor damage and the loss of an eye. His family exulted when he was briefly helped to his feet last month, and hoped that he might be able to leave rehabilitation soon for an extended care facility, however limited his horizons. Seven family members of another victim, Ashley Moser, take turns making sure the 25-year-old woman, a paraplegic after a neck wound, is rotated twice a night in her bed. Her aunt, Annie Dalton, reports Ashley remains deeply depressed with little motivation as she faces the fact that her 6-year-old daughter, Veronica, was shot dead that night while the paralyzed mother lost a fetus soon after the gun spree.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no closure here,\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. Dalton, a retired public school principal, politely reported of Ashley\xe2\x80\x99s life. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a tough road,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, citing all manner of bureaucratic tangles about health insurance, fading rehabilitation coverage, other financial demands beyond estimating, and endless tasks like the family\xe2\x80\x99s learning to move Ashley on a board to distant doctors\xe2\x80\x99 appointments.'b'There is familiar ritual in Aurora\xe2\x80\x99s aftermath that the rest of the nation needs to know. A charity fund that grew so quickly after the carnage \xe2\x80\x94 to about $5 million \xe2\x80\x94 is depleted. It was distributed by Ken Feinberg, the respected compensation guru from 9/11 and other tragedies, under a formula that devotes 70 percent to those who suffered brain damage or paralysis \xe2\x80\x94 something more than $200,000 each. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s not enough money,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Feinberg apologized to claimants with lower-rated trauma. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a horrible situation,\xe2\x80\x9d he said of Aurora\xe2\x80\x99s needs.'b'In caring for her niece, Ms. Dalton can barely speak of the fresh massacre in Newtown or the \xe2\x80\x9cunreal\xe2\x80\x9d power of the National Rifle Association in dominating the conversation about a problem that in the last 40 years has taken one million lives and left countless others like Ashley and her family to manage unspeakably debilitated lives. \xe2\x80\x9cThe next tragedy is on its way,\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. Dalton said of the one certain lesson in Ashley\xe2\x80\x99s fate.'b'The dark art of statehouse gerrymandering reached a new low in Virginia this week. Senate Republicans in Richmond used the absence of a Democratic member, who traveled to the presidential inauguration, to ram through a 'b'surprise redistricting map'b' patently designed to aid the G.O.P.\xe2\x80\x99s grab for majority power in the next election.'b'The chamber is divided 20-20 between the parties. A redistricting plan had been adopted after the 2010 census. But no sooner had Senator Henry Marsh III, a black civil rights leader, left for the inauguration on Martin Luther King\xe2\x80\x99s Birthday than the Republicans pounced like street thugs to limit debate to 30 minutes and pass their shabbily partisan ploy by a vote of 20 to 19.'b'Like most states, the Virginia commonwealth has a long history of political eye-gouging in the pursuit of voting maps that boost the careers of one party\xe2\x80\x99s members while keeping voters in the dark. But the Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 blitzkrieg was breathtaking as they dredged up an innocuous House bill, grafted their remapping scheme onto it, and rushed it to the floor without any notice to the public.'b'The Republican House is expected to approve the changes, which would make eight of the state\xe2\x80\x99s 40 Senate districts \xe2\x80\x94 including six held by Democrats \xe2\x80\x94 more heavily Republican. At the same time, more Democrats would be packed into three solidly Democratic districts. Andrew Cuomo of New York presented an extra-lean state budget this week, his third conservative spending plan since taking office in 2011. The total outlays for fiscal year 2013-14, including federal funds to rebuild after Hurricane Sandy, will be almost $143 billion. The budget contains some real bonuses, including a plan to raise the minimum wage and a proposal for a workable database for gun ownership. But it could also raise the debt load, especially in struggling upstate areas.'b'The budget, which must be approved by the Legislature before April 1, increases state spending by less than 2 percent statewide. That is admirable restraint, but the budget is not free of Albany\xe2\x80\x99s traditional sleight-of-hand, like one-time cash infusions. For instance, the governor would dip into reserves for the state insurance fund, although he does say that the money will go mainly to capital projects, not daily expenses. And since the state is nearing a debt limit imposed in 2000, the governor wants to free the State University of New York to issue more of its own debt in the future.'b'One of the more questionable aspects of the budget is a provision labeled the \xe2\x80\x9cStable Rate Pension Contribution Option.\xe2\x80\x9d Innocent as that sounds, the provision would give local communities the freedom to stretch out their pension obligations to the state by paying less now, and almost certainly more later on. The mayor of Syracuse, Stephanie Miner, describes this as \xe2\x80\x9ckicking the can down the road.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'State Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli would have to approve this idea, a decision he should consider carefully. Communities like Syracuse pay pension costs into the state\xe2\x80\x99s $150 billion pension fund, and lower contributions from these communities could make the state plan more vulnerable.'b'Besides, most of these cities need more help than this revision to the pension plan. Nor does this budget offer these communities anything new in the way of unrestricted state assistance.'b'There are other questions for legislators to consider, but by Albany standards this is mostly a low-trauma budget that will need only a few fixes.'b'The Pentagon\xe2\x80\x99s decision to 'b'end its ban on women in combat'b' is a triumph for equality and common sense. By opening infantry, artillery and other battlefield jobs to all qualified service members regardless of sex, the military is showing that categorical discrimination has no place in a society that honors fairness and equal opportunity.'b'Defense Secretary Leon Panetta, who overturned the ban this week, and the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who unanimously urged him to do it, deserve praise for bringing military policy in line with reality. Women have been in the thick of combat in Iraq and Afghanistan for more than a decade. More than 280,000 have been deployed there, thousands have been injured and more than 150 killed. With the rule abolished, such service and sacrifice will no longer be unofficial and unrecognized.'b'It is encouraging that the push for change came from the top, from leaders who said integration was no bar to a stronger, better military. The Pentagon also was facing pressure from lawsuits, including one brought last November on behalf of four service women and the Service Women\xe2\x80\x99s Action Network, an advocacy group, claiming that gender-based discrimination was unconstitutional and unfairly harmed their careers.'b'One plaintiff, Maj. The result will be more diversity, from a deeper pool of talent, and thus a stronger, better military.'b'There will also be grumbling. When the news broke Wednesday afternoon, military news sites like Army Times and Marine Corps Times lit up with comments, some ranging from laughably sexist to reprehensible. \xe2\x80\x9cThey shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be bused in from the field every 3 days for a shower while the guys stay out for 45 days,\xe2\x80\x9d said one commenter. \xe2\x80\x9cThe castration of the U.S. Army continues,\xe2\x80\x9d said another. \xe2\x80\x9cGod help us all.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Some right-wing commentators rehashed false stereotypes that women couldn\xe2\x80\x99t hack it, and warned that women would be captured and raped and men would get shot trying to protect them instead of killing the enemy. These lurid hypotheticals deny the reality that military women face far greater danger of sexual assault and harassment from their fellow troops \xe2\x80\x94 a crisis that the Pentagon has slowly been addressing, and that full combat integration should help to remedy. Adding women to the leadership corps will foster a healthier military culture freed from testosterone-soaked abuse and scandal.'b'Many in the military already understand that many women can do combat jobs as well as men, if not better, but none have the chance to prove it. \xe2\x80\x9cFully support,\xe2\x80\x9d one Army Times commenter wrote of the new policy, \xe2\x80\x9cas long as the training and the physical standards for such positions remain what they need to be to accomplish the mission and make every team member able to provide support and cover for their teammates.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'To the Editor: 'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Make Law Schools Earn a Third Year'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by Daniel B. Rodriguez and Samuel Estreicher (Op-Ed, Jan. 18), argued that legal education should be reduced from the traditional three years to two. Even as a second-year law student (saddled with loans and still not in sight of graduation), I find this effort to make law school more affordable misguided.'b'In any law school, the first year is devoted entirely to broad survey courses. The second and third, by contrast, combine more of the same with opportunities for practical experience and interdisciplinary study. Compressing these years into one would require the retention of the survey courses (needed to pass the bar) and the reduction or elimination of the rest. A result would be all breadth and no depth.'b'Yet the J.D. was originally intended to encompass not just the study of law but the whole social context in which law takes place, the study of \xe2\x80\x9cthe whole field of man as a social being,\xe2\x80\x9d as one university president ambitiously put it.'b'In a world that already conceives of lawyers as failing to look past laws and cases to the human beings they govern, such depth should be required, not optional.'b'BILL WATSON'b' Chicago, Jan. 18, 2013'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Hurray for Daniel B. Rodriguez and Samuel Estreicher\xe2\x80\x99s plea to let students take the New York State bar exam after two years of law school rather than three. But the students must return to school, forgoing perhaps $100,000 in earnings and increasing debt by $50,000.'b'The third year is claimed to offer \xe2\x80\x9cclinical\xe2\x80\x9d expertise and studies in a specialty. School of Public Affairs, University of Texas at Austin.'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'The problem with law schools (and I see this from a vantage point of practicing law for more than 40 years and hiring lawyers just out of law school) is not one of economics \xe2\x80\x94 the price of a third year of law school. Rather, the problem is one of students not getting value for their money.'b'Law schools have never figured out a way to train law school graduates so that they are ready to practice law. Law school graduates often do not know the way to the courthouse and everything that comes before the courthouse. Today, a recent law school graduate is able only to be a clerk for a United States Supreme Court justice, but not able to practice law in any real sense.'b'Other professional schools have figured out a way to obtain competent and experienced professors who can transmit their skills to the students. Not so in law schools. The law school graduate is fit to perform virtually none of the basic things that a lawyer must do.'b'Adding to the problem is that judges, who are among the most overworked and underpaid professionals in the country, will have to spend their time in on-the-job training.'b'Frankly, law school is a waste of money for the students and their parents, and is best equated to the price one must pay to belong to a union.'b'RAOUL LIONEL FELDER'b' New York, Jan. 22, 2013'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Penny-wise and pound-foolish best describes the proposal for two years of law school instead of three.'b'As Daniel B. BAUM'b'\nNew York, Jan. 22, 2013'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of medicine, microbiology and immunology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.'b''b'CAMBRIDGE, Mass.'b'CITING an escalating dispute over islands in the East China Sea, The Economist 'b'warned'b' last week that \xe2\x80\x9cChina and Japan are sliding toward war.\xe2\x80\x9d That assessment may be too alarmist, but the tensions have bolstered the efforts of some American analysts who have urged a policy to \xe2\x80\x9ccontain\xe2\x80\x9d China.'b'During a recent visit to China, I was struck by how many Chinese officials believe such a policy is already in place and is the central purpose of President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cpivot\xe2\x80\x9d toward Asia. \xe2\x80\x9cThe pivot is a very stupid choice,\xe2\x80\x9d Jin Canrong, a professor of international relations, declared publicly. \xe2\x80\x9cThe United States has achieved nothing and only annoyed China. China can\xe2\x80\x99t be contained,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.'b'Containment was designed for a different era, and it is not what the United States is, or should be, attempting now. At the start of the cold war, containment meant economic isolation of the Soviets and regional alliances like NATO to deter Moscow\xe2\x80\x99s military expansion. Later, to the chagrin of George F. Kennan, the father of containment, the doctrine led to the \xe2\x80\x9cdomino effect\xe2\x80\x9d theory behind the escalation of the Vietnam War.'b'Cold war containment involved virtually no trade and little social contact. But China now is not what the Soviet Union was then. It is not seeking global hegemony, and the United States not only has an immense trade with China but also huge exchanges of students and tourists.'b'When I worked on the Pentagon\xe2\x80\x99s East Asia strategy in 1994, during the Clinton administration, we rejected the idea of containment for two reasons. If we treated China as an enemy, we were guaranteeing a future enemy. If we treated China as a friend, we kept open the possibility of a more peaceful future.'b'We devised a strategy of \xe2\x80\x9cintegrate but hedge\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 something like Ronald Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9ctrust but verify.\xe2\x80\x9d America supported China\xe2\x80\x99s membership in the World Trade Organization and accepted Chinese goods and visitors. But a 1996 declaration reaffirmed that the postwar United States-Japan security treaty was the basis for a stable and prosperous East Asia. President Clinton also began to improve relations with India to counterbalance China\xe2\x80\x99s rise.'b'This strategy has enjoyed bipartisan support. President George W. Bush continued to improve relations with India, while deepening economic ties with China. His deputy secretary of state, Robert B. Zoellick, made clear that America would accept the rise of China as a \xe2\x80\x9cresponsible stakeholder.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9crebalancing\xe2\x80\x9d toward Asia involves moving naval resources to the Pacific, but also trade, human rights and diplomatic initiatives. As his national security adviser, Thomas E. Donilon, 'b'said'b' in November, the American-Chinese relationship \xe2\x80\x9chas elements of both cooperation and competition.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Asia is not a monolith, and its internal balance of power should be the key to our strategy. Japan, India, Vietnam and other countries do not want to be dominated by China, and thus welcome an American presence in the region. Unless China is able to attract allies by successfully developing its \xe2\x80\x9csoft power,\xe2\x80\x9d the rise in its \xe2\x80\x9chard\xe2\x80\x9d military and economic power is likely to frighten its neighbors, who will coalesce to balance its power.'b'A significant American military and economic presence helps to maintain the Asian balance of power and shape an environment that provides incentives for China to cooperate. After the 2008-9 financial crisis, some Chinese mistakenly believed that America was in permanent decline and that this presented new opportunities. A result was that China worsened its relations with Japan, India, South Korea, Vietnam and the Philippines \xe2\x80\x94 a misstep that confirmed that \xe2\x80\x9conly China can contain China.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But America\xe2\x80\x99s rebalancing toward Asia should not be aggressive. We should heed Mr. Kennan\xe2\x80\x99s warning against overmilitarization and ensure that China doesn\xe2\x80\x99t feel encircled or endangered. The world\xe2\x80\x99s two largest economies have much to gain from cooperation on fighting climate change, pandemics, cyberterrorism and nuclear proliferation.'b'With China becoming more dependent on Middle Eastern energy, we should discuss maritime regulations to ensure free passage of ships and include China in Pacific naval exercises. We should help China develop domestic energy resources like shale gas and encourage China and Japan to revive their 2008 plan for joint undersea gas exploitation. And we should make clear that if China meets certain standards, it can join the negotiations over the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a proposed free-trade agreement around the Pacific Rim.'b'Containment is simply not a relevant policy tool for dealing with a rising China. Power is the ability to obtain the outcomes one wants, and sometimes America\xe2\x80\x99s power is greater when we act with others rather than merely over others.'b'For most of President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s first term, Republicans used legislative trickery to try to prevent the functioning of two federal agencies they hate, the National Labor Relations Board and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. First they would filibuster the president\xe2\x80\x99s nominees to the agencies, knowing that neither agency could operate without board members or a director. Then they would create fake legislative sessions for the Senate during its recess, intended solely to prevent Mr. Obama from making recess appointments as an end run.'b'Astonishingly, 'b'a federal appeals court upheld this strategy'b' on Friday. Mr. Obama had declared that Congress was not really open for business during its one-minute, lights-on-lights-off sessions intended only to thwart him, and he made recess appointments. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit said his N.L.R.B. appointments were unconstitutional, buying the argument of Republicans that the Senate was really in session.'b'The court even broke with the presidential practice of 150 years by ruling that only vacancies arising during a narrow recess period qualify for recess appointments.'b'White House officials said the administration would appeal the decision to the Supreme Court, but if it is upheld, it will invalidate scores of decisions made by the labor board over the last year. Without lawfully appointed members, the board would lack a quorum and could take no action, unable to police union elections or ensure that companies treat unions properly. That is exactly the outcome hoped for by business interests and the right, furious that a board under Democratic control tends to rule in labor\xe2\x80\x99s favor (after years of ruling for business during the Bush years).'b'The decision also threatens the work of the consumer bureau, which has been operating under a director, Richard Cordray, appointed during a recess after Republicans filibustered his nomination. A similar lawsuit is moving through the courts challenging his appointment.'b'The administration\xe2\x80\x99s lawyers made 'b'a solid argument'b' that a legislative session during which no business takes place, and when no nominations can be considered, is not a real session. The vast majority of senators, in fact, were out of town. Used in this way, the administration said, sham \xe2\x80\x9cpro forma\xe2\x80\x9d sessions prevented two executive-branch agencies from performing their lawful duties. Both agencies were created by majorities in Congress, but they were undermined by minorities.'b''b'The court\xe2\x80\x99s opinion'b' took no notice of the underhanded nature of these actions: Senate Republicans asked the House to remain in session solely to prevent Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s recess appointments, and 'b'the Constitution prevents the Senate from adjourning'b' without the consent of the House, even if it meets only for a minute every three days. Using a cramped definition of \xe2\x80\x9crecess,\xe2\x80\x9d the panel\xe2\x80\x99s Republican-appointed judges allowed a minority to abuse 'b'the recess-appointments clause'b' of the Constitution for political ends.'b'The situation demonstrates how dysfunctional Washington has become because of these Republican abuses. Although Democrats also used pro forma sessions for this purpose under President George W. Bush, Republicans have blocked Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s appointments at a far higher rate, and they have gone much further by trying to shut down executive agencies through use of the filibuster.'b'Democrats could have changed this by agreeing to curb filibuster abuses this week, particularly on high-level presidential appointments, but they squandered the opportunity. The court\xe2\x80\x99s decision demonstrates how their timidity is being used against them. With no sign that Republicans are willing to let up on their machinations, Mr. Obama was entirely justified in using his executive power to keep federal agencies operating.'b'The federal courts are bearing down on the New York City Police Department\xe2\x80\x99s constitutionally suspect stop-and-frisk program, under which hundreds of thousands of citizens are stopped on the streets each year, often illegally and for no discernible reason. Earlier this month, the federal judge who is presiding over three lawsuits that challenge different parts of the program 'b'issued her harshest ruling yet'b', putting the city on notice that some aspects of stop and frisk are clearly unconstitutional.'b''b'The ruling'b', by Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court in Manhattan, came in the case of Ligon v. the City of New York. The case was brought on behalf of people who say they were illegally stopped, given tickets or arrested on trespassing charges in private apartment buildings, some of them in buildings where they lived.'b'The judge excoriated the city for flagrant indifference to the Fourth Amendment. The amendment has been interpreted by the courts to mean that police officers can legally stop and detain a person only when they have a reasonable suspicion that the person is committing, has committed or is about to commit a crime.'b'The department\xe2\x80\x99s patently illegal strategy, the judge said, encouraged officers to \xe2\x80\x9cstop and question first, develop reasonable suspicion later.\xe2\x80\x9d The ruling focuses on detentions that occurred as people were entering or leaving one of many residential buildings in the Bronx whose managers had simply asked the department to patrol the area and arrest trespassers. The Trespass Affidavit Program, or TAP, has thus not only led to unjustified detentions but has also placed untold numbers people at risk of detention merely for entering their own homes or visiting friends and relatives. Their experiences, as described in the ruling, makes perfectly clear why the largely minority citizens targeted and victimized by the program come away feeling angry and ill used.'b'Describing the typical, humiliating sequence of events, the judge wrote: \xe2\x80\x9cThe police suddenly materialize, stop the person, demand identification, and question the person about where he or she is coming from and what he or she is doing.\xe2\x80\x9d She added that \xe2\x80\x9cattempts at explanation are met with hostility; especially if the person is a young black man, he is frisked, which often involves an invasive search of his pockets; in some cases the officers then detain the person in a police van,\xe2\x80\x9d where he or she is grilled about drugs or weapons. In some cases, the stop escalates into an arrest, the judge noted, with the person fingerprinted and held overnight. Even if the charges are quickly dropped, the arrest can follow the person for years.'b'The judge tore into the city for persisting in this behavior even after prosecutors and department lawyers had become aware that unlawful stops were occurring. In 2011, for example, the Bronx prosecutor\xe2\x80\x99s office become so concerned about the legality of stops made outside the TAP buildings that it routinely 'b'declined to prosecute'b' cases based on them.'b'Judge Scheindlin ordered the Police Department to immediately cease trespass stops outside TAP buildings unless officers have the reasonable suspicion required by law, though she has issued a temporary stay. She has also scheduled a remedy hearing in March, at which time she could require the city to take various remedial steps, including a formal written policy explaining the circumstances under which officers can legally stop people on suspicion of trespass.'b'There are other procedures that can be followed without threatening law enforcement. Instead of defending the indefensible, the city should finally bring the stop-and-frisk program into line with the law.'b'Somalia has been the paradigm of failed states since before 1993, when militants shot down two Black Hawk helicopters and killed 18 American soldiers in Mogadishu. One of the world\xe2\x80\x99s poorest, most violent countries, it has been pummeled by warring militias, famine and pirates. But the country recently has shown enough positive movement that the Obama administration 'b'last week'b' hosted President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud in Washington and recognized Somalia\xe2\x80\x99s government for the first time in more than two decades. It remains to be seen whether competing warlords and clans can ever cooperate to build a real state. Mr. Mohamud needs to follow through on a United Nations plan for reconciliation.'b'It is early to draw firm conclusions, and there are many differences, but Somalia may offer some cautionary advice for the fight now being waged by France at the other end of the African continent against militants in Mali. Degrading militants is likely to take years. Regional forces, rather than foreign forces from farther afield, are best positioned to lead the fight. And political progress is at least as important as military gains.'b'When I was a kid, my parents would occasionally go out together for dinner at a restaurant. Nothing more painful than not being noticed.'b'Boehner\xe2\x80\x99s speech, to the Ripon Society, included repeated references to the fact that the Senate has not passed a budget for several years. They can\xe2\x80\x99t 'b'wait'b'.'b'Once they do, we\xe2\x80\x99ll talk about it over dinner. I hope there are bears in the plot.'b'CORVALLIS, Ore.'b'IT\xe2\x80\x99S rare that our daily lives adhere to dramatic form. But as reported on 'b'Today.com/Moms'b' (\xe2\x80\x9cWaiter hailed as hero after standing up for boy with Down syndrome\xe2\x80\x9d), among other places, a little morality play took shape a few days ago in a Houston restaurant.'b'According to the Today.com article, the Castillo family \xe2\x80\x94 Eric, Kim and their 5-year-old son, Milo, who has Down syndrome \xe2\x80\x94 were having dinner at Laurenzo\xe2\x80\x99s Prime Rib when a family nearby asked to be seated elsewhere.'b'As the waiter, Michael Garcia, recounted to the NBC affiliate KPRC-TV in Houston: \xe2\x80\x9cI heard the man say, \xe2\x80\x98Special needs children need to be special somewhere else.\xe2\x80\x99 My personal feelings took over, and I told him, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to be able to serve you, sir.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9c \xe2\x80\x98How could you say that?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Garcia said he asked the man before he left the restaurant. \xe2\x80\x9c \xe2\x80\x98How could you say that about a beautiful 5-year-old angel?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d'b'For many people, this will be a simple feel-good story. But as the father of an 11-year-old girl with Down syndrome, I found the story more complicated. Beyond its satisfying ending, you can learn a lot about the conflicted place of Down syndrome in the world. The casual insensitivity of the patron\xe2\x80\x99s remark, while not always expressed this blatantly, is all too common. And whether you call Mr. Garcia a hero or not, he unquestionably did the right thing, and his kind of bravery makes an enormous difference in the lives of people with disabilities.'b'As Ms. Castillo pointed out, he put his job on the line. Even more inspiring, he knew the Castillo family, who are regulars at the restaurant, and he acted in the name of connection, denying the very separation \xe2\x80\x94 between \xe2\x80\x9cspecial\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cnormal\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 that the unidentified patron implied.'b'Ms. Castillo\xe2\x80\x99s characterization of her son also stood out because it broke through the prescribed roles of the story. Her description is loving and positive, yet she emphasizes ordinary qualities as well as angelic ones. She said her son likes to give hugs, but is also occasionally \xe2\x80\x9cobnoxious which, like any other 5-year-old, he can be.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'She also noted that Milo has friends \xe2\x80\x9cboth with and without Down syndrome.\xe2\x80\x9d That detail stayed with me, not only because it is true to my experience but also because it suggests how far we\xe2\x80\x99ve come. The history of disability in our country is mostly tragic. During decades of routine institutionalization and sterilization, a shared preschool \xe2\x80\x94 let alone friendship, or being a valued regular customer at a Houston restaurant \xe2\x80\x94was not on the table. If there were a slogan for those grim decades, \xe2\x80\x9clet them be special somewhere else\xe2\x80\x9d would sum things up pretty well.'b'Most of the progress for children with Down syndrome in the United States \xe2\x80\x94 their right to go to school, for instance \xe2\x80\x94 is recent and gained momentum, in part, from a recognition that \xe2\x80\x9csomewhere else\xe2\x80\x9d often meant an institutional horror no human being should ever have to experience. Geraldo Rivera\xe2\x80\x99s 1972 hidden-camera expos\xc3\xa9 of the Willowbrook State School on Staten Island was instrumental in showing exactly how grim conditions could be. That expos\xc3\xa9 was one small part of a tidal change in which advocates for the disabled inspired by the civil rights movement, committed parents and others fought for the things that today\xe2\x80\x99s parents take for granted. When our daughter Laura was born, my wife and I often wondered about the future. But we did not wonder whether she would be allowed to go to kindergarten.'b'Our advances, however, are still a work in progress. While it\xe2\x80\x99s true that open bigotry is less common than it used to be, the absence of direct hostility is not the same as the absence of ignorance. The word \xe2\x80\x9cretard\xe2\x80\x9d is common in the schoolyard and on our screens: while our taboos about difference shift with incredible speed, slurs about intellectual disability often get a pass. From the movies \xe2\x80\x9cTropic Thunder\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cThe Hangover,\xe2\x80\x9d from Rahm Emanuel to Ann Coulter, \xe2\x80\x9cretard\xe2\x80\x9d still tends to be seen as edgy, not bigoted. Of course, the issues in question transcend labels: in the Houston restaurant, the word \xe2\x80\x9cspecial\xe2\x80\x9d was used as an insult, which only testifies to the resilience of prejudice. Any word can be repurposed for contempt.'b'What is it about intellectual disability that we find so difficult? Sometimes it seems our focus on \xe2\x80\x9cpositive\xe2\x80\x9d qualities, like being \xe2\x80\x9ccute\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9chappy\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9csweet,\xe2\x80\x9d is meant to compensate for disability. We\xe2\x80\x99re a long way from seeing all human beings as part of a single continuum. We also, it has to be said, do a lot better with children than adults \xe2\x80\x94 perhaps because historically we imagine adults with Down syndrome as children. A child with Down syndrome may have a place at the table, but adults are a different matter. In housing and employment, their place is uncertain; the 'b'recent scandal 'b'in New York State with rampant, unchecked abuse in group homes should give pause to anyone who thinks that our American history with disability has come to a happy ending.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s moving to me that Milo Castillo\xe2\x80\x99s story takes place in a restaurant, given the civil rights history of lunch counters and water fountains. What\xe2\x80\x99s a more visceral expression of belonging than where we\xe2\x80\x99re allowed to eat? Where else would manners and rights intersect? As presented in the television report, the opinion voiced by the unidentified patron \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cbe special somewhere else\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 is seen as a shocking instance of rudeness. It is. But more significantly, it\xe2\x80\x99s the sentiment that, when widespread, makes it possible for people to lose rights in the first place.'b'Dehumanizing practices depend on dehumanizing ideas. Instead of seeing the scene in the restaurant as a story with a heroic resolution, we might see it as a debate carried out in words and actions. Taking a kid with Down syndrome to a restaurant is a statement: he\xe2\x80\x99s a family member first, and he belongs. Saying that the kid shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be there, as the patron did, is one response; Mr. Garcia\xe2\x80\x99s principled refusal to provide service is yet another. That scene, tidy as it is, is only one part of a long American conversation about who does and doesn\xe2\x80\x99t belong.'b'Beneath the human interest story, in other words, is a question about who counts as human. For parents of children with Down syndrome like me, every daily act is an answer. What I live for, though, is the day when the question doesn\xe2\x80\x99t come up.'b'In late March 2009, 'b'Yahoo Sports published a story'b' alleging that the University of Connecticut had violated 'b'N.C.A.A.'b' rules in its efforts to recruit Nate Miles, a 6-foot-7 basketball player from Toledo, Ohio. The N.C.A.A. enforcement staff, led by Tim Nevius, one of its top investigators, opened an inquiry.'b'By then, Miles was back in Toledo; he\xe2\x80\x99d been expelled from UConn in October 2008, before ever playing a game. No longer a \xe2\x80\x9cstudent-athlete,\xe2\x80\x9d Miles refused to cooperate. Yet Nevius interviewed Dr. Chris MacLaren, a Florida orthopedic surgeon, who had once operated on Miles\xe2\x80\x99s foot. Without any consent from the patient, Nevius asked for, and MacLaren provided, details of Miles\xe2\x80\x99s surgery and its costs.'b'This, of course, was a gross violation of medical ethics. It was also, in all likelihood, a violation of 'b'medical privacy laws'b'. But when several lawyers involved in the case brought this potential illegality to the attention of the 'b'Committee on Infractions'b' \xe2\x80\x94 which metes out punishment to rules violators, and which includes a number of lawyers \xe2\x80\x94 the response was coldly dismissive. A medical release from Miles \xe2\x80\x9cwas not required,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Shepard Cooper, then the committee director. How did he know? Because Nevius had told him so. So much for the law.'b'Earlier this week, Mark Emmert, the N.C.A.A. president, acknowledged that the enforcement staff had, once again, done something deeply unethical. Without Smith\xe2\x80\x99s support, it\xe2\x80\x99s unlikely the bill could get to the Senate floor.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Paul Bibeau, who writes \xe2\x80\x9ca blog of dark humor\xe2\x80\x9d from Virginia, 'b'points out'b' a numerical oddity about the effects of the Virginia law that turns out, upon reflection, to be more stinging than funny: \xe2\x80\x9cThis bill counts an Obama voter as 3/5 of a person.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That is because, as Talking Points Memo 'b'says'b', \xe2\x80\x9cObama voters would have received almost exactly 3/5 of the electoral vote compared to their actual population \xe2\x80\x94 30.7 percent of the electoral vote over 51 percent of the popular vote.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This is not where we should be in 2013, debating whether to pass bills to reduce urban voters to a fraction of the value of other voters and hoping that someone with the power to stop it thinks it\xe2\x80\x99s a \xe2\x80\x9cbad idea.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'LOS ANGELES'b'THIRTY years ago, I was given a diagnosis of schizophrenia. My prognosis was \xe2\x80\x9cgrave\xe2\x80\x9d: I would never live independently, hold a job, find a loving partner, get married. My home would be a board-and-care facility, my days spent watching TV in a day room with other people debilitated by mental illness. I would work at menial jobs when my symptoms were quiet. Following my last psychiatric hospitalization at the age of 28, I was encouraged by a doctor to work as a cashier making change. If I could handle that, I was told, we would reassess my ability to hold a more demanding position, perhaps even something full-time.'b'Then I made a decision. I would write the narrative of my life. Today I am a chaired professor at the University of Southern California Gould School of Law. I have an adjunct appointment in the department of psychiatry at the medical school of the University of California, San Diego, and am on the faculty of the New Center for Psychoanalysis. The MacArthur Foundation gave me a 'b'genius grant'b'.'b'Although I fought my diagnosis for many years, I came to accept that I have schizophrenia and will be in treatment the rest of my life. Indeed, excellent psychoanalytic treatment and medication have been critical to my success. What I refused to accept was my prognosis.'b'Conventional psychiatric thinking and its diagnostic categories say that people like me don\xe2\x80\x99t exist. Either I don\xe2\x80\x99t have schizophrenia (please tell that to the delusions crowding my mind), or I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have accomplished what I have (please tell that to U.S.C.\xe2\x80\x99s committee on faculty affairs). But I do, and I have. And I have undertaken research with colleagues at U.S.C. and U.C.L.A. to show that I am not alone. There are others with schizophrenia and such active symptoms as delusions and hallucinations who have significant academic and professional achievements.'b'Over the last few years, my colleagues, including Stephen Marder, Alison Hamilton and Amy Cohen, and I have gathered 20 research subjects with high-functioning schizophrenia in Los Angeles. They suffered from symptoms like mild delusions or hallucinatory behavior. Their average age was 40. Half were male, half female, and more than half were minorities. All had high school diplomas, and a majority either had or were working toward college or graduate degrees. They were graduate students, managers, technicians and professionals, including a doctor, lawyer, psychologist and chief executive of a nonprofit group.'b'At the same time, most were unmarried and childless, which is consistent with their diagnoses. (My colleagues and I intend to do another study on people with schizophrenia who are high-functioning in terms of their relationships. Marrying in my mid-40s \xe2\x80\x94 the best thing that ever happened to me \xe2\x80\x94 was against all odds, following almost 18 years of not dating.) More than three-quarters had been hospitalized between two and five times because of their illness, while three had never been admitted.'b'How had these people with schizophrenia managed to succeed in their studies and at such high-level jobs? We learned that, in addition to medication and therapy, all the participants had developed techniques to keep their schizophrenia at bay. For some, these techniques were cognitive. An educator with a master\xe2\x80\x99s degree said he had learned to face his hallucinations and ask, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the evidence for that? Or is it just a perception problem?\xe2\x80\x9d Another participant said, \xe2\x80\x9cI hear derogatory voices all the time. ... You just gotta blow them off.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Part of vigilance about symptoms was \xe2\x80\x9cidentifying triggers\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cprevent a fuller blown experience of symptoms,\xe2\x80\x9d said a participant who works as a coordinator at a nonprofit group. For instance, if being with people in close quarters for too long can set off symptoms, build in some alone time when you travel with friends.'b'Other techniques that our participants cited included controlling sensory inputs. For some, this meant keeping their living space simple (bare walls, no TV, only quiet music), while for others, it meant distracting music. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll listen to loud music if I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to hear things,\xe2\x80\x9d said a participant who is a certified nurse\xe2\x80\x99s assistant. Still others mentioned exercise, a healthy diet, avoiding alcohol and getting enough sleep. A belief in God and prayer also played a role for some.'b'One of the most frequently mentioned techniques that helped our research participants manage their symptoms was work. \xe2\x80\x9cWork has been an important part of who I am,\xe2\x80\x9d said an educator in our group. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you become useful to an organization and feel respected in that organization, there\xe2\x80\x99s a certain value in belonging there.\xe2\x80\x9d This person works on the weekends too because of \xe2\x80\x9cthe distraction factor.\xe2\x80\x9d In other words, by engaging in work, the crazy stuff often recedes to the sidelines.'b'Personally, I reach out to my doctors, friends and family whenever I start slipping, and I get great support from them. I eat comfort food (for me, cereal) and listen to quiet music. I minimize all stimulation. Usually these techniques, combined with more medication and therapy, will make the symptoms pass. But the work piece \xe2\x80\x94 using my mind \xe2\x80\x94 is my best defense. It keeps me focused, it keeps the demons at bay. My mind, I have come to say, is both my worst enemy and my best friend.'b'THAT is why it is so distressing when doctors tell their patients not to expect or pursue fulfilling careers. Far too often, the conventional psychiatric approach to mental illness is to see clusters of symptoms that characterize people. Accordingly, many psychiatrists hold the view that treating symptoms with medication is treating mental illness. But this fails to take into account individuals\xe2\x80\x99 strengths and capabilities, leading mental health professionals to underestimate what their patients can hope to achieve in the world.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not just schizophrenia: earlier this month, The Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry posted a study showing that a small group of people who were given diagnoses of autism, a developmental disorder, later stopped exhibiting symptoms. They 'b'seemed to have recovered'b' \xe2\x80\x94 though after years of behavioral therapy and treatment. A recent New York Times Magazine article described a new company that hires high-functioning adults with autism, taking advantage of their unusual memory skills and attention to detail.'b'I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to sound like a Pollyanna about schizophrenia; mental illness imposes real limitations, and it\xe2\x80\x99s important not to romanticize it. We can\xe2\x80\x99t all be Nobel laureates like John Nash of the movie \xe2\x80\x9cA Beautiful Mind.\xe2\x80\x9d But the seeds of creative thinking may sometimes be found in mental illness, and people underestimate the power of the human brain to adapt and to create.'b'An approach that looks for individual strengths, in addition to considering symptoms, could help dispel the pessimism surrounding mental illness. Finding \xe2\x80\x9cthe wellness within the illness,\xe2\x80\x9d as one person with schizophrenia said, should be a therapeutic goal. Doctors should urge their patients to develop relationships and engage in meaningful work. They should encourage patients to find their own repertory of techniques to manage their symptoms and aim for a quality of life as they define it. And they should provide patients with the resources \xe2\x80\x94 therapy, medication and support \xe2\x80\x94 to make these things happen.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEvery person has a unique gift or unique self to bring to the world,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of our study\xe2\x80\x99s participants. She expressed the reality that those of us who have schizophrenia and other mental illnesses want what everyone wants: in the words of Sigmund Freud, to work and to love.'b'In one of the 23 'b'executive actions'b' on gun control signed this month, President Obama instructed the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and other federal science agencies to conduct research into the causes and prevention of gun violence. He called on Congress to aid that effort by providing $10 million for the C.D.C. in the next budget round and $20 million to expand the federal reporting system on violent deaths to all 50 states, from the current 18.'b'That Mr. Obama had to make such a decree at all is a measure of the power of the gun lobby, which has 'b'effectively shut down'b' government-financed research on gun violence for 17 years. Research on guns is crucial to any long-term effort to reduce death from guns. In other words, treat gun violence as a public health issue.'b'But that is precisely what the National Rifle Association and other opponents of firearms regulation do not want. In the absence of reliable data and data-driven policy recommendations, talk about guns inevitably lurches into the unknown, allowing abstractions, propaganda and ideology to fill the void and thwart change.'b'The research freeze began at a time when the C.D.C. was making strides in 'b'studying gun violence as a public health problem'b'. Before that, the issue had been regarded mainly as a law enforcement challenge or as a problem of disparate acts by deranged offenders, an approach that remains in sync with the N.R.A. worldview.'b''b'Public health research emphasizes'b' prevention of death, disability and injury. It focuses not only on the gun user, but on the gun, in much the same way that public health efforts to reduce motor vehicle deaths have long focused on both drivers and cars.'b'The goal is to understand a health threat and identify lifesaving interventions. At their most basic, gun policy recommendations would extend beyond buying and owning a gun (say, background checks and safe storage devices) to manufacturing (childproofing and other federal safety standards) and distribution (stronger antitrafficking laws), as well as educating and enlisting parents, physicians, teachers and other community leaders to talk about the risks and responsibilities of gun ownership.'b'But by the early 1990s, C.D.C. gun research had advanced to the point that it contradicted N.R.A. ideology. Some studies found, for example, that people living in a home with a gun were not safer; they faced a significantly elevated risk of 'b'homicide'b' and 'b'suicide'b'.'b'The N.R.A. denounced the research as \xe2\x80\x9cpolitical opinion masquerading as medical science,\xe2\x80\x9d and in 1996, Congress took $2.6 million intended for gun research and redirected it to traumatic brain injury. It prohibited the use of C.D.C. money \xe2\x80\x9cto advocate or promote gun control.\xe2\x80\x9d Since then, similar prohibitions have been imposed on other agencies, including the National Institutes of Health.'b'Technically, the prohibition is not a ban on all research, but the law has cast a pall that even prominent foundations and academic centers cannot entirely overcome. That is in part because comprehensive public health efforts require systematic data gathering and analysis, the scale and scope of which is a government undertaking. To understand and prevent motor vehicle deaths, for instance, the government tracks more than 100 variables per fatal crash, including the make, model and year of the vehicles, the speed and speed limit, the location of passengers, seat belt use and air bag deployment.'b'Guns deaths do not get such scrutiny. That does not mean we do not know enough to act. The evidence linking gun prevalence and violent death is strong and compelling; 'b'international comparisons'b' are also instructive.'b'But we need more data to formulate, analyze and evaluate policy to focus on what works and to refine or reject what does not. How many guns are stolen? How do guns first get diverted into illegal hands? How many murderers would have passed today\xe2\x80\x99s background checks? What percentage of criminal gun traces are accounted for by, say, the top 5 percent of gun dealers? How many households possess firearms: is it one-third as some surveys suggest, or one-half?'b'The gun lobby is likely to claim that any federally financed gun research, per se, is banned by law, a charge that would force debate of whether evidence-based policy recommendations are tantamount to lobbying. Or the C.D.C. may choose to focus on data collection and leave the policy recommendations to outside researchers. That would be a sorry situation for government scientists, but an improvement over the status quo.'b'It is obvious that gun violence is a public health threat. A 'b'letter'b' this month to Vice President Joseph Biden Jr.\xe2\x80\x99s gun violence commission from more than 100 researchers in public health and related fields pointed out that mortality rates from almost every major cause of death have declined drastically over the past half century. Motor vehicle deaths per mile driven in America have fallen by more than 80 percent. But the homicide rate in the United States, driven by guns, is almost exactly the same as it was in 1950.'b'Carl Malamud is the founder and president of the nonprofit 'b'Public.Resource.Org'b'. It\xe2\x80\x99s like going to Italy and saying you invented a pasta.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI HAVE nothing against priests,\xe2\x80\x9d writes Garry Wills in his provocative new book, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy Priests? A Failed Tradition,\xe2\x80\x9d and I\xe2\x80\x99d like at the outset to say the same. During a career that has included no small number of formal interviews and informal conversations with them, I\xe2\x80\x99ve met many I admire, men of genuine compassion and remarkable altruism, more dedicated to humanity than to any dogma or selective tradition.'b'But while I have nothing against priests, I have quite a lot against an institution that has done a disservice to them and to the parishioners in whose interests they should toil. I refer to the Roman Catholic Church, specifically to its modern incarnation and current leaders, who have tucked priests into a cosseted caste above the flock, wrapped them in mysticism and prioritized their protection and reputations over the needs and sometimes even the anguish of the people in the pews. I have a problem, in other words, with the church\xe2\x80\x99s arrogance, a thread that runs through Wills\xe2\x80\x99s book, to be published next month; through fresh revelations of how assiduously a cardinal in Los Angeles worked to cover up child sexual abuse; and through the church\xe2\x80\x99s attempts to silence dissenters, including an outspoken clergyman in Ireland who was recently back in the news.'b'LET\xe2\x80\x99S start with Los Angeles. At one point Cardinal Mahony instructed a priest whom he\xe2\x80\x99d dispatched to New Mexico for counseling not to return to California, lest he risk being criminally prosecuted. That sort of shielding of priests from accountability allowed them, in many cases across the United States, to continue their abusive behavior and claim more young victims.'b'Cardinal Mahony, who led the Los Angeles archdiocese from 1985 to 2011, 'b'released a statement'b' last week in which he said that until 2006, when he began to meet with dozens of victims, he didn\xe2\x80\x99t grasp \xe2\x80\x9cthe full and lasting impact these horrible acts would have\xe2\x80\x9d on the children subjected to them. This hubris abetted the crisis: the particular sway that abusers held over their victims and the special trust they received from those children\xe2\x80\x99s parents were tied into the church\xe2\x80\x99s presentation of priests as paragons.'b'And this hubris also survives the crisis, manifest in the way that the Vatican, a gilded enclave so far removed and so frequently out of step with the rest of the world, clamps down on Catholics who challenge its rituals and rules. Much of what these dissenters raise questions about \xe2\x80\x94 the all-male priesthood, for example, or the commitment to celibacy that priests are required to make \xe2\x80\x94 aren\xe2\x80\x99t indisputable edicts from God. They\xe2\x80\x99re inventions of the mortals who took charge of the faith.'b'And yet with imperious regularity, Vatican officials issue their relished condemnations. These officials are reliably riled by nuns, a favorite target of their wrath. And they\xe2\x80\x99ve been none too pleased with an Irish priest, the Rev. Tony Flannery, 66, who was 'b'suspended from his ministry'b' by the Vatican last year and informed, 'b'he recently said'b', that he could return to it on the condition that he publicly express his endorsement of a range of official positions that he had questioned, including the exclusion of women from the priesthood. Last Sunday he broke a long silence to say that the Vatican had threatened him with excommunication and to call its approach toward him \xe2\x80\x9creminiscent of the Inquisition.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Among the Vatican\xe2\x80\x99s issues with him was his stated belief in a 2010 article that the priesthood, rather than originating with Jesus and a specially selected group of followers, was selfishly created later by a \xe2\x80\x9cprivileged group within the community who had abrogated power and authority to themselves.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That may sound like an extreme assertion, but the new book by Wills, a Pulitzer Prize winner who has written extensively about Christianity and the church, says that at the start, Christianity not only didn\xe2\x80\x99t have priests but opposed them. The priesthood was a subsequent tweak, and the same goes for the all-male, celibate nature of the Roman Catholic clergy and the autocratic hierarchy that this clergy inhabits, an unresponsive government whose subjects \xe2\x80\x94 the laity \xe2\x80\x94 have limited say.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt can\xe2\x80\x99t admit to error, the church hierarchy,\xe2\x80\x9d Wills told me on the phone on Thursday. \xe2\x80\x9cAny challenge to their prerogative is, in their eyes, a challenge to God. You can\xe2\x80\x99t be any more arrogant than that.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe Catholics were taught not only that we must have priests but that they must be the right kind of priests,\xe2\x80\x9d he writes in the book, which argues that priests aren\xe2\x80\x99t ultimately necessary. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat we were supposed to accept is that all priesthoods are invalid ones except the Roman Catholic.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s an awfully puffed-up position, and there\xe2\x80\x99s a corresponding haughtiness in the fact that bishops can assign priests to parishes without any real obligation to get input or feedback from the parishioners those priests serve. This way of doing business in fact enabled church leaders to shuttle priests accused of molestation around, keeping them one step ahead of their crimes.'b'It has also helped to turn many Catholics away from the church, while prompting others to regard its leaders as ornamental and somewhat irrelevant distractions. They cherish the essence and beauty of their religion. They just can\xe2\x80\x99t abide the arrogance of many of its appointed caretakers.'b'Prime Minister David Cameron, like much of the British public, is ambivalent about his country\xe2\x80\x99s future in the European Union. He correctly recognizes that a Britain outside the union would count for less in world affairs, forfeit the privileged access it now enjoys to its largest trading partner, and lose its seat at the European table where matters of great importance to Britain are discussed \xe2\x80\x94 from cross-border banking rules to environmental regulation.'b'Yet he wishes the European project had limited itself to a loose customs union instead of the more ambitious goal of \xe2\x80\x9can ever closer union\xe2\x80\x9d enshrined in the founding treaties that Britain accepted when it joined in 1973 and embodied in a host of labor, environmental and human rights standards, border conventions and consumer regulations. It did not, and most of Mr. Cameron\xe2\x80\x99s European partners do not wish to revisit that fundamental question.'b'Mr. Cameron expressed his ambivalence 'b'in a long- awaited speech on Wednesday'b'. He pretended that Britain could have it both ways. Without going into details of what he might find acceptable, he promised that if his Conservatives won the next election, in two years, he would try to renegotiate the terms of British membership and submit the results to a referendum in 2017 or 2018.'b'Wednesday\xe2\x80\x99s elegant straddle may serve Mr. Cameron\xe2\x80\x99s political needs of the moment. But, for Britain, it is an unwise and risky course. It presages four or five years of costly uncertainty for potential investors in a struggling British economy that Mr. Cameron\xe2\x80\x99s wrongheaded austerity policies have failed to revive. Ambivalence may prove a political luxury with a high economic price tag. And we are concerned that Britain\xe2\x80\x99s European Union partners may be inclined to take its voice less seriously, not more, during the run-up to the promised referendum.'b'That referendum may not happen. Four years is a long time in British politics and in the evolution of the European Union. Germany holds potentially important elections this year. So does Italy. In Britain, the Conservatives trail Labour in the polls. Mr. Cameron\xe2\x80\x99s coalition partner, the Liberal Democrats, are more enthusiastic about Europe and less enthusiastic about a referendum than he is. Mr. Cameron\xe2\x80\x99s real aim for now may be to appease militant euro-skeptics in his party and nip a growing challenge from the United Kingdom Independence Party on his right.'b'As this page has often argued, there is much to criticize in the way the European Union runs its affairs, from wasteful agricultural subsidies to the catastrophic mishandling of Greece\xe2\x80\x99s sovereign debt. Mr. Cameron is right to challenge Europe to become less protectionist and more democratic. He is right to insist that the 10 union countries that have not joined the euro not be ignored in economic and financial policy discussions by the 17 that have. But it is hard to see how he can press these views unless Britain remains an active and respected voice in European deliberations, now and in the future.'b'DAVOS, Switzerland'b'IT\xe2\x80\x99S the annual conclave of the presumed powerful, 'b'the World Economic Forum'b' in Davos, with the wealthy flying in on private jets to discuss issues like global poverty. As always, it\xe2\x80\x99s a sea of men. This year, 'b'female participation is 17 percent'b'.'b'Perhaps that\xe2\x80\x99s not surprising, considering that global business and political leaders are overwhelmingly male. In America, only 'b'17 percent of American Fortune 500 board seats'b' are held by women, a mere 3 percent of board chairs are women \xe2\x80\x94 and women 'b'are barely represented in President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s cabinet'b'.'b'Indeed, I\xe2\x80\x99m guessing that the average boardroom doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have much better gender equality than a team of cave hunters attacking a woolly mammoth 30,000 years ago.'b'So what gives? A provocative answer comes from 'b'Sheryl Sandberg'b', the chief operating officer of Facebook, who has written a smart book due out in March that attributes the gender gap, in part, to chauvinism and corporate obstacles \xe2\x80\x94 but also, in part, to women who don\xe2\x80\x99t aggressively pursue opportunities.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe hold ourselves back in ways both big and small, by lacking self-confidence, by not raising our hands, and by pulling back when we should be leaning in,\xe2\x80\x9d Sandberg writes in the book, 'b'called \xe2\x80\x9cLean In.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe internalize the negative messages we get throughout our lives, the messages that say it\xe2\x80\x99s wrong to be outspoken, aggressive, more powerful than men. We lower our own expectations of what we can achieve. We continue to do the majority of the housework and child care. We compromise our career goals to make room for partners and children who may not even exist yet.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Sandberg and I discussed the issue on a panel here in Davos, and I think that there is something real and important in what she says. When I lecture at universities, the first questions are invariably asked by a man \xe2\x80\x94 even at a women\xe2\x80\x99s college. When I point at someone in a crowd to ask a question, the women in the area almost always look at each other hesitantly \xe2\x80\x94 and any man in the vicinity jumps up and asks his question.'b''b'A McKinsey survey'b' published in April found that 36 percent of male employees at major companies aspired to be top executives, compared with 18 percent of the women. 'b'A study of Carnegie Mellon M.B.A. graduates'b' in 2003 found that 57 percent of the men, but only 7 percent of the women, tried to negotiate a higher initial salary offer.'b'Sandberg, one of the most prominent women in corporate America, is not known as a shrinking violet.
