She confesses that when she was in elementary school, she trained her younger brother and sister to follow her around, listen to her give speeches and periodically shout: \xe2\x80\x9cRight!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Yet she acknowledges that she has harbored many insecurities, sometimes shedding tears at the office, as well as doubts about her juggling of work and family.'b'When she joined Facebook as its No. 2, she was initially willing to accept the first offer from Mark Zuckerberg, the founder. She writes that her husband and brother-in-law hounded her to demand more, so she did \xe2\x80\x94 and got a better deal.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am hoping that each woman will set her own goals and reach for them with gusto,\xe2\x80\x9d Sandberg writes. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd I am hoping that each man will do his part to support women in the workplace and in the home, also with gusto.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Yet I wish that there could be two versions of Sandberg\xe2\x80\x99s book. One marketed to young women would encourage them to be more assertive. One marketed to men (and women already in leadership) would emphasize the need for structural changes to accommodate women and families.'b'Is Sandberg blaming the victim? I don\xe2\x80\x99t think so, but I also don\xe2\x80\x99t want to relax the pressure on employers to do a much better job of recruiting and promoting women.'b'Nature and social mores together make motherhood more all-consuming than fatherhood, yet the modern job was built for a distracted father. That\xe2\x80\x99s not great for dads and can be just about impossible for moms \xe2\x80\x94 at least those who don\xe2\x80\x99t have great wealth or extraordinary spouses.'b'Sandberg famously leaves the office at 5:30 most days to be with her kids, but not many women (or men) would dare try that.'b'Some people believe that women are more nurturing bosses, or that they offer more support to women below them. I\xe2\x80\x99m skeptical. Women can be jerks as much as men.'b'But we need more women in leadership positions for another reason: 'b'considerable evidence suggests'b' that more diverse groups reach better decisions. Corporations should promote women not just out of fairness, but also because it helps them perform better. Lehman Brothers might still be around today 'b'if it were Lehman Brothers &amp; Sisters'b'.'b'So, yes, let\xe2\x80\x99s encourage young women to \xe2\x80\x9clean in,\xe2\x80\x9d but let\xe2\x80\x99s also change the workplace so that when they do lean in and assert themselves, we\xe2\x80\x99re directly behind them shouting: \xe2\x80\x9cRight!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Scientists who had 'b'stopped research'b' during the past year on a newly created bird flu virus because of safety and terrorism concerns have announced plans to resume their work. We wish we could be as sanguine as they are that all the earlier concerns have been dealt with.'b'The concerns arose after two research groups, one in the Netherlands and one in Wisconsin, genetically altered a bird flu virus, which seldom infects humans but is lethal when it does. Five to nine genetic mutations in the Dutch experiment allowed the bird flu virus to spread by coughs and sneezes among ferrets, a laboratory model for what might happen in humans.'b'The scientists published their first papers last year in two leading journals, Science and Nature, after agreeing to a voluntary moratorium on further research until governments and research organizations could decide on ground rules to protect the public.'b'Now, they say, 'b'the work can resume'b' in countries that have set conditions to ensure safety and security. That will not help the Wisconsin researchers, whose work was financed by the National Institutes of Health, which has not yet issued guidelines. But it may benefit the Dutch team, whose work was also financed by the N.I.H. but which believes it can use money from other sources to restart its studies.'b'Critics of the research had focused initially on whether terrorists might steal the virus or use the publications as a blueprint to make their own lethal strain. Later the emphasis shifted to safety \xe2\x80\x94 the risk that the virus might escape from a laboratory or that inept imitators might unwittingly unleash an epidemic.'b'The researchers claim that the benefits of the research \xe2\x80\x94 greater understanding of how flu viruses adapt to mammals and advance warning as to whether bird flu is close to becoming transmissible through the air \xe2\x80\x94 outweigh what they consider small risks in such experiments.'b'But as 'b'an editorial in Nature'b' observed, \xe2\x80\x9can independent risk-benefit analysis\xe2\x80\x9d of such research \xe2\x80\x9cis still lacking.\xe2\x80\x9d The editorial warned, wisely, \xe2\x80\x9cThe potential risks of the work demand exceptional precautions in any future research.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'SNOW was my first love. From November\xe2\x80\x99s first flakes and the season\xe2\x80\x99s first blizzard, to unexpected midnight dustings and late March blasts, snow fell frequently and happily on my childhood in western Massachusetts. I never complained about the unshoveled, post-blizzard darkness of my paper route, nor about scrambling over icy drifts en route to school. In the evenings I read in front of our wood stove, captivated by thoughts of Narnia\xe2\x80\x99s endless winter.'b'Snow gives us a new world. It gives us (not least) a day off to contemplate it. Snow bestows silence: deep snowfalls \xe2\x80\x9cspread their peace,\xe2\x80\x9d said Saint-Exup\xc3\xa9ry. Above all, snow gives meaning to the great indoors. Thoreau wrote that in winter, \xe2\x80\x9cwarmth stands for all virtue.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Coming in from the cold requires going out. I loved to build fires as dusk and snow began to fall; even more, I loved to stagger with an armful of logs back to a house aglow between an ivory landscape and an ice field of stars.'b'Fortunately, despite worries about a warming planet, no one is predicting the end of snow anytime soon. Some cold places will see more snow, because warmer air can carry more moisture. In the Northern Hemisphere, snow coverage this past December was the greatest since records began in 1966, 'b'Rutgers University\xe2\x80\x99s Global Snow Lab'b' reported. But Dr. 'b'David Robinson'b', a climatologist at Rutgers, warns that year-to-year fluctuations and regional differences can deceive casual observers. In general, he says, there has been an \xe2\x80\x9coverall decline in snowfall.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Other studies echo that conclusion. The 'b'United States Global Change Research Program'b'\xe2\x80\x99s recently released draft 'b'National Climate Assessment'b' reports that \xe2\x80\x9cOverall snow cover has decreased in the Northern Hemisphere, due in part to higher temperatures that shorten the time snow spends on the ground.\xe2\x80\x9d The report also notes a decline in the frequency of very snowy winters and in snow accumulations in the American West, and said we can expect more rainstorms \xe2\x80\x9cin previously snow-dominated settings.\xe2\x80\x9d A 'b'recent study'b' by the Natural Resources Defense Council warns that without action on climate change, the snow season in the Northeast will be halved by 2100.'b'I have some sympathy for those who say good riddance to snow. Snow, when it overturns our normal routines, can be its own reward: a Berkshire friend\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cblizzard action plan\xe2\x80\x9d involves music and joyful bread-baking. But disrupted transportation and the challenges that winter weather can impose on older people are no joke.'b'Whatever your 'b'feelings for snow'b', its evanescence will cost you. 'b'Frank Lowenstein'b', a climate specialist with 'b'the Nature Conservancy'b', told me: \xe2\x80\x9cthe snowpack out West is how we store water for the summer for half the country. And it\xe2\x80\x99s disappearing.\xe2\x80\x9d That means less summer water for cities, agriculture and recreation. It means more wildfires. Changing ecosystems will also affect wildlife, while less snowy landscapes absorb still more heat from the sun. The National Climate Assessment expects heat-related deaths to increase more than winter-weather-related fatalities will decline.'b'Nor should we forget how often and how beautifully snow has fallen upon America\xe2\x80\x99s cultural landscape. Think Rockwell and Frost, of course, Bing Crosby and 'b'Emerson'b' (\xe2\x80\x9cthe mad wind\xe2\x80\x99s night-work/The frolic architecture of the snow\xe2\x80\x9d). It\xe2\x80\x99s not as if Melville compared the 'b'color of his whale'b' to a cold winter rain. We may not associate snowboarders with quiet contemplation of winter\xe2\x80\x99s formal elegance. But note the words chosen by 'b'Protect Our Winters'b', a snowboarder-founded group that encourages winter sports enthusiasts to \xe2\x80\x9csave a season that fuels our passions.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'The National Ski Areas Association'b' has already enrolled about 20 ski areas in its Climate Challenge program (slogan: \xe2\x80\x9cKeep Winter Cool\xe2\x80\x9d).'b'IF you\xe2\x80\x99re still unmoved by what we\xe2\x80\x99ll lose as the snows melt from America\xe2\x80\x99s lands and imagination, then join me on a Dickensian tour of the ghost of winter future \xe2\x80\x94 also known as Britain.'b'Snow in Britain is beloved but rare: beloved because it\xe2\x80\x99s rare. The Oxford scholar Robert Douglas-Fairhurst reminded me that a few unusually snowy winters, coincidental with Dickens\xe2\x80\x99s childhood, infused \xe2\x80\x9cA Christmas Carol,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThe Pickwick Papers\xe2\x80\x9d and, ultimately, the modern British psyche with blizzard-laden fantasies out of all proportion to actual precipitation, at least of the frozen kind. If Dickens got Britain\xe2\x80\x99s fictitious snowball rolling, think of 'b'Dylan Thomas'b', the winter weather at 'b'Harry Potter'b'\xe2\x80\x99s Hogwarts, and \xe2\x80\x9cThe Snowman,\xe2\x80\x9d a deeply beloved children\xe2\x80\x99s book ('b'the film'b' was introduced by David Bowie, whose recent surprise single a British reviewer compared to unexpected overnight snow).'b'Last weekend\xe2\x80\x99s widespread snow across Britain 'b'produced scenes'b' as joyful and exuberant as ever. Still, not all Britons love their rare winter guest. Stephen Bayley, a critic and writer, despises snow. Mr. Bayley fingers Prince Albert, Queen Victoria\xe2\x80\x99s consort, for bringing Christmas trees to Windsor, and \xe2\x80\x9cwith them a sort of Teutonic forest-worship which, in the popular imagination, was associated with snow.\xe2\x80\x9d And Dr. Douglas-Fairhurst notes that British snow, like most love affairs, \xe2\x80\x9ctends to bring as much misery as pleasure.\xe2\x80\x9d Britain\xe2\x80\x99s inability to clear snow from roads and rails is legendary.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s also suspicious, given the joyful day off from work and school that typically results. But whatever the truth behind the snowy London streets undisturbed by \xe2\x80\x9csnow ploughs,\xe2\x80\x9d the contrast between Britain\xe2\x80\x99s snow-blind love and the damp browns of the country\xe2\x80\x99s typical winter landscape offers a chilling warning to Americans taking pleasure in yet another season of sidewalks that don\xe2\x80\x99t require shoveling. Tennyson \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cring, happy bells, across the snow!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 reminded the Victorians that it is better to have loved and lost. True for snow? Americans may know sooner than they might wish.'b'Is there a stranger figure in American literature than the narrator of \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick\xe2\x80\x9d? He says, \xe2\x80\x9cCall me Ishmael\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 the very first words of the book \xe2\x80\x94 but that isn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly the same as saying \xe2\x80\x9cMy name is Ishmael.\xe2\x80\x9d He could be anyone, of any name, but Ishmael is what the reader must agree to call him before the book can get under way. I recently drove with a friend from my farm in New York State to Southern California, and Ishmael was our companion. We picked him up, so to speak, on the dark, icy streets of New Bedford, round about 1851, and delivered him within sight of what he calls \xe2\x80\x9cyour contemplative Pacific,\xe2\x80\x9d ageless as always.'b'As \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick\xe2\x80\x9d proceeded \xe2\x80\x94 read aloud by the sterling William Hootkins \xe2\x80\x94 I began to feel as though we were carrying a garrulous hitchhiker, a transcendental encyclopedist, indeed a back-seat whaler of sorts. Sometimes Ishmael reclined at his leisure, telling his tale with an outspoken, formal bravado, the way he tells the Town-Ho story to some Spanish gentlemen in Lima in the 54th chapter. Mostly, he leaned forward into the space between the driver\xe2\x80\x99s and passenger\xe2\x80\x99s seats, shifting between philosophical agony and philosophical reverie, looking out upon the country passing by, moralizing it for us, perpetually searching out its meaning.'b'And to Ishmael nothing escaped meaning, no matter how slight or significant it was. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you not find a strange analogy to something in yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d That was his perpetual question. It sprang to mind at the sight of the sedimentary road cuts in rural Missouri, at the glutted rivers we passed, at harvested fields laced with frost. A pasture of white cattle gave Ishmael the shivers. To him, nothing was merely itself. This world of appearances through which we were driving, real enough to us, was to Ishmael but the spiritual world protruding into our senses. At Marsha\xe2\x80\x99s Country Kitchen in Chandler, Okla., everyone stared at us as we entered \xe2\x80\x94 two New Yorkers and their imaginary narrator. We felt as though we had approached some metaphysical border, as though we ourselves were members of the phantom boat crew Ahab smuggles aboard the Pequod, at whom everyone stares in wonderment when they make their first appearance in Chapter 47.'b'I stopped to look at the long disused lamps in the window of the thrift shop next door to Marsha\xe2\x80\x99s, and in my ear Ishmael whispered, once again, \xe2\x80\x9cDo you not find a strange analogy?\xe2\x80\x9d Nothing would placate him but saying yes. And yet, somehow, I came to love his digressions, philosophical and factual. They are as characteristic of Ishmael as his puzzling inner knowledge of Ahab\xe2\x80\x99s state of being. If we had driven to California as circuitously as Ishmael narrates, we would be somewhere in the Yukon now, bound for Los Angeles.'b'I began to be glad of a few things. The most important is this: \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick\xe2\x80\x9d was published eight years before Darwin\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cOn the Origin of Species.\xe2\x80\x9d What would Ishmael have made of evolution? How it would have enriched, not to say engulfed, his telling! In \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick,\xe2\x80\x9d nature is a horror. If a creature is believed to be knowing, like the great white whale, it is assumed to be malevolent. And if it has no humanlike awareness, it is endowed, like the polar bear, with \xe2\x80\x9cirresponsible ferociousness.\xe2\x80\x9d Beneath \xe2\x80\x9cthe loveliest tints of azure,\xe2\x80\x9d there is \xe2\x80\x9cthe universal cannibalism of the sea.\xe2\x80\x9d Under Ishmael\xe2\x80\x99s tutelage, I began to feel guilty for admiring the sunset as we rolled toward Albuquerque. Who knew what the sun was scorching as it rolled over the horizon?'b'I was always glad at day\xe2\x80\x99s end too, when we parked and turned off \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick.\xe2\x80\x9d Not that the book ended then. Usually, in the evening, I would begin reading the book where we had left off listening. I have never been so struck by the silence of the printed word. I have never grasped so clearly how inward words have to go in our minds before they come alive. I was the one leaning forward, hearkening to Ishmael, keenly aware of the whiteness of the page, just as I had been every time I\xe2\x80\x99d read \xe2\x80\x9cMoby-Dick\xe2\x80\x9d before.'b'Someone must survive to tell the tale, and I will be giving nothing away to say that it is Ishmael, lone survivor of the Pequod. My question is this. Why does Ishmael survive in italics? The rest of the book is set in roman type, but the epilogue is not. What manner of being is this italicized survival? I searched for the strange analogy that must be hidden in it, but I could not find it.'b'I would like to say that we drove down to the docks at San Pedro to drop off Ishmael and his carpetbag, where he might drive away the spleen and regulate his circulation by putting to sea again. But of course we did nothing of the sort. We parked instead under the peaceful, flickering shade of an Australian eucalyptus, which put me in mind of those Sydney men \xe2\x80\x9cso much distrusted by our whaling captains.\xe2\x80\x9d And then we disembarked ourselves, while Ishmael vanished into the soft California light.'b' 'b''b''b'LORD knows there\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of bad news in the world today to get you down, but there is one big thing happening that leaves me incredibly hopeful about the future, and that is the budding revolution in global online higher education. Nothing has more potential to lift more people out of poverty \xe2\x80\x94 by providing them an affordable education to get a job or improve in the job they have. Nothing has more potential to unlock a billion more brains to solve the world\xe2\x80\x99s biggest problems. And nothing has more potential to enable us to reimagine higher education than the massive open online course, or MOOC, platforms that are being developed by the likes of Stanford and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and companies like Coursera and Udacity.'b'Last May 'b'I wrote about Coursera'b' \xe2\x80\x94 co-founded by the Stanford computer scientists Daphne Koller and Andrew Ng \xe2\x80\x94 just after it opened. Two weeks ago, I went back out to Palo Alto to check in on them. When I visited last May, about 300,000 people were taking 38 courses taught by Stanford professors and a few other elite universities. Today, they have 2.4 million students, taking 214 courses from 33 universities, including eight international ones.'b'Anant Agarwal, the former director of M.I.T.\xe2\x80\x99s artificial intelligence lab, is now president of edX, a nonprofit MOOC that M.I.T. and Harvard are jointly building. Agarwal told me that since May, some 155,000 students from around the world have taken edX\xe2\x80\x99s first course: an M.I.T. intro class on circuits. \xe2\x80\x9cThat is greater than the total number of M.I.T. alumni in its 150-year history,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'Yes, only a small percentage complete all the work, and even they still tend to be from the middle and upper classes of their societies, but I am convinced that within five years these platforms will reach a much broader demographic. Imagine how this might change U.S. foreign aid. For relatively little money, the U.S. could rent space in an Egyptian village, install two dozen computers and high-speed satellite Internet access, hire a local teacher as a facilitator, and invite in any Egyptian who wanted to take online courses with the best professors in the world, subtitled in Arabic.'b'YOU just have to hear the stories told by the pioneers in this industry to appreciate its revolutionary potential. One of Koller\xe2\x80\x99s favorites is about \xe2\x80\x9cDaniel,\xe2\x80\x9d a 17-year-old with autism who communicates mainly by computer. He took an online modern poetry class from Penn. He and his parents wrote that the combination of rigorous academic curriculum, which requires Daniel to stay on task, and the online learning system that does not strain his social skills, attention deficits or force him to look anyone in the eye, enable him to better manage his autism. Koller shared a letter from Daniel, in which he wrote: \xe2\x80\x9cPlease tell Coursera and Penn my story. I am a 17-year-old boy emerging from autism. I can\xe2\x80\x99t yet sit still in a classroom so [your course] was my first real course ever. During the course, I\xc2\xa0had to keep pace with the class, which is unheard-of in special ed.\xc2\xa0Now I know I can benefit from having to work hard and enjoy being in sync with the world.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'One member of the Coursera team who recently took a Coursera course on sustainability told me that it was so much more interesting than a similar course he had taken as an undergrad. The online course included students from all over the world, from different climates, incomes levels and geographies, and, as a result, \xe2\x80\x9cthe discussions that happened in that course were so much more valuable and interesting than with people of similar geography and income level\xe2\x80\x9d in a typical American college.'b'Mitch Duneier, a Princeton sociology professor, wrote an essay in The Chronicle of Higher Education in the fall about his experience teaching a class through Coursera: \xe2\x80\x9cA few months ago, just as the campus of Princeton University had grown nearly silent after commencement, 40,000 students from 113 countries arrived here via the Internet to take a free course in introductory sociology. ... My opening discussion of C. Wright Mills\xe2\x80\x99s classic 1959 book, \xe2\x80\x98The Sociological Imagination,\xe2\x80\x99 was a close reading of the text, in which I reviewed a key chapter line by line. I asked students to follow along in their own copies, as I do in the lecture hall. When I give this lecture on the Princeton campus, I usually receive a few penetrating questions. In this case, however, within a few hours of posting the online version, the course forums came alive with hundreds of comments and questions. Several days later there were thousands. ... Within three weeks I had received more feedback on my sociological ideas than I had in a career of teaching, which significantly influenced each of my subsequent lectures and seminars.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Agarwal of edX tells of a student in Cairo who was taking the circuits course and was having difficulty. In the class\xe2\x80\x99s online forum, where students help each other with homework, he posted that he was dropping out. In response, other students in Cairo in the same class invited him to meet at a teahouse, where they offered to help him stay in the course. A 15-year-old student in Mongolia, who took the same class as part of a blended course and received a perfect score on the final exam, added Agarwal, is now applying to M.I.T. and the University of California, Berkeley.'b'As we look to the future of higher education, said the M.I.T. president, L. Rafael Reif, something that we now call a \xe2\x80\x9cdegree\xe2\x80\x9d will be a concept \xe2\x80\x9cconnected with bricks and mortar\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 and traditional on-campus experiences that will increasingly leverage technology and the Internet to enhance classroom and laboratory work. Alongside that, though, said Reif, many universities will offer online courses to students anywhere in the world, in which they will earn \xe2\x80\x9ccredentials\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 certificates that testify that they have done the work and passed all the exams. The process of developing credible credentials that verify that the student has adequately mastered the subject \xe2\x80\x94 and did not cheat \xe2\x80\x94 and can be counted on by employers is still being perfected by all the MOOCs. But once it is, this phenomenon will really scale.'b'I can see a day soon where you\xe2\x80\x99ll create your own college degree by taking the best online courses from the best professors from around the world \xe2\x80\x94 some computing from Stanford, some entrepreneurship from Wharton, some ethics from Brandeis, some literature from Edinburgh \xe2\x80\x94 paying only the nominal fee for the certificates of completion. It will change teaching, learning and the pathway to employment. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is a new world unfolding,\xe2\x80\x9d said Reif, \xe2\x80\x9cand everyone will have to adapt.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'IN 1942, 71 years before last week\xe2\x80\x99s Pentagon decision allowing women on the front lines of combat, the United States government established the Women\xe2\x80\x99s Army Corps, with Athena as its insignia, and welcomed our country\xe2\x80\x99s first female military recruits.'b'One of these pioneering women was a corporal from Big Spring, Tex., named 'b'Nellie Gray'b'. After the war ended, Gray finished college (with an assist from the G.I. Bill) and moved to Washington, D.C., where she worked for decades at the State Department and the Department of Labor, earning a law degree at night from Georgetown University along the way. Then the social upheavals of the 1970s arrived, the soldier-turned-bureaucrat-turned-lawyer helped found one of America\xe2\x80\x99s most enduring mass movements, establishing an annual protest march that continues to the present day.'b'That protest is the March for Life, the annual rally against Roe v. Wade.'b'When she organized the first march, in January 1974, it drew 20,000 anti-abortion marchers to the capital. On Friday, 40 years after Roe and six months after Gray\xe2\x80\x99s death at the age of 88, the marchers numbered in the tens or even hundreds of thousands.'b'If she had chosen a different political cause, Gray\xe2\x80\x99s trajectory \xe2\x80\x94 from soldier to working woman to professional activist \xe2\x80\x94 would be a case study for students of second-wave feminism. But the cause she did choose \xe2\x80\x94 and in whose service she issued strident attacks on \xe2\x80\x9cfeminist abortionists\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 has endured precisely because it has had a more complicated relationship to female advancement than some cultural stereotypes would suggest.'b'Those stereotypes link the anti-abortion cause to traditionalist ideas about gender roles \xe2\x80\x94 to the belief that a woman\xe2\x80\x99s place is in the home, or at least that her primary identity should be maternal rather than professional. Writing in the Reagan era, the sociologist Kristin Luker argued that this dimension of the debate trumped the question of whether unborn human life has rights: \xe2\x80\x9cWhile on the surface it is the embryo\xe2\x80\x99s fate that seems to be at stake, the abortion debate is actually about the meaning of 'b'women\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'lives.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This remains a dominant pro-choice understanding of the abortion conflict \xe2\x80\x94 and not without reason, since it finds vindication to this day in the idiot \xe2\x80\x9cmansplaining\xe2\x80\x9d of amateur gynecologists like Todd Akin.'b'But such an understanding was too simplistic when Nellie Gray founded the March for Life, and it\xe2\x80\x99s grown steadily less compelling with time. As 'b'Jon Shields'b' of Claremont McKenna College pointed out last year, pro-life sentiment has been steady over the last four decades even as opposition to women in the work force (or the military, or the White House) has largely collapsed. Most anti-abortion Americans today are also gender egalitarians: indeed, Shields notes, pro-life attitudes toward women\xe2\x80\x99s professional advancement have converged so quickly with pro-choice attitudes that \xe2\x80\x9cthe average moderately pro-life citizen is a stronger supporter of gender equality than even the typical strongly pro-choice citizen was in the early 1980s.\xe2\x80\x9d Among the younger generation, any \xe2\x80\x9cdivide over women\xe2\x80\x99s roles nearly disappears entirely.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The pro-life cause has proved unexpectedly resilient, in other words, not because millions of Americans are nostalgists for a world of stricter gender norms, but because they have convinced themselves that the opportunities the feminist revolution won for women can be sustained 'b'without'b' unrestricted access to abortion.'b'This conviction is crucial to understanding why opinion on abortion has been a persistent exception to the liberalizing cultural trends that have brought us gay marriage, medical marijuana and now women in combat. It helps explain, too, why public opinion on the issue doesn\xe2\x80\x99t break down along the gendered lines that many liberals expect \xe2\x80\x94 why more women than men, for instance, told the latest 'b'Pew survey'b' that abortion was \xe2\x80\x9cmorally wrong\xe2\x80\x9d and (in smaller numbers) that Roe should be overturned.'b'It also has long-term implications for how the abortion debate plays out. The best way to argue with a Todd Akin is to dismiss him as a chauvinist, a creep and the enemy of a more enlightened future. But the best pro-choice rebuttal to the young idealists at the March for Life or the 'b'professional women'b' who 'b'lead today\xe2\x80\x99s anti-abortion groups'b' isn\xe2\x80\x99t that they\xe2\x80\x99re too reactionary \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s that they\xe2\x80\x99re too utopian, too radical, too na\xc3\xafve.'b'This means that the abortion rights movement, once utopian in its own fashion, is now at its most effective when it speaks the language of necessary evils, warning Americans that while it might be pretty to think so, the equality they take for granted simply can\xe2\x80\x99t be separated from a practice they find troubling.'b'For its part, if the pro-life movement wants not only to endure but to triumph, then it needs an answer to this argument. That means something more than just a defense of a universal right to life. It means a realist\xe2\x80\x99s explanation of how, in policy and culture, the feminist revolution could be reformed without being repealed.'b'MEETING Simon for the first time was one of the most sublime experiences I\xe2\x80\x99ve had. With every coy head nod, casual hand wave and deep eye gaze, I felt he already knew me.'b'Simon is a humanoid robot being developed at the Georgia Institute of Technology for the purposes of exploring intuitive ways for people and machines to live and work alongside one another. I had designed the robot\xe2\x80\x99s shell \xe2\x80\x94 its outward appearance \xe2\x80\x94 so I knew exactly what to expect, but interacting with it as a programmed and somewhat sentient creature surprised me in ways I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t expected.'b'Simon understood spoken sentences and used social skills to respond appropriately. If it didn\xe2\x80\x99t understand a certain request, it raised its arms in an apparent plea for forgiveness or tilted its head to express confusion. Its ears lit up when it recognized a color, and it spoke back to me when I was finished talking.'b'Simon, a research effort and not meant to be sold, is part of a growing collection of social robots that can essentially see, hear, feel and react through humanlike sound and movement. Our future may not match our sci-fi fantasies of androids with limbs, torsos and expressive faces meandering around our rooms to pick up clothes and mix cocktails, but robots are entering our homes in subtle ways, through countertop appliances, hand-held tools and wearable gadgets that display specialized and isolated robotic behaviors.'b'YOUR coffee maker or camera may already have some of these elements, responding automatically to shut themselves off or follow a sequence of timed commands (wait 30 seconds, take a picture; at 6 a.m. start brewing, etc.) and the next generation of products will be only more sophisticated in this regard.'b'Whereas designers typically use form, color and materials to make an object express some human element (a drill handle may have a pattern that looks aggressive, a toaster might have knobs and dials that seem friendly), we\xe2\x80\x99re entering a time when sound, light and movement are equally important parts of the creative palette. Everyday objects whose expressive elements have long been static will now glow, sing, vibrate and change position at the drop of a hat.'b'The behaviors of these future robotic objects may be utilitarian, like a lamp that bends to follow the items you reposition on a desk, or they may provide feedback, like'b' a fork that vibrates 'b'when you\xe2\x80\x99re eating too fast. They won\xe2\x80\x99t require you to press a sequence of buttons to make things happen, but they will work alongside you in unobtrusive ways, responding to caresses, waves or verbal commands. Some might just sit back and observe you to understand what you need.'b'A robotic cutting board might guide you while you cook and offer helpful tips when your knife skills aren\xe2\x80\x99t up to par. Many products will be connected to the Internet, with access to what\xe2\x80\x99s happening in the larger world. A raincoat might glow or whistle when it knows you\xe2\x80\x99ll need it on your commute. Many webcams used for video conferencing already raise their heads to let you know when someone is ready on the other side of a conversation and soon during a chat they will mimic your body\xe2\x80\x99s movements to help express your point to a friend across the globe. A medicine bottle might open its lid to offer you a precise dose or automatically call your pharmacist when it\xe2\x80\x99s empty.'b'Washing machines will text or call you when your laundry is done. Robotic appliances will become ever more energy-conscious \xe2\x80\x94 many automated thermostats already adjust themselves appropriately, combining knowledge of their users\xe2\x80\x99 patterns with information about how to conserve energy.'b'As products become smarter, their behaviors will mean they essentially have continuing conversations with us, whether they include verbal exchanges or not. Just like we read subtle cues from our pets (we see a dog\xe2\x80\x99s ears and believe that he feels sad, guilty or excited), we\xe2\x80\x99ll read emotion from our products, perceiving nuances of dialogue and a sense that the object is \xe2\x80\x9calive.\xe2\x80\x9d For example, colored lights on a robotic vacuum cleaner will tell us what\xe2\x80\x99s going on inside: green, slow pulsing indicates \xe2\x80\x9cAll systems go!\xe2\x80\x9d; rapid red flashing pleads \xe2\x80\x9cHelp! Something is amiss here.\xe2\x80\x9d A jubilant melody at the end of a washing machine cycle says, \xe2\x80\x9cEverything went well and your clothes are ready!\xe2\x80\x9d When a video conferencing webcam in an office lowers its head, it\xe2\x80\x99s saying: \xe2\x80\x9cBye! Going to sleep now.\xe2\x80\x9d These animated behaviors blend together and it\xe2\x80\x99s human nature to read them as emanating from a living entity.'b'Through their personalities, these objects will offer us emotional value along with other features. Siri, the iPhone speech recognition search engine, has already won the hearts of many by displaying a consistent, witty personality with which people can converse. 'b'Autom'b', a new countertop weight-loss product, was created by researchers who learned that a robotic coach with expressive eyes and face was more effective at keeping dieters eating better and exercising more because the emotional bond was created.'b'Even robots with minimal expressions, like the 'b'Roomba'b' floor cleaner, have led people to treat them as living entities, bestowing names on them and perceiving moments of celebration and even guilt. Researchers at Georgia Tech have found that this emotional connection leads people to feel empathy for the product, making them much more accepting of mechanical flaws that would otherwise be seen as a nuisance.'b'Browsing Amazon.com reviews of the Roomba reveals just how compelling this sense of life is: \xe2\x80\x9cWe have named our new Roomba Rosie. She is my new best friend. I vacuumed with my 15-year-old Kirby before letting Rosie do her thing...She is wonderful. Most of my furniture is too heavy to move each week. She cleaned under those pieces and I was amazed at what she picked up.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'When working for the firm Smart Design, designing a floor-cleaning robot for a company called Neato Robotics, I studied research that had been conducted around the Roomba and knew that shaping the vacuum\xe2\x80\x99s personality would be as important in building a positive relationship between product and owner as any other element. To do that, my team and I dissected typical service personalities, like the hotel maid you never see, the chatty bartender and the proper nanny. \xe2\x80\x9cWhich of these should this vacuum be?\xe2\x80\x9d we wondered.'b'I also asked the team to break down the product\xe2\x80\x99s behavior into critical \xe2\x80\x9cmoments\xe2\x80\x9d for personality definition. With people, we know that a person\xe2\x80\x99s true character is revealed during moments of extremes \xe2\x80\x94 both negative (stress, anger, fear) and positive (pride, jubilation, satisfaction). To define the robot\xe2\x80\x99s character, we identified the extremes and then created a language of expression that combined light patterns, a sound palette and choreographed movements.'b'For example, getting stuck under the couch would be a moment of distress, as would its batteries running low. Completely cleaning a room\xe2\x80\x99s carpet might be a moment of jubilation. We wanted to define exactly what the robot would do at these moments. What sounds should it make? How should it move? Just as we might work with a color or material specialist in a traditional product, here we worked with a music composer to create a palette of sounds.'b'While the idea of charming entities all around us, guiding us through everyday tasks and reminding us to do things throughout the day may seem benign, some experts raise concerns about the implications of robots in our daily lives. Once designers can perfect the art of manipulation, manufacturers can use this power to entice people to adopt behaviors that may not be in their best interest. There could be, for instance, a robot that tempts you to buy more unhealthy food or buy a lottery ticket.'b'In addition, there are many security concerns around robotic objects, especially when they are mobile and in the intimate space of the home. For example, what happens when your products get hacked in a nefarious scheme to allow a criminal to see inside your house or, worse, when they are hacked to manipulate a person to behave in a way that he otherwise wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have?'b'Despite the potential risks, the future will be rich with sensor-based, animated objects using expressive sound, light, motion and screens to praise, encourage, advise and comfort us. We\xe2\x80\x99ll have fun with TVs and music players that reposition themselves in response to our dance moves, we\xe2\x80\x99ll be relieved of chores by robots that pick up our crumbs and scrub the floors, and we\xe2\x80\x99ll stay fit with robotic parasites that curl around our wrists to take health stats and exhort us to get off the couch.'b'With this throng of sentient objects in our lives, we\xe2\x80\x99ll have to negotiate a whole new set of relationships. Will we adore our new products as if they were pets, doting on them and anticipating their greetings? Or will all this lively communication create an annoying cacophony of gadgets? My hope is for the former, but it will depend on the designers\xe2\x80\x99 ability to devise interactions that consider emotional value as important as any other product attribute. If designed well, these mechanical creatures, like my robotic pal Simon, can tug at our heartstrings in a new way.'b'SAN DIEGO'b'IN November I quit my job as the editor of Wired to run 3D Robotics, the San Diego-based drone company I started with a partner as a side project three years ago. We make autopilot technology and small aircraft \xe2\x80\x94 both planes and multirotor copters \xe2\x80\x94 that can fly by themselves. The drones, which sell for a few hundred bucks, are for civilians: they don\xe2\x80\x99t shoot anything but photographs and videos. And they\xe2\x80\x99re incredibly fun to build (which we do with the ample help of robots). It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a hard decision to give up publishing for this.'b'But my company, like many manufacturers, is faced with a familiar challenge: its main competitors are Chinese companies that have the dual advantages of cheap labor and top-notch engineering. So, naturally, when we were raising a round of investment financing last year, venture capitalists demanded a plausible explanation for how our little start-up could beat its Chinese rivals. The answer was as much a surprise to the investors as it had been to me a few years earlier: 'b'Mexico'b'. In particular, Tijuana.'b'Like many Americans, until recently, when I heard \xe2\x80\x9cTijuana\xe2\x80\x9d I thought only of drug cartels and cheap tequila. \xe2\x80\x9cTJ,\xe2\x80\x9d though, is a city of more than two million people (larger than neighboring San Diego), and it has become North America\xe2\x80\x99s electronics assembly hot spot: most of the flat-screen TVs sold in the United States, from companies like Samsung and Sony, are made there, along with everything from medical devices to aerospace parts. Jordi Mu\xc3\xb1oz, the smart young guy who had taught me about drones and then started 3D Robotics with me, is from TJ \xe2\x80\x94 and he persuaded me to build a second factory there to supplement the work we were doing in San Diego.'b'Shuttling between the two factories \xe2\x80\x94 in San Diego, where we engineer our drones, and in TJ, where we assemble them \xe2\x80\x94 I\xe2\x80\x99m reminded of a similar experience I had a decade earlier. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, I lived in Hong Kong (working for The Economist) and saw how that city was paired with the \xe2\x80\x9cspecial economic zone\xe2\x80\x9d of Shenzhen across the border on the Chinese mainland in Guangdong Province. Together, the two created a world-beating manufacturing hub: business, design and finance in Hong Kong, manufacturing in Shenzhen. The clear division of labor between the two became a model for modern China.'b'Today, what Shenzhen is to Hong Kong, Tijuana is becoming to San Diego. You can drive from our San Diego engineering center to our Tijuana factory in 20 minutes, no passport required. (A passport is needed to come back, but there are fast-track lanes for business people.) Some of our employees commute across the border each day; good doctors are cheaper and easier to find in TJ, as are private schools, although it\xe2\x80\x99s generally nicer to live in San Diego. In some ways, the border feels more like the notional borders of the European Union than a divide between the developed and developing worlds.'b'And it\xe2\x80\x99s not just TJ. To the east, in Ju\xc3\xa1rez, Dell computers are built by 'b'Foxconn'b', the company that manufactures more than 40 percent of the world\xe2\x80\x99s electronics (including Apple\xe2\x80\x99s iPhone and iPad). To the south, in Quer\xc3\xa9taro, a factory builds the transmissions that General Motors installs in its Corvettes. The design of General Electric\xe2\x80\x99s GEnx turbine jet engine and the production of interior elements of Boeing\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'787 Dreamliner'b' also happen in Mexico. Manufactured goods are the country\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'chief export'b', with private investment in this sector among the highest in the world.'b'The notion that Mexico offers only cheap labor is just plain off the mark. Mexico graduates some 'b'115,000 engineering students'b' per year \xe2\x80\x94 roughly three times as many as the U.S. on a per-capita basis. One result is that some machine specialists are typically easier to find in TJ than in many big American cities. So, for that matter, are accountants experienced in production economics and other highly skilled workers.'b'What all these pieces add up to is a model \xe2\x80\x94 one that might hold the long-sought answer for how American manufacturers can compete with those in China, India and the next generation of economic powerhouses. That\xe2\x80\x99s because the TJ template isn\xe2\x80\x99t so much about outsourcing as it is quicksourcing. And that\xe2\x80\x99s also the way to create thousands of good jobs in the United States.'b'As any entrepreneur can tell you, the shorter and more nimble a supply chain is, the better.'b'First, a shorter supply chain means that a company can make things when it wants to, instead of solely when it has to. Strange as it may seem, many small manufacturers don\xe2\x80\x99t have that option. When we started 3D, we produced everything in China and needed to order in units of thousands to get good pricing. That meant that we had to write big checks to make big batches of goods \xe2\x80\x94 money we wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t see again until all those products sold, sometimes a year or more later. Now that we carry out our production locally, we\xe2\x80\x99re able to make only what we need that week.'b'Second, there\xe2\x80\x99s less risk. If we make an error in a design, we\xe2\x80\x99ve wasted at most a few days\xe2\x80\x99 worth of production. If there\xe2\x80\x99s something wrong in the production process itself, we can spot it fast. We control the component inventory, so we can see what\xe2\x80\x99s going into our goods and know that we\xe2\x80\x99re not being ripped off with used or pirated parts. And if we want to protect our intellectual property, we can do so without having to trust that other companies will uphold our interests above all others. And that\xe2\x80\x99s saying nothing about political risk, environmental risk or P.R. risk, all of which companies like Apple and Walmart have learned about in China the hard way.'b'Third, it\xe2\x80\x99s simply faster. We still order some parts from China, and even though we use FedEx, it always seems to take weeks, and sometimes months, longer than we\xe2\x80\x99d planned. That\xe2\x80\x99s not a criticism of China; it\xe2\x80\x99s merely intrinsic to any arm\xe2\x80\x99s-length relationship between small buyers and big makers. If we were Apple, we\xe2\x80\x99d get overnight service. But we\xe2\x80\x99re not, so we wait.'b'Finally, a short supply chain is an incentive to innovate. If you\xe2\x80\x99re outsourcing the manufacturing of huge parcels of a product, you can\xe2\x80\x99t change that product until you\xe2\x80\x99ve sold all the ones you\xe2\x80\x99ve already made (at least not if you want to stay in business). So that often means sitting on your hands, waiting for Version 1 to sell out before starting to make Version 2. But when you\xe2\x80\x99re doing just-in-time manufacturing, you can change the product every day if you want \xe2\x80\x94 whether to take advantage of some better or cheaper component or to improve the design.'b'In the land of the long supply chain, meanwhile, things are changing, too. Inflation-adjusted labor costs in China have more than tripled in the past decade. Wages in China\xe2\x80\x99s southern cities are approaching $6 an hour, roughly what they are'b' in Mexico'b'.'b'Whether factors like these are enough to turn American businesses from outsourcers to quicksourcers remains an open question. But I\xe2\x80\x99m betting my money that they will. The sense of possibility I felt when I first crossed from Hong Kong to Shenzhen in 1997 is what I now feel when I cross from San Diego to Tijuana. The trade routes of the 21st century don\xe2\x80\x99t have to follow Marco Polo from West to East. Indeed, in the new manufacturing landscape, the routes don\xe2\x80\x99t have to take you far at all.'b'In the face of sanctions, North Korea has threatened \xe2\x80\x9call-out\xe2\x80\x9d action on its \xe2\x80\x9csworn enemy\xe2\x80\x9d the United States.'b'BELLAIRE, Tex.'b'I AM a New England liberal, born and bred. I have lived most of my life in the Northeast \xe2\x80\x94 Boston, New York and Philadelphia \xe2\x80\x94 and my politics are devoutly Democratic. In three decades, I have voted for a Republican exactly once, holding my nose, in a mayoral election in which the Democratic candidate seemed mentally unbalanced.'b'I am also a Texas resident and a gun owner. I have half a dozen pistols in my safe, all semiautomatics, the largest capable of holding 20 rounds. I go to the range at least once a week, have applied for a concealed carry license and am planning to take a tactical training course in the spring. I\xe2\x80\x99m currently shopping for a shotgun, either a Remington 'b'870 Express Tactical'b' or a 'b'Mossberg 500 Flex'b' with a pistol grip and adjustable stock.'b'Except for shotguns (firing one feels like being punched by a prizefighter), I enjoy shooting. At the range where I practice, most of the staff knows me by sight if not by name. I\xe2\x80\x99m the guy in the metrosexual eyeglasses and Ralph Lauren polo, and I ask a lot of questions: What\xe2\x80\x99s the best way to maintain my sight picture with both eyes open? How do I clear a stove-piped round?'b'There is pleasure to be had in exercising one\xe2\x80\x99s rights, learning something new in midlife and mastering the operation of a complex tool, which is one thing a gun is. But I won\xe2\x80\x99t deny the seductive psychological power that firearms possess. I grew up playing shooting games, pretending to be Starsky or Hutch or one of the patrolmen on \xe2\x80\x9cAdam-12,\xe2\x80\x9d the two most boring TV cops in history.'b'A prevailing theory holds that boys are simultaneously aware of their own physical powerlessness and society\xe2\x80\x99s mandate that they serve as protectors of the innocent. Pretending to shoot a bad guy assuages this anxiety, which never goes away completely. This explanation makes sense to me. Another word for it is catharsis, and you could say that, as a novelist, I\xe2\x80\x99ve made my living from it.'b'There are a lot of reasons that a gun feels right in my hand, but I also own firearms to protect my family. I hope I never have to use one for this purpose, and I doubt I ever will. But I am my family\xe2\x80\x99s last line of defense. I have chosen to meet this responsibility, in part, by being armed. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a choice I made lightly. I am aware that, statistically speaking, a gun in the home represents a far greater danger to its inhabitants than to an intruder. But not every choice we make is data-driven. A lot comes from the gut.'b'Apart from the ones in policemen\xe2\x80\x99s holsters, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I saw a working firearm until the year after college, when a friend\xe2\x80\x99s girlfriend, after four cosmopolitans, decided to show off the .38 revolver she kept in her purse. (Half the party guests dived for cover, including me.)'b'It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t until my mid-40s that my education in guns began, in the course of writing a novel in which pistols, shotguns and rifles, but also heavy weaponry like the AR-15 and its military analogue, the M-16, were widely used. I suspected that much of the gunplay I\xe2\x80\x99d witnessed in movies and television was completely wrong (it is) and hired an instructor for a daylong private lesson \xe2\x80\x9cto shoot everything in the store.\xe2\x80\x9d The gentleman who met me at the range was someone whom I would have called \xe2\x80\x9ca gun nut.\xe2\x80\x9d A former New Yorker, he had relocated to Texas because of its lax gun laws and claimed to keep a pistol within arm\xe2\x80\x99s reach even when he showered. He was perfect, in other words, for my purpose.'b'My relationship to firearms might have ended there, if not for a coincidence of weather. Everybody remembers Hurricane Katrina; fewer recall Hurricane Rita, an even more intense storm that headed straight for Houston less than a month later. My wife and I arranged to stay at a friend\xe2\x80\x99s house in Austin, packed up the kids and dog, and headed out of town \xe2\x80\x94 or tried to. As many as 3.7 million people had the same idea, making Rita one of the largest evacuations in history, with predictable results.'b'By 2 in the morning, after six hours on the road, we had made it all of 50 miles. The scene was like a snapshot from the Apocalypse: crowds milling restlessly, gas stations and mini-marts picked clean and heaped with trash, families sleeping by the side of the road. The situation had the hopped-up feel of barely bottled chaos. After Katrina, nobody had any illusions that help was on its way. It also occurred to me that there were probably a lot of guns out there \xe2\x80\x94 this was Texas, after all. Here I was with two tiny children, a couple of thousand dollars in cash, a late-model S.U.V. with half a tank of gas and not so much as a heavy book to throw. When my wife wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t let me get out of the car so the dog could do his business, that was it for me. We jumped the median, turned around, and were home in under an hour.'b'As it happened, Rita made a last-minute turn away from Houston. But what if it hadn\xe2\x80\x99t? I believe people are basically good, but not all of them and not all the time. Like most citizens of our modern, technological world, I am wholly reliant upon a fragile web of services to meet my most basic needs. What would happen if those services collapsed? Chaos, that\xe2\x80\x99s what.'b'IT didn\xe2\x80\x99t happen overnight, but before too long my Northeastern liberal sensibilities, while intact on other issues, had shifted on the question of gun ownership. For my first pistol I selected a little Walther .380. I shot it enough to decide it was junk, upgraded to a full-size Springfield 9-millimeter, liked it but wanted something with a thumb safety, found a nice Smith &amp; Wesson subcompact that fit the bill, but along the way got a little bit of a gun-crush on the Beretta M-9 \xe2\x80\x94 and so on.'b'Lots of people on both sides of the aisle own firearms, or don\xe2\x80\x99t, for reasons that supersede their broader political and cultural affiliations. Let me be clear: my personal armory notwithstanding, I think guns are woefully under-regulated. It\xe2\x80\x99s far too easy to buy a gun \xe2\x80\x94 I once bought one in a parking lot \xe2\x80\x94 and I loathe the National Rifle Association. Some of the Obama administration\xe2\x80\x99s proposals strike me as more symbolic than effective, with some 300 million firearms on the loose. But the White House\xe2\x80\x99s recommendations seem like a good starting point and nothing that would prevent me from protecting my family in a crisis. The AR-15 is a fascinating weapon, and, frankly, a gas to shoot. So is a tank, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t need to own a tank.'b'Alas, the days of \xc3\xa0 la carte politics like mine seem over, if they ever even existed. The bigger culprit is the far right and the lunatic pronouncements of those like Rush Limbaugh. But in the weeks since Newtown, I\xe2\x80\x99ve watched my Facebook feed, which is dominated by my coastal friends, fill up with anti-gun dispatches that seemed divorced from reality. I agree it would be nice if the world had exactly zero guns in it. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t see that happening, and calling gun owners \xe2\x80\x9ca bunch of inbred rednecks\xe2\x80\x9d doesn\xe2\x80\x99t do much to advance rational discussion.'b'Thus, my secret life \xe2\x80\x94 though I guess it\xe2\x80\x99s not such a secret anymore. My wife is afraid of my guns (though she also says she\xe2\x80\x99s glad I have them). My 16-year-old daughter is a different story. The week before her fall semester exams, we allowed her to skip school for a day, a tradition in our house. The rule is, she gets to do whatever she wants. This time, she asked to take a pistol lesson. She\xe2\x80\x99s an NPR listener like me, but she\xe2\x80\x99s also grown up in Texas, and the fact that one in five American women is a victim of sexual assault is not lost on her. In the windowless classroom off the range, the instructor ran her through the basics, demonstrating with a Glock 9-millimeter: how to hold it, load it, pull back the slide.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll probably have trouble with that part,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cA lot of the women do.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh really?\xe2\x80\x9d my daughter replied, and with a cagey smile proceeded to rack her weapon with such authority you could have heard it in the parking lot.'b'A proud-papa moment? I confess it was.'b'Republicans have a problem. For years they could shout down any attempt to point out the extent to which their policies favored the elite over the poor and the middle class; all they had to do was yell \xe2\x80\x9cClass warfare!\xe2\x80\x9d and Democrats scurried away. In the 2012 election, however, that didn\xe2\x80\x99t work: the picture of the G.O.P. as the party of sneering plutocrats stuck, even as Democrats became more openly populist than they have been in decades.'b'As a result, prominent Republicans have begun acknowledging that their party needs to improve its image. But here\xe2\x80\x99s the thing: Their proposals for a makeover all involve changing the sales pitch rather than the product. When it comes to substance, the G.O.P. is more committed than ever to policies that take from most Americans and give to a wealthy handful.'b'Consider, as a case in point, how a widely reported 'b'recent speech by Bobby Jindal'b' the governor of Louisiana, compares with his actual policies.'b'Mr. Jindal posed the problem in a way that would, I believe, have been unthinkable for a leading Republican even a year ago. \xe2\x80\x9cWe must not,\xe2\x80\x9d he declared, \xe2\x80\x9cbe the party that simply protects the well off so they can keep their toys. We have to be the party that shows all Americans how they can thrive.\xe2\x80\x9d After a campaign in which Mitt Romney denounced any attempt to talk about class divisions as an 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cattack on success,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' this represents a major rhetorical shift.'b'But Mr. Jindal didn\xe2\x80\x99t offer any suggestions about how Republicans might demonstrate that they aren\xe2\x80\x99t just about letting the rich keep their toys, other than claiming even more loudly that their policies are good for everyone.'b'Meanwhile, back in Louisiana Mr. Jindal is pushing 'b'a plan to eliminate the state\xe2\x80\x99s income tax'b', which falls most heavily on the affluent, and make up for the lost revenue by raising sales taxes, which fall much more heavily on the poor and the middle class. The result would be big gains for the top 1 percent, substantial losses for the bottom 60 percent. Similar plans are being pushed by a number of 'b'other Republican governors'b' as well.'b'Like the new acknowledgment that the perception of being the party of the rich is a problem, this represents a departure for the G.O.P. \xe2\x80\x94 but in the opposite direction. In the past, Republicans would justify tax cuts for the rich either by claiming that they would pay for themselves or by claiming that they could make up for lost revenue by cutting wasteful spending. But what we\xe2\x80\x99re seeing now is open, explicit reverse Robin Hoodism: taking from ordinary families and giving to the rich. That is, even as Republicans look for a way to sound more sympathetic and less extreme, their actual policies are taking another sharp right turn.'b'Why is this happening? In particular, why is it happening now, just after an election in which the G.O.P. paid a price for its anti-populist stand?'b'Well, I don\xe2\x80\x99t have a full answer, but I think it\xe2\x80\x99s important to understand the extent to which leading Republicans live in an intellectual bubble. They get their news from Fox and other captive media, they get their policy analysis from billionaire-financed right-wing think tanks, and they\xe2\x80\x99re often blissfully unaware both of contrary evidence and of how their positions sound to outsiders.'b'So when Mr. Romney made his infamous \xe2\x80\x9c47 percent\xe2\x80\x9d remarks, he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t, in his own mind, saying anything outrageous or even controversial. He was just repeating a view that has become increasingly dominant inside the right-wing bubble, namely that a large and ever-growing proportion of Americans won\xe2\x80\x99t take responsibility for their own lives and are mooching off the hard-working wealthy. Rising unemployment claims demonstrate laziness, not lack of jobs; rising disability claims represent malingering, not the real health problems of an aging work force.'b'And given that worldview, Republicans see it as entirely appropriate to cut taxes on the rich while making everyone else pay more.'b'Now, national politicians learned last year that this kind of talk plays badly with the public, so they\xe2\x80\x99re trying to obscure their positions. Paul Ryan, for example, has lately made a transparently dishonest attempt to claim that when he spoke 'b'about \xe2\x80\x9ctakers\xe2\x80\x9d'b' living off the efforts of the \xe2\x80\x9cmakers\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 at one point he assigned 60 percent of Americans to the taker category \xe2\x80\x94 he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t talking about people receiving Social Security and Medicare. (He was.)'b'But in deep red states like Louisiana or Kansas, Republicans are much freer to act on their beliefs \xe2\x80\x94 which means moving strongly to comfort the comfortable while afflicting the afflicted.'b'Which brings me back to Mr. Jindal, who declared in his speech that \xe2\x80\x9cwe are a populist party.\xe2\x80\x9d No, you aren\xe2\x80\x99t. You\xe2\x80\x99re a party that holds a large proportion of Americans in contempt. And the public may have figured that out.'b'WITH its 'b'ambitious proposal'b' to pay doctors in public hospitals based on the quality of their work \xe2\x80\x94 not the number of tests they order, pills they prescribe or procedures they perform \xe2\x80\x94 New York City has hopped aboard the biggest bandwagon in health care. Pay for performance, or P4P in the jargon, is embraced by right and left. It has long been the favorite egghead prescription for our absurdly overpriced, underperforming health care system. The logic seems unassailable: Reward quality, and you will get quality. Stop rewarding waste, and you will get less waste. QED! P4P!'b'If only it worked.'b'For if you spend a little time with the P4P skeptics \xe2\x80\x94 a data-bearing minority among physicians and health economists \xe2\x80\x94 you will come away full of doubts. In practice, pay for performance does little to improve outcomes or to control costs. But if you look hard enough at why this common-sense approach doesn\xe2\x80\x99t deliver, you find some clues to what might.'b'The New York plan would give hospitals bonuses to distribute to their doctors based on such indicators as patient satisfaction, speeding the flow of cases through the system and administering specific therapies. It is an attempt to get ahead of the federal law we all know as Obamacare, which includes rewards for hospitals that peg pay to a list of quality metrics. I\xe2\x80\x99ve said before that I consider 'b'Obamacare an important leap forward'b', mainly for extending the basic safety net to millions of Americans. And there are aspects of the law, notably the Medicare Independent Payment Advisory Board, that may help bring down costs, if Congress can resist the temptation to interfere. But the pay-for-performance provisions are a triumph of theory over experience.'b'The first problem with P4P is that it does not address the biggest problem. 'b'Americans spend more'b' than twice as much per capita as other developed countries on health care \xe2\x80\x94 a crippling 18 percent of the country\xe2\x80\x99s economic output, and growing. Before studying the statistics, I assumed the root of the problem was doctors who, paid piecemeal for the services they provide, load up patients with marginal tests and treatments. In fact, America\xe2\x80\x99s health care system is not much different from other developed countries in the volume of service. Our doctors prescribe more or less the same number of pills and X-rays, perform similar numbers of blood tests and surgeries, as doctors in the best European countries. While there are undoubtedly savings to be had by cutting unnecessary services (shortening hospital stays, for example), the main problem is that our system charges far more for each service \xe2\x80\x94 each office visit, each hip replacement, each day in a hospital bed, each dose of antibiotic. \xe2\x80\x9cThe facile explanation is that doctors do too much,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peter Bach, a doctor at Memorial Sloan-Kettering who studies quality of cancer care. \xe2\x80\x9cBut if you compare us to other countries on volume, we\xe2\x80\x99re not leading in any category. The flip side is, we pay double for a lot of stuff.\xe2\x80\x9d (Actually, we lead in tonsillectomies and knee replacements, but his point is generally right.)'b'Doctors cite a number of reasons our medical treatments cost more \xe2\x80\x94 the high price of malpractice insurance being a favorite, and genuine, culprit. But the main reason everything costs less in other countries is that other countries tend to have one big payer \xe2\x80\x94 usually the government \xe2\x80\x94 with the clout to bargain down prices. A single-payer system has, so far, proven politically unpalatable in this country. And even Medicare, which has the power of scale and uses it to drive down prices, wields its power sparingly, because doctors threaten to stop serving Medicare patients if the reimbursements fall too low. As hospitals merge into mightier megachains, they may be able to bargain down the payments to doctors and drug companies and device-makers, and create economies of scale by standardizing treatments. (The physician and New Yorker writer 'b'Atul Gawande proposed'b' in a provocative August article that hospitals could drastically improve productivity by studying the example of restaurant chains like the Cheesecake Factory.) But that\xe2\x80\x99s not what P4P is about.'b'Instead of leverage, P4P employs incentives. Reduce the length of stay for acute-care patients, cut the rate of readmission for pneumonia cases, make sure heart-attack victims get a talk about diet before they are discharged, and you stand to find a little windfall in your paycheck.'b'Critics, who have evidence from a host of pilot programs, say that the bonuses are typically too small to change behavior; New York\xe2\x80\x99s would be a maximum of 2.5 percent of a doctor\xe2\x80\x99s salary, and most P4P programs pay less than that. Often the performance indicators measure things that are not within the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s control. Luis Marcos, a former president of the agency that runs New York\xe2\x80\x99s public hospitals, plucked several examples from the list of 13 metrics proposed for New York. Reducing waits in the emergency room (No. 4) is a worthy goal, he said, but it depends on a whole cast of people, from the clerk who greets the patient to the orderly who makes the bed ready. Shortening hospital stays (No. 13) requires having someone in the community \xe2\x80\x94 family, a social worker \xe2\x80\x94 to receive the patient; that\xe2\x80\x99s an especially hard requirement for hospitals that treat a lot of low-income or homeless people.'b'Another problem with P4P is that providers learn how to manipulate the results. \xe2\x80\x9cOnce you define performance, people manage toward those metrics and neglect other things that don\xe2\x80\x99t get counted,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Princeton health economist Uwe Reinhardt, who writes for The Times\xe2\x80\x99s Economix blog. New York doctors have a favorite, possibly apocryphal, story of medical providers gaming the system: Miami hospitals that use patient feedback as a performance measure wait until spring to do their surveys, because that\xe2\x80\x99s when the cranky, hard-to-please New Yorkers go home from their winter refuge.'b'Ashish Jha, a doctor at the Harvard School of Public Health, argues that P4P might get results if the incentive payments to hospitals were substantially bigger, the formulas were simplified and the performance indicators were kept to a few, clear measures that doctors and patients agree matter: mortality rates, infection rates, recurrence of heart attacks. \xe2\x80\x9cIf hospitals achieve great outcomes, it matters little how they did so,\xe2\x80\x9d Jha wrote in the latest Journal of the American Medical Association. And death rates are harder to game than administrative procedures.'b'Jha also proposes a little experiment in behavioral psychology: give hospitals 100 percent of the bonus at the beginning of the year, but require them to send a refund at the end of the year to pay for any shortcomings. Givebacks really focus the mind.'b'PETER PRONOVOST, a physician and professor at Johns Hopkins, says that rather than bribe doctors to adopt better practices, we should play to doctors\xe2\x80\x99 professionalism. Pronovost is famous for a scheme that drastically reduced infections associated with catheters by disseminating to doctors and nurses a simple, five-point operating-room checklist of reminders: Wash your hands, wear a sterile mask, etc. No pay incentives were involved, just an appeal to professional pride \xe2\x80\x94 and, later, public reporting of the results. \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t rule out economic incentives,\xe2\x80\x9d Pronovost told me. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you can do a lot just working with professional norms.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Pronovost has a more radical piece of common sense to offer. He proposes that the United States create an agency that would do for medicine what the Securities and Exchange Commission does for securities markets: compile and audit information about the performance of hospitals, and make it public. Rankings of hospitals now come either from news organizations or consumer groups working with untested and inconsistent data, or they are propaganda produced by medical providers themselves. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are stronger regulations about what a company can say about toothpaste than what a hospital can claim about quality,\xe2\x80\x9d Pronovost said.'b'For image-conscious doctors and hospitals, pride and shame might be the most effective kind of carrots and sticks.'b'Gov. Andrew Cuomo negotiated a package of criminal justice changes with the Legislature 'b'last winter'b' that broadly expanded New York State\xe2\x80\x99s DNA database by requiring all convicts to submit a DNA sample. Disappointingly, the measure did not include other important fixes that would further strengthen law enforcement\xe2\x80\x99s ability to exonerate the innocent and convict the guilty.'b'Mr. Cuomo pledged to revisit the issue and is now doing so. In his 'b'State of the State'b' speech, he said he would press the Assembly and the Senate this year to address two of the biggest causes of wrongful convictions: false confessions and witness misidentification.'b'Building on recommendations by the Innocence Project and a special task force created by the state\xe2\x80\x99s chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, Mr. Cuomo would require the police to videotape interrogations of people charged with serious crimes, including homicides, kidnapping and violent sex offenses \xe2\x80\x94 a step that would bring New York in line with 18 states and the District of Columbia.'b'New York City\xe2\x80\x99s police commissioner, Raymond Kelly, has begun to put such a policy in place. This is a positive step, but it does not relieve Albany of the responsibility to establish uniform and enforceable statewide standards.'b'Mr. Cuomo is also calling for improvements in eyewitness identification. The goal is to make lineups and photographs of suspects less susceptible to the subjective judgment of the enforcement personnel involved.'b'A lot will depend on how hard Mr. Cuomo fights for these ideas. But he is heading in the right direction.'b'By including gay rights in the arc of the struggle for civil rights \xe2\x80\x94 the road \xe2\x80\x9cthrough Seneca Falls and Selma and Stonewall\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 President Obama linked his presidency to ending antigay discrimination and underscored the legal wrong of denying gay people the freedom to marry.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOur journey is not complete until our gay brothers and sisters are treated like anyone else under the law,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Obama famously said in 'b'his second Inaugural Address'b', \xe2\x80\x9cfor if we are truly created equal, then surely the love we commit to one another must be equal as well.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Now that Mr. Obama has declared that he believes denying gay people the right to wed is not only unfair and morally wrong but also legally unsupportable, the urgent question is how he will translate his words into action. That was Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s formulation when 'b'he first announced his support for same-sex marriage'b' in May, and even then it made no sense, except perhaps as political cover approaching the general election campaign.'b'Marriage is traditionally regulated by the states, but there are constitutional limits on what states may do. The Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s 1967 ruling in Loving v. Virginia prevented states from forbidding marriages between interracial couples like Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s own parents.'b'Furthermore, the day after the Proposition 8 case is argued, the Justice Department will be asking the Supreme Court to invalidate the Defense of Marriage Act, the atrocious 1996 statute that denies federal benefits to lawfully married same-sex couples. The government will be arguing that discrimination against gay people, a vulnerable minority group, is presumptively unconstitutional. It is hard to see how the marriage act\xe2\x80\x99s discrimination is presumptively invalid but not California\xe2\x80\x99s wiping out of existing marriage rights for gay people that were mandated by the state\xe2\x80\x99s top court.'b'The outcome of the Proposition 8 case is likely to affect the lives of gay, lesbian and bisexual Americans for years to come, even if the final disposition is not sweeping enough to wipe out all state laws currently banning same-sex marriage. A strong filing by the Justice Department, forthrightly declaring that denying the freedom to marry violates the Constitution, would put the full weight of the federal government on the side of justice and could influence the shape of the ruling.'b'For the administration to be missing in action in this showdown risks conveying a message to the justices that it lacks confidence in the constitutional claims for ending gay people\xe2\x80\x99s exclusion from marriage or that it believes Americans are not ready for a high court ruling making marriage equality the law of the land \xe2\x80\x94 impressions strikingly contradicted by legal precedent, the lessons of history and by the president\xe2\x80\x99s own very powerful words.'b'Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s Inaugural Address appeared to reflect a deepened understanding that the right to marry the person of one\xe2\x80\x99s choice is a fundamental right \xe2\x80\x9cunder the law.\xe2\x80\x9d He needs to make sure his solicitor general conveys that sound legal view loud and clear in the Proposition 8 case.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Where Is the Taking?'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 20):'b'There is nothing \xe2\x80\x9cradical\xe2\x80\x9d about the Koontz family\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'argument to the Supreme Court'b' that government can\xe2\x80\x99t impose unrelated, unjustified burdens on people seeking land-use permits.'b'When the Koontzes sought a development permit for a few acres in Orange County, Fla., they were told that they must finance extensive wetlands mitigation on government land \xe2\x80\x94 costing up to $150,000. 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Amgen Gets a Gift From Congress'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 23): I do not know what is more disturbing, the fact that members of Congress continue to enact pieces of legislation (the \xe2\x80\x9cfiscal cliff\xe2\x80\x9d bill, in this case) that they have not read, or that parts of bills are written by Senate aides with apparently little or no oversight and no accountability.'b'What I do know is that the \xe2\x80\x9cup to $500 million\xe2\x80\x9d additional cost to Medicare over two years is unacceptable. Rodriguez and Samuel Estreicher (Op-Ed, Jan. 18), about proposed changes to law school that would allow students to take the New York State bar exam after only two years of law school:'b'This is not a novel concept. I am studying for the New York bar exam after completing only one year of law school. In New York, students can complete only the first year of law school, take the bar and follow it by three years of work (clerkship) in a law firm. This approach is very practical and underused.'b'Allowing students to take the bar after two years without the work requirement is a good idea, but the one-year plus work requirement is better: it minimizes law school debt while ensuring that students get legal experience working in a law firm, and the bonus is that presumably their jobs will be waiting for them at those law firms after they pass the bar.'b'This solves both problems in legal education, onerous debt and the lack of practical, real-world experience of new law school graduates.'b'I do not place the blame squarely on law schools. Potential law students need to take responsibility for taking on debilitating loans as well. But illusion, assumption and haste have had starring roles in our amorous escapades before.'b'Think about war brides and wartime romances, about couples from the greatest generation who met just before 'b'D-Day'b' or traded glances at the 'b'U.S.O.'b' and then did their tortured wooing almost entirely by post. What they took wasn\xe2\x80\x99t an accurate measure of each other but a leap of faith.'b'And as vessels of self-revelation, were letters much more trustworthy than tweets? Beth Bailey, a historian at Temple University, told me that during the 19th century, when such missives were considered \xe2\x80\x9can essential way to get to know people,\xe2\x80\x9d there were how-to books that provided not only letter-writing templates but also \xe2\x80\x9cphrases for how to communicate your true self.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Until the dawn of cars and greater mobility, there wasn\xe2\x80\x99t dating as we came to understand it; there were visits on porches and in parlors, often under the intrusive gazes of nattering relatives. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was very limiting,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrew Cherlin, a sociologist at Johns Hopkins University.'b'And there weren\xe2\x80\x99t all that many visits, either. Cherlin said that a person back then might meet his or her spouse just 10 times before marrying, and that this minimal contact enabled you to \xe2\x80\x9cpresent yourself much differently than you will later on.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In the 1950s, with its drive-in diners and back-seat fumbling, teenagers in lust finally had quality time away from meddlesome parents, going off to sock hops and going steady. But the choreographed roles they played and the chauvinistic rituals they obeyed didn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily tease out someone\xe2\x80\x99s real personality and definitely didn\xe2\x80\x99t give young women anything approaching full autonomy.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s no ideal stratagem for figuring out whom any one of us should be with and how to chart a course to that person, no fail-safe process for determining whether a twosome will endure.
