The reason was fear: Fear that they might return to the minority one day, fear that a weakened filibuster might hurt them, fear that Republicans might change the rules to the disadvantage of Democrats if they regain a majority.'b'Similarly, fear is preventing many Democrats from fully embracing President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s sensible and long-overdue proposals on curbing gun violence. A proposal to require background checks on all gun buyers \xe2\x80\x94 the top priority of most gun-control groups because of its effect on handgun proliferation \xe2\x80\x94 is beginning to win strong bipartisan support. But Democrats from swing states \xe2\x80\x94 including Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader \xe2\x80\x94 are 'b'backing away from a bill'b' to ban semiautomatic assault weapons, and it is not clear if the Senate will vote to prohibit high-capacity ammunition magazines.'b'Senate Democrats'b' are not even united 'b' on the obvious need to raise additional tax revenues as part of budget agreements to reduce the deficit. Though Senator Charles Schumer of New York is pushing to raise more revenue through tax reform, Max Baucus of Montana, who leads the tax-writing Finance Committee, has resisted the idea.'b'Mr. Baucus, who has also expressed skepticism about an assault-weapons ban, comes from a state that supported Mitt Romney last year, as do most of the other nervous Democrats. It\xe2\x80\x99s true that the growing support for gun-control measures and for higher taxes on the rich is not spread evenly across the country, and that the party\xe2\x80\x99s majority in the Senate is precarious.'b'But senators have an obligation to lead public opinion, not to follow it blindly. Hunters in red states know full well that a semiautomatic weapon bristling with military features is unnecessary to bring down a deer or a duck. If Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, who just won re-election comfortably, were to make that case, he might change a few minds, given his unquestionable support for Second Amendment rights.'b'If Mr. Manchin explained that such a ban was anything but a \xe2\x80\x9cgun grab,\xe2\x80\x9d people would pay attention. Instead, though he supports background checks, 'b'he will not endorse anything further'b'.'b'After four years of timidity, Senate Democrats say they will finally vote on a budget this year, no longer afraid to stand up for higher tax revenues and targeted spending increases. That is a sign of progress, but it remains to be seen how strong a budget will pass and how many Democrats will back it.'b'Politicians play in a rugged arena and are understandably obsessed about losing power. But that power needs to be used for something other than perpetual re-election. The next two years will challenge lawmakers of both parties to demonstrate that they came to Washington for a purpose.'b'You see America and its education system in all their glorious, exhilarating, crushing, infuriating contradictions in our national high school chess champion team.'b'Chess tends to be the domain of privileged schools whose star players have had their own personal chess coaches since elementary school. Yet the national champion team comes from a high-poverty, inner-city school, and four-fifths of its members are black or Hispanic.'b'More astounding, these aren\xe2\x80\x99t even high school kids yet. In April, New York\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'Intermediate School 318'b' in Brooklyn, where 70 percent of students qualify for free or reduced-price lunches, 'b'became the first middle school team ever'b' to defeat kids about four years older and win the national high school championship.'b'The champs are kids like Carlos Tapia, a Mexican-American in the eighth grade, whose dad is a house painter and mom a maid. The parents can\xe2\x80\x99t play chess and can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to give Carlos his own room, but they proudly make space for his 18 chess trophies.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cChess teaches me self-control\xe2\x80\x9d that spills over into other schoolwork, Carlos said in the I.S. 318 chess room, as a rainbow of students hunched over their boards, brows furrowed.'b'This will be my last column for a number of months, as I\xe2\x80\x99m taking a leave to work on a new book with my wife. So I asked 'b'my Twitter'b' followers what they\xe2\x80\x99d like me to write about in this column, and one suggested I address: 'b'How do you do your job without getting incredibly depressed?'b''b'I promise, I\xe2\x80\x99m not the Eeyore of journalists. The truth is that covering inequality, injustice and poverty can actually be inspiring and uplifting because of kids like Carlos. Just sprinkle opportunity around, and dazzling talents turn up.'b'This isn\xe2\x80\x99t about chess. It\xe2\x80\x99s about investing in kids in ways that transform their trajectories forever. The returns on capital would make Wall Street jealous.'b'Take Rochelle Ballantyne, who was raised by a single mom from Trinidad and soared on the I.S. 318 chess team. Rochelle, now 17 and aiming to become the first African-American woman to become a chess master, has won a full scholarship to Stanford University. She\xe2\x80\x99s planning to attend even though she has never visited the campus.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe were meant to break stereotypes,\xe2\x80\x9d Rochelle told me. \xe2\x80\x9cChess isn\xe2\x80\x99t something people are good at because of the color of their skin. We just really work very hard at it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That seems to be the secret. A part-time chess tutor named Elizabeth Spiegel arrived at I.S. 318 in 1999 and parlayed a tiny budget into a team that drills tirelessly. A dynamic, passionate teacher who volunteered much of her time, she nurtured a team that since 2000 has won more middle school championships than any other in the country.'b'One way of assessing what she has accomplished: Based on estimated chess ratings, Albert Einstein would rank third on the I.S. 318 team.'b'I wish the column could end on this triumphant note. But if these extraordinary kids are a reminder of what can happen when we invest in creating opportunity, they are also a reminder that budget cuts fall disproportionately on the needy.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFunding for extracurricular activities has dried up,\xe2\x80\x9d said John Galvin, an assistant principal who oversees the 95-member chess team. The kids run bake sales, candy sales and walkathons to raise the $50,000 needed to attend tournaments each year, but on trips they sometimes survive on peanut butter.'b'Galvin has tried approaching corporations and hedge funds for donations but has had little luck. Budget cuts have already trimmed the after-school chess club to three days a week from five.'b'A moving documentary about the team, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Brooklyn Castle'b',\xe2\x80\x9d is scheduled to air on PBS later this year, and that may help with fund-raising.'b'But similar cutbacks are playing out all across America. In 35 states, inflation-adjusted school financing is below 2008 levels, 'b'according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities'b'. As of July, school districts have slashed 328,000 jobs since 2008, and budget cuts have devastated early childhood education that lays the foundation for children\xe2\x80\x99s lives.'b'Affluent kids continue to enjoy nursery school and chess tutors, even as programs for poor kids are eliminated. Education is the best escalator out of poverty, but for too many kids it\xe2\x80\x99s creaking to a standstill.'b'As we make historic fiscal decisions in the coming months, let\xe2\x80\x99s not balance budgets by slashing investments in our future. That would be like economizing on heating bills by feeding the front door into the fire.'b'While on leave, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be rooting for kids like Carlos to soar to another national championship \xe2\x80\x94 and far beyond. Given the returns, the question isn\xe2\x80\x99t whether we can afford to invest in opportunities for kids but how we can possibly afford not to.'b'You may not think of your cat as an invasive species. 'b'But it is'b', in fact, a kind of superpredator, camouflaged by its affinity for humans, its playfulness, its ingratiating independence. Anywhere outdoors, the domestic cat occupies a dominant and unthreatened niche; its few natural enemies, like coyotes, are no match for tens of millions of free-roaming cats, including beloved pets and feral cats.'b''b'A new report'b' by the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute and the United States Fish and Wildlife Service presents a staggering picture of the damage cats can do \xe2\x80\x94 some 2.4 billion birds and 12.3 billion mammals killed a year as a median range. The prey are not just noxious rodents like rats, but small native mammals of every description. In fact, cats kill more wild creatures in the United States than any other human-linked cause \xe2\x80\x94 including automobiles, pesticides and buildings that migratory birds collide into.'b'Most of the killing is done by stray or feral cats, and there is no easy way to reduce that population. Programs that trap and neuter feral cats and then release them may actually encourage more people to abandon cats to the wild. Conservationists in Australia, where the feral cat problem is perhaps even more serious, have experimented successfully with allowing the cat\xe2\x80\x99s natural predator there \xe2\x80\x94 the dingo \xe2\x80\x94 to rebound in numbers.'b'But most Americans will never put up with a burgeoning coyote population, which leaves euthanasia for feral cats as the unpalatable response to reducing the wildlife slaughter.'b'Meanwhile, cat owners could help by treating their cats more like dogs. After all, it is a rare dog owner who lets a pet loose to roam the neighborhood.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'The European Union\xe2\x80\x99s unilateral effort to tax United States airlines in the name of addressing climate change threatens thousands of United States jobs at a time when our airlines are already overtaxed and competing with heavily state-backed foreign carriers (\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Your Biggest Carbon Sin May Be Air Travel'b',\xe2\x80\x9d news analysis, Sunday Review, Jan. 27).'b'Airline pilots play a critical role in protecting the environment. Along with our union\xe2\x80\x99s efforts to promote sound environmental policy, pilots also make our commitment clear in the cockpit, through single-engine taxiing, technology-enhanced departure and arrival procedures, and other emission-cutting flight operations.'b'The true solution to reducing emissions is maximizing voluntary measures that are already proved to make a difference and creating international emissions guidelines through the International Civil Aviation Organization.'b'The United States airline industry\xe2\x80\x99s employees need the federal government to make certain our industry thrives and to help us deliver on our drive to compete and win in the global marketplace.'b'LEE MOAK'b'\nPresident, Air Line Pilots Assn. Intl.'b'\nWashington, Jan. 29, 2013'b''b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Teacher Evaluation Fight'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 19):'b'\xc2\xa0Teacher evaluations should be used to develop educators, not fire them, just as student evaluations should be used to develop students, not fail them.
